HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Washington Brags as Trade Deficit Sets a Record

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
"The chief business of the American people," said Calvin Coolidge, "is business."
Not since the 1920's has America been more supremely confident in itself as an economic machine. That may help explain why some in Congress appear to be in no hurry to conclude the impeachment fiasco. For all the talk about doing the nation's business, there does not seem to be much pressing domestic business. 
 The biggest policy squabble in Washington is over the precise method by which we Americans should invest in American business to secure our retirement. The President would have the Government buy around 4 percent of more-or-less every business that sells stock to the public, although he has not spelled out details. In addition, he would give each of us (or at least each of us who isn't deemed too rich) some money to choose our own stocks. The Republicans would let us use Social Security money to buy our own stocks. Both are certain that buying stocks is a sure-fire way to make money.
This confidence comes as the current period of growth takes its place as the longest peacetime expansion ever, a fact for which President Clinton is pleased to claim credit even if the current recovery was 19 months old when he was elected on a platform that emphasized just how badly the economy was doing under President George Bush.
The stock market has been going up almost continuously since 1982, with the 1987 crash remembered as little more than a buying opportunity that was then seen -- wrongly -- as a sign of problems in the American economy. Americans, who a decade ago bristled at sanctimonious economic lectures from Japan, now specialize in making such speeches.
If pride precedes a fall, watch out.
The country's balance-of-payments deficit is nearing a record. Imports are up and exports are down as Americans spend all that they earn, and then some. The trade deficit -- the most important part of the balance-of-payments picture -- set an annual record in the first 11 months of 1998, and will grow larger this year.
The risk is that some day there will be a balance-of-payments crisis that leads to a tumbling dollar and the need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to defend the currency, no matter what the consequences are for the domestic economy. (That is, in fact, one way to explain what is happening in Brazil.)
There is no American crisis now because foreigners are happy to invest their dollars in our economy. They see greater risk in other countries and are as enamored as anyone by rising American stock prices. The dollar remains the only reserve currency for many foreign central banks, which are happy to hold large dollar balances.
If Washington were worried about the trade deficit, there might be talk about tax increases to restrain domestic demand and offset the expansionary monetary policy that the Federal Reserve adopted last year when it was worried about international collapse. Instead, the problem is all but ignored, and the only nod to it comes in the form of protectionist demands that Japan stop exporting so much steel to this country. As the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said last week, protectionism is no solution and would likely make our problems worse.
The dollar's popularity will not last indefinitely. The euro will erode its pre-eminent international position, and if Japan ever gets its economic act together, that country will attract more investment. If an American balance-of-payments crisis does develop, it is likely to come as a surprise and to be accompanied by a falling stock market, as confidence in America declines and both foreign and domestic investors try to bail out before it is too late.
Trade deficits are not nearly as interesting as lies about sex. But they may be more important.

HEADLINE: Prosperity and the Neediest Cases

 BODY:
Most of us know the charitable impulse that wells up during the holidays. The impulse may be seasonal, but the needs of the neediest persist all year long. Hunger, homelessness, disease, poverty, ignorance -- these things never waver, though our consciousness of them does. When the holidays end, we turn back to what we fondly call "our own lives" with a sense of relief. But there is no such thing as "our own lives" in that narrow sense. A mother and her children slipping into homelessness or a young man coming to the end of his senses without decent care are inescapable elements of our own lives. Whether we like it or not, the prosperity we enjoy is intolerable unless we share it with people who cannot gain even the rudiments of prosperity by themselves.
Like other charitable fund-raising drives, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is a remarkable enterprise. The people who give are as diverse as the people who receive. Small checks, large checks, checks that are never given another thought, checks that represent hardship in themselves. It is a moving spectacle. Yet it is hard to look out across this city and nation, to assess the stunning prosperity we enjoy, and not feel that, when it comes to aiding the neediest, Americans are truly parsimonious. We enjoy something of a civic renaissance in New York without really wondering who has been left out, who is worse off now than before. The welfare rolls shrink and the unemployment lines dwindle, which only makes it harder to see that some part of our new prosperity is simply illusion -- a decision to look in one direction and not another. 
 The seven agencies whose work is financed in part by the Neediest Cases Fund are the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service; the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York; the Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn; the Children's Aid Society; the Community Service Society of New York; UJA-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. These agencies meet a responsibility that has been increasingly shunted to the private sector during the past two decades. They need generous support.
Every dollar raised during this appeal is used for direct aid in the city's five boroughs. No money is diverted for solicitation or administrative expenses. Contributions are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087.

HEADLINE: True Color of Money

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In his essay on the connection between having money and having a good life ("Don't Be Shocked, but Money Isn't Everything," My Money, My Life, Jan. 10), Jeffrey Nesteruk said, "We ask for a raise instead of grappling with our lack of self-worth." 
 Hmmm. Imagine a Christmas Eve in London, many years ago. Ebenezer Scrooge is chatting with Bob Cratchit: "Bob, about this raise you've been wanting . . . have you ever considered going into therapy?"
 
ROBERT J. BROSELOW
Lubbock, Tex., Jan. 12

HEADLINE: Social Security Investment Plan Raises a Debate

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
A proposal by President Clinton to invest some portion of Social Security reserves in stocks ignited a brushfire of criticism last week, although the attacks may have focused on easily solved problems and ignored some thornier issues.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said he strongly doubted that the plan could be insulated from political interference. Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, argued that the concept would give the Government undue influence over corporate affairs. Other critics asked how the Government could pursue an antitrust case against Microsoft if it were also a Microsoft shareholder. 
 But lawyers, administrators and scholars point out that stock investments by governments and their agencies are neither new nor rare. States, cities and several independent Federal agencies, including the Federal Reserve System, have pension plans that have invested heavily in stocks for years. And those investments have not, they say, created the widespread problems critics predict.
What has proven difficult is determining who bears the burdens of any losses and who reaps the benefits of any surpluses -- a question made compelling by the difficulty of predicting market performance. Even more daunting is the challenge of providing small retirement accounts, like those envisioned by both the President and his Republican critics, without being overwhelmed by administrative costs.
Francis X. Cavanaugh has a snappy answer to the question of whether the Government can invest in stocks without becoming bogged down in political shenanigans or corporate meddling. "Can it be done? It's been done," he said. "We did it."
Mr. Cavanaugh was the first executive director of the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board, created by Congress in 1986 to cover Federal employees, including members of Congress like Mr. Archer.
Asked about potential conflicts between shareholding and governing -- as in the Microsoft case -- Mr. Cavanaugh shrugged. Since the plan invests in a stock index fund, he said, the accounts of the Federal lawyers and the Federal judge in the Microsoft case almost certainly hold a few Microsoft shares. But because Congress designed the agency to be insulated from both the political process and the corporate battlefield, he said, no "horror stories" have emerged. The White House has also cited the protections of a stock index fund, which mimics the performance of a market benchmark like the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, in defending its plan.
Strong legislation protects the agency from political pressure, he said. Corporate meddling is precluded because the commercial bank selected to manage agency investments also votes its shares on matters like takeovers and executive compensation. The only factor the bank can consider in casting its votes, Mr. Cavanaugh added, is what is best for retirees.
"The question is not can it be done. The question that should be asked," he said, "is whether the Congress, having protected three million Federal employees from political manipulation of their retirement funds, will be willing to extend that same protection to the 150 million beneficiaries of Social Security."
Not everyone agrees that the Federal retirement system's approach would work for a fund as large as a Social Security stock fund would be -- the President's proposal calls for investing about $700 billion in stocks over the next 15 years, an amount that would have made it the largest single investor in today's market.
Roy Schotland, a Georgetown law professor who helped drive the campaign to modernize the pension plan for university and college faculty, said it might be wiser to delegate the voting of shares to an independent fiduciary institution. Others said the problem could be resolved by requiring the Government to vote with the majority of other shareholders in important disputes.
Most statewide pension funds have invested in stocks for years, as have most large municipal pension programs. According to Nicholas Greifer, senior policy analyst with the Government Finance Officers Association in Chicago, only three states -- Indiana, South Carolina and West Virginia -- did not permit stock market investments by statewide pension funds as of 1997. Since then, all three have obtained legislative or voter approval to permit such investments, he said.
The state funds have a somewhat uneven record when it comes to insulating investment decisions from improper influences, several pension industry executives said. Roland Machold, who retired in July as director of the New Jersey Division of Investments, said that over the years "there is hardly a state that hasn't had some brush with scandal with its pension fund."
But most frequently, Mr. Machold said, those problems have involved the selection of outside consultants or investments in exotic assets, like venture capital investments in local businesses, substandard mortgages, and poorly understood investments like derivatives. "The states have almost never screwed up buying nationally listed securities," he said.
State legislatures have occasionally ordered pension funds to abstain from certain investments -- in companies doing business in South Africa during apartheid and, more recently, in tobacco companies. But most state pension funds with strong professional leadership have avoided interference by special interests, said Ian Lanoff, who ran the Labor Department's compliance program under ERISA, the Federal law governing private pensions, in the Carter Administration and who now specializes in pension law in Washington.
He cited the refusal by New York City's pension funds to help bail the city out in its fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's and later refusal of Michigan public pension funds to help rescue the Chrysler Corporation. More recently, he said, the largest public pension funds have been largely successful in resisting efforts to ban investments in Northern Ireland and in companies involved in Holocaust reparations disputes.
ERISA requires pension funds to base investment decisions solely on the best interests of retirees, Mr. Lanoff said. "Most states have taken ERISA principles and applied them to their own plans." Similar standards would help insulate a Social Security fund even further from political interference, he said.
But public pension funds have been less successful in insulating themselves from politics in the tug-of-war over fund surpluses and shortfalls, said Gene Kalwarski, a public pension specialist at Milliman & Robertson in Washington.
There have been "vicious and bitter debates" over whether surpluses in public pension funds should be used to improve retirement benefits or to reduce the amount taxpayers must contribute the next year, he said. Similarly, if a fund falls short -- perhaps because of stock market losses -- the battle rages over whether to cut benefits or raise taxes.
It is unrealistic to expect that such battles -- already a feature of the Social Security debate -- will not continue, especially if future stock returns do not mirror recent strong gains, several legal scholars said.
Defenders of the plan assume that any shortfalls would remain the responsibility of Federal taxpayers, as they are now.
Such uncertainties persuade some that stock investments by the Social Security fund raise more problems than they solve. "My own instinct is to be very chary," said Richard Nathan, director of the Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York in Albany. "The past in the stock market is not necessarily prologue."
Donald J. Boyd, who specializes in state government studies at the Institute, shared that concern. "State funds are large, very, very large," he said, "but the Social Security fund would be huge. That makes it more visible, but more cumbersome."
But trying to give beneficiaries a stock market tonic in the form of small individual accounts -- a feature of both the President's plan and several Republican alternatives -- raises administrative problems that Mr. Cavanaugh says would be virtually insurmountable.
The cost of providing individual plans, similar to corporate 401(k)'s, to workers at businesses with 10 or fewer employees would consume most of what the typical Social Security beneficiary could afford to invest, Mr. Cavanaugh said.
The vast majority of America's 6.5 million businesses are very small, he said. And it is that factor, not the number of Social Security participants, that will determine the "economies of scale."
Already, he said, financial services companies charge about $300 for each participant in such small-scale plans. Since the average Social Security wage is approximately $20,000 a year, a worker trying to save 2 percent of that would invest just $400 a year but pay $300 a year in expenses.
While the White House and Republicans have disputed that administrative costs would be that high, Mr. Cavanaugh is not persuaded. "You would be better off putting your money in the mattress," he said.

HEADLINE: Gore Building Network in California

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
As Vice President, Al Gore has traveled to California so many times that aides have lost count. They think his latest trip this weekend, his second of the year already, is the 52d. But they are not eager to bet on it.
While the exact number does not matter much, what Mr. Gore has done there behind the scenes probably does. Over the last three years, he has built a prodigious network of constituent groups and contributors to help him win California's 54 electoral votes, the most of any state, and help him become the fifth incumbent Vice President to capture the White House by election. (The others were John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, Martin Van Buren and George Bush.) 
 California has always been critical in the Presidential equation. But by moving up its primary to join New York and eight other states on March 7 in 2000, just weeks after the first two election tests, the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary, California's primary holds life-threatening powers over underfinanced campaigns that are still forming.
While that may suggest an urgent need to organize and tap financial sources, Mr. Gore appears to be the only aspirant from either party who has amassed a powerful array of support at this early juncture of the 2000 campaign. And the advantage appears compelling.
"Don't forget, we're just at the very beginning," said Gina Glantz, campaign manager for Bill Bradley, the former New Jersey Senator who recently entered the Presidential race. "Sooner more than later, we'll have a more formal organization in California. But we're just getting started."
That is apparently more than any other Democrat challenging Mr. Gore has done. Art Torres, chairman of the California Democratic Party, said any others who might be contemplating a run, like Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, had not significantly raised their profiles in the state.
"The fact that the primary is so early, they should have started organizing six months ago," Mr. Torres said. "If they would ask me for advice now, I'd tell them not to waste their money."
Mr. Bradley, who lectured at Stanford University after his three terms in the Senate, is not without considerable ties to California. He has campaigned for Democrats from swing districts, like Representatives Ellen O. Tauscher and Gary A. Condit, and his friendship with Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, could lead to big contributions.
"But the reality is, Gore is leaps and bounds in front," said Representative Loretta Sanchez of Orange County, a director of Mr. Gore's political action committee, Leadership '98, and an incoming chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, a position that requires neutrality.
Mr. Gore's strength in California flows directly from the power of incumbency and instant access to Air Force Two, a combination that allows him to deliver Federal largess and to campaign for Democrats whenever he wants -- and often on the same trip.
The mix worked especially well last year. On a dozen visits, he announced grants and programs worth more than $550 million, and almost every Democrat running for statewide office won in November, including Gray Davis, the state's first Democratic Governor in 16 years.
Just as he did in planning for this weekend, Mr. Gore has always made special efforts to court the same groups that twice turned out money and votes for President Clinton, including Hispanic and black voters and people in the entertainment industry.
Through science and technology issues, long a passion of his, Mr. Gore has tried expanding that base by impressing environmentalists and Silicon Valley executives with his knowledge of topics like "salmon as an indicator species" and "massive parallel computing."
In addition, he has taken unusual steps to familiarize himself with high-tech issues, meeting periodically with small groups of industry representatives at all levels -- "Gore Techs," his aides call them -- to discuss new and future technologies.
"He gave an address on forestry, water issues and clean air about a year ago at Lake Tahoe," said Ruth Hunter, a board member of the California League of Conservation Voters. "He was more informed than some of the enviros."
While environmentalists have typically supported Democrats, that has not necessarily been the case with people in high-tech fields, whose philosophies tend to be more Libertarian and Progressive than Democrat and Republican.
But Jerry Yang, a co-founder of Yahoo, the Internet portal, said he and other high-tech executives had grown to respect Mr. Gore for interest in issues vital to Internet growth, like privacy and electronic commerce.
"In one meeting I was in with him, he talked very eloquently about network economics, how decision making can be distributed in the network world," Mr. Yang said. "It's good to see that he can think about these things and not reduce himself to sound bites."
Would Mr. Yang put any Republicans in the same category as Mr. Gore? "Nobody I know as a Presidential candidate," he said.
With people of Hispanic descent now California's fastest growing ethnic group, making up 30.8 percent of the state's population, Mr. Gore has pursued them as aggressively as any group. Last year, he often appeared at campaign and issue-related events with Cruz M. Bustamante, who became the state's first elected Lieutenant Governor of Hispanic descent, and with Antonio R. Villaraigosa, the new State Assembly Speaker. In one East Los Angeles event with Hispanic union workers days before the election, Mr. Gore delivered his entire get-out-the-vote message in Spanish.
"I know George Bush Jr. is doing all he can to show support for the Latino community in Texas, speaking Spanish and all that," said Mr. Bustamante, who refers to Mr. Gore as Alberto. "But I can't think of any candidate, Democrat or Republican, who could break the bond that exists for the Vice President."
Yvonne Burke, a Los Angeles County supervisor, said Mr. Gore had developed a similar bond with many black Californians for promoting issues important to low-income people, like economic development in inner-city neighborhoods and employment discrimination.
She said the Vice President also won points when he attended events like the funeral last fall of Tom Bradley, who was a hero to many blacks as the first black Mayor of Los Angeles.
"Often, people coming to California, come to raise money and only see the more affluent communities," Ms. Burke said. "The President has always been visible in all of Los Angeles's communities, and the Vice President's approach has been very similar."
As for fund-raising, a sensitive subject for Mr. Gore since his 1996 appearance at a Buddhist temple almost led to a Justice Department investigation, the Vice President is relying heavily upon people in the entertainment industry who raised money for Mr. Clinton.
They include David Geffen, the record industry executive, and Rob Reiner, the actor and director. Both said Mr. Gore had attributes certain to give him advantages over other candidates, some that made him more attractive than Mr. Clinton was before becoming President.
"In 1992, Bill Clinton had to start from scratch," Mr. Geffen said. "Al Gore is extremely well-known and well-liked. I can't imagine why he would not enjoy great support." Mr. Geffen called Mr. Bradley a "very decent and honorable guy," but a primary candidate who has "zero chance" to defeat Mr. Gore.
Mr. Reiner had Mr. Gore's help last year, leading a successful ballot initiative to raise taxes on cigarettes and use the money for children's services. He said he was impressed by Mr. Gore's enthusiasm and grasp of issues.
"He'll say that he's not as glamorous as President Clinton," Mr. Reiner said of the Vice President. "But in a strange way, that makes people even more dedicated to him. He's a policy wonk, but at least with him you get none of the extras and distractions you get with the President."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From John Paul's Message About the Poor and the Rich

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Pope's Apostolic Exhortation yesterday on the mission for the Roman Catholic Church in the Americas, as provided by the Vatican:
Among the positive aspects of America today, we see in civil society a growing support throughout the continent for democratic political systems and the gradual retreat of dictatorial regimes; this has immediate moral implications. The church looks sympathetically upon this evolution insofar as it favors an evermore marked respect for the rights of each individual including those accused and condemned, against whom it is never legitimate to resort to modes of detention and investigation -- one thinks especially of torture -- which are offensive to human dignity. . . . 
 There is an economic globalization which brings some positive consequences, such as efficiency and increased production, and which, with the development of economic links between the different countries, can help to bring greater unity among peoples and make possible a better service to the human family. However, if globalization is ruled merely by the laws of the market applied to suit the powerful, the consequences cannot but be negative. These are, for example, the absolutizing of the economy, unemployment, the reduction and deterioration of public services, the destruction of the environment and natural resources, the growing distance between rich and poor, unfair competition which puts the poor nations in a situation of ever-increasing inferiority. . . .
And what should we say about the cultural globalization produced by the power of the media? Everywhere the media impose new scales of values which are often arbitrary and basically materialistic, in the face of which it is difficult to maintain a lively commitment to the values of the Gospel. . . .
More and more, in many countries of America, a system known as neo-liberalism prevails; based on a purely economic conception of man, this system considers profit and the law of the market as its only parameters, to the detriment of the dignity of and the respect due to individuals and peoples. At times this system has become the ideological justification for certain attitudes and behavior in the social and political spheres leading to the neglect of the weaker members of society. Indeed, the poor are becoming ever more numerous, victims of specific policies and structures which are often unjust. . . .
Love for the poor must be preferential, but not exclusive. The Synod Fathers observed that it was in part because of an approach to the pastoral care of the poor marked by a certain exclusiveness that the pastoral care for the leading sectors of society has been neglected and many people have thus been estranged from the church. The damage done by the spread of secularism in these sectors -- political or economic, union-related, military, social or cultural -- shows how urgent it is that they be evangelized.

HEADLINE: A Place to See Eagles Soar

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: FORESTBURGH, N.Y.

 BODY:
Great wings outstretched, a bald eagle soared over the open water of the Mongaup Reservoir, giving the group of observers a brief, brilliant sighting before it rose behind the tall white pines. The number of eagles wintering here in the Upper Delaware watershed of Sullivan County has grown steadily in recent years. So has the phenomenon of eagle watching.
More than a dozen bundled and layered visitors, some of whom traveled long miles for a glimpse of the eagles, took shelter from the brisk January winds in a public viewing blind. Trained volunteers were directing them in using telescopes to spot the elusive birds. 
 Most of the people who make the trip do not consider themselves avid bird watchers. Instead, they are drawn by the mystique of the endangered bald eagle. And that is exactly what Sullivan County officials are counting on -- that their natural resources, including the largest wintering population of bald eagles in the Northeast, can make their area an attractive destination for people from the New York City region interested in a one-day or weekend excursion.
The tourists could provide a much-needed economic boost for the Catskill Mountain region.
Donna Schmidt has seen bald eagles before, in Nova Scotia and Alaska. Still, she chose to spend three hours driving here from Long Island with her husband, her 15-month-old son, two nephews and her sister-in-law to see eagles in flight.
"It's more special to see them here, so close to your own backyard -- and I wanted them to see them," she said, referring to her husband, Steven, and 6-year-old nephew, Kyle Delgado.
"I'll come back again when Steve Jr. is older," she said. "Next time it would be nice to stay over."
The County Manager, Jonathan Drapkin, said the county was trying to overcome the loss of many resort hotels. "So many people have a fixed memory of the large, self-contained hotels as they were," he said. "We want people to know there's some of the best fly-fishing in the Northeast here; that you can canoe or raft the Delaware."
The eagles migrate here primarily from Canada. It is the sight of open fresh water that attracts them.
They can have their fill of fresh fish, then perch in the pines among large tracts of undisturbed land, including 12,000 state-owned acres managed strictly for the eagles' protection.
"There's a general shifting and recognition by the county that our natural resources are an economic resource," said Lori Danuff-McKean, who works with the county as founder and volunteer president of the nonprofit Eagle Institute, a year-old organization dedicated to the protection of the bald eagle and other birds of prey.
As many as 15 institute-trained volunteers can be found each weekend during prime viewing season -- January through March -- beside roads and rivers and in the Mongaup blind. They act as guides for group field trips, like the one arranged by the Schmidt family. They staff popular viewing locations, equipped with binoculars and telescopes, where they help visitors who come unguided and advise on proper etiquette. They are trained to monitor eagle activity and weather conditions and to look for birds tagged and banded for identification by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
"On a beautiful day, we can expect to see 40 to 50 people who have come on their own to a designated viewing area," Ms. Danuff-McKean said.
As of mid-January, a record 179 bald eagles were counted in the Upper Delaware watershed and its associated reservoirs. Peter Nye, who heads the state's endangered species unit in Albany, said 89 adults and 90 immature birds were spotted from the air during the annual midwinter count on Jan. 11.
Many reservoirs are very low right now, and there is not much ice-free water, Mr. Nye said. "But no matter how bad the conditions, this area still provides some amount of suitable habitat for bald eagles, and we've still recorded record numbers."
The Mongaup Valley Wildlife Management Area, just below Monticello, was created in 1990 when the state bought the 12,000 acres as a reserve for the bald eagle. It is the best place to see eagles in New York State, Mr. Nye said. But the eagles are extremely sensitive to the presence of humans, and that creates some concerns.
"We need to insure that in five or seven years we will have the habitat to support the numbers of breeding pairs," Mr. Nye said. "The new challenge is to identify enough suitable habitat, then manage and protect it."
Gene Lamoriello, president of the Sullivan County Visitors Association, said the county was working to draw visitors, but he added, "We recognize that if you overwhelm a delicate balance, you lose your attraction."

HEADLINE: Albright Starts Visit to Moscow as Russia's Wariness Grows

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright embarks Sunday on a trip to a weakened but obstinate Russia, with little expectation on either side that much will improve in a relationship plagued by disagreement on everything from Russia's economic collapse to air strikes against Iraq.
In contrast to the euphoria of the heady days when Russia was envisioned as a full member of a "Group of Eight" industrialized democracies, the hope today is to keep a dialogue alive, an Administration official said. 
 Ahead of her arrival, Russian officials were openly referring to the "sour" nature of the relationship with the United States.
Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov has stridently criticized the air strikes against Iraq, and his First Deputy Prime Minister, Yuri Maslyukov, was in Washington last week complaining about an economically flattened Russia being forced to live under the thumb of an American-dominated International Monetary Fund.
To this mix of problems, the Administration suddenly added a new one: the unveiling this week of its plan to deploy a new missile defense system that would require renegotiation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, a move that the Russians have historically opposed.
In pique over the air strikes against Iraq in December, the lower house of the Russian Parliament last month abruptly canceled the vote on the ratification of Start 2, the treaty that would reduce both nations' stockpiles of nuclear weapons. The Administration's missile defense system proposal would almost certainly further complicate passage of Start 2 in the Parliament, Russian arms control experts said.
The hardening of the stalemate on the strategic arms treaty, which has languished in the Russian Parliament since 1993, was further confirmation that the notion of a "strategic partnership" -- once key to the Clinton Administration's approach to Russia -- has all but evaporated.
Russia's disarray, added a senior Administration official who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity, made it "more than ordinarily difficult to reach decisions on even the most important policy questions."
Clearly, Ms. Albright will not be doing any business with the ailing President, Boris N. Yeltsin -- it was not even clear, officials said, whether she would see him. Instead, she will focus her energies on Mr. Primakov, whom she met many times when he was Foreign Minister before his elevation to Prime Minister in the political chaos that followed Russia's ruble devaluation and virtual default on Aug. 17.
In an indication the Clinton Administration acknowledges the Yeltsin era is all but over, Ms. Albright is scheduled to meet with three likely presidential candidates: Yuri M. Luzhkov, the Mayor of Moscow; Aleksandr I. Lebed, the former general, and the economist Grigory Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko party.
Virtually all of the issues on Ms. Albright's agenda with Mr. Primakov address problems associated with Russia's economic collapse.
The week before her arrival, Mr. Maslyukov, the leading Communist member of Mr. Primakov's Government, was told by the I.M.F. and Administration officials that the assumptions in the draft Russian budget were unrealistic and not sufficient to qualify Russia for a new loan.
Russia, in its turn, is making a big issue of negotiating new troop levels under the 1990 treaty that established levels for conventional forces for a Europe still divided into NATO and the now defunct, Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. This is Moscow's way of expressing opposition to NATO's embrace of three former Warsaw Pact countries -- Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary -- which become alliance members in April. Both Russian and Clinton Administration officials suggest that as an area where Ms. Albright may make progress.
Ms. Albright will also stress the Administration's unhappiness over what it contends is Russia's heightened assistance to Iran on missile technology in the last six months.
Last week, the Administration slapped economic penalties on three Russian institutions after asserting that they were providing Iranian scientists with technical assistance. In response, the Russian Foreign Ministry said that talking to Russia "in the language of sanctions and pressure is absolutely unacceptable."
Most likely, Administration officials said, Ms. Albright will tell the Russians that, if Russia does not stop assisting Iran in this way, the United States will end the joint American-Russian satellite launch program that expires next year and is worth about $1 billion to Russian aerospace companies.
Ms. Albright will also probe Mr. Primakov's position on Iraq, officials said. Mr. Primakov, who prides himself on his knowledge of the Arab world, has denounced the Administration's policy on Iraq in the strongest terms.
On Kosovo, where the Russians are traditionally sympathetic to the cause of fellow Slav Orthodox Serbs but are apparently wearying somewhat of the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, Ms. Albright might achieve a little more, officials said. Russia has said it opposes NATO air strikes against the Serbs, who are fighting an insurgency of ethnic Albanian guerrillas in the Serbian province of Kosovo, but they might use their influence with Mr. Milosevic to have him comply with a cease-fire agreement reached last October.

HEADLINE: Resistance to Argentine 'Dollar'

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Argentine Government's announcement this week that it would consider replacing its peso with the dollar over the next several years has soothed the concerns of international investors that Argentina might follow Brazil's example and devalue its currency.
But sharp attacks from the opposition, which controls the lower house of Congress and leads in opinion polls before presidential elections, has dimmed the likelihood that the proposal will get very far. And American officials said today that they doubted Argentina would decide to "dollarize" its economy unless it came under dire pressure from an economic meltdown in Brazil. 
 The idea of using the dollar, as Panama and Liberia do, was discussed at a Cabinet meeting on Thursday. In what appeared to be a trial balloon afterward, the Central Bank president, Pedro Pou, told reporters that a "monetary association treaty" with the United States could eventually lead to a common currency across the Americas.
President Carlos Saul Menem has the power to decree the change. But Mr. Pou said that rather than act alone, the Government would seek to negotiate a treaty with the United States.
Such a treaty would require the consent not only of the United States Senate and both houses of the Argentine Congress but also of whoever is elected to replace Mr. Menem as President early next year.
Opposition leaders, including the Mayor of Buenos Aires, Fernando de la Rua, the Alianza coalition candidate who currently has a healthy lead in the polls, expressed nationalistic scorn for the idea. "It's not very serious," he said.

HEADLINE: Olympic Ideals and the Raw Truth Are Now Facing Off Because Restraint Vanished

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Jan. 23

 BODY:
As senior officials of the International Olympic Committee completed a report on the Salt Lake City bribery scandal, they were met with a troubling reality. The financial revival that saved the Olympics 15 years ago has mutated into the big-money excesses that threaten to cripple the Games today.
The commission investigating the scandal met today for 15 hours but announced no further resignations by I.O.C. members, as a half-dozen officials pleaded their cases in an attempt to avoid expulsion in the largest corruption scandal to hit the Olympic movement. As many as 11 members face the choice Sunday of resigning or being suspended and eventually expelled amid allegations of accepting cash payments, medical treatment, tuition aid and other lavish benefits totaling an estimated three-quarters of a million dollars. 
 "The International Olympic Committee will not tolerate improprieties of any kind," said Kevan Gosper, a senior I.O.C. member from Australia, even as he tried to justify offers of $35,000 apiece to two I.O.C. members from Africa on the eve of Sydney's two-vote victory over Beijing to play host to the 2000 Summer Games.
 
Samaranch Faces Decisive Moments
Juan Antonio Samaranch, the 78-year-old Spanish marquis, faces the most destabilizing moment of his presidency since he assumed control of the Olympic movement in 1980, when the five Olympic rings were fool's gold.
The 1972 Summer Games in Munich shed the blood of Israeli athletes and any notion that sport and politics were not intertwined. Unwilling to finance the 1976 Winter Games with public money, Denver passed them off to Innsbruck, Austria. The 1976 Summer Games in Montreal left a debt of $1 billion. The 1980 Summer Games in Moscow were boycotted by the United States after the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan.
"The Olympic movement was in trouble," said Dick Pound, an I.O.C. vice president from Montreal who is heading the Salt Lake City investigation. "The I.O.C. had little financing, unity was shaky at best and the Games were becoming a cold war battleground."
Los Angeles won the 1984 Summer Games in 1978 essentially because no one else wanted them. Teheran lost interest when the Shah's regime began to collapse. Islamic fundamentalism had no use for sport. The Soviets led a retaliatory boycott in Los Angeles, but what could have been a cold war disaster became a hot property.
Peter Ueberroth brought to Los Angeles an Olympics that was privately financed through television rights fees, corporate sponsorships, ticket sales and licensing agreements. Shrewdly, he gave exclusivity to various categories of corporate sponsorships. Coca-Cola was the official soft drink, IBM the official technology sponsor, Levi-Strauss the official outfitter.
"In Lake Placid, they had 50 official Band-Aid sponsors," joked Anita DeFrantz, an I.O.C. vice president from Los Angeles, referring to the 1980 Winter Games. "Peter had one sponsor per category, which created value for the sponsor and allowed him to demand larger amounts of money."
When the 1984 Summer Games turned a profit of $220 million, everyone now wanted in. "Peter added a couple of zeros to everything," said John Argue, who was president of the Los Angeles bid committee.
A year later, at an I.O.C. meeting in East Berlin, one of the most infamous food fights in Olympic history took place among cities vying for the 1992 Summer Games. Brisbane, Australia, sent in a plane full of lamb and lobsters for a party whose tab has been placed at nearly $2 million. Paris also airmailed a gastronomical feast. "It was probably the most food they had ever seen in East Berlin," Mr. Pound said.
 
An Organization That Answers to Itself
There were no rules, so there were no rules to be broken. Ms. DeFrantz heard stories of I.O.C. members being put up in one of Paris's most exclusive hotels "for a long time, with their families. It was out of control."
The 1992 Summer Games were eventually awarded to Barcelona, Spain, in 1986. That year, the I.O.C. placed a limit of $150 on gifts that I.O.C. members could receive, but like traffic rules in Italy, this limit appeared to be more of a suggestion than a law. There are no real checks and balances on the I.O.C., which answers to no one but itself.
"I always say it's better to be an I.O.C. member than a king," said Fred Ball, who was a member of Salt Lake City's bid committee for the 2002 Winter Games.
In 1994, the I.O.C. began holding the Winter and Summer Games in separate years. The Winter Olympics now stood alone, instead of in the shadow of the Summer Games. More corporate money could be raised, budgets increased and so did the projected economic benefit. Salt Lake City's expected budget of $1.45 billion is nearly as large as the budget for the 1996 Summer Games in Atlanta. The estimated economic impact in Salt Lake City for the 2002 Winter Games is $2.8 billion.
"In the past, the winner was the city willing to lose the most money," Mr. Pound said. "Now the Games are seen as having a beneficial economic impact."
The bidding process has become a sort of neurotic mating ritual in which bid cities, eager to please I.O.C. members, tend to spend money "like drunken sailors on leave," Mr. Pound said. Salt Lake City spent $14 million in private funds just trying to win the 1998 and 2002 Winter Games.
"It's a corrupt process," said Robert Helmick, who resigned as an I.O.C. member and as president of the United States Olympic Committee after being accused of conflict of interest in 1991. "It starts with first-class air tickets for I.O.C. members and their wives. That's $10,000 to $12,000. Then there is the excessive life style bestowed on I.O.C. members by the bid cities. Fur coats, jewelry. They might pay for college tuition for someone's kid. Or find him a job. It goes beyond what is appropriate."
Some I.O.C. members have been as eager to receive as the bid cities have been eager to give.
"When people from poorer countries travel to the United States, they are very impressed," said Francois Carrard, the executive director of the I.O.C. "The different level in standards can lead to temptation. The other side is generous and says, 'My dear friend, what can I do for your family?' But those people should have read the rules. Blame has to be shared."
 
Influencing a Vote, Every Two Years
Because a vote is now held every two years to name a city to host the Winter or Summer Games, there is steadier work for so-called middlemen, or agents. Mr. Pound spoke sharply this week of wanting to rid the Olympic movement of these agents, who reportedly promise to deliver a bloc of votes for exorbitant sums of money. He said there were allegations that bidders hoping to bring the Winter Games to Sion, Switzerland, were approached by an agent who claimed he could deliver 25 I.O.C. votes for $2 million.
"By the time we are through with so-called Olympic agents, I doubt that it will be a profitable business, if it ever was," Mr. Pound said.
Salt Lake City began setting off alarms at the U.S.O.C. as early as 1989, when it was attempting to become the American candidate city to bid on the Winter Games. At the time, officials were concerned about the image that drinking was not allowed in the Mormon capital. The Olympics are as much a 16-day party as a 16-day sporting competition.
U.S.O.C. officials who came to inspect Salt Lake City said they found their hotel rooms stocked with bottles of wine and cases of beer. Once, the inspection team was taken out in a horse-drawn carriage while champagne was served. "We told them that was overkill," said Sandy Knapp, who led the selection committee.
A case of beer and a few bottles of wine were penny ante stuff, but the U.S.O.C.'s initial vigilance lagged as the inducements in Salt Lake City grew to include cash payments and benefits of more than $100,000 apiece to some I.O.C. members.
Having the Olympics come to Salt Lake City was considered a paramount necessity by the U.S.O.C., whose officials feared that corporate support might swoon after the Atlanta Olympics and that the U.S.O.C.'s quadrennial budget of $400 million could shrink by as much as $100 million.
With Salt Lake City as host, the U.S.O.C. has made $54.5 million from its cut of television rights fees and expects to earn approximately $193 million more in cash and supplies in a joint marketing agreement. Not until November of 1997 -- two years after the Salt Lake vote -- did the U.S.O.C. institute a formal policy limiting gifts to officials by bid cities to $50 in one phase of the bid process and $150 in another.
"Did my predecessors fall down on the job?" said Bill Hybl, the U.S.O.C. president. "In the future, we're going to do a great deal more."
 
A Secretive Management Style
There is growing evidence that Mr. Samaranch was aware of improprieties in the bidding process. Mr. Pound said he had once been offered a $1 million bribe during television rights negotiations for the Games and had informed Mr. Samaranch. But no disciplinary action was taken. Paul Henderson, who headed Toronto's unsuccessful bid for the 1996 Summer Games, said that Mr. Samaranch approved an arrangement in which the Toronto bid committee paid the rent for the husband of Pirjo Haggman, an I.O.C. member from Finland. She resigned last Tuesday.
Mr. Samaranch has both democratized the Olympic movement by providing more opportunities for women and athletes from developing nations, and has made it more elitist with his autocratic, secretive management style. He has said that the Olympic movement is more important than the Catholic Church, and he threw a $16 million party in 1994 to celebrate the I.O.C.'s centennial congress, two years after athletes were left to swelter in an un-air-conditioned village at the 1992 Summer Games in his native Spain.
"They don't want to catch too many people," Arnold Beckett, a former member of the I.O.C.'s medical commission, said of the committee's attitude toward doping. "It won't look good."
The same criticism has been applied to corruption. His detractors believe that Mr. Samaranch didn't want to know. Or didn't want to act. He said he received only rumors. Either way, everything he built has begun to collapse.
"The I.O.C. needs to worry about losing the magic of the Olympics," said Charlie Battle, who was in charge of international relations for the Atlanta Olympic organizing committee. "As they have become such big business and have become so obsessed with being big and having the best athletes, they have lost a little of the magic of bringing the whole world together in the interest of peace. They don't think people will pay big money for that. To me, that's all they've got."

HEADLINE: Despite Billions Spent, A History of Failures

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
After decades of neglect and deferred maintenance that left New York City schools crumbling, leaky, shabby and sometimes dangerous, the State Legislature created the School Construction Authority in 1988 with a mandate to resurrect the vast archipelago of 1,100 aging public school buildings by Jan. 1, 2000.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo went to a Harlem school, a Gothic 1901 pile of decrepit walls and broken windows, to sign the law that stripped the Board of Education of school construction tasks and assigned the authority to restore the system and build scores of new schools. Speakers portrayed the future in rosy terms: billions of dollars to come over the next decade, a new beginning for a million pupils. 
 But 10 years and $7 billion later, critics say, the reality is still a bleak portrait of dilapidated, sometimes hazardous schools; of cost overruns and endless delays; of rapid turnover in the agency's leadership, and of waste, inefficiency and incompetence in hundreds of school projects.
And yesterday, Gov. George E. Pataki -- citing systemic failures, horror stories of children lunching in cafeterias under umbrellas, and allegations of attendance records falsified by bureaucrats to inflate their budgets -- ordered a sweeping investigation of school construction in the city.
For years, politicians, educators and parents have called for an overhaul of the school construction process, and with many projects coming in years late, millions over budget and poorly executed, they have had plenty of ammunition. Critics have pointed to many causes: unqualified contractors, poor site supervision, too little money, and policy decisions beyond the authority's control.
In a 71,000-word report this month, the Board of Education pronounced the state of the city schools generally poor -- one-third needed major exterior work and another third had antiquated electrical wiring and ancient coal furnaces -- and said that, at best, the schools might be in fair condition after a five-year, $11 billion rebuilding effort that would require Federal, state and city help.
The authority, whose three trustees are named by the governor, the mayor and the city schools chancellor, has had some successes, building 43 new schools and creating new classrooms for more than 70,000 students. By contrast, the Board of Education, starved by the city's financial crisis, built only two schools between 1975 and 1988.
Moreover, by offering incentives for early completion of work and imposing penalties for poor performance, the authority said last year that it had reduced the number of projects behind schedule to 33 percent, from a staggering 88 percent in 1996. It has replaced scores of project managers to improve supervision, and has said it could do better if burdensome rules were lifted.
Still, the authority has been plagued by problems. The Board of Education identifies projects the authority must undertake, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sets the authority budgets, which fluctuate like yo-yos, and 70 percent of the contractors who responded to a survey said they would not bid for school work.
With accounts of one bungled job after another, the renovation of Erasmus Hall, the city's oldest high school, has become a paradigm case. Design began in 1985, but construction did not start until 1992. It was a $22 million fix-up that would take three years. But asbestos was discovered, the board ordered the authority to drastically redraft its plans in 1994 and delay piled upon delay.
The project is still ongoing, the cost is now upward of $100 million and officials hope for completion before the turn of the century. In the meantime, teachers and students have been bombarded by noise and dust, plastic tarpaulins have been used to stop leaks in a computer lab and rainstorms bring out umbrellas for students eating in the cafeteria.
"It is time to demand better," the Governor said yesterday.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIAL: THE CONSERVATIVES;
Where the President's Sins Aren't Winked At and a Terrible Price Is Feared

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: PENDLETON, S.C., Jan. 23

 BODY:
In this stretch of the Bible Belt where highways are punctuated with billboards about "Heaven. Hell. The Choice Is Yours," it has been one bad week.
What hurts most is the impeachment trial in Washington. It has become painfully obvious here that the Senate will not convict President Clinton. In this community that perceives itself as a fire wall against indecency, many people sound despondent. They say the nation will pay a terrible price for winking at the President's sins. 
 Almost as hurtful are Mr. Clinton's soaring approval ratings. With poll after poll reminding them that they are out of step with the rest of the country, people here say they feel isolated. Many suspect that the polls are rigged.
Johnny Landreth Jr., owner of Landreth Appliances, said he is convinced that Americans want the President removed, no matter what the polls say. "Either the pollsters are asking the wrong questions or this country is so wrong morally that we are going down the tubes," said Mr. Landreth, who was eating a fried-chicken lunch beneath the "Absolutely No Profanity" sign at Bill's Cafe on Highway 76.
Rubbing salt in the week's wounds, as people here perceive it, was that "show business" State of the Union speech that polls said Americans loved so much, along with the endless broadcasts of the President's lawyers attacking the House case against Mr. Clinton.
About two-thirds of voters here and across the state disapprove of Mr. Clinton and want him removed by the Senate, according to an early January poll by Richard Quinn, a Republican political consultant.
"South Carolina is immune to Bill Clinton's charms," said Mr. Quinn, whose office is in Columbia, S.C., and who has done Presidential polling here since 1980. "We know him too well. He is seen by voters here as the prototype of the Southern con artist."
This state is one of the most conservative in the South. Since 1964, with the exception of Jimmy Carter's first campaign, voters have not chosen a Democrat in a Presidential election. The State Legislature in 1996 banned same-sex marriages. That same year the Greenville County Council, representing one of the state's most prosperous regions, declared homosexuality incompatible with community standards.
Political antipathy toward Mr. Clinton's policies and religious outrage over his involvement with a White House intern have mingled here in the western edge of the state with home-grown pride in the case for conviction. Representative Lindsey Graham, a Republican who serves this part of the state, is one of the House prosecutors, or managers, making oral arguments against Mr. Clinton.
People here smile with satisfaction when describing Mr. Graham's just-folksy arguments against the President in the Senate chamber last Saturday.
Speaking by phone from Washington, Mr. Graham said he can feel the rage that's bubbling up across his district over Mr. Clinton's likely acquittal in the Senate.
"It is pretty tough," said Mr. Graham, who gets angry calls whenever he concedes on talk shows that the President's defenders may have a point. "They are letting me know in no uncertain terms what they think of this guy. There is probably nothing I could say about the President that would be too out of bounds for my constituents."
In Bill's Cafe, Mr. Landreth's wife, Linda, describes Mr. Clinton's probable acquittal as a frightening signal of trouble ahead.
The President's behavior, she said, is a modern-day re-enactment of the biblical story of David, king of the Israelites, and Bathsheba, a married woman not his wife.
"He looked at Bathsheba and instead of going back in his house, he sent for her and had adultery with her and the Lord made him pay," Mrs. Landreth said. "Now, why was Clinton with Monica Lewinsky when he should have been in his own house with Hillary? I think it means that this country is going to go down."
The Third Congressional District, which Mr. Graham represents, which snakes along the state's western border with Georgia, from the Savannah River nuclear power site up to the North Carolina border, percolates with of religious and entrepreneurial zeal.
"The regional economy is as good as we can remember in our lifetimes," said Burrell Nelson, head of the Economic Development Alliance of Pickens County.
Unemployment, at 2.8 percent, is far below the national average. Mr. Nelson said that a boom in metal-working, plastics and chemical industries means that just 1,500 people are without jobs in a county of 104,000. The region has also been inundated with retirement and vacation development, as well as new industrial parks and shopping malls.
But the Up County, as it is called here, has clung tenaciously amid the boom to its fundamentalist Christian roots. On every highway there are billboards and church signs warning, "Watch Thoughts Before They Become Works," and asking, "Troubled? Have You Tried Prayer?"
At the Feed Place cafe in the town of Pickens, where a "meat and three" -- that is, a choice of meat and three vegetables -- goes for $5.25, the men's room does not have condom machines. Instead, there are "salvation" brochures stacked on the toilet. They show a life preserver labeled "CHRIST" being thrown to a man swimming in a stormy sea labeled "SIN."
National indifference to sin is a nagging problem that several top students at Pickens High School say they worry about, especially as it applies to what Mr. Clinton has been up to in Washington.
"If the President can commit perjury and get away with it, does that mean the next President can do something even worse and get away with it?" asked Amy Garrison, 17, a senior who has been admitted to nearby Clemson University.
Echoing an argument Mr. Graham made on the Senate floor last Saturday, Ms. Garrison said, "If the Senate can kick out Federal judges for lying and obstructing justice, why should the President be above the law?"
In Mr. Graham's home town of Seneca, where about 80 churches serve a population of 12,000 people, Pastor Bill Rinehart of the United Assembly of God Church said his congregants are struggling to perform their Christian duty to "love and accept" the President.
That duty conflicts with the equally important Christian obligations to teach values to children, Mr. Rinehart said.
"How do you do this when the President is a sociopath?" asked Mr. Rinehart . "Anarchy has got to be somewhere down the road."
The pastor compared Mr. Clinton's future to that of the Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, whose execution by a firing squad was broadcast to the world in 1989.
Mr. Rinehart said that while he is "frustrated" by national polls showing that the President is more popular than ever, there are countless precedents showing that majorities can be horribly mistaken.
"The Roman Empire fell because the majority of the people were hedonistic and self-gratifying," Mr. Rinehart said, adding that he finds disturbing American parallels to Rome's fall, in particular the public's willingness to put economic good times above "honor and truth."
Irked but less apocalyptic, Ralph Gleaton, Pickens County assistant prosecutor, said the expected acquittal of the President in the Senate reminds him of criminal cases he has lost.
"It's the same frustration I felt when I believed a jury knew a defendant to be guilty and chose to let him go anyway," said Mr. Gleaton, a prosecutor for four years.
Mr. Gleaton, though, said he had learned to live with losing cases that, in a just world, he should have won. In the same fashion, he expects that he and other angry people in South Carolina will figure out a way to live with the President's survival.
"I got to tell you, in all honesty, I don't worry about it that much," Mr. Gleaton said. "If he is not convicted, the sun will still rise in the east and my dog will still lick my face."

HEADLINE: Health Programs and Education Get Help in Whitman's Budget

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
With an extra $1.1 billion to spend in the coming fiscal year, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will recommend giving a quarter of it back to taxpayers and using most of the rest to cover increased spending for public schools, state colleges, open space preservation and expanded health care programs for children and the elderly, New Jersey officials said today.
The Governor's $19.1 billion spending plan, outlined today by senior administration officials, includes $200 million to cover the first installment of the property tax rebate plan that she announced this month. Mrs. Whitman will formally present her budget to the Legislature on Monday. 
 The strong economy and proceeds from the nationwide tobacco settlement have helped swell the state's coffers and push up revenue forecasts for the next 18 months, said State Treasurer James A. DiEleuterio Jr.
Of the $92 million that New Jersey expects to receive next year from the tobacco settlement, Governor Whitman will recommend spending $18.6 million for new programs aimed at reducing smoking among teen-agers, Mr. DiEleuterio said. The state is to collect $7.6 billion over the next 25 years as part of the settlement of a class-action suit against the major tobacco companies.
Also, Mr. DiEleuterio said the Governor would propose using $36.4 million to cover increases in the cost of health benefits for state employees. The remaining money would be used for new mental health programs for state prisoners, early cancer screening, expanded health care for elderly residents, and other programs.
Spending would rise about 4.5 percent, including money that Mrs. Whitman and state lawmakers have said they intend to return to taxpayers this year. Mrs. Whitman has also recommended that $750 million be placed in the state's so-called "rainy day" reserve fund.
In addition to the $200 million for the property tax rebate program, Mrs. Whitman's budget includes $23 million for a program that freezes property taxes for low-income elderly and disabled homeowners. The budget also accommodates a $22 million tax cut, proposed by Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, a Republican, which would excuse about 200,000 low-income residents from paying state income taxes.
In terms of new spending, Mrs. Whitman is proposing a $317.7 million increase for public schools, $70.7 million for state colleges and universities, $100 million for open space preservation, $10 million for new initiatives to help spur residential development in cities, and $30 million for expanded health care programs for low-income children and the elderly. "With this, her sixth budget, it is fair to say that Governor Whitman's vision of a government that balances fiscal prudence with social compassion has succeeded," said John Farmer, the Governor's chief counsel.
Under the proposed budget, there would be no layoffs of state workers. State aid to municipalities would also rise by $23 million, the first significant increase since Mrs. Whitman took office. The increase includes money, requested by Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican, to cover routine inflationary increases for municipal services. The budget also sets aside up to $35 million in incentives for the state's 566 municipalities to reduce costs by sharing more services, like police and fire departments.
William Dressel, executive director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, said the budget "appears to be pretty good news, but we have to fully evaluate the details."
When Governor Whitman unveiled her five-year property tax rebate plan in her State of the State address, she undercut one of the Democrats' most effective campaign weapons: the state's high property tax rates.After her bruising re-election campaign in 1997, Mrs. Whitman promised voters that she would help reduce the property tax burden.
Under the plan, Mrs. Whitman would begin sending rebate checks to homeowners this year. The checks, which would average about $120 this year, would eventually rise to $600 in the fifth year of the program at a cost of $1 billion for that year.
Some critics say that Mrs. Whitman, whose second and final term ends in 2002, should not have proposed a program whose costs will rise steeply after she leaves office. They say it is the latest in a series of moves that she has made over the last six years that push costs, like debt service payments, into future years.
Some Democratic lawmakers said Mrs. Whitman should consider speeding up the property tax rebate schedule, considering the state's rosy revenue picture. "We have enough money to do more right now," said Assemblyman Joseph Charles Jr. of Jersey City.
Mr. Charles also said that Democrats are encouraged by what he called the "Governor's professed conversion" on property taxes. "But we remain skeptical about the way she is proposing to spend the revenue windfalls arising from these heady economic times and her fiscal policy of increased borrowing," he said.
Mr. Charles said he expected debate over how the proceeds from the tobacco settlement should be spent. Under the agreement, states can largely spend the money however they want.
When asked why Mrs. Whitman had proposed using some of the tobacco settlement money to pay for health benefits for state employees, Mr. Farmer said it was part of the Governor's plan to put all of the proceeds into health programs.
Mr. Collins, the Assembly Speaker, described the proposal as a "very good budget."
"It has a lot of aid to help citizens in various communities," he said. "I am particularly pleased with the increase in the higher education budget. I am also pleased that there are no layoffs."
Mr. DiEleuterio said that the strong economy has pushed up revenue estimates by $275 million for this fiscal year, which ends on June 30. He said the state, anticipating strong growth but at a more moderate pace during the next 18 months, is expecting that revenues will be $897 million more in the new fiscal year. "This has been the best two-year period, 1997 and 1998, in the last 10 years," he said.
He said most of the money is coming from growing sales, income and corporate tax collections. He said half of the increase in state income tax collections can be attributed to the Wall Street economic boom.
State Senator Bernard F. Kenny, a Democrat from Hoboken who is a member of the Budget and Appropriations Committee, said Democrats would "monitor the plan closely," considering that the budget is heavily dependent on the economy. "It would be a tragedy for the taxpayers of New Jersey if the benefits of a thriving national economy were squandered on election-year gimmicks," he said.

HEADLINE: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid

 BODY:

To the Editor:
How nice that everybody in Washington wants to save Social Security. The conservatives want to privatize it, make it voluntary or reduce its benefits. The President wants to add billions in budget surpluses to its trust fund, investing a good part in the stock market (editorial, Jan. 22). 
 But "saving" Social Security is unnecessary. Its allegedly impending bankruptcy is based on a myth concocted by the Administration: that economic growth in the United States will slow to Depression-era levels. One of the myth's originators, former Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, recently called this assumption "wildly pessimistic," as indeed it is. Given a reasonable forecast of only 2.2 percent annual growth in gross domestic product, Social Security will be solvent for as long as anyone dares predict.
 
JOHN GLASEL
Tenafly, N.J., Jan. 22, 1999

HEADLINE: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Lester C. Thurow (Op-Ed, Jan. 18) questions why Americans are feeling so rich that spending levels have risen to the point where we have a negative savings rate. He points out that "the bottom 60 percent of Americans cannot benefit from the market boom since they don't own any stock." What he doesn't understand is that people at the lower rungs of the economic ladder don't spend based on what they have but on their ability to remain employed.
While it may be true that most Americans don't directly benefit from the rising stock market, all the good financial news increases their confidence that they will have jobs six months from now. 
 They can overreach a little and catch up over time.
Unemployment may have been lower in 1961 and 1962, when savings rates were higher, but Americans didn't have 10 cable news channels and the Internet from which to get rosy financial news.
 
KEN LEE
Holmdel, N.J., Jan. 18, 1999

HEADLINE: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Bruce Bartlett ("Why Won't Clinton Cut Taxes?", Op-Ed, Jan. 19) makes some inappropriate comparisons to buttress his case that Federal taxes are too high on working people. He compares the average Federal tax burden in 1998, when incomes were high, to the recession years 1992 and 1983, when incomes were low. Tax rates decrease as incomes fall so that they are always lower during recessions. 
 Most important, he neglects to mention that the reason why tax rates for working-class families have not declined more since the 1980's is that tax relief has been focused on the well-to-do, including the latest capital gains reduction and tax relief for college tuition payments.
 
ROBERT CHERRY
Brooklyn, Jan. 19, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Brooklyn College, CUNY.
