HEADLINE: All's Fair?

BYLINE: By Jeremy Waldron; Jeremy Waldron is the Maurice and Hilda Friedman Professor of Law at Columbia University. His latest book is the forthcoming "Law and Disagreement."

 BODY:

ALL THE LAWS BUT ONE
Civil Liberties in Wartime.
By William H. Rehnquist.
Illustrated. 254 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $26. 
 In the early hours of May 25, 1861, a Maryland state legislator named John Merryman was arrested in connection with an attempt to disrupt the transport of Union troops from Baltimore to Washington. Merryman was held at Fort McHenry, under the command of Gen. George Cadwalader. The day after his arrest, Merryman's lawyer obtained a writ of habeas corpus, directing General Cadwalader to produce the prisoner so that a Federal court could examine the case for his detention. The general instead sent one of his officers to say that he was authorized by the President of the United States to suspend habeas corpus during the present emergency in Maryland. (What President Abraham Lincoln had actually commanded was that the resistance in Maryland was to be counteracted by "the most prompt and efficient means . . . even, if necessary . . . the bombardment of their cities and, in the extremest necessity, the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus.") The judge responded by ordering that the general himself be brought by force to the courtroom.
A United States marshal went to Fort McHenry to serve the writ of attachment, but -- not surprisingly -- he returned empty-handed. General Cadwalader would not receive him. The judge considered whether it would be worth forming a posse to bring the general into court but decided against it, fearing that the posse would be resisted with superior force. Instead, he delivered an opinion stating that the President did not have the authority to suspend habeas corpus. He sent a copy of his decision to the White House, reminding the President of his sworn duty "to take care that the laws be faithfully executed." Lincoln made no direct response to the court, nor did his Administration appeal the decision. (And the Army certainly did not release Merryman.) But in a speech to Congress on July 4, the President presented his critics with a challenge. The laws as a whole were being resisted in this rebellion, he said. Are "all the laws, but one, to go unexecuted, and the Government itself go to pieces, lest that one" -- habeas corpus -- "be violated?"
In those days, Justices of the Supreme Court sometimes sat as Federal circuit judges. The judge in the case of Merryman was Roger Taney, Chief Justice of the United States, and the author of the infamous Dred Scott decision (which in 1857 had held that African-Americans could not be citizens). Needless to say, Northern opinion was as outraged by Taney's decision in Merryman as it was by the earlier infamy. The New York Times thundered that the case presented "the ungracious spectacle of . . . the soldier eager to punish, and the jurist to exculpate a traitor." Nevertheless, five years later (after the Union victory and with a Lincoln appointee -- Salmon P. Chase -- as Chief Justice) the Supreme Court reached essentially the same conclusion as Taney in a case called Ex Parte Milligan. "The Constitution of the United States is a law for rulers and people, equally in war and in peace. . . . The Government, within the Constitution, has all the powers granted to it, which are necessary to preserve its existence." Habeas corpus could be suspended, but only by Congress; and even then, the majority said, civilians could not be held by the Army for trial before a military tribunal, not even if the charge was fomenting an armed uprising in a time of civil war.
William H. Rehnquist is 16th in the line of Chief Justices that includes Taney and Chase. With "All the Laws But One: Civil Liberties in Wartime," he has written a book that explores Lincoln's situation, not primarily through legal or philosophical analysis but by taking us through the variety of cases, from the 1860's to the 1940's, in which civil liberty issues in time of war have arisen.
The book is mainly narrative history, giving us an account of the Civil War cases, the cases that arose during and immediately after World War I and the cases that challenged the imposition of martial law in Hawaii and the removal and internment of Japanese-Americans in the Western states during World War II. Actually, that summary is a little misleading. There are 13 chapters on the 1860's and only five on the 20th-century cases: indeed, there are fewer than 30 pages on the World War II internments, compared with more than 60 on the Milligan case alone. That makes the book a little lopsided, the more so because the disparity is never explained by the author.
Still, Rehnquist presents full and fascinating human profiles of the major participants in these cases -- the statesmen, the soldiers, the suspects, their lawyers and the judges -- and a level of detail about the hearings and the decisions that provides the reader with some understanding of what it must have been like to grapple with these issues in a time of crisis. Not least is the sense that we get, in a case like Merryman, of what a clash between the executive and the judiciary is actually like: this provides a healthy reminder of how much we usually rely, in the last resort, on executive submission in upholding the rule of law.
In places, perhaps, there is a bit too much detail: at times it seems Rehnquist wants to write like J. Anthony Lukas in "Big Trouble," giving us a history of everything that is mentioned in the history and a background to everything that is furnished as background. Do we really need to know that the author of the majority opinion in Milligan went to stay with his uncle, an Episcopal rector, when he was 5? Or to be reminded, at the beginning of the chapter on Japanese internments, about ruinous inflation in Germany after the Kaiser's abdication in 1918? Readers will find themselves flipping rather impatiently through some of these pages.
But if they are looking for provocative opinions or predictions -- what this Chief Justice will do if a case like Milligan or Korematsu (the most famous of the World War II Japanese internment cases) ever comes before his Court -- they will be disappointed. Rehnquist is quite sparing in his commentary. He criticizes the Supreme Court majority in Milligan for holding that Congress had no power to permit trials of civilians by military tribunals in time of war, but mainly because that issue was not presented on the strict facts of the case. And the courts, he says, should not decide constitutional questions unnecessarily. He does speculate that maybe "Congress should be able to provide for trial of defendants by a judge without a jury" -- something like the Diplock courts in Northern Ireland -- "in a carefully limited class of cases dealing with national security in wartime." But this is not a suggestion he explores in any detail. He agrees with Judge Learned Hand's insistence in one of the World War I cases that the courts should resist any attempt by the Government to equate strongly worded criticism of conscription with advocacy of resistance to it. And he offers a helpful analysis of the Japanese-American cases by suggesting, first, a distinction between discrimination against groups of citizens and discrimination against aliens, and second, a distinction between a policy of evacuating people from coastal areas and a policy of continuing detention.
Most important, Rehnquist expresses concern about the alacrity with which the Roosevelt Administration accepted the military's advice about the dangers posed by Japanese nationals and citizens of Japanese ancestry. The President's approval of internment was "perfunctory," given in the course of a telephone conversation. As Attorney General Francis Biddle said later: "I do not think he was much concerned with the gravity or implications of this step. He was never theoretical about things. What must be done to defend the country must be done."
A nation that prides itself on the principle of civilian control of the military should recognize that concern for civil liberties is as much the job of the President as the courts. If it is, as Rehnquist suggests, the task of public opinion to insure that both branches take these issues seriously, then he can be congratulated for providing in a very readable form some of the material they will need for the responsible fulfillment of that duty.

HEADLINE: BEYOND THE CANAL, PANAMA PRISTINE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL FINKEL; MICHAEL FINKEL is the author of "Alpine Circus" to be published by Lyons this year.

 BODY:
I WENT to Panama on a hunch last September, which was pretty much the only way I could go. Reliable travel information about the country was surprisingly difficult to find.
The nation receives no more than a thin chapter in any guidebook I could locate and an Internet search proved equally anemic. Even the most peripatetic of my acquaintances could furnish no advice. To me, this was heartening. I am a selfish traveler -- I prefer to be surrounded by as few of my fellow itinerants as possible -- and the less I was able to learn about Panama the more interested I became. 
 My hunch was that Panama was similar to Costa Rica, only without the tourists. The two nations share a 150-mile-long border and the same entrancing blend of landscapes: extensive rain forests, lush mountain ranges, reef-laden coastlines. And while Costa Rica is famed for its eco-consciousness, Panama, I discovered, has quietly established 16 national parks and 8 other natural reserves in the last 25 years.
Panama has set aside nearly one-third of its total land area as protected areas, according to the guidebooks, which makes it one of the world's most preserved countries. And yet, when I perused classified ads for tours, I counted 11 outfitters headed for Costa Rica, yet not a single offer for a Panama trip. (This disparity may soon change, as Panama has embarked on a concerted effort to attract visitors, including the opening of a tourist bureau in the United States, near Miami.)
I did have a few concerns about my trip. It was less than 10 years ago that President George Bush, in response to the killing of a United States marine by Panamanian soldiers and a declaration of war against the United States by the legislature, launched an invasion of Panama City, and a mere seven years since the end of Manuel Noriega's cocaine-financed paramilitary regime.
The State Department advised travelers that some regions near the Colombian border may be dangerous and that there is occasional anti-American sentiment in the country. But it said that crime in Panama City is typical of metropolitan areas and made no mention of the areas I wanted to see. I wasn't sure whether Panama's reputation as dangerous was warranted, but there was only one good way to find out.
I met my friend and occasional travel partner Katinka de Ruiter in Atlanta, and we caught the easy four-hour flight into Panama City. It was not the high tourist time -- December through April is the so-called summer dry season -- but even so, the airplane was eerily empty.
Panama City is an unfortunate introduction to Panama. It's a loud, unattractive metropolis, the streets dominated by buses that have been airbrushed in spasms of jarring colors, like graffitied subway cars. Each bus is independently owned and decorated, and they bolt from one stop to the next drag-race style. Crossing the street is often a death-defying sprint.
Even the colonial part of the city, established by the Spanish in the 17th century and known as Casco Viejo (Old Crown) but referred to in English as the Colonial Quarter, is seedy and charmless. At least a dozen people warned us not to venture out at night. My first impression was that I'd made a poor choice of a vacation destination.
Still, there was an intriguing vibrancy to the city. An entire district of Panama City consists of modern skyscrapers housing international banks, and the nearby Panama Canal (which will revert to full Panamanian control at the end of this year) is a steady source of employment and income. There are casinos and high-priced nightclubs and Wal-Marts. Shops and markets were bustling. Salsa music seemed to float in and out with the sea breeze.
Spanish is the national language, but almost everyone speaks a little English. Here and there, I spotted members of the Kuna tribe, the most distinctive of Panama's five indigenous peoples. The Kuna men wear standard Western garb, but the women wear dozens of beaded bracelets on both arms and both legs, thick gold nose rings and billowing blouses embroidered with dazzling, joyous tapestries called molas that reminded me of Keith Haring's distinctive painting style.
I sampled street food from a half-dozen places -- empanadas (meat-stuffed turnovers); ceviche (heavily marinated raw fish); ropa vieja (literally "old clothes," Panama's version of fajitas) -- and drank the water, safe and delicious, straight from public taps. We hopped a short bus ride to the Miraflores Locks and watched an oil tanker complete part of its 10-hour journey through the canal.
But we had come to see the countryside, not the city. The day after we arrived, that was our first order of business. We took a bus west, over the canal on the soaring, steel Bridge of the Americas, and out of the city.
Panama is an unusually shaped country, long and narrow and curled at both ends, like a tilde. Panama City is on the Pacific coast, halfway between the Colombia border, to the east, and the Costa Rica border, to the west. West of the city was a stretch of grazing lands and then the mountains rose up, gentle and treed, and the land became increasingly fertile, the roadside lined with coffee groves and fields of sugar cane.
Though the traffic was light and the Inter-American Highway was newly paved, we arrived in David, capital city of Panama's southwestern province of Chiriqui, two hours late -- the 200-mile trip took seven hours instead of the scheduled five. No one on the bus seemed even mildly perturbed.
We caught another bus north, out of David -- where, in the space of less than a block, we passed a banana seller guiding his overloaded mule toward the market and then roared by a brightly lighted Internet cafe -- and into the mountains. Both Katinka and I are amateur mountaineers (if the required equipment is nothing more than decent footwear we'll give it a shot), and our destination was Boquete, a small town an hour from David at the base of Volcan Baru National Park, site of Panama's tallest peak and sole volcano. We'd been told by several people that the summit of Volcan Baru, elevation 11,401 feet, is the only place in the world from which both the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans could be seen, and so singular or not, that tidbit was enough to put us in a hiking mood.
Boquete is a gem. The town, population 3,000, is snuggled high in the fertile foothills of Volcan Baru. Both the coffee and the oranges grown here are purported to be the finest in Panama. The Rio Caldera meanders through, bubbling alongside pastel-painted homes and tiny cafes; flowers grow everywhere, and the air, free of the smothering humidity of the Panamanian lowlands, carries the taste of jasmine. There are hot springs nearby and a volcano overhead and the people walking the streets had the relaxed, satisfied glow of health spa denizens. It has been claimed that several residents of Boquete have lived more than 115 years, and I choose to believe it.
Katinka and I rented a simple room, with a cold-water shower and a clear view of Baru, at the adorable Pension Topas. It cost $10 a night; a generous and healthy breakfast -- homemade bread, locally grown oranges -- was an additional $3 each. (The official currency is the United States dollar, but it is generally referred to as the balboa.) The proprietor, a German named Axel who spent his first six years in Panama as a tomato farmer before opening the Topas in 1992, told me that the last few years, under the presidency of Ernesto Balladares, have been a time of unprecedented prosperity. The roads, the schools, the economy, all, Axel said, have been overhauled.
In the morning, we visited Cafe Time, a hole in the wall (literally), and fortified ourselves with rich local coffee. Then, for a couple of dollars, we hired a ride on the back of a pickup truck to the entrance of the 35,336-acre Volcan Baru National Park (and made an agreement with the driver to return for us at sunset).
I'd never been in a situation where I wanted more people to be in a national park, but there was not a single person anywhere, not even a park ranger. A field worker coming up the road, machete in hand, explained that Panama saw so few tourists in low season that many national parks were unstaffed and that any group that happened by was welcome to hike or camp, without charge. The path to the summit, he said, is simple to follow.
And so we climbed the volcano, a nine-hour round-trip hike during which we saw only two other tourists, both young men from Panama City. The first several miles were in thick rain forest, and we ascended accompanied by a pleasing soundtrack -- a jungle chorus of dripping and chirping and buzzing and squawking. Then mist began threading through the treetops and soon the forest started to steam, and finally the clouds let loose and the rain came down.
It fell with a force I had never before experienced; it was like standing under a waterfall. The hiking path turned into a roiling brown river. Our waterproof jackets became waterlogged. Then, as quickly as it started, the rain stopped. And by the time we scrambled up a steep section of boulder-steps to reach the large cross marking the highest point of Panama, the clouds were in full retreat and with only a turn of our heads we could look north or south and see the shores of the two great oceans of the world.
The next day, we took the bus down out of the mountains and then north along the highway in Bocas del Toro Province. Within a matter of hours, we were at the edge of the Caribbean Sea and in a different world. At the rough-edged fishing town of Chiriqui Grande, we hired a water taxi (about $10 each) to take us on the 40-minute trip to Isla Bastimentos, one of the larger islands of the 200 or so in the compact Bocas del Toro archipelago.
There are two major Caribbean island groups in Panama -- the Bocas del Toro, in the far west, and the San Blas, east of Panama City, home of the Kuna people, who run the islands as an autonomous province, with their own language and system of governance, and who grow what are purported to be some of the tastiest coconuts in the world. Katinka and I finished our Panama trip with a very brief visit to the San Blas (I can confirm the coconut claim), but we first went to Bocas del Toro to explore Bastimentos National Park. The park, founded in 1988 as Panama's first marine preserve, serves to protect the beaches used as nesting grounds by three species of sea turtles, as well as miles of delicate coral reefs.
There is a tiny village on Isla Bastimentos, home to maybe 200 people. A cement path connects all the houses, which are on stilts and have thatched roofs. Every family has a dugout canoe, used to travel from island to island -- fishermen deliver their catches to nearby Isla Carenero, which we were told has the finest seafood restaurants around.
There are palm trees and banana trees and bushes blooming with fireworks of huge red flowers. The local language is called Guari-guari, a crazy mixture of English and Spanish and the native Guaym tongue. Chickens ran loose; brilliant butterflies flitted about. A tiny shop sold bananas for a penny apiece. Children played on a small soccer pitch and on a basketball court, where the basket was nailed to a palm tree.
I walked the length of the village path and everyone waved hello. Two people told me they had once moved to America and didn't like it, and came right back to Bastimentos. A calypso band was jamming in the town bar. A glass of rum cost 75 cents. There were no souvenirs for sale, no T-shirt shops, no one trying to serve as a guide.
We took a room ($10) at the Pension Bastimentos, which was also run by a German couple, Tom and Ena Reichelt. The pension was built atop a dock, and the waves broke onto shore under our room's floorboards. There were no locks on the doors, no glass in the windows. Otti, the Reichelt's parrot, would occasionally hop through the window frame and squawk out a greeting.
Ena said we had arrived just in time for dinner, and we were in for a treat -- several bush rats, a native rodent, had recently been trapped, and she was combining the meat with some iguana to make a pasta sauce. "Bush rat is my specialty," she said. It had a distinct flavor -- something like smoked duck -- and the Panama rum went well with it.
We awoke to the sound of roosters, purchased a few bunches of bananas, and set off across the island in search of quiet beaches. Twenty feet beyond the last house in town, we were in thick jungle. Lizards skittered along tree branches. Neon frogs -- red with black dots, and no bigger than a thimble -- bounded through the underbrush. Leaf-cutter ants marched along the narrow trail, each carrying a piece of palm frond that looked like a green flag.
It took less than half an hour to reach the first beach, one of 11 on the island. The sand was pure white and extended along a bay for nearly a mile. Wave-polished sea shells and chunks of brain coral were strewn about; pelicans dived into the warm sea. But what I found most satisfying -- what made me feel I'd had a lucky, brilliant intuition about Panama -- is that on this particular beach, on this particular day, nobody else was there.
 
Crossing the Big Ditch to mountains and beaches
The Panama Tourist Bureau has opened an office near Miami. You can contact it for brochures and general information at Post Office Box 144351, Coral Gables, Fla. 33114; (800) 557-0017, fax (305) 854-4589. In Panama City, the bureau's number is (507) 226-7000, fax (507) 226-4002. Information on the Web is available at www.panamatours.com.
Lonely Planet has just published a guidebook to Panama ($16.95). It also offers "Central America on a Shoestring" ($19.95), which includes Panama information; call (510) 893-8555 or see www.lonelyplanet.com.
Panama gets more visitors during the dry season, mid-December through April, than other times. If you would like to have huge national parks virtually all to yourself, then go during the rainy season, May through November. I was there in September, and while it did rain nearly every day, the showers lasted only an hour or so, and left the air feeling scrubbed and fresh-smelling.
To witness Panama at its most festive, visit during carnival, the weekend before Ash Wednesday, which is Feb. 17 this year.
 
Getting There and Around
A number of major airlines, including American and Continental, fly to Panama City from the United States.
It's easy and inexpensive to fly domestically -- tickets are rarely more than $50 one way. Reservations can be made the same day, and the longest flight is less than an hour. Aeroperlas, (507) 263-5363, is the major domestic airline.
 
Where to Stay and Eat
There are dozens of hotels in Panama City, ranging in price from the 185-room Miramar Intercontinental, (507) 214-1000, where doubles start at $185 and suites are $415 to $1,700, to the Hotel Central, (507) 262-8044, in in the heart of Casco Viejo, where doubles are $11.55 a night (mine was less than pristine).
For outstanding seafood, visit the Avenue Balboa market, where you can buy a fish and have it cooked for $2 in the restaurant upstairs. The ajillo sauce is great.
In Boquete, we enjoyed the excellent and inexpensive Pension Topas, (507) 720-1005. It has six rooms, four with private baths. They are decorated with bright murals, have great views of the Volcan Baru and cost $12 to $26.40 a night. A large breakfast is $3.80
On Isla Bastimentos, in the Bocas del Toro archiepelago, the Pension Bastimentos, ($10 a night) was basic (no telephone and often, not even electricity) but friendly. Any boat taxi, though, will drop you off right at the pension's dock.
On Isla Carenero, order the catch of the day at Pago Rajo. Here, as everywhere rural we visited, it is difficult to pay even $15 for a meal. MICHAEL FINKEL

 BODY:

Walking in Wales
 
Q. I am planning a hiking trip to Wales this spring, and would like some general information on trails. -- Mindy Dillon, Buffalo
 
A. There are thousands of miles of walking paths throughout Wales, ranging from those that traverse the heather moorlands and mountainous terrain of the 845-square-mile Snowdonia National Park in the north, to less demanding trails that crisscross the gentle countryside of central Wales. Other popular destinations are in the western coastal regions of Pembrokeshire National Park and southern Wales' mountainous Brecon Beacons National Park. Wherever you roam, especially in the parks, you're likely to encounter abundant wildlife, including seals and numerous bird species. 
 The Wales Tourist Board publishes a free 53-page guide called "Walking Wales" that includes a selection of walks long and short, tough and easy. Nearby accommodations and a small map with Ordnance Survey references accompany each entry. Among the short walks is the four-mile St. Brides Major Walk that incorporates both inland countryside and segments of the 14-mile Glamorgan Heritage Coast in southern Wales. Sites on the route include a ruined castle, the remains of an old walled garden, the sandy beach at Dunraven Bay, traces of a Celtic settlement and an ancient church. Among the longer walks are the 182-mile Offa's Dyke Path, which crosses the England-Wales border 13 times; and the 186-mile Pembrokeshire Coast Path with its rugged cliff trails and sandy beaches.
The guide also includes a 10-page list of publications on hiking in Wales, a list of tourist office addresses and phone numbers, advice on transportation; and other useful information. It is available from the Wales Tourist Board, Department PP12, Post Office Box 1, Cardiff, Wales; telephone (44-1222) 457766, fax (44-1222) 482436.
Among the companies specializing in hiking in Wales are Acorn Activities, in Hereford, (44-1432) 830083; fax (44-1432) 830110, and Heart of Wales Farm and Country Holidays, telephone and fax (44-1686) 688444.
You may also be interested in a spring walking festival. From May 28 to 31, the Llanelli Festival of Walks will include 10 hikes along coastal paths, and through the hills of southern Wales; the walks range from 6 gentle miles to 10-mile strenuous walks. The fee is $24.50. A festival dinner costs $16. The Festival Office in Llanelli, telephone (44-1554) 770077, can provide information on lodgings in the area.
 
Brazilian Rhythm Festival
 
Q. I would like to go to the Panorama Percussivo Mundial festival in Salvador, Brazil. Please provide information. -- Mabel MacDonald, Aspen, Colo.
 
A. The six-year-old Panorama Percussivo Mundial (World Percussive Panorama, or Percpan, as it is called in Brazil) is a jubilant festival that showcases international percussion-based music -- both traditional and modern -- from Brazil, Africa, the Caribbean and other areas. Even though the festival is only two months away, promoters for the event, which will be held March 22 to 27 in Salvador, the capital of the northeastern state of Bahia, are not releasing details about international performers, with whom they're still in negotiation. It has been announced that the Brazilian songwriter Gilberto Gil and Nana Vasconcellos, a percussionist, will act as masters of ceremony.
 You're likely to see some colorful performances by musicians and dancers decked out in headdresses, feathers and flowing robes. Calabash and gourd rattles, cowbells, an exotic variety of drums, even a pair of wooden shoes, provided the rhythms for last year's festival, which included Doudou N'Diaye Rose, a Senegalese drum and dance ensemble, the Japanese group Wadaiko Yamato and the Brazilian composer Hermeto Pascoal.
In addition to the evening performances (there are about five a night), you can attend daily two-hour workshops, led by participating musicians.
Percpan will take place in downtown Salvador's Castro Alves theater (Praca 2 de Julho, Campo Grande). Nightly ticket prices are likely to be the same as last year: $8, $4 for students. For more information call (55-71) 243 6364, or by E-mail to percpan@e-net.com.br.
 
Rare Book Shops in Paris
 
Q. Do you know the names of bookstores in Paris that specialize in rare books? Simon Lagroste, Providence, R.I.
 
A. Most of Paris's antique book stores (called librairies) are concentrated in two distinctly different neighborhoods: on the Left Bank, in the fifth arrondissement near the Sorbonne and in the sixth arrondissement between St.-Germain-des-Pres and Odeon; and on the Right Bank in the area around the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore, as well as in the eighth and ninth arrondissements. The Left Bank shops are in a neighborhood for printers and book shops, which were established in the 15th century. At that time, the first printing press arrived in the city, and was housed in the Sorbonne.
Shops you might come across include: Alain Brieux, at 48 Rue Jacob in the sixth arrondissement. It was established at the end of the 19th century, and began specializing in rare medical and scientific books and instruments in 1958. It is open Monday to Saturday from 10 to 1 and 2 to 6:30; telephone (33-1) 42.60.21.98.
Librairie Gourmande, 4 Rue Dante in the fifth, stocks many rare books on the art of dining from the 16th century to the present. It is open every day from 10 to 7; (33-1) 43.54.37.27.
Librairie Beres, 14 Avenue Friedland in the eighth, is reputed to have the best collection of rare books from the 9th to the 20th centuries, on subjects ranging from politics and economics to literary first editions. Hours are 9 to 6 daily; (33-1) 45.63.85.53.
 Laurent Coulet, 166 Boulevard Haussmann in the eighth, specializes in handsomely bound works of French literature from the 16th to the 18th centuries. It is open Tuesday to Saturday from 10 to 12:30 and 2 to 6:30; (33-1) 42.89.51.59.
For rare maps, atlases and engravings from the 15th to the mid-19th centuries, you might want to go to the Librairie La Bail-Weissert, 5 Rue Lagrange in the fifth. The shop includes original topographical maps of the world, as well as maps of European cities, regions and a collection of architectural engravings. Hours are Monday to Saturday, from 10 to 12:30 and 2 to 7; (33-1) 43.29.72.59. SUZANNE MacNEILLE

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Stretch Market For Limousines

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
THE passengers in those limousines are not all haughty film stars sipping Cosmopolitan cocktails. In the last few weeks, I heard about a Halloween birthday party where 15 costumed 8-year-olds had a ball riding to a New York restaurant in a maximo limousine. A friend, at loggerheads with a son about who would drive the second car needed to get seven people to Connecticut for Christmas dinner, hired a stretch limo for the whole group for $240 each way and was delighted with the trip and the sociability.
Even I, after years as a limo shunner, have at last seen the inside of a super stretch. At the travel agents' convention in Los Angeles in October, a hotel organization sent a long white limo to take a group of us to a reception. Lacking an alternative, I climbed aboard with nine others: three facing front, two facing back and five along the side. I have since learned that this was probably a 120-inch stretch, meaning that the sedan had been cut apart and 10 more feet of car inserted in the middle. 
 If 8-year-olds and people like me, who are neither getting married nor going to a prom, are riding in limousines, it dawned on me that things must have undergone a radical change. And indeed they have.
 
A Cost-Effective Choice
Bruce Kosman, president of 1-800-Limo-Center, a new national network of companies with headquarters in Rochelle Park, N.J., said there has been an explosion in the chauffeured-car business in the last two to three years. "When I was young, a limo was something of a luxury," he said. "Today the corporate world has realized it is the most cost-effective way to get around. If a $500,000-a-year executive is flying to someplace to close a $10 million deal, it does not make sense for him to get a rental car, figure out where he's going, drive there, find a parking place and walk in wilted." He said that estimates in the business, which is quite fragmented, put annual growth at 11 percent.
The magazine Limousine and Chauffeured Transportation, published in Torrance, Calif., reports that nationally 65 percent of company operators reported average revenue increases of 29 percent last year; 6 percent reported a decline, the rest level revenues. The magazine's editor, Sara Eastwood-McLean, said that companies now tend to buy each other out so that after 13 years of growth or stability in the total number of companies, 1998 saw a decline from 9,600 operators to 9,100.
Scott A. Solombrino, president of Dav El Chauffeured Transportation Network, with headquarters in Chelsea, Mass., said his company has grown an average of 28 percent a year for five years. The worldwide fleet, he said, totals 10,400 vehicles. Like Mr. Kosman, he said that corporate business was powering the expansion, particularly businesses' belief that resources were being wasted when executives were using rental cars.
"The second big force is the advent of the female executive," Mr. Solombrino said. "A company knows it is incurring a liability if a female C.E.O. arrives in Dallas at 11 P.M. and takes a cab to the hotel. They have demanded the use of chauffeured cars, and pretty soon everyone in the company begins to see the value of protecting all executives. Women executives are our best clients."
A third factor he cited was an out-of-control economy, saying that the same prosperity that was soaking up the first-class and business-class airline seats was causing car-service fleets to expand on the double. Right now, with gasoline prices way down, the companies are doing well and can expand. But, Mr. Solombrino said, he was not sure that growth would stay at 28 percent this year.
Dav El is business-oriented, he said: Less than 5 percent of its volume involves proms, weddings, nights on the town or gambling expeditions. In any case, he said, not many cars are sitting in the parking lot on Saturday and Sunday: Weekend corporate business has tripled in five years because so many companies now hold meetings over the weekend to take advantage of lower air fares.
Nationally, according to Limousine and Chauffeured Transportation magazine, corporate business accounted for 24 percent of the operators' income last year, airport trips 22 percent and weddings 20 percent. In 1996, corporate business was at 19 percent, airport trips 23 percent and weddings 24 percent.
Corporate clients use black sedans, most often Lincoln Town Cars, rather than the extra-long babies seen at Oscar night or prom time. On Christmas Day, when three of us needed to get from Captiva Island, Fla., to Fort Myers, and local taxis were not available, employees at the marina recommended Royal Palm Luxury Car Service. A comfortable black Town Car driven by the small company's president, Anthony Paolercio, who had a career at I.B.M. and left New York three years ago, scooped us up. He packed our luggage into the big trunk, recommended a place to buy oranges to take home, and three of us glided to our meeting spot for $75. We asked him to recommend a service as smooth and reliable as his elsewhere.
That was difficult, he said, and limo people agree, because if a recommended company proves a lemon, this could alienate a longtime customer from the original car service. So Royal Palm is part of still another of the growing number of limo networks: Empire International, in Norwood, N.J. It is headed by David Seelinger, who owns the part of the company serving New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and has affiliates in 250 cities worldwide. It is growing so rapidly that the telephone message that played spoke of 100 cities, which Mr. Seelinger said was only a year out of date.
 
Plenty of Listings
The listings under Limousine Service cover most of nine pages in the Manhattan Yellow Pages, and almost four more pages of listings, some duplicates, appear under Car Service. It's pretty easy to tell which companies have contracts with corporations and law firms (clients use vouchers rather than cash) just by looking at the tags in the limo windows outside big office buildings, especially late at night on Wall Street. But the profusion of choices for the individual consumer means that a network or a trade name is a big help.
That is how 1-800-Limo-Center got into the business in July, Mr. Kosman said. After months of travel and checking into existing services in other cities, he said he was trying to think how to market directly to customers. He decided that 1-800-Flowers was the model to follow, and eventually he got American Express to be his "messenger" and put his leaflets into customer mailings.
Like the two other networks discussed here -- and there are doubtless others -- Limo Center takes reservations and credit card numbers and then bills the client for everything, including tip, so no cash is needed at the time of the ride.
The networks have varying prices and ways to respond to foul-ups, particularly cars that do not show up, but networks' basic response is to cancel the charge. Clients who do not find their cars waiting call the 800 number, according to the operators, and another car is dispatched if need be. Outside the network system, in a city like New York, when law firms and similar businesses have contracts with limo companies, they may not be able to fulfill a request if the weather turns bad, or it is a major holiday.
The big networks use airline computer systems to find out if the flights they are meeting will be severely delayed. These companies have access to buses for large groups, and also have minibuses with conference tables for business groups that want to work on the way.
Here are some details on the three networks.
1-800-Limo-Center is the company's name, and the 24-hour number translates to (800) 546-6236. The company started in July, and headquarters are at 336 West Passaic Street, Rochelle Park, N.J. 07662. It operates in the top 150 airports in the country through its links to 200 companies, 190 in the United States and the rest in London, Paris, Rome and Canada.
Prices are based on distance, which is determined by a computer program showing ZIP codes. These rates are quoted on the phone; a sheet of sample rates shows a trip from O'Hare Airport in Chicago to a downtown address in the 60618 ZIP code starts at $44 for a trip in a sedan, $74 in a 6-passenger limo and $94 in an 8- to 10-passenger limo. To Evanston, Ill., the rates are $40, $70 and $90.
To these rates, the company adds a 15 percent tip for a sedan (20 percent for longer cars) and a 10 percent processing fee. For domestic flights, the first 30 minutes of waiting time after the posted arrival is free. There is a $15 charge for meeting international flights, but no further charges for waiting time. There is a 15-minute grace period for non-airport pickups. The additional charge for each 15 minutes of waiting time is $11 for sedans and $15 for limos.
If the car does not show up in 15 minutes, the customer must call the 800 number; if no car then responds, this call avoids a no-show charge, which is the cost of the trip, the tip and waiting time. If the car never does show up, the cost of alternative transportation is paid by the company. Cancellations not made two hours or more in advance incur a charge of $44 for a sedan, $60 for a limousine.
Dav El Chauffeured Transportation Network, 200 Second Street, Chelsea, Mass. 02150, operates in 458 cities, 284 of them in the United States. The toll-free number is (800) 922-0343. Reservations may be made by phone, fax or Internet, and travel agents can reach the company on Apollo or Sabre reservation systems. The company approves customers' credit and opens an account.
In the United States and Canada, the company uses standard indexed hourly prices, which Mr. Solombrino says represent a national average. These are below the market rate in New York, he said, although they may be above elsewhere. A sedan costs $49 an hour, plus 15 percent tip. An 80-inch stretch Lincoln, holding seven people (six in two back seats, one in the front passenger seat) costs $63 an hour, plus 20 percent tip. An executive van for nine people with a table costs $63 plus a 15 percent tip. A regular passenger van for 15 people is $63 an hour, plus 15 percent. Waiting time costs the same as driving time.
Empire International, 55 Walnut Street, Norwood, N.J. 07648, (800) 451-5466, operates in 250 cities through a licensing arrangement. Outside the New York three-state area, it uses regional prices based on a computer program that gives the distance. In Chicago, for example, the trip from O'Hare to ZIP code 60618 would cost $80 in a sedan, plus a 15 percent tip. The same trip by limo or van would be $115 plus 15 percent. In smaller cities, the price is a minimum of $100, which is the two-hour minimum at $50 an hour, plus 15 percent. The company will establish individual accounts.

PUB-DATE: January 24, 1999

SECTION: Section 6; Page 36; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3706 words

HEADLINE: Spies Wanted

BYLINE: By Tim Weiner; Tim Weiner is a Washington correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
The phone yanked Steve Drescher from a deep slumber early on a mid-November Monday. He shook the weekend's cobwebs from his head and mumbled hello. The Central Intelligence Agency was calling.
 "Hi, remember me?" said the voice on the line. "I'm Mike. I'm with the C.I.A. We're interested in you." 
 Drescher came slowly into consciousness, wondering what the man was talking about, and why the C.I.A. was calling him -- a 19-year-old sophomore at Ohio State University. Then he dimly remembered dropping off a resume several weeks earlier with an agency recruiter on Career Day, the bustling job fair that Ohio State holds for its 48,500 students. Drescher, a budding computer programmer, had been much more focused that day on a job at Microsoft or Compuserve.
 The next night, he sat under a fluorescent light in a campus conference room, too nervous to touch his cooling pizza, listening to Mike try to convince him and 25 other students that it would be neat to be a spy.
 "I'm clueless as to what I would actually do for the C.I.A.," Drescher said to me. "The only thing I have to go on is the movies. To me, it's 'Mission: Impossible.' "
 The world's most famous intelligence service has kicked off the biggest recruiting drive in its history, digging deeply into the American landscape for a vein, a nugget, a trace of talent. Never before has it been so easy to arrange an interview with the agency: just call (800) 562-7242 ("JOBS C.I.A."), or log onto www.cia.gov. Answer the want ads in The Economist, The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal -- then come on in for a lie-detector test! A few years from now, you, too, could be digging up dirt in Khartoum, skulking through the bazaars of Peshawar or poring over documents purloined from Pyongyang.
 George J. Tenet, the Director of Central Intelligence, says he has to mount "a very aggressive way to bring people in" -- two or three thousand bright young Americans in the next few years -- or risk the slow death of American intelligence. "To do what I expect to do, to have the depth that I expect that we need to have, you have to go recruit the best and the brightest," he says.
 In fact, Tenet hopes to make the clandestine service bigger than it was at the height of the cold war, to open more overseas stations and bases, to mount more complex and more expensive secret operations. And he wants the nation's sharpest talents to come to work at C.I.A. headquarters as intelligence analysts, information technicians and in-house experts on everything from Afghanistan to Zimbabwe. In sum, he aims to revitalize an agency that has been mired in a slough of despond -- terrible publicity, terrible morale, terrible credibility.
 "I will not allow the C.I.A. to become a second-rate organization," Tenet told a gathering of the agency's employees recently. By most accounts, including Tenet's, the hiring blitz is the most important internal affair on the agency's agenda for the rest of the century. Congress will pump hundreds of millions of extra dollars into the agency over the next few years to get new blood flowing.
 But success is hardly assured. With the cold war a fading memory and the C.I.A. increasingly scorned as a bungling bureaucracy, who really wants to be a spy anymore?
At the Ohio State job fair, the agency has set up a spiffy booth sandwiched between Chase Manhattan and a computer company. The recruiters hand out vaguely informative pamphlets and brochures. Fear and ignorance about the C.I.A. are rampant, judging from interviews with students at the fair.
 "People don't have a very clear idea of what they do," says Tim Paradis, 22, editor of the school paper, The Lantern. "It's a dark Government agency." Richelle Sherwood, 24, an Air Force veteran who speaks Vietnamese, says, "I don't really know a lot about them, except they do all this secret stuff." Karl Curtis, 21, an information-systems major, is intrigued but uninformed. "You've heard the rumors, you've seen the movies, you're curious about what weird things they do," he says. "I guess you'd get to know the dirty things, the cool things about the world. And a 'top secret' clearance is a really marketable skill."
 Marwan Saleh, 22, wearing a brush cut and a sharp suit, stands out. He looks as if he'd make a perfect spy. A fiercely patriotic Palestinian-American who's mellifluously fluent in Arabic, he's also a frequent visitor to the homeland, the holder of a political-science degree -- and slated to receive an M.B.A. this spring in global supply and demand. The C.I.A. would fall at his feet. But he's not likely to let them. "I'm an American Democrat," he says. "I believe as an American that it's my duty to question and help develop American policy. And the C.I.A. seems like it would be executing policy. And I can't blind myself. I have my own political views." He moves on.
 Two thousand college students parade past the booth this afternoon. Not many stop to chat. After all, the Heathers and Jennifers and Ryans and Karls are competing in a cutthroat environment, one in which the strong will be clicking their corporate keypads -- and the weak will be asking if you want fries with that shake. And considering that even the Steak 'n' Shake recruiters are offering $40,000 salaries that pay more than most C.I.A. entry-level jobs, bringing top students into the agency is no small challenge. Try as it might, the C.I.A. is going to have a tough time promoting the spy trade as just another smart career option.
The task of drawing talented people into the C.I.A. falls to four of George Tenet's most trusted men: Buzzy Krongard, a multimillionaire investor who serves as the Director's consigliere; Gil Medeiros, head of the C.I.A.'s newly created Recruitment Center; Dave Carey, the agency's executive director; and Dick Calder, its chief administrative officer. Sitting around a table on the C.I.A.'s seventh floor, in their crisp white shirts and quiet ties, they outwardly resemble Madison Avenue admen of yesteryear.
 The C.I.A.'s marketing push has yielded many new applicants: the Web site and want ads draw 50,000 resumes a year. But there's a mismatch between the people who want in and the people the agency wants to let in. Of those who formally apply, four out of five will never make it past an initial interview.
"We are not for everybody, and everybody is not for us," Medeiros says. "There are a fair number of resumes we have to throw away." Perhaps the biggest obstacle in recruiting young Americans, he says, is "the lack of awareness of history" among them. "It is amazing how little they know about us." And most of what they know is wrong: a jumble of "The X-Files," half-remembered headlines and good old-fashioned American paranoia. The recruiters know that a lot of people think the C.I.A. is some sort of secret police force, running around the United States killing people with high-tech guns. "I don't know if that is good or bad, actually," Medeiros says, and everyone laughs.
 "We do get a lot of crazies," Krongard says.
 Carey elaborates. "What you see, in the average group of 15 kids, is some who are reasonably well informed, who have looked at the Web page, who have actually tried to figure us out a little," he says. "And then there are those who think it is going to be 007."
 It never quite was 007, and it surely never will be again. Once upon a time in the cold war, the agency would never have advertised itself. It would have been unthinkable, unnecessary, unseemly. But when the hammer and sickle came down over the Kremlin, the veterans of the cold war began cleaning out their desks.
 Over the past six years, the C.I.A. has lost about 4,000 of its most experienced and skilled people: about 20 percent of its spies, analysts, scientists and technology experts. Ten years ago, the agency was probably 10 years ahead of the public sector when it came to computer capability. No longer. The agency desperately needs, right now, hundreds of computer wizards comfortable with the latest technology. But competing with the likes of Microsoft and I.B.M. is proving increasingly difficult.
 The decline has been most significant at the C.I.A.'s directorate of operations -- the clandestine service, the spies who serve abroad. At least 7 percent of the spy cadre has left the agency in each of the past six years. That adds up to about a thousand spies, and it leaves not many more than a thousand in place. The departures of hundreds of officers in their 30's and 40's were especially troubling to the C.I.A.
 This same instability has permeated the agency's top brass. No Director of Central Intelligence has served for more than two years in this decade. The whirlwind has at times left the C.I.A. directionless, a ship in irons. And bad publicity -- traitors within, snafus abroad -- further angered and depressed the agency.
 "There were tremendous internal morale problems," says John M. Deutch, Director of Central Intelligence in 1995 and 1996. "Tremendously poor morale and tremendously poor credibility."
 And as the agency went through director after director, "there was not a clear articulation of what the agency's mission would be," says John McMahon, deputy director of Central Intelligence in the 1980's. Without that clarity, the agency's spies "just wallow in their own stew" -- an unsettling state of affairs for a nation that calls itself the last great superpower.
 The accumulated miseries of the post-cold-war spy service damaged the C.I.A.'s ability to keep its best people. The agency hired about 25 new covert-operations officers in 1995, and lost six times as many to retirement. "You can't run a clandestine service worldwide if your intake is 25 a year," McMahon says. Making matters worse, in 1996, Harold J. Nicholson, a turncoat inside the agency, sold to the Russians the names of three years' worth of graduates of the C.I.A.'s internal school for spies, ruining their ability to work overseas.
 So the C.I.A. has to build a new fleet of spies. People who can hack into a computer system, pose as a cocaine kingpin, think like a terrorist, be fluent in cultures that are not American and speak silkily to people who may be murderers. It takes a special strain of Homo sapiens to do this work in secret and stay sane. A spy must know how "to use deception, to use manipulation, to use, frankly, dishonesty in the pursuit of his job," says Jeffrey Smith, the C.I.A.'s general counsel in 1995 and 1996. "The management of the agency must always worry about finding that extraordinarily rare individual who has the talent to deal in this deceptive and manipulative world and keep his or her own moral ballast."
 Finding, hiring and keeping such exceptional minds is looking increasingly difficult. "How do you recruit people like this?" asks Bob Gates, Director of Central Intelligence in 1991 and 1992. The C.I.A. has become highly bureaucratic, he says , less and less willing to admit creative oddballs -- "people that are a little different, people who are eccentric, people who don't look good in a suit and tie, people who don't play well in the sandbox with others," he says. "The kinds of tests that we make people pass, psychological and everything else, make it very hard for somebody who may be brilliant or have extraordinary talents and unique capabilities to get into the agency."
 The agency used to recruit new people through an underground network at the best universities and officers' clubs. The talent-spotting system it had among student bodies was unique. It existed on every major college campus in the country -- not just Yale (where the crew coach recruited) and Princeton (where at least one dean did the tapping), but at the University of Texas and Holy Cross too. And mandatory military service gave the agency the ability to sign up thousands of officers who had spent time abroad in Europe or Asia. When the draft ended 26 years ago, Calder says, the C.I.A. lost access to "a lot of people who had experience in the military, who had actually lived overseas and understood what that was about and perhaps developed a curiosity and an interest in certain cultures."
 And in those years, before the national nervous breakdown over Vietnam and Watergate, the agency had an aura of mystery and power that it may never regain. Its officers "were told time and time again that they were an elite organization and it was a badge of honor to be recruited and selected to work in C.I.A.," says McMahon. They were members of a secret society that outclassed Skull and Bones.
But most of the people milling around at the Ohio State job fair were born after the collapse of Saigon in 1975. The cold war ended when they were still kids. What's more, says Milt Bearden, a retired C.I.A. veteran: "Their appreciation of American history is probably from Oliver Stone movies, or a very cursory reading of history, as Americans haven't been forced by world events to do much with history. And so how do they recruit today?" Lacking the core mission and the esprit de corps that the cold war gave it, the C.I.A. has to go to colleges and corporations and try to get people interested in selfless, anonymous Government work, in an age of selfishness and self-involvement, when all the threats facing the United States put together don't add up to a single Soviet missile.
 The agency's hunger for talent was slaked a little at Ohio State, though the students' interest in intelligence seemed driven less by intense patriotism than by their perception that Government work would be a safe harbor, a sinecure protected from the brutal efficiencies of the marketplace. By December, the agency had received resumes from 123 Ohio State students, interviewed 30 and conditionally offered jobs to 18. Five or six of those students will wind up working for the agency after passing the lie-detector tests and the other physical and psychological screenings that are part of life at the C.I.A., the recruiters say.
 Although the agency said it was pleased with its haul, no one from Ohio State seemed to have the wherewithal to fill more exotic posts going begging -- jobs for an applied research psychologist with a Ph.D. (the agency needs one for in-house headshrinking) and for biologists and chemists interested in unconventional weaponry. Nor did any of the students seem to have the special talents needed for covert operations, the only job at the C.I.A. that involves a year of specialized in-house training.
 The C.I.A.'s talent-hunters hit 50 more campuses this fall. Their campaign generated close to 100 job applications a day. In addition, the agency is focusing attention on the children of ethnic Americans. This is another way in which the old C.I.A. used to find the people it needed, and which it is trying to recreate. "The people we were hiring in the beginning were much more diverse," says Gates. "We had a lot of ethnic Americans. We had a lot of people from Eastern Europe, from Russia, from Ukraine, from Germany, people who had a remarkable mastery of languages because they had lived abroad for most of their lives."
 For decades, though, the agency has been too American, too white, too culturally narrow, Gates says, unable to dispatch "an Asian- American into North Korea without him being identified as some kid who just walked out of Kansas, or African-Americans to work around the world, or Arab-Americans." In 1992, when Gates was Director, he wanted to hire a candidate who was an American citizen raised in Azerbaijan. "He spoke Azeri fluently, but he didn't write English very well," Gates recalled. "And so he was rejected because he didn't pass our English test. And when I was told this, I just went crazy. I said: 'I've got thousands of people here who can write English, but I don't have anybody here who can speak Azeri. What have you done?' "
 The agency is painfully aware of its former Director's diagnosis and is trying to cure the disease of conformity. The C.I.A., which analyzes both open and secret information from around the world, isn't fluent in the languages that half the world speaks: "Chinese, Korean, Arabic, Farsi -- you know, the languages nobody learns because of the low grade-point averages," Carey says. Too few languages means too little cultural acuity. This leads to mirror-imaging -- projecting American thinking onto foreign cultures, and thus misreading them. Far too few C.I.A. analysts have ever seen the countries they analyze. There are too many political scientists steeped in theory, and too few who have haggled in an Arab bazaar or walked through an African village.
 Now the agency is combing the cities and the suburbs of America looking for the children of immigrants and refugees, particularly young men and women who grew up in first-generation Asian and Arab households, and reaching out to these potential recruits through ads in ethnic newspapers throughout the United States. The languages these people speak -- and their physical appearance -- could come in handy when the C.I.A. tries to penetrate nations like Iraq or North Korea once more with home-grown American spies.
 The agency will live or die in years to come by its ability to project an image of international intrigue and intellectual adventure to smart young people, without repelling them with rigid internal security systems or repeating overseas conduct that goes against the American grain. Simply mounting a recruitment drive "doesn't answer the question: Can we recruit the person we need?" says McMahon, who spent 35 years in the C.I.A. "We can't really address that until the agency understands what it's going to be in 5 or 10 years, and I guarantee you it will not and cannot be what it is today."
The story of Maureen Lenihan suggests that the C.I.A. needs to work on that understanding. Twenty-five, whip-smart and patriotic, Lenihan had been thinking about nuclear weapons since she was a child growing up in Las Vegas. When the earth moved for her, it was the underground tests out in the desert.
 "It all goes back to the test site," Lenihan says. "It made you think about annihilation and international security and what you could do about it." She became a National Merit Scholar, took an undergraduate degree in international relations, entered a Presidential job program, earned a master's degree at the Georgetown School of Foreign Service -- a longtime C.I.A. farm team -- with a 3.7 average. She was very interested in chemical weapons. And she wanted to work for the C.I.A.
 The agency, in turn, was very interested in her. She already had top-secret clearances for a two-year stint on a national commission studying issues of Government secrecy and security, where she focused on the use of the polygraph. Lenihan's C.I.A. interviewers "told me that I had the right capabilities and the right background," she says. But it took the agency forever to offer her a job -- and the offer came with a poison bouquet.
The recruiters have talked to enough students to know that the lie-detector turns people off. Most courts regard it as legally and scientifically worthless. And yet the C.I.A.'s Office of Security has always used it to weed out potential traitors. "Their reliance on the polygraph is truly insane," in the opinion of John Deutch, the former Director of Central Intelligence. The agency knows that many recruits cannot stomach the idea that they have to pass lie-detector tests and undergo a rigid inquiry into their personal histories -- an investigation of every aspect of the past seven years of their lives -- to get in the front door at the C.I.A.
 Lenihan submitted to the lie-detector test. The C.I.A.'s polygraphers told her that she had "problems": her intimate understanding of their machine and its pitfalls, they said, had tainted her performance. She knew too much about the polygraph to pass one. Months went by, a year, a year and a half. She took a job with a Presidential commission on the spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons, a commission administered by the C.I.A. But first, she was told, she had to go over to the agency for a standard security briefing.
 "I walked in the door thinking I had put this behind me," she says. "I was feeling -- yeah, I gave up some dignity and self-respect, but in the end they cleared me. They ask you to give up your freedom of speech; you sign papers saying you will not talk about your work for the rest of your life. It's a very serious commitment. And you do it willingly. I went in there with open eyes, and they attacked me."
 The C.I.A. confronted her. "They had my folder out," she says. "They were reading my file to me. They twisted it, saying I had used countermeasures" -- the tricks of a spy -- "to try to fool the polygraph. They told me to sign a paper saying I would not commit any more indiscretions or any further misconduct or I would be subject to termination. I refused to sign anything that incriminated me. It enraged me. It enrages me still."
 Nevertheless, in July, the C.I.A. offered her a position. She turned them down flat.
 "The work could have been exciting," she says. "The work could have made a positive contribution to national security. But what they put me through, I could never work for them. I'm 25 years old. I can choose my career path. Do I want to work for an agency that doesn't trust me?" Lenihan has since taken a position at the Justice Department. (Mindful of her security clearances, she checked with the C.I.A. to make sure she was allowed to be interviewed.)
 The Director of Central Intelligence was apopletic when he heard what happened to Lenihan, and his staff says it was an aberration that won't be repeated. "I won't tolerate putting talented people on a string," Tenet says. "The single most important legacy I can leave this institution is people that insure its excellence 20, 30, 40 years from now. I believe that right down to my bones."
 But Maureen Lenihan, one of the best and the brightest, won't be among them. "The fundamental problem of C.I.A. is they can never explain the things they do," she says. "So you have to take at face value what they say they do. And that's hard."

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
A More Perfect Future

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
The clues to the biggest news of the next millennium still lie scattered in the last years of the last one, like gems and beads waiting to be strung into a precious new object. You have to gather nuggets from many sources to get a glimpse of the planet's political future. Here's a revealing sampling of clippings I have recently accumulated:
 Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations: "People who want to control and dictators who want to suppress the spread of information are going to have nightmares. . . . In quite a few areas we have had revolutions that have been caused by fax, and network, and Internet." 
 The Economist: "Every day, $1.5 trillion moves around the world's foreign-exchange markets. Companies merge across national borders and even talk of changing nationality completely. . . . When politicians in Paris or Jakarta thunder about Anglo-Saxons, they are referring not to gunboats but to George Soros, Rupert Murdoch and the Visigoths of the Internet."
 A Times dispatch from Moscow: "Even the Communist Party has a Web site. . . . While Russia sometimes seems to revert to its old peculiar ways . . . it can no longer afford to shun the club of civilized nations, hemmed in as it is by MTV on one side and the I.M.F. on the other."
 And one from Rome: "Leaving the United States behind, more than 100 countries achieved a 50-year goal today by agreeing on the fundamentals for an international court to prosecute war criminals and tyrants."
 George F. Will: "The Spanish judge who yesterday made progress in persuading Britain to extradite Gen. Augusto Pinochet, former dictator of Chile, for trial concerning human rights violations is practicing what is called justice without borders.' . . . If what is called international law -- it is international, but is it law? -- ignores fences, will nations be more neighborly?"
 A Times dispatch from Aachen, Germany: "It has become usual for people who work in this western German city to live in Belgium and play a weekly tennis match in the Netherlands."
 From an investigation by Douglas Frantz in The Times: "Royal Caribbean, a Liberian corporation with its headquarters in Miami, made what the Justice Department described as an unprecedented claim: that a private company doing business in the United States was immune from criminal prosecution because its oil-dumping ships fly foreign flags."
 And from a summary by David F. Sanger in The Times: "President Clinton told Europe that unless it complies with a World Trade Organization ruling to open its banana market, he will slap 100 percent tariffs on $500 million in European goods, perhaps as soon as February."
 The Economist: "The 11 euro members' rights to inflate, to finance budget deficits by printing money and to boost exports temporarily by currency devaluation are being handed over to the new European Central Bank. . . . This amounts to policy disarmament."
 C. Fred Bergsten in The Washington Post: "Germany's decision to terminate its beloved mark and France's willingness to eliminate its historic franc represent the most dramatic voluntary surrender of sovereignty in recorded history."
Yes, sovereignties and frontiers are evaporating before our eyes. Their disappearance leads to new cohesions, as in Western Europe, or new disintegrations, farther East. The decline of the nation-state leaves global corporations and intercontinental banks bestriding the planet. And supranational institutions are taking root, managing currencies, policing commerce, yearning to punish "crimes against humanity."
 But where shall we station reporters to cover the evolving regime? Where are its legislators and tax collectors, its cops and jails? As borders dissolve, who will manage the flow of migrants and write rules for the virtual road? Who will monitor the claims of alien corporations, guarantee foreign loans, crack down on polluters of the seas and atmosphere? Who will define crimes against humanity, elect the definers and count the votes for electors?
 Common currencies are worthless without common rules and policies. But there cannot long be rules and laws without legislators, or legislators without elections. World-class crimes are meaningless without worldwide rights for individuals. And the rights of individuals are safe only if protected by a government to which they consent. "When a man hangs from a tree," wrote E.B. White, "it doesn't spell justice unless he helped write the law that hanged him."
 The earliest Americans experienced a similar disjunction at the end of the 18th century. As Carl Van Doren described their predicament:
 "The Articles of Confederation under which they lived was not so much a government as a league of states, in which the individual states retained a large part of their sovereignty. Congress was not a general legislature, but a diplomatic assembly, in which the states had equal votes. There was no general executive, no general judiciary. Congress could raise money only by asking the states to contribute their quotas for Confederation expenses. The Confederation government did not operate directly on the people of the United States, but only through the states themselves. . . .
 "There were no American coins of any kind. Where hard money was used, it had to be a confusion of English sovereigns, French louis d'or, Spanish pistoles or dollars, Portuguese moidores or johanneses, ducats or caroluses from different countries. . . . Delegates coming to Philadelphia from other sections had to adjust their money to Pennsylvania pounds and shillings."
 Those delegates came together not as representatives of states but as "we the people" in probably the most portentous event of modern history. They formed "a more perfect Union" by ceding to a Federal regime the powers required to establish justice, insure domestic tranquillity, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare and secure the blessings of liberty. Call it one millennium's inspiration for the superstructure the world must surely design in the next.

LENGTH: 1391 words

HEADLINE: ART / ARCHITECTURE;
Everyday Art in India

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
THIRTY years ago, the Philadelphia Museum of Art presented a ground-breaking exhibition titled "Unknown India: Ritual Art in Tribe and Village." The show was aptly named.
Organized by the art historian Stella Kramrisch (1896-1993), it brought together work from outside India's ancient classical traditions. Instead of grand temple sculptures, one found pocket-size metal images cast in a threadlike filigree technique and intended for home altars. Rather than court paintings, there were embroidered textiles stitched by women from recycled saris with scenes of local weddings, and storytelling scrolls illustrating Hindu epics in a style as vivid and fantastic as anything produced by Bombay film studios today. 
 This was, in short, art for everyday life, of a kind still produced in rural India. But with its relatively modern dates (mostly 19th and 20th century), and its "folk art" look, it was a kind of material seldom on display in mainstream museums and little known to Western audiences.
Much has changed since the 1960's. Qualitative distinctions between fine art and folk art have been rethought. Vernacular art is taking its rightful place in elite collections. Maybe that's why the small exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum, "Threads of Cotton, Threads of Brass: Arts of Eastern India and Bangladesh from the Stella Kramrisch Collection" (through May 30), carries a thrill of delight rather than a shock of surprise.
The show is, in a sense, a reprise of "Unknown India" three decades later and in miniature. But the real "unknown" here may be Stella Kramrisch herself, a former curator at the museum, and one of the century's outstanding art historians. When she died, obituaries in the national press were few. Although she had been a pioneering figure in her field, the field itself -- the art of South Asia -- is one that only a handful of people in the West know or care much about.
Kramrisch knew it intimately and cared about it passionately. This comes across in her writing. Her two best-known books, "The Hindu Temple" (1946) and "The Presence of Shiva" (1981), are total immersion experiences, almost trance inducing with their insistent verbal cadences and their dense web of references to myth, literature and visual symbolism.
But her investment in Indian culture is perhaps most evident in the life she lived, a brief account of which was written by the Sanskrit scholar Barbara Stoler Miller in 1983 as an introduction to a book of Kramrisch's essays, "Exploring India's Sacred Art" (out of print in the United States, but available in an Indian edition).
Kramrisch was born in what is now the Czech Republic, the only child of two bookish, upper-middle-class parents, who moved to Vienna before she began grade school. The city was rich in cultural ferment. Gustav Klimt and Egon Schiele were the contemporary artists Kramrisch grew up with; she saw Nijinsky dance with the Ballets Russes. (She studied dance herself and performed publicly while still in her teens.)
She was fascinated by the work of Northern European mystical writers like Meister Eckhart and Jakob Boehme, and Asian philosophy was in the air in the years around World War I. She encountered it in Kandinsky's writing on art and in the Theosophy of Rudolf Steiner (whom she knew). Her early discovery of the Bhagavad-Gita in German translation confirmed her specific interest in Indian culture.
But it was only after she finished a dissertation on early Buddhist sculpture at the University of Vienna in 1919 that she visited India for the first time. On a trip to England she met the poet Rabindranath Tagore, who invited her to a school he had established in Bengal. She went straight from London to Bombay, stopping in Vienna only long enough to meet with her parents in the train station.
Within a few years she was teaching art at the University of Calcutta, the only woman and the only European on the faculty. She remained something of an outsider to both Indian and colonial social circles, neither of whom knew quite what to make of her. But she seems not to have cared. She lived alone in a house in the grounds of the university's botanical garden, accompanied by a pet hyena and steeped in her work.
That work resulted in extensive travel across the subcontinent to visit and document Buddhist sites and Hindu temples, some of them renowned, many crumbling and forgotten. In the countryside she studied the dynamic world of Bengali village life and culture, and many of the objects in "Threads of Cotton, Threads of Brass" are among those she collected in the field in the 1920's.
She also experienced Indian religion firsthand when she became a devotee of Shiva and the disciple of a Tantric monk. In Miller's account, he subjected her to a harrowing initiation at Kalighat temple in Calcutta, having her sit on a corpse ready for cremation, and pulling her off only when the fire had been lit. Kramrisch did not, one suspects, undergo the ordeal in a spirit of scientific disinterest, and the emotional commitment and risk it entailed subtly warms her scholarship.
In 1929, she married an India-based Hungarian economist, Laszlo Nemenyi, though they spent most of their 21-year marriage apart, absorbed in separate careers. He was named economic adviser to the new government in Pakistan in 1947. Nationalist sentiment ran high at the time and Kramrisch's position in Calcutta grew uncomfortable. She had planned to spend her life in India, but when Nemenyi was shot and killed in Karachi in 1950, she left for America. Within a few years she began working at the Philadelphia Museum and teaching at the University of Pennsylvania and New York University's Institute of Fine Art.
Academic fashions come and go, and research is, to some degree, based on a principle of planned obsolescence. The work of any one scholar is, after all, meant to be refined or challenged or simply superseded by that of another. And in an era when sociologically derived Western theory has been a primary interpretive lens through which non-Western art is viewed, Kramrisch's metaphysical approach to Indian art and architecture, always criticized by some historians, has fallen somewhat out of favor.
But the tides are always shifting; the present climate seems increasingly to encourage the synthesis of a wide range of disciplines and approaches, old and new, orthodox and otherwise. In any case, the catalogue Kramrisch wrote for "Unknown India" remains one of her monuments. So does the extraordinary collection of Indian art she brought to the Philadelphia Museum, now overseen by her curatorial successor, the gifted young American art historian Darielle Mason.
Some pieces arrived with Kramrisch in 1950 and were sold to the museum a few years later. Such was the case with a fabulous sandstone sculpture of the multiarmed goddess Durga, bursting with aggressive energy from her carved niche. Other works, including most of the pieces in "Threads of Cotton, Threads of Brass" she willed to the museum.
The Durga is on permanent display; most of the village and tribal objects, many not exhibited since "Unknown India" 30 years ago, will return to storage at the end of the show. It's great to see them together now. As one moves back and forth from classical stone icons of Buddhas and Hindu deities to the tiny images of brass horses and quilts sewn with scenes of village life, the marriage of elite and popular traditions that is the essence of Indian art becomes clear.
And popular traditions are, after a long period of apparent decline, on the upswing, as was evident in a show of contemporary embroidered quilts organized by Molly Aitken at the Asia Society last summer. These quilts were executed with exactly the same technique as the 19th-century pieces in Philadelphia, but their narratives now dealt with pressing, up-to-the-minute social issues like spousal abuse, female infanticide and AIDS.
Kramrisch would doubtless have found the results fascinating and heartening, both as evidence of continuity with the past and spiritual tenacity in the present. This is the kind of response that profound cultural empathy can produce. Kramrisch had such empathy and it is a hidden thread that binds together a museum collection that she shaped equally with her scholarship and her spirit.
