SECTION: Section 2; Page 35; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2222 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Amid Serene Natural Beauty, A Residue of Brutal Trauma

BYLINE: By MURRAY WHYTE; Murray Whyte, who lived in Vancouver until recently, writes on the arts for The National Post in Toronto.

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia

 BODY:
ON the fringe of Vancouver's junkie-ridden, impoverished inner city, Stan Douglas makes art that speaks of failure.
It's a subject that has brought the 38-year old artist considerable success. "Nut*ka," a deep exploration of the onset of post-colonial era -- and its destructive force -- near his Vancouver home got Mr. Douglas short listed for the Guggenheim Museum's Hugo Boss Prize in 1996. The work, a meditative, multilayered video, explores a savage tale extracted from the faded history of colonialism here on the Canadian West Coast and the connection of its intrusive violence to the present. Mr. Douglas's newest film work, "Win, Place or Show," will be on view at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea starting Feb. 11 alongside a work by the Glaswegian artist Douglas Gordon in a show called "Double Vision." Like "Nut*ka," the piece delves deep into the heart of a local debacle, as Mr. Douglas examines a brutish public-housing project planned for his Vancouver neighborhood in the 1950's but never built. 
 Mr. Douglas is not alone in his fascination with Vancouver's particular manifestations of modern trauma. Jeff Wall, Rodney Graham, Roy Arden and Ken Lum have all turned a critical, realist eye to the havoc wreaked by the march of developmental progress, each using his hometown and its environs to comment on themes and phenomena that stretch far beyond the limited boundaries of the Canadian West Coast.
The resulting work has earned for each recognition that stretches beyond Vancouver as well: Mr. Wall and Mr. Douglas were the first Canadians invited to show at the Whitney Biennial, in 1995. Mr. Wall, a conceptual photographic artist who has enjoyed an international reputation for almost two decades, had a major retrospective exhibition in 1997 that traveled from the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles to the Hirshhorn in Washington, to the Art Tower Mito near Tokyo, in addition to shows at the Marian Goodman Gallery in New York.
Mr. Graham, 49, whose work includes elaborate installations, film, photography, sculpture, text pieces and hypothetical architecture, recently gained widespread recognition for "Vexation Island," a film piece that was a hit at the 1997 Venice Biennale. The somber, rich photographs of the rough spaces in which the developed and undeveloped chafe have won Mr. Arden, 41, places in prestigious collections like those of the Musee d'Art Contemporain in Geneva and the Staatsgalerie in Stuttgart. Mr. Lum, 42, represented in New York by the Andrea Rosen Gallery, has also built an international career with works like a recent series of diptychs in which photographs and words play off one another to betray the anxiety of contemporary life. In one of the diptychs, the text, which reads, in heroic comic-book font, "Mounties and Indians" (1989), is balanced against a photograph of red-coated Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers who pose, smiling, with a group of native Canadians. The result is an awkward image that evokes the memory of the area's colonial past even as the victors stand arm-in-arm with the vanquished.
Mr. Douglas's "Win, Place or Show," like other recent works, has a decidedly local flavor, as its subject was found quite literally in his backyard: the housing project slated for his district would have seen his own house razed had it been built. For Mr. Douglas, the sparing of his neighborhood was part of his inspiration. "In some ways," says Mr. Douglas, a tall, soft-spoken African-Canadian, "this is the only part of this city that seems real."
The question of what is real and what is not is constant and pervasive in this seaside city of 1.8 million people. Its oceanside core, distinct and opposite from Mr. Douglas's inner-city home but less than two miles away, gleams with an almost surreal sheen of newness. Sparkling condominium towers, in turn dwarfed by the spectacular coastal mountains that surround them, compete for precious views of ocean and mountains, beaches and old-growth forest, which collude in a picture-postcard image too perfect to be trusted.
It is just this sort of imagery these artists hold in contempt: as Mr. Wall, now 52, wrote in the catalogue for "Cameres Indiscretes," ("Candid Cameras") a 1992 exhibition in Barcelona, Spain, featuring Mr. Lum, Mr. Graham, Ian Wallace and Mr. Wall himself, the contemporary conceptual art for which the city has become known evolved from "a rejection of a mythic self-image of Vancouver" -- a mythology that romanticizes landscape, native culture and the place of the Europeans who claimed it. It is in the work of these artists that the broader darkness behind the apparent regional success is exposed. Where there is economic development and construction, there is the conspicuous consumption of land and nature; where there is cosmopolitan diversity, there is racial tension; where there is urbanity, there is displacement, poverty and class division.
In Mr. Wall's spectacular, inert "history-painting" photographs, which he meticulously stages using actors, the artist has often zeroed in on the dark, personal brutality spawned by the onset of contemporary society. Cosmopolitan diversity begets racist conflict, as in "Mimic" (1982), a street scene in which an unshaven, greasy Caucasian man lifts his middle finger behind the back of an Asian man. In "The Outburst" (1989), the noble, industrial-age notion of honest work for fair pay dissolves as a garment-factory manager goes ballistic on one of his sweat-shop employees.
A more homely assault of suburban development on nature is evident in Mr. Arden's recent photographs, seen in 1996 at American Fine Arts in SoHo. In these he makes critical pictorial comment on the vulgar convention of developer-driven construction projects as they impose themselves in both the urban and rural landscape. In "Model House and Honda Warehouse" (1993), the hilarity of unreasoned development is captured as a suburban home of ridiculously grand scale squats in a barren field, the only other nearby structure a Honda storage building, while British Columbia's signature coastal mountains loom in the distance.
For Mr. Graham, human estrangement from nature persists, as if every attempt made to reconcile our differences ends in some sort of defeat, either cataclysmic or trivial. Thus, his "75 Polaroids" (1976-1988), taken in a forest at night without a flash, are consequently black.
The transformative force of contemporary progress is hardly a concern unique to Vancouver; modern reality has imposed itself with equal disregard all over the continent. Vancouver has become for some artists a stand-in for this phenomenon -- as Mr. Wall has often said, a generic example whose particulars are irrelevant to the greater issue.
In Mr. Graham's film, "Vexation Island," set in the South Pacific, where an 18th-century Englishman marooned on a desert island is doomed to repeat his actions over and over in an endless loop -- a Freudian reference to neurosis, where compulsive repetition takes the place of actual memory -- there appears to be no connection to his home at all.
"It doesn't have much to do with Vancouver," says Mr. Graham, a manic, bespectacled man with close-cropped, salt-and-pepper hair. "Oh, wait: yes, it does," he interrupts himself, peering through thick black-framed glasses with eyes that betray a pending joke. "I wanted to set that piece about as absolutely, geographically far away from Vancouver as possible. I liked the idea of being opposite from Vancouver on the globe."
Mr. Graham takes some sardonic glee from running down his hometown, but he has, in earlier works, explored issues essential to it. In "Millennial Project for an Urban Plaza (With Cappuccino Bar)" (1986), he plotted a design for a fanciful building meant to house only a gigantic pinhole camera, the sole purpose of which is to wait for a lone seedling tree, planted in front of the structure, to grow tall enough to be captured in the camera's sight.
It's an earnest reversal, according to Mr. Graham, committing a building to waiting for a tree, where so often in the march of progress forests have yielded to the building of cities. But it also leaves the tree subject to the whim of technology and comically stranded out of its element -- another miscarried attempt to reconcile urban society's estrangement from the natural.
This theme also comes clear in the work of Mr. Wall, who has rejected the idea that Vancouver in particular plays any role in his work. In fact, Mr. Wall, who declined to be interviewed for this article, has recently begun to make pictures in Los Angeles, where the transformative forces of progress have caused at least equal havoc.
But he has, at times, stepped back from his elaborately controlled depictions of personal interaction and trauma to capture images of broader scale. It is here that his work can be seen as influenced by the unstoppable advance of progress on Vancouver and its environs, says Kerry Brougher, who, as a curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, designed Mr. Wall's traveling retrospective in 1997.
Mr. Brougher recalls his first trip to Mr. Wall's hometown when he met the artist to prepare for the show. "It seemed like everywhere I turned, I saw Jeff Wall," Mr. Brougher says in a phone interview from Oxford, England, where he is now director of the Museum of Contemporary Art. "The essential bareness of the place, the light, the constant gloom, all seemed to speak of the particular imagery you see in his work."
Mr. Wall's pictures that speak of the interval between the natural and developmental encroachment are among his most potent, says Mr. Brougher. "Coastal Motifs" (1989) is one of these: the omnipresent mountains, ominous and looming, cloaked in mist, are given visual weight equal to the eerily deserted industrial bay in the foreground.
LIKE Mr. Wall, Mr. Douglas has often dealt with the social and physical damage wrought by development and progress. In "Nut*ka," shot on Vancouver Island's Nootka Sound, where Europeans first made contact with West Coast native people, a smoke-belching pulp mill on the Sound, is captured in photographs that accompany the film.
In "Pursuit, Fear, Catastrophe" (1992), Mr. Douglas builds on the notion of the social inequity spawned by the industrial age as he examines Ruskin, British Columbia -- named for the English critic and social reformer John Ruskin -- where a series of settlements eventually gave way to a now-abandoned power plant. Mr. Douglas's film tracks an unsolved murder from the 1930's in Ruskin, when Japanese-Canadians, ostracized in Vancouver, went to Ruskin to form a berry-farming community. Their idyll collapsed when they were forced into internment camps by the Canadian Government at the start of World War II.
Unlike Mr. Wall, Mr. Douglas wants you to know where his work comes from. Rather than becoming detached from the local phenomenon, he embraces it. In the opinion of Lynne Cooke, the curator of the Dia Center, there is never even slight concern that his work will recede into the regionalist realm. "It's the local and the global," she says. "Stan's work comes out of rooted experience and specific histories of a place, but the issues themselves are current and have much wider applicability. I think it's partly that that makes him such an important figure, and one that people look to."
"Win, Place, or Show," is a slight departure for Mr. Douglas, in that it dreams rather than documents, invents rather than explores. Its dream is a modernist reverie, in which the housing project proposed for Mr. Douglas's neighborhood was actually built.
"It took me a while to realize it, but this is modernist architecture," Mr. Douglas says, surveying the 1950's building plans with a degree of incredulity. North American housing projects that were actually built -- like the now-abandoned Robert Taylor Homes in Chicago, which became synonymous with urban blight -- were a far cry from modernist architecture's ideals of democracy and efficiency. "The Robert Taylor Homes are the nearest thing to a realized radiant city of Le Corbusier, even though it's in the most brutal terms," says Mr. Douglas, thumbing through a binder thick with reports describing the project that never was. "But in reality, that utopic idea became like a sort of warehousing for the poor."
In Mr. Douglas's film, two dock workers occupy one of the apartments of his hypothetical public-housing project. Instead of an oppressive cell, though, the apartment becomes part of Le Corbusier's modernist ideal realized: a living space as refined as it is simple, removed from the housing-project reality that shunted the working poor into the living-space equivalent of a storage bin. On the movie set of the fantasy apartment, elegant Danish furniture and contemporary art grace the room, where the workers' daily life -- their jokes, arguments and fights -- plays out in an endless loop.
It's a transitional piece, Mr. Douglas says, his final glimpse at a final disappointment here -- a "sci-fi" exploration of a hypothetical modernist success that never was. "I'm sort of off that kick now," he says. "Instead of sort of mulling over failure, I've become interested in what comes next. You know, what to do with all those ruins."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
In a New Fosse Vehicle, A Headlong Joy Ride

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
EVEN as their budgets and, occasionally, their aspirations have ballooned, Broadway musicals give the impression of having grown smaller in recent years, at least in part because of the near-disappearance of dance from the American musical theater. Dance is still there, but it's either nondescript, as in "Footloose," or solemnly obligatory, almost instructive, as in "Ragtime." The sense of excitement and discovery has disappeared. If you have any doubt about what has been lost or, better yet, if you just want to have a terrifically entertaining night of Broadway theater, then you can't afford to pass up "Fosse," now at the Broadhurst.
Here is a very particular, epic-size musical revue. In its consideration of the career of Bob Fosse as dancer, choreographer and director on Broadway, in Hollywood and on television from the late 1940's into the 1980's, it celebrates the art, high spirits and dazzling inventiveness of a theater now known only through revivals. 
Be warned, however. "Fosse" is an anthology composed mostly of climaxes for which there are no build-ups. Some numbers are presented in their entirety, while others are spliced into medleys and not always easy to identify. Yet the elegant-looking production is given cohesion by the dynamic character and the restless mind of Fosse himself. There is also the pure exhilaration that comes only rarely these days, when watching a cast of 32 talented performers dancing and singing with an energy that, from time to time, threatens to raise the roof.
As "Fosse" looks back over approximately 40 years of dance in theater and movies, it inevitably prompts the question: What happened?
It may be Jerome Robbins who forever confounded our expectations for dance in the Broadway musical. His contributions still astonish: think of his role in transforming "Fancy Free," the Robbins-Leonard Bernstein ballet, into "On the Town" (1944), of his priceless Keystone Kops ballet for "High Button Shoes" (1947), of "The Small House of Uncle Thomas" ballet for "The King and I" (1951) and of those balletic gang rumbles in "West Side Story" (1957). He led us to believe that it would be the classically trained choreographer, skilled also in modern dance, who would bring new life and meaning to the American musical theater.
Robbins was as much at home in a Broadway house as in Ballet Theater. He brought a breadth of vision to musical shows that was unique and, by comparison, called attention to what some people saw as the limitations of such Broadway-bred choreographers as Fosse, Michael Bennett and Gower Champion.
An unfair comparison, really. Robbins was not just a great choreographer. He was a genius. He was one of a kind, without compare. He wasn't someone next to whom anyone else can be measured without the help of a large footstool.
Choreographers of the stature of Fosse, Bennett and Champion were masters of their own class of entertainment. No wonder they became directors: Broadway was then a dancing place.
If you have seen the work of the choreographers from ballet and modern dance who have recently been corralled by the musical theater, you might have noticed that there haven't been any Jerome Robbinses among them. You might also have realized that these recruits can be even more limited in their vision than the earlier generation of hoofers who went on to become superlative Broadway choreographers. (The one possible exception: Garth Fagan, the modern dancer and choreographer whose work is integral to the success of Julie Taymor's vision of "The Lion King.")
The problem facing contemporary Broadway choreographers is not only training but also experience. As the number of musical shows produced each year has dwindled, and as dance has come to look like an afterthought in the operettas that have dominated the scene, the choreographic gene pool has all but dried up.
No more that opportunity for Broadway gypsies to move from one show to several others within a single season, to survive flops, hits and road tours, to be hired and fired and to know that there is another show casting around the corner, if not this week, then next. No time to acquire the itch, not simply to dance well but to create one's own idiosyncratic dance vocabulary.
If you saw Fosse's film "All That Jazz" (1979), a gorgeous but self-absorbed Fellini-esque examination of the life of a director very much like himself, you already know that he was a man given to excess. The air he breathed was filtered through his cigarettes. He drank too much, ate amphetamines for breakfast, loved his wife and mistress and was faithful to neither. The film's most flamboyant conceit: Fosse's foreseeing his own death, which was to come in 1987 when he was 60.
Except for his fine screen version of "Cabaret"
(1972) and "Lenny," his comparatively disciplined biographical film about Lenny Bruce, all of Fosse's movies reflect the tendency toward excess that marked his life, though not his shows. He went a little mad in the movie studio, like the kid who decides he is able to fly with a parasol.
Note "Sweet Charity" (1969), the first film he directed. Among other things, the manic cross-cutting from one image to the next and the use of gigantic real-life locations, from Lincoln Center to Wall Street and the Brooklyn Bridge, all but swamp the adaptation of his hit Broadway show of 1966. He effectively upstages not only Shirley MacLaine, the star, the book by Neil Simon and the Cy Coleman-Dorothy Fields score, but also his own distinctive choreography.
There is something infectiously cheeky and bold about Fosse's movies as well as his shows. Yet his singular strength is his choreography, which, when seen in the theater at its best, cuts to the quick. It can make us laugh, and sometimes, without warning, as in the final moments of "Chicago," it can become unaccountably moving. These are the gifts of the man whose work is now being recalled on the stage of the Broadhurst.
As a choreographer, Fosse is a satirist. He is cool, spare of detail. At his best, he is also a brilliant caricaturist, someone who uses a minimal number of precisely drawn lines to express the essence of a single character, of several characters, of a whole raft of characters, in a specific time, place and circumstance.
I remember (I hope accurately) the initial image in the Broadway production of "Sweet Charity": Gwen Verdon, seen alone in silhouette against an orange-lighted cyclorama, her weight on one leg, her hip thrust to the other side, one arm akimbo -- a Broadway taxi dancer waiting for a customer and waiting, maybe forever, for life.
"Sweet Charity" provides "Fosse" with two of the show's most elegant sequences: the marvelously comic "Rich Man's Frug," in which Manhattan nobs, as ferret-faced as Maurice Sendak characters, sweep around a nightclub as if untroubled even by gravity (as choreographed by Fosse, the dancers appear to float), and "Big Spender," wherein Charity's taxi-dancer pals stand at the bar and face the audience, alternately wheedling and intimidating their would-be customers.
Some of the other memorable numbers recalled: "Steam Heat" from "The Pajama Game" (1954), "Mr. Bojangles" from "Dancin' " (1978), "Take Off With Us -- Three Pas de Deux" from "All That Jazz," in which three nearly nude couples, one heterosexual, one homosexual and one lesbian, make love, going as far as a standard modern balletic vocabulary allows, and the foot-stomping grand finale, "Sing, Sing, Sing," also from "Dancin'."
My favorite: a sly, spirited take on the old standard "Me and My Shadow" from Fosse's last show, "Big Deal" (1986), in which Eugene Fleming, Kim Morgan Greene and Dana Moore add a sexual dimension to the song so languidly and sentimentally sung by Ted Lewis from the 1920's into the 1950's.
Somewhat less effective, in part because they can be seen in context next door at the Shubert Theater where "Chicago" is playing: Fred Ebb and John Kander's "Razzle Dazzle" and "Nowadays." "Shoeless Joe From Hannibal, Mo.," from "Damn Yankees" (1955), also isn't helped by the fact that the number was better done in the 1995 Broadway revival, choreographed by Rob Marshall.
Richard Maltby Jr. is the director responsible for coordinating the many talents involved, including Gwen Verdon, Fosse's widow, the show's artistic adviser, and Ann Reinking, Mr. Fosse's companion, who is the co-director and (with Fosse) co-choreographer. Note that the spiffy production was initiated and is being presented by Livent Inc., the bankrupt Canadian company (which is also presenting "Ragtime"), founded by the besieged, deposed entrepreneur Garth Drabinsky.
Note also two other expert performers who help to make this enterprise work: Valarie Pettiford, who is both an accomplished Fosse dancer and a singer to shake the rafters, and that superb dancer Scott Wise, who also sings the elegant though abbreviated "Razzle Dazzle."
Seeing so much of Fosse's extraordinary work, in such a condensed form, also provides clues as to the identity of those who may have influenced him. Fosse himself acknowledged his debt to Jack Cole, the Broadway and Hollywood choreographer sometimes credited for having created "jazz dancing." "Fosse" also brings to mind Charlie Chaplin, an association I had never noticed before. If Charlie Chaplin had been a choreographer, he might have created dances like Fosse's.
The resemblance is remarked on not because of Fosse's fondness for derby hats and gloves. Rather, it's because the singular fashion in which Fosse uses the dancer's body, at rest and in motion, so frequently evokes Chaplin mannerisms, everything from the way the Tramp walks and stands to the way he controls his hands, even his elbows.
One big difference: Chaplin depends on close-ups of the Tramp's face to verify what has already been made clear. Fosse appreciates the full figure. The costumes he favors for his dancers, including black leotards, have a way of deflecting attention from individual features to allow movement to become the principal expression of character.
"Fosse," you should understand, is a rich, bewitching show.
'Art' "Art," Yasmina Reza's superbly funny French play, is clearly a theatrical phenomenon both in this country, where it is being seen in Christopher Hampton's English translation, and abroad, where it is playing -- or has played -- in more than 40 countries. It seems to be unstoppable.
At the Royale Theater in New York, Judd Hirsch, Joe Morton and George Wendt have replaced the English cast, which earlier replaced Alan Alda, Victor Garber and Alfred Molina, who opened the show at the Royale last March. That company has just opened at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles. Another company is at the Royal George in Chicago. London, where the play opened in 1996, is on its ninth company. Meanwhile, "Art" continues in Paris.
Among the other places it has been seen: India, Peru, Belarus, Japan and Serbia. Remember, this is a comedy about three Frenchmen, members of the bourgeoisie, whose longtime friendship is about to dissolve in acrimony over the acquisition by one of the friends of a white-on-white painting. Does wit suddenly sell like kung-fu movies? In some places, apparently.
A return visit to the Royale to see the new cast confirms my original reaction: "Art," directed in New York as well as in London by Matthew Warchus, is an exceptionally wise and sophisticated work. It succeeds in being stylishly contemporary without ever dropping brand-names or references to any celebrity born after Seneca. Further, it is a play that seems to fit with ease any number of good if quite different actors.
Mr. Wendt, who is still best remembered as Norm in the long-running sitcom "Cheers," easily slips his large frame into the role of Yvan. It's a part actors might die for: the harried friend who helps precipitate the crisis by becoming engaged and rebelling against his position as the comedy relief for the two other men.
Mr. Hirsch is furiously, seriously comic as Marc, the full-time control freak. Mr. Morton is splendidly condescending as Serge, the divorced doctor who embarks on a life as a collector by buying the painting for a price his pals find ludicrous, 200,000 francs, or approximately $40,000.
"Art" is a delight in the economy of its construction. Running 90 minutes and played without an intermission, it never seems to hurry but, by the time it ends, a friendship has been analyzed in the kind of minute psychological detail you are more likely to find in a well-written short story or novel. "Art" breathes as if it had a life of its own.
There is something mysterious about writing so firm and true: it is infinitely adaptable. After watching each of the three casts I have seen play it, I have been convinced that no one else did it better, or even quite the same.

HEADLINE: With Lockout Over, Players Work Out

BYLINE: By DAN MARKOWITZ

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
THE small fleet of sport utility vehicles in the New York Knick parking lot outside the Physical Education Building at Purchase College here two weeks ago signaled that the National Basketball Association lockout had indeed ended.
But with a 50-game season beginning on Feb. 5, Michael Jordan's retirement announcement and practice sessions where players from any N.B.A. team and free agents could work out their kinks at the Knicks' training site, business was anything but back to normal. Still, the rack of 15 Spalding official N.B.A. balls was rolled out by the Knicks' strength coach, Greg Brittenham, and Knick regulars like Allan Houston, John Starks, Charlie Ward and Chris Childs, along with a newcomer, Marcus Camby, gladly went through their paces. 
 "Mouths have been watering to get to this point," said Houston, who said he worked out religiously during the lockout, playing games at Basketball City at the Chelsea Piers in Manhattan and shooting and lifting weights on his own. "The misconception is that just because we weren't practicing as a team, guys weren't doing anything. Guys were still working out and staying in shape. But there's actually nothing like the intensity of playing real games and practices."
Childs, the Knicks' back-up point guard, looked in prime shape as well, but he derided pick-up games as doing more damage than good. "It's not the same magnitude of going to the gym with your teammates and being pushed to the top level," he said. "You can't do that away from the pro ranks."
A couple of former Westchester High School basketball stars, Rasul Salahuddin, 25, of Mount Vernon and Long Beach State, and Rasaun Young, 23, of New Rochelle and the University of Buffalo, joined the open practice. Both players have designs on filling the Knicks' vacant fifth guard spot.
Reggie Freeman, 23, another New York City product out of Rice High School, said the lockout would hurt young, inexperienced players' chances. "It's worse now because they want veteran guys that have been in the system more," he said, referring to team management.
Coach Jeff Van Gundy of the Knicks could not yet set foot on the special elevated and cushioned court built here because of the N.B.A. rule that the head coaches could not run practices until the collective bargaining agreement was signed. But all the accouterments of a regular practice -- the towels, the Gatorade bucket, the box of Power Bars, Kleenex, tape, sugarless chewing gum and lozenges -- were provided by an equipment manager..
The rookie hopefuls got lost in the shuffle of newspaper reporters and television camera crews sticking tape recorders and microphones in front of Ward, Childs and Houston, asking them for poignant Jordan memories. "You know you're great when people mimic you," Childs said.
Ward said, "I can tell my children 10, 15 years from now that I played against him, and I've got the pictures to prove it."
Houston said: "Just because Michael is not here this season it doesn't take away from who wins the championship. It takes a lot to get to the finals. We're not going to change our goals. We're not going to expect to be there just because he's not."
Even with Jordan's absence, the Knicks were not being picked as N.B.A. finalist quality. That lofty perch was expected to be filled by the Indiana Pacers in the East and the Utah Jazz in the West.
The man who could possibly redeem the Knicks' chances, along with the reported newly acquired guard, Latrell Sprewell, is their captain and the players' union president, Patrick Ewing. He was vacationingbefore beginning the rigors of training.
Ewing is most likely to have a lot of the anger harbored by N.B.A. fans over the lockout directed at him when he sets foot on the court in Madison Square Garden. Childs said Knick fans should show some sympathy for Ewing -- who made unrealistic comments during the lockout about millionaire N.B.A. players fighting for their economic survival -- and should look at "the sacrifice Patrick has made." He continued: "Financially and even physically, because he had to involve himself with the negotiations, it took time away from his family and working out."
Referring to the lockout, Childs said: "Everybody's at fault -- the players, the owners, the league -- and everybody lost, nobody won. It has hurt the game tremendously. It's just human nature. When you take something away from people that they enjoy so much, fans are not going to forget it right away."
After the informal practice, a small group of fans entered the gymnasium, including Gabriel Perez, 12, of Brooklyn, who took a day off from school and came here with his uncle. Hoping to get autographs as he watched the players shoot, Gabriel had already forgotten the lockout.
"I'm going to watch the games because I like the Knicks," he said.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Plans to Preserve a Black Beach Enclave in Florida

BYLINE: By JANE TANNER 

DATELINE: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla.

 BODY:
A Jacksonville banker who bought an oceanfront lot in American Beach here last November plans to press for a master plan to stave off encroachment of high-end resorts on either side of an enclave that traces its special character back to the days of segregation.
The banker, Tony T. Brown, a senior vice president at Nationsbank Florida, is seeking to persuade other property owners to create a community development district and a financing plan to upgrade and preserve the neighborhood on the northernmost island off Florida's east coast. 
 Land purchases for new projects are rare at American Beach, developed in the 30's as a resort for blacks barred from whites-only beach areas, and has retained a feeling of community and cultural identity.
Most of the roads in its 78 acres are unpaved and the community lacks basic sewer and water infrastructure. Still, the property is coveted by high-end resorts to the north and south of it -- Amelia Island Plantation and Summer Beach, which are rapidly using up the last of their oceanfront property in the ongoing construction of condominiums, homes and golf courses.
The 18.2-square-mile Amelia Island, of which American Beach is a part, is a 35-minute drive across the Intracoastal Waterway from Jacksonville International Airport. It was a sleepy blue-collar community with a small quiet section of high-priced homes and condominiums at its southern end until the 90's.
Now it is dominated by upscale development. Private planes frequently fly into the island's small airport, where expansion, but not commercial service, is planned.
Mr. Brown bought a 50- by 100-foot parcel on the waterfront from a family trust, paying $89,500. He said he was holding off construction of a vacation home for his family until modern infrastructure is in place -- as are more than a dozen other American Beach property owners.
He said that he also planned to close this Friday on a second lot, where he plans to construct a four-unit apartment buiding. In addition, he said, he is working with longtime residents to create a museum to preserve the enclave's black heritage.
"As a practitioner of redevelopment, I want to practice what I preach," he said. At Nationsbank, now a subsidiary of BankAmerica following a merger last year, he oversees the institution's involvement in neighborhood revitalization in Florida.
Among other property owners pressing for a master plan is Michael Stewart, a Bell South regional manager for corporate affairs whose grandfather built a home in American Beach in 1941.
Mr. Stewart and Frank Morgan Jr., a real estate professional whose family owns more than an acre, joined Mr. Brown last month to discuss capital improvements with local officials. "For long-term viability, infrastructure is a must," Mr. Stewart said. "But it's not the panacea."
In November, Mr. Brown met with the American Beach Homeowners Association. Of the enclave's 125 lots, about 80 have homes; only 20 have year-round residents.
He found members of the homeowners association wary when he tried to persuade them to endorse his draft proposals for revitalizing the neighborhood. Ultimately such a plan would have to go before the local commissioners of Nassau County, the island's governing entity, for approval.
Mr. Brown's proposal offers several options to finance capital improvements such as sewage and water utilities. Among those discussed have been property-tax increases directed back to the neighborhood and issuance of bonds.
THE homeowners are seeking more details and have invited Mr. Brown back to give them. "There are people who come along from time to time like Mr. Brown who talk about developing American Beach," said Annette Myers, head of the homeowners' association. "Sometimes you don't know where these people are coming from."
Mrs. Myers said that residents were concerned about property values rising too high for elderly residents on fixed incomes, about retaining a mix of affordable housing and about keeping a vibrant ethnic identity.
American Beach residents have cause for concern, since resort owners and speculators have coveted the property. But so far, with 125 separate property owners and vocal residents determined to keep its historic identity intact, no one has been able to assemble enough for large projects.
Walter Gossett, the Nassau County manager, said that Mr. Brown's goals were realistic. "It is an ambitious undertaking, but I think it has the potential to succeed," Mr. Gossett said. "It is the best plan I've seen come down the pike. I think it would be a welcome development in Nassau County."
American Beach was founded in the 30's by Abraham Lincoln Lewis, an insurance magnate who was Florida's first black millionaire. Lewis, who co-founded the Afro-American Insurance Company in Jacksonville in 1901, bought 20 acres in 1935 that became the original American Beach.
He encouraged others to buy lots to create a lively beach getaway for black families. Michael Stewart's grandfather Ralph, for instance, was an actuary with Afro-American Insurance. Over the years, prominent black businessmen bought lots and built homes. At its peak, the enclave comprised 200 acres. But since the 60's the neighborhood has not moved forward. Many homes are vacant and rundown and neighbors want the boarded-up, ramshackle home adjacent to Mr. Brown's lot condemned and torn down.
In contrast to the near standstill at American Beach, the surrounding wealthy resorts are busy expanding. On 83 acres that once was part of American Beach, Amelia Island Plantation is building a 94-home gated golf retirement community, with houses that range in size from 1,500 to 2,056 square feet and in price from $230,000 to $350,000.
The 1,333-acre resort community -- begun in 1974 by the Sea Pines Company, which also developed Hilton Head, S.C. -- also is completing a seven-story, 21-unit luxury condominium. Nine of its 3,300-square-foot units have sold for an average of $900,000.
In a separate project, the resort is building two more seven-story condominiums, called Beach Side Villas, each with 21 units. The first was finished in December; the other will be completed in August. The 2,500-square-foot units are selling at $590,000 on average, and the first building is sold out.
Only a 600-foot oceanfront stretch remains, and that likely will be developed into condominiums, said Norman Bray, executive vice president of real estate development for Amelia Island Plantation. He expects the community to be built out completely by 2002.
"Everything has heated up in the last five years with the strong economy," Mr. Bray said.
Just to the north of American Beach the Summer Beach resort is developing the last parcels of its 500-acre community. Seven 14-unit condominium buildings called Carlton Dunes are currently under construction at the northern end of Summer Beach.
The 3,880-square-foot units have been selling for $750,000 to $1.3 million.
While property values are rising quickly on either side, values in American Beach remain relatively low. For instance, while Mr. Brown paid $89,500 for his 50- by 100-foot oceanfront lot, just to the south in Amelia Island Plantation resort, two lots, each 40-by-180 feet, sold last year for $425,000 a each, Mr. Bray said. Three other nearby oceanfront lots, 100 by 215 feet, sold for $1.3 million each. They will be developed with single-family homes.
Mr. Brown does not anticipate values at that level in American Beach, even though some high-priced lots are within walking distance. But he does look at Summer Beach and Amelia Island Plantation with both a touch of envy and a sense of opportunity. "There's no reason we can't be developed nicely too, and have that type of area here," he said.

HEADLINE: In the Region / Connecticut;
New Powers for Towns to Protect Neighborhoods

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THREE months ago the General Assembly passed the Connecticut Village Districts Act, an amendment to the state zoning statutes that allows municipalities to greatly strengthen the roles of their zoning bodies. The action has pleased preservationists and planning and zoning commissions, but has troubled many builders, real estate professionals and architects.
Unlike historic districts, which are established by a two-thirds vote of affected residents, the measure authorizes local commissions to establish districts anywhere they deem appropriate as a means of preserving a neighborhood's character, whether it is historic, of more recent vintage, economically modest, mixed use, or whatever. 
 Under the new law, building permits can be denied to applicants who do not comply with regulations for renovations or new construction within a district.
Lawyers and municipal officials say that the amendment will limit the construction of immense "trophy" homes in inappropriate neighborhoods, and yet allow "big box" stores to be built, provided they abandon their generic architecture and conform to the new regulations.
The bill, which was signed into law by Gov. John G. Rowland after having been passed with almost no notice outside the chambers of the legislature, has so far been adopted by only one community -- Brooklyn, a 24-square-mile town of 6,700 residents in the northeast corner of the state.
But as word of the legislation spreads, village districts are being considered in a growing number of towns from Canterbury to Greenwich by planning and zoning commissions that have long sought legal means to reject projects that they feel destroy the integrity of a neighborhood.
The bill states in part that "village districts shall protect the distinctive character, landscape, and historic structures of such areas and may regulate alterations and improvements in view of public roadways, including but not limited to design and placement of buildings, maintenance of public views; design, paving materials and placement of public roadways; design, relationship and compatibility of structures, plantings, signs, roadways, street hardware, color, size, height, proportion of openings, roof treatments, and lighting of residential and commercial property."
It also states that "the removal or disruption of historic, traditional or significant structures or architectural elements shall be minimized."
"The good thing is it takes into consideration the esthetics of a town," said Terry J. Tondro, professor of real property law at the University of Connecticut. "My biggest criticism is it's too general. Regulating color and esthetics could be challenged. For legal due process it needs a whole lot of clarification. If a zoning commission is careful it could do that."
THE same concerns were voiced by William Ethier, executive vice president of the Connecticut Homebuilders Association. "The bill is so vague and open-ended," he said, "that in the wrong hands it could be very abusive of property owners and applicants for new construction and remodeling. A lot of builders who have looked at the act are concerned because they they don't know what to do with it."
He is working with the Connecticut chapter of the American Planning Association, which endorsed the bill, on amendments to be presented to the current legislative session. Wendy Johnston, Town Planner for Wilton and head of the chapter, applauds its purpose. "It offers a chance to do innovative planning," she said, "but under the current wording it's not easy for towns to write precise zoning regulations."
Real estate brokers say they understand and appreciate the concept of protecting a neighborhood's singular appeal as an enhancement for sales. But Timothy Calnen, government affairs director of the Connecticut Association of Realtors, expressed the view that "real estate is premised on property rights."
"The act could severely restrict the ability of people to transfer property and improve it with alterations," he said.
He would like to see more public participation through a provision calling for notification by certified mail of residents of a proposed village district that a designation is pending. The notification would come prior to the required public hearing by the local planning and zoning commission.
In Greenwich, a town perpetually deluged with applications for office buildings, oversized mansions and fast-food restaurants, Diane Fox, the Town Planner, enthusiastically supports the bill.
"We are exploring three areas that would qualify for village district status -- in Byram, Cos Cob and Old Greenwich," she said. "We are defining the commercial areas, schools and libraries that adjoin them in six or seven streets of each area, reflective of the history of development in those neighborhoods." She has asked for a copy of Brooklyn's local ordinance to study.
Similarly mixed neighborhoods in Stamford are seen as ideal candidates for village districts by Renee Kahn, director of the city's Historic Neighborhood Preservation Program. "We're very interested," she said. "The bill doesn't have the elitist quality of a historic district, so it could be very useful if you live in a little side street and a McDonald's wants to come in. You are protected from the noise, the lights and traffic. If your house looks out the back on one of those establishments it's a disaster."
UNDER the new law, each village district board is required to submit proposals for renovations or new construction to an architect or architectural review board for recommendations before approving or rejecting them.
"I think establishing village districts is worth a try, but I'm torn," said William H. Glover, a partner at Centerbrook Architects in Centerbrook. "I've served on zoning commissions and know from experience that you can't legislate beauty. As an architect I would rather not have a committee tell me what's appropriate in a particular situation, but as a resident it would be nice to have some means of preventing some of the disastrous developments that often occur."
The whole idea of village districts germinated two years ago as a vehicle for convincing the state's Department of Transportation to retract its plan for widening the portion of Route 6 that runs through the historic center of Brooklyn. Route 6 is being rebuilt across Connecticut, from the New York State border to the Rhode Island line.
John J. Filchak, executive director of the Northeast Council of Governments, one of Connecticut's regional planning agencies, was called in to devise a bill giving the town the final say on the design and appearance of Route 6 in the village area.
The Department of Transportation strongly opposed the measure as presented to the legislature in 1997 and it failed to pass.
"We need to have ultimate authority for creating a balance between road safety and capacity," Carl Bard, project coordinator for the Department of Transportation, said at the time.
When a much broader bill passed last year the department agreed to retain the mile-and-a-half roadway through central Brooklyn at its present width of 24 feet. A need to eliminate a dangerous curve will, however, require the demolition of four homes and the removal of one historic house to the back of its property.
"For the first time in the history of Connecticut zoning," said Mr. Filchak, "planning and zoning commissions are allowed to set up rules and regulations as to how things will look and interact."
John Shannahan, director of the Connecticut Historical Commission, recently moderated a panel on village districts, attended by a standing-room crowd. "We have over 340 national, state and local historic districts in the state," he said, "mostly residential and mostly without design control or esthetic review. We have a new tool here."
Ambiguity of language and the absence of a set of architectural standards that could be interpreted for a variety of village districts bother Gurdon H. Buck, partner and urban planner at the Hartford law firm of Robinson & Cole.
"The act is what I would call a good start," he said, citing the Westville neighborhood of New Haven, the Victorian downtown of Shelton, Federal portions of Ridgefield and late 18th-early 19th century Middle Haddam as potential village districts.
Representative Jefferson D. Davis, a Pomfret Democrat who is chairman of the planning and zoning development committee, introduced the bill.
"I don't agree that it's too broad in its authorization," he said. "It allows for discretion by planning and zoning commissions within a defined framework. A unique aspect is the consideration of public views of hills, parks, waterways -- an opportunity to define the relationships in our towns between our built and nonbuilt environments. And it addresses a tragedy in urban, suburban and even rural settings -- the reliance on zoning that divides towns into single use areas, driving out residential opportunities downtown."
"Often people don't give a new law a chance to be put into practice," he said, adding that he is more interested in giving it a year to sift out than amending it now.

HEADLINE: Dodging Bullets In Overseas Trade

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
WHEN the Asian financial crisis broke in July of 1997, it caused worries in Connecticut. Some of the Asian nations whose economies were hardest hit were among the state's 10 largest overseas trade partners, and while foreign trade makes up only about 6 percent of the state's economy, it is a segment that has steadily grown over the last decade.
With the recent release of the first comprehensive analysis of the situation, however, there is cause for cautious optimism. Sales by Connecticut companies to Asia have faltered, but not as badly as was feared. Economists and business executives are hopeful that the effects on jobs will remain small, and that trade will begin picking up soon. 
 "The general conclusion was it's affected us," said Will McEachern, editor-in-chief of The Connecticut Economy, a quarterly publication by the University of Connecticut's Center for Economic Analysis. But, he added, "unless it gets worse, it hasn't had a big effect on the economy."
The Connecticut Economy led its Fall 1998 issue with the following cover title: "A Mild Case of the Asian Flu." In a survey by the Connecticut Business and Industry Association of manufacturers in the state, almost a third of respondents reported a loss in sales they attributed to Asian economic problems.
The fears of manufacturers and service industry companies are complex, reflecting the complexities of a global marketplace.
National currencies throughout Asia have devalued drastically, making exports from the United States far more expensive than before, and making it harder for Asians to afford them. At the same time, it has made Asian imports less expensive in the United States, challenging the competitiveness of American companies.
There have been layoffs, stock market jitters and a slowing of economic growth in the United States as a result. In Connecticut, manufacturing export sales went down 11 percent for the first three quarters of 1998 compared with the same period in 1997.
But mitigating the effects and holding job losses low in Connecticut is the nature of the state's exports -- largely high-tech specialty products and services including insurance, pharmaceuticals and electronics that have continued to sell better than the consumer goods, raw materials and agricultural products that other states export, according to Peter Gioia, an economist with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association.
An example is Locknetics Security Engineering, a company in Bristol that makes electronic locks. Its president, James Scott, said in the 1990's the company's exports increased from 4 percent to 18 percent of its sales, roughly evenly divided between Asia and Europe. Locknetics made all of the magnetic doors for the new Hong Kong airport, the largest in the world.
Lately, however, Locknetics' sales in Asia have slowed considerably; devaluations have doubled the price that Asians must pay. "Our products have become very expensive for them," Mr. Scott said.
But Mr. Scott said he has seen signs of renewed orders from Singapore and elsewhere in Asia as construction projects that had been put on hold there have begun to restart. His company is also getting interest from construction projects in Japan where it had no business before, as well as from the Middle East and South America.
Mr. Scott attributed that interest to the reputation his company's products: the kind of locks operated with key pads, identification cards and handprint recognition devices that are familiar features of techno-thriller fiction.
Overall, said Mr. McEachern, foreign sales by the electric and electronic equipment segment of Connecticut manufacturing declined in 1998's first three quarters by 37 percent, as did the industrial machinery and computers industries segment. Precision instruments had about a 15 percent decline for the same period, he said.
The only bright spot has been in the transportation segment, in which export sales increased by about 20 percent in the first half and were still holding up for the first three quarters, he said.
Much of that was due to Pratt and Whitney's aircraft engine sales, which were brisk, even to Asia, according to Mr. Gioia. Boeing announced production cuts and layoffs earlier this month due to cancellations of Asian aircraft purchases, which has the potential of affecting Pratt and Whitney, but the company also sells to Boeing's competitors so it is too early to tell if there will be any impact, Mr. Gioia said.
"I don't think the effect has been dramatic," he said of the overall impact of the Asian economic crisis. "It hasn't been as much as people expected."
The fact that the Asian situation makes those countries' products less expensive, and more competitive, in other parts of the world might strengthen their economies faster than anyone expects, and some companies in the United States that make parts for Asian products would benefit from that, Mr. Gioia observed. So even though cheaper imports might negatively affect some Connecticut companies in the short term, it could be positive in the long term, he said. "It's a very tough thing to predict," he concluded.
Foreign sales of services, like insurance, are even more difficult to track, but that sector has also slowed because of the Asia situation, according to The Connecticut Economy.
United Technologies, based in Hartford, which owns Pratt and Whitney, has announced it expects this year's profits to be down 15 percent largely because of the Asian crisis, but "we're not concerned about it," said a company spokesman, Peter Murphy. United Technologies also owns Otis Elevator and Sikorsky Aircraft, the helicopter manufacturer.
Mr. Murphy noted that Asia is undergoing the biggest urbanization transformation in the history of the world, with 700 million people moving to the cities. That, he said, is an unstoppable force for economic growth, so whatever economic problems Asia is experiencing now are only temporary. "That is clearly the market of the future," Mr. Murphy said, and United Technologies is taking advantage of the opportunities the devaluation of Asian currencies offers to purchase companies and form joint ventures there.
Meanwhile, the state's exports still show strength, said Mark Prisloe, a senior economist at the state's Department of Economic and Community Development. Asian countries account for 21 percent of the state's total foreign trade. Although exports to Asia dropped 11.4 percent in 1998, he said, the previous year, they rose 14 percent.
But figures like that can be deceiving, he said. Connecticut's exports to Canada, its largest foreign trade partner, rose only 1.9 percent for the first three quarters of 1998 while exports to Taiwan, the state's 10th largest trade partner, rose 24.5 percent. "I would not make too much of any quarter's data," he said.
"Connecticut seems to have fared better than some of the other states," noted James C. Nicholas, executive director of the Connecticut World Trade Association, an organization that promotes foreign trade. He said some of the more optimistic estimates for when the Asian crisis would end range from 18 months to three years.
Japan is the key to Asia's recovery, said Mr. Nicholas, because it exports capital as well as products to its neighbors. That is reflected the thinking of others, including Mr. McEachern who was far less sanguine about the prospects for a quick end to the Asian economic crisis. He said Japanese students who attend his classes at the University of Connecticut are very anxious about it. "The students who I've talked to have very little confidence in the Japanese Government's ability to resolve the problem," he said.
Nevertheless, The Connecticut Economy quantified the effect of the Asian crisis on Connecticut as a loss of only about 0.2 percent of the 127,000 jobs generated by foreign trade in the state. "It comes at a time when the rest of the economy has been doing well," Mr. McEachern said. However fast Asia's recovery is, the economists writing for The Connecticut Economy forecast a return to rapid growth in export-related jobs in the state beginning in 2000. Unless there is another dramatic development, its analysis predicts, "the Asian crisis by itself holds little threat for the state's economy."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 4; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
He's at Home In the Pulpit, Wherever It Is

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: LINCOLN PARK

 BODY:
EVER since the civil rights movement forged the link between the black church and the world of politics, many African American preachers have found it to be a good policy to keep one eye on their flocks and the other on what the local politicians were up to.
It was through just such concerned involvement that DeForest (Buster) Soaries Jr., pastor of the First Baptist Church of Lincoln Gardens, ended up giving the invocation at the Somerset County Republican Dinner in the fall of 1993. At his side on the dais sat a big-name political consultant, Ed Rollins, who was campaign strategist for a no-name Republican underdog in the gubernatorial race, Christine Todd Whitman. 
 Mrs. Whitman is now Governor, of course, and 10 days ago Dr. Soaries was confirmed as her latest Secretary of State, an appointment that will make it possible for him to keep that eye on government by giving him a seat at the center of power in Trenton.
True, he conceded, the Secretary of State's position does not require a lot of heavy lifting -- the state constitution lists his first duty as "keeper of the Great Seal of the State" -- but as the 47-year-old minister put it, "the weight of what is being lifted is in proportion to the strength of the lifter."
And Mr. Rollins? He has retired to the world of book contracts, speaking fees and cable television appearances, but his presence on the dais with Dr. Soaries that day has a lot of do with how the new Secretary got the job.
That's because of something Mr. Rollins did one week after Mrs. Whitman was elected, putting out the story that the victorious Republicans had bribed unidentified black ministers with a half million dollars to advise their parishioners to stay home on election day. It did not take Dr. Soaries long to realize that as a black minister recently seen smiling and schmoozing with Mr. Rollins, he had a problem, and that Mrs. Whitman had a problem, and that Mr. Rollins's hasty denial was not going to solve it.
"I called up the Governor's office and I told them that Christie needs to be at the 7 A.M. service in my church on Sunday, and she was there," Dr. Soaries recalled.
In the days that followed, Dr. Soaries, who had endorsed Jim Florio, the incumbent Governor defeated by Mrs. Whitman, stood with the Governor-elect and found other black ministers to do so. Jesse Jackson and Al Sharpton came and went, Mr. Rollins announced his retirement from politics, and the first crisis of the Whitman administration gradually faded. And Mrs. Whitman had met her go-to man in the state's tricky racial politics.
Some people worried that Dr. Soaries, who says he is a political independent, had tied himself too closely to the Republicans, but that was not his concern, he said. "I had an interest in disproving this story not so much to protect the Republicans, as to defend the church," he said.
That church today worships in a tiny, 1930's-era building. But behind it a new, $10 million church is rising, as big as an airport terminal, spacious enough to accommodate the 5,100 enrolled members in First Baptist in two services.
The new church, and the swelling size of the congregation, are part of Dr Soaries's legacy since he arrived in Somerset in 1990 from Shiloh Baptist Church in Trenton, where he worked under the celebrated Rev. Howard S. Woodson.
The move to his own church was not an easy one. First Baptist had had only two ministers in its 53 years. It had no formal annual budget, it had no bylaws and it had no guidelines for electing a successor. In the highly factionalized scramble to advance three different candidates, Dr. Soaries won a plurality but not a majority.
"I came to a church that was divided," he said, and listening to his account of those years gives a sense of how he operates in politics as well as in church management.
Rule one: no purges.
"We were facing a situation where we could have had a lot of little churches breaking off -- Second Baptist, Third Baptist -- but we held it together, and we did it with the same people, we didn't say some people were out and some people were in."
From a membership of 1,500, First Baptist had grown to 5,100 members and has spun off six non-profit corporations, including a credit union and a community development corporation.
That Dr. Soaries should value democracy and inclusiveness in church management may be related to the total absence of dissent in the Montclair household where he grew up. DeForest Soaries Sr., a cleric and a teacher at Kinney Junior High in Newark and himself the son of a West Indian preacher, was not a man inclined to argue details with his three children.
"He was a benevolent dictator, emphasis on dictator," Dr. Soaries said of his father.
The son graduated from Fordham University, and, moved by his grandmother's anguish at the murder of Martin Luther King Jr., he took a master's from Princeton Seminary and a doctorate in theology from the Theological Seminary in Dayton, Ohio, the old Methodist divinity school. He lives in Franklin Park with his wife, Donna, and their 9-year-old twins, Malcolm and Martin.
Dr. Soaries intends to keep preaching every Sunday while he is Secretary of State, and to keep pushing for the interests of the poor and neglected in his official capacity during the week. As he outlined his goals, he might have been drawing from the sermon he had just delivered, based on the prophet Micah's commandment to "do justice."
"It can be a position of major leadership instead of one of minor observation," Dr. Soaries said of his government job. "I intend to consult with the Governor on her budget message, and intend to consult with the Attorney General on law enforcement as it affects areas that are underserved by police, and I expect to be in consultation with all of the boards and commissions as an advocate of the Governor's notion of personal responsibility."
And what about the Govenor's responsibility to minorities, a subject that has landed her in tight spots several times since the Rollins episode? Mrs. Whitman is innocent of bigotry, Dr. Soaries said, but needed coaching in managing those relations.
"She was not raised to think racially," the preacher said. "In a clinical sense, that is a virtue, but in a real-world sense, it can be hazardous."
Translation: race is so pervasive an issue, for good or ill, that to ignore it invites trouble.
On the day of his Martin Luther King Day sermon, Dr. Soaries offered a similarly balanced view of the relations between the races. His assessment was half good -- pure bigotry has abated -- and half bad:
"We still live in separate worlds," Dr. Soaries said of blacks and whites. "We don't really see the other side, and that's true of the black middle class and lower-income minorities -- they don't really know each other, either. That is something we all need to address."
 
'There Are Those Who Are in Need of Mercy'
Last Sunday Dr. DeForest B. Soaries Jr. delivered his Martin Luther King Day sermon at First Baptist Church of Lincoln Park, in Somerset. His text was the prophet Micah's well-known admonition to "do justice, love mercy and walk humbly with your God." Here are excerpts from his message:
 
EVERYBODY loves mercy when mercy visits their house. Everybody loved mercy when mercy stops by their way. But believe I hear Micah saying we ought to love mercy when God bestows mercy on other folks. . . .
Don't get me wrong -- there are people who are victims of their own irresponsibility. I don't want anybody to think that I am so naive as to think that every person who is unemployed, that they have been the victim of discrimination. I don't want you to think that in 1999 that all of our problems and all of our poverty is still a consequence of the outstretched arms of 200 years ago slavery. Yes, some of us are responsible for our own condition and we are the victims of the choices we've made and the chances we've taken.
Having said that, there are those who are in need of mercy. That grandmother, whose child died from an overdose of drugs, now she's trying to raise her children left behind by her child -- that grandmothers need the support from the community and from the government -- she needs what the Bible calls mercy! Five thousand young people in the city of Newark whose parents have died from AIDS, by no fault of their own they are the victims of circumstances beyond their control, they need some mercy! Children born, languishing in hospitals, their parents on drugs, those children could not choose the family to which they were born, those children need mercy!
When we've become so self-sufficient, when we've become so proud of our having pulled ourselves up by our mythical bootstraps, when we've become so middle class and uppity-up, when we become so high-falutin' in society, when we no longer celebrate the fact that God is a merciful God and he needs us to be what Assisi calls "instruments of God's peace," we are irrelevant, and history will have nothing to celebrate as a consequence of our lives.
Martin King was a man who loved mercy, and worked that God would manifest his mercy on those who needed God's attention!
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1583 words

HEADLINE: Tourism Figures Show a Drop

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THE crescent of picturesque villages bordering the Hudson River was once known as Millionaire's Row, a strand of lavish vacation hideaways along the shore where the wealthy whiled away their summers. But in the last year, the popularity of the historic estates as Westchester tourist destinations has waned, and officials are wondering why.
The number of visitors to five sites in Westchester managed by the nonprofit Historic Hudson Valley in Tarrytown -- among them the popular Kykuit, the home of four generations of Rockefellers -- was down nearly 7 percent last year from 1997. 
 "This comes as a real wake-up call," Burns Patterson, marketing director for Historic Hudson Valley, said.
Mr. Patterson and others responsible for tourism on both county and state levels said the figures may only represent a temporary fluctuation and therefore have little long-term significance. Or they could presage difficult times ahead for the industry, because the five sites represent some of the Hudson Valley's main attractions.
"It could be just a blip on the radar screen, but we don't know," said Harold E. Vogt, chief executive officer of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce. "It also could have long-range implications. Either way, we're taking this very seriously."
Georgia G. Kalayjian-Murphy, president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau of Westchester, which is affiliated with the County Chamber of Commerce, agreed that the decrease at the Hudson Valley sites should not be ignored.
Mr. Patterson said 200,000 people visited the historic estates last year compared with 1997, when there were 214,000 visitors.
In addition to administering Kykuit (pronounced KYE-cut), which is considered the centerpiece of the tourist sites along the river, Historic Hudson Valley also manages tourism for four other estates in Westchester.
They are Washington Irving's 17th-century house Sunnyside in Tarrytown, Philipsburg Manor in Sleepy Hollow, the home of Frederick Philipse, a carpenter who eventually earned his fortune as a slave trader; the Union Church of Pocantico Hills in Sleepy Hollow, which has stained-glass windows by Matisse and Chagall, and Van Cortlandt Manor, an 18th-century manor house in Croton-on-Hudson.
In addition, Historic Hudson Valley, which was founded by John D. Rockefeller Jr. in 1951, is responsible for visitor activity at Montgomery Place, a 434-acre historic site in Annandale-on-Hudson in northern Dutchess County. In calculating the annual number of visitors, the organization tallies people coming through the turnstiles and does not count lecture series sales or other related events outside the premises, Mr. Patterson explained. The group's mission, he said, is to preserve the culture, landscape and history of the Hudson River Valley. At least in part, the decrease in tourism last year at the county's best known historic sites can be attributed to wet weather in the spring. "But when you live by the sword," he added ruefully, "you also die by the sword." At Sunnyside, for example, torrential rains had an adverse effect on events like an outdoor exhibition by local artists and a Victorian-style picnic planned on the lawn for Mother's Day.
"Our intention was to show guests that we offered more than just dusty old house tours," Mr. Patterson said.
Although he acknowledged that the organization could buy a large tent or even umbrellas for every visitor -- and could even promote rain-or-shine events -- Mr. Patterson said, "We'll never be able to weatherproof ourselves 100 percent."
Robert W. Elliott, Director of Economic Development for the county, said the numbers reported by Historic Hudson Valley were "unfortunately not an anomaly" and possibly indicated a wider trend.
Mr. Elliott said there have been similar, though still early and unconfirmed, reports of tourism on the decline from other historic sites in Westchester.
"At the very least," he said, "this is something to pay attention to."
Looking at the last eight years, however, the growth at Kykuit, Sunnyside, Philipsburg Manor, Union Church and Van Cortlandt Manor has been extremely healthy, Mr. Patterson said. Visitor figures in 1991 were 96,000. And when compared with 200,000 this year, that represents a 108 percent increase.
But a 1996 study conducted by Marist College in Poughkeepsie for the nonprofit Hudson River Greenway Council -- a state-appointed group charged with establishing a chain of riverfront parks and scenic open space between Albany and New York -- concluded that many of the historic sites along the Hudson have not been marketed aggressively enough and could handle even more visitors.
Dr. Ann Davis, a professor of economics and director of the college's Bureau of Economic Research, said last week that interviews with visitors at 50 sites along the Hudson, from Albany to New York City, revealed that most of them learned about sights in the Hudson Valley from friends, family and word of mouth -- and were not drawn to the spots either by travel services or advertising campaigns.
"There's a very large potential here that's not being tapped," Dr. Davis said. She said that according to the Marist College study of visitors about 51 percent of them were 50 or older and 62 percent had college or graduate degrees. Those findings suggested that more marketing should be aimed at those groups.
Maggie Vinciguerra, executive director of Greenway Council, said that her organization was studying new marketing strategies for historic sites. She also said that the organization would make recommendations to market sites as part of a region rather than as individual places to visit. Ms. Vinciguerra said that was the strategy adopted in Williamsburg, Va., where tourist numbers are now increasing again after a period of decline. She also said Williamsburg was advertising multiple-day stays rather than one-day trips.
Ms. Kalayjian-Murphy of the Convention and Visitors Bureau said she was puzzled by the downturn at the Historic Hudson Valley sites, especially in light of other tourism figures in Westchester. For example, taxable hotel sales for the county in fiscal year 1997, the last year for which figures are available, were $173.4 million -- 26 percent more than in fiscal year 1996, when they were $137.9 and 104 percent more than in 1992, when they were $85.2 million.
Taxable hotel sales for 1998 should top $201 million when the tallying is done later this winter, Ms. Kalayjian-Murphy predicted.
Also, visitor spending generated more than $25.7 million in county sales taxes in 1997, up from $10.6 million the year before, Ms. Kalayjian-Murphy said.
But she cautioned: "We can't always be breaking the records. Perhaps when the numbers go so high, they're bound to hit a peak."
Estimates show that based on industry standards of measuring such things, the average Kykuit day tripper, for example, spends $59 in the county on gas, restaurants, and the like, Ms. Kalayjian-Murphy said. And for every overnight hotel stay, $189 is the average amount spent in addition to the cost of the room.
Mr. Elliott at the county's Economic Development Office observed that Ms. Kalayjian-Murphy's numbers included business travelers staying at hotels and therefore did not accurately represent the problems being experienced by Historic Hudson Valley or any other cultural institutions.
The numbers of visitors to Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, the former estate of Jay Gould, the financier, were also disappointing last year. They rose by 1 percent in 1998, to 78,780 visitors from 78,000 the year before, Ms. Kalayjian-Murphy said.
Meanwhile, officials of the Convention and Visitors Bureau and other agencies said they were stepping up efforts to increase numbers for the coming tourist season. At Sunnyside, the season begins on April 10 and 11 with a celebration of Washington Irving's birthday. The bureau will be the host to a Travel Expo at the County Center in White Plains on March 11 and 12. And Ms. Kalayjian-Murphy said her group, the county and others like Historic Hudson Valley were working closely with New York City groups to sponsor Westchester tours.
Metro-North Railroad, for example, is working with the bureau to sponsor One-Day Getaways to sites like Rye Playland -- "the most popular attraction that we offer," said Daniel O'Connell, a marketing director for the railroad. He said the beach and amusement park draws 15,000 Metro-North riders a summer. Some guided tours of the Hudson Valley are offered year-round; other packaged events are available seasonally. Rye Playland topped the one million visitor mark in 1998, the best attendance in a decade.
Meanwhile, tourism in New York City has grown in recent years, with 33 million domestic and international travelers visiting the city in 1997, the most ever in one year, according to New York City's Tourism Bureau. The state, too, has reported healthy figures. "Tourism is New York State's second-largest industry with an economic impact of $46 billion per year," Charles A. Gargano, chairman of Empire State Development, said recently. The largest industry in the state is agriculture, with an economic impact of more than $60 billion a year.
Gov. George E. Pataki reported in 1997 that figures released by the Travel Industry Association of America on people who take part in historic and cultural activities showed that the state ranked second only to California in attracting those tourism dollars. Pennsylvania was third.
