HEADLINE: After the Blizzard, A New Hartford Team?

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
THE New England Blizzard of the bankrupt American Basketball League may be gone, but the team, which was based in Hartford, is not forgotten by its legion of fans. Indeed the team may not be gone for good.
Two high-ranking state officials are trying to fill the void that was created when the league ceased operations in late December, resulting in the demise of the popular Blizzard, who played their home games at the Hartford Civic Center. 
 Lieut. Gov. M. Jodi Rell and Commissioner James F. Abromaitis of the Department of Economic and Community Development have sent letters to the presidents of the National Basketball Association and the Women's National Basketball Association, respectively, requesting that the surviving women's league, which is owned by the N.B.A., put a franchise in Hartford. Ms. Rell and Mr. Abromaitis pointed to the huge drawing power of the Blizzard, which led the A.B.L. in home attendance during its first two seasons and was far ahead again when the league filed for bankruptcy protection and suspended operations on Dec. 22. They also asked that the W.N.B.A. and N.B.A. reconsider a policy of placing franchises for women's teams only in cities where N.B.A. teams play. The women's teams play in N.B.A. arenas during the summer months when the men's league is not functioning. Ms. Rell's letter was sent to David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, on Jan. 13, two days after the State Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, announced he had issued a subpoena for N.B.A. documents to determine whether the league used its economic muscle to block the American Basketball League's access to sponsors and to television contracts.
Though neither Mr. Stern nor Valerie Ackerman, the president of the W.N.B.A., which was a rival to the A.B.L., responded immediately to the letters, at least one W.N.B.A. official has said publicly that the league was unlikely to put a franchise in Hartford. "If we were to go into New England, it would have to be in Boston," Renee Brown, the women's league director of player personnel, said. "That's the W.N.B.A. policy."
Jeff Twiss, a spokesman for the Boston Celtics, said that Celtics' officials had discussed the possibility of applying for a W.N.B.A. franchise. "There were some internal discussions about it several months ago," Mr. Twiss said in an interview, adding that the discussions took place before the American Basketball League -- which played a fall and winter schedule -- suspended operations. Asked whether a W.N.B.A. team based in Boston might play some of its games in Hartford, Mr. Twiss said that was a possibility. "But then we'd also consider other cities in New England like Providence, Worcester, Springfield and Bangor, Maine," he said.
Until a few years ago, the Celtics played about a half dozen games at the Hartford Civic Center each season. While Boston has been a hotbed of professional basketball since the 1950's, when the Celtics began a long reign as the dominant team in the N.B.A., the city has never been tested as a market for women's basketball. By comparison, both the New England Blizzard and the University of Connecticut women's basketball team, have both drawn well at the Hartford Civic Center.
If a W.N.B.A. franchise were awarded to Boston or Hartford, it could not happen until next year at the earliest. Mark Pray, a spokesman for the league, said that the women's league had already decided to add two new franchises this summer -- in Orlando and in Minneapolis -- which will give the league 12 teams. "So far as I know, there've been no discussions about further expansion," Mr. Pray said.
In asking that the league reconsider its policy of awarding women's team franchises only to cities with N.B.A. teams, Ms. Rell said in her letter, "As evidenced by the Blizzard, it has been proven that the true base of women's basketball fans in New England is in Hartford. There are tens of thousands of women's basketball fans in Connecticut who would jump at the opportunity to see their favorite professionals" such as Jen Rizzotti and Kara Wolters" -- both Blizzard players who previously had been stars of UConn teams -- playing again at the Civic Center.
Mr. Abromaitis, a former UConn basketball star, noted in his letter to the W.N.B.A. Commissioner Val Ackerman that the Blizzard's home attendance last season, with more than 10,000 spectators a game, was larger than that of six of the eight W.N.B.A. franchises "without the benefit of W.N.B.A. marketing and promotion."
"Support for women's basketball at both the professional and college levels has been a unique Connecticut phenomenon over the past decade and continues to grow," Mr. Abromaitis wrote.
One of the team's -- and the league's -- biggest sponsors was the Hartford-based Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company. Phoenix is also the A.B.L.'s biggest creditor, having guaranteed a $6 million bank loan to help bankroll the league. The company, at least for now, has retained most of the Blizzard's 13-member front-office staff.
What the A.B.L. never recovered from, it seems, was its inability to get a season-long contract with a major television network. After issuing a subpoena of N.B.A. records relating to the W.N.B.A., the Attorney General, Mr. Blumenthal, said he had received information from industry sources that the N.B.A. used methods that might have blocked such a contract and, indeed, led to the collapse of the A.B.L.
"There's evidence that the N.B.A. used sharp economic elbows to exclude the A.B.L. from fair play, including access to essential financial rights like TV and product sponsorship," Mr. Blumenthal said, adding that "any indications of unfair, exclusive arrangements or restrictions imposed on broadcasters would be of very powerful importance."
The attorney general's subpoena -- which must be answered by Feb. 3 -- requests information on conditions and restrictions that the N.B.A. might have imposed on sponsors, broadcasters or manufacturers to the detriment of the A.B.L. Mr. Blumenthal said he was hopeful that the N.B.A., which organized the W.N.B.A. after the A.B.L. was formed, would not fight the subpoena. "Their interests would be better served if they did not fight it," he said in an interview. He also said that he has talked with attorneys general in other states where A.B.L. teams were situated, and that some of them were considering similar action.
Asked if his issuance of a subpoena for N.B.A. records could jeopardize Hartford's chances of getting a W.N.B.A. franchise, Mr. Blumenthal said, "There's no way it could hurt, and it might actually help indirectly." Meanwhile, Blizzard players have been blocked from playing with other teams since the A.B.L. has refused to release them claiming they are still assets of the league during its bankruptcy proceedings. The league has maintained its stance even though the players have not been paid since November.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Decoding The Murky Rent Laws

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
WHILE most New Yorkers are aware that there are two basic forms of rent regulation -- rent control and rent stabilization -- there is often confusion about what each does and where each came from. Here are some of the more significant differences between rent control and rent stabilization, along with a brief description of their origins.
"What we have here is a confusing patchwork of laws," said David Ng, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer.
Mr. Ng explained that both forms of rent regulation were the product of state and local laws. Rent control, Mr. Ng said, applies to rental units in buildings built before Feb. 1, 1947, that have been continuously occupied by the same tenant or a legal successor tenant since before July 1, 1971. 
 Rent stabilization, on the other hand, applies to apartments in buildings with six or more units constructed between Feb. 1, 1947, and Jan. 1, 1974, and to tenants who moved into similarly sized buildings built before Feb. 1, 1947 if the move-in date was after June 30, 1971. It also applies to certain loft buildings and some buildings that participate in tax-abatement or other government programs.
According to the most recent survey conducted by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, there were 70,572 rent-controlled apartments and 1.05 million rent-stabilized apartments in the city in 1996. The total number of rental units in the city at that time was 2.02 million.
And while both rent control and rent stabilization are made possible by state laws -- the Local Emergency Rent Control Act and the Emergency Tenant Protection Act , respectively -- further actions are required on the local level for rent regulations to apply in specific municipalities. (While New York City has the vast bulk of rent regulated apartments, more than 50 other municipalities across the state have also adopted rent control or rent stabilization laws.) The actions, which are generally required every three years, include a declaration of a housing emergency -- deemed to exist when vacancy rates are below 5 percent -- and the adoption or renewal of local rent-control or rent-stabilization laws.
So, for example, while the Legislature in June 1997 extended the Emergency Tenant Protection Act for six years -- to June 2003 -- that did not automatically extend rent stabilization in New York City for the same amount of time. That is because, Mr. Ng said, the New York City Rent Stabilization Law, which put into effect the provisions of the state's Emergency Tenant Protection Act, is set to expire on March 31, 2000, and must itself be extended to remain in effect beyond that date.
While the state's Local Emergency Rent Control Act has no automatic expiration date, New York City must nevertheless renew its local Rent and Rehabilitation Law for rent control to remain in effect after March 31, 2000.
Mr. Ng said that rent-regulated apartments -- both rent-stabilized and rent-controlled -- become decontrolled in a number of ways. For example, he said, regulated apartments that are vacated can be deregulated if the legal rent that can be charged to a new tenant, either immediately or after improvements, reaches $2,000.
In addition, Mr. Ng said, even occupied tenants can lose their regulated status under the luxury decontrol provisions of the Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1993. Under that law, which was amended in 1997, an apartment can be decontrolled when the rent is $2,000 or more and the annual income of the tenant exceeds $175,000 for two years preceding the landlord's petition for decontrol.
Moreover, Mr. Ng. said, apartments subject to the rent-control law lose their status upon vacancy. In buildings of six or more units, they then fall under the provisions of the rent-stabilization regulations, once a negotiated rent has been set with the new tenant. In smaller buildings, Mr. Ng. said, the apartments are usually decontrolled.
Michael McKee, associate director of the New York State Tenants & Neighbors Coalition, a tenant-advocacy group based in Manhattan, said that the most significant difference between rent control and rent stabilization is the manner in which rent increases are calculated.
In New York City, he said, increases in rent controlled apartments are determined by what is known as the Maximum Base Rent/ Maximum Collectible Rent system. With that system, he said, the maximum collectible rent is defined as the highest rent that can be charged for an apartment at a given time. The maximum base rent for each apartment -- an amount originally set in 1972 and then adjusted every two years to reflect increases in operating costs -- is frequently higher than the maximum collectible rent.
Under the current rent-control laws, Mr. McKee said, the maximum collectible rent can be increased by up to 7.5 percent each year, as long as it does not exceed the maximum base rent.
Increases for rent-stabilized apartments, on the other hand, are calculated on an "inflation-sensitive" basis by the nine-member Rent Guidelines Board, with two representatives each of landlords and tenants and five public representatives. In calculating yearly increases for rent-stabilized tenants, Mr. McKee said, the board takes into consideration increases in the owner's operating expenses, adjusted for inflation.
While it is often thought that rent increases for rent-stabilized tenants generally exceed those for their rent-controlled counterparts, Mr. McKee said, the opposite frequently occurs. Over the last several years, he said, increases for rent-stabilized tenants have stayed at around 2 percent for a one-year lease and 4 percent for a two-year lease. Increases for rent-controlled tenants, on the other hand, frequently amount to 7.5 percent each year because the spread between the maximum collectible rent and the maximum base rent -- both of which increase on a regular basis -- often remains wide enough to allow for the maximum increase in the collectible rent.
Martin Heistein, a Manhattan lawyer who frequently represents landlords, pointed out that while owners of both rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments can also obtain rent increases for major capital improvements, there are different rules that apply to each. Generally, Mr. Heistein said, increases for major capital improvements -- defined as buildingwide improvements that benefit all tenants -- are based on a seven-year period of amortization of the cost of the improvement, allocated on a "per-room, per-month" basis.
So, for example, a $50,000 major capital improvement in a building with 25 four-room apartments would result in a monthly increase of $5.95 per room. (The amortization of $50,000 over seven years is $7,142.85 a year or $595.23 a month. When apportioned equally among 100 rooms, that amounts to an increase of $5.95 per room per month.)
For rent-stabilized tenants in New York City, Mr. Heistein said, the rent increase for a major capital improvement that is collectible in any one year may not exceed 6 percent of the rent. Moreover, he said, the increase is retroactive to the date 30 days after the owner filed the application for the increase. For rent-controlled tenants the increase can be as much as 15 percent of the tenant's rent, Mr. Heistein said. However, he said, major-capital-improvement increases for such tenants are effective only from the date of the order granting the increase; they cannot be applied retroactively.
Another difference between rent control and rent stabilization, Mr. Heistein said, is that owners of rent-controlled apartments in New York City can generally pass along increases in fuel costs to tenants landlords in rent-stabilized buildings cannot.
At the same time, tenants in rent-stabilized apartments have a right to sublet their units, but tenants in rent-controlled apartments do not.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
How Stocks Could Work For Social Security

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
IT'S fun to talk about what to do with 15 years' worth of projected surpluses in the Federal budget, particularly when the number in question is a tidy $4.4 trillion. That is what President Clinton was doing last week when he lobbed his Social Security proposals in front of the nation.
Such a discussion is much more enjoyable than contemplating how much smaller those numbers might be if -- Heaven forbid -- the economy fell into recession between now and 2015. 
 Still, any number of important people inside the Beltway were far from amused at Mr. Clinton's suggestion that part of the surplus he wants to target for Social Security -- a sum of about $700 billion -- be invested in stocks and corporate bonds instead of Treasury securities.
Peter A. Diamond, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and chairman of a panel of the nonpartisan National Academy of Social Insurance that issued a report on the issue last month, shared his thoughts on the topic last week via telephone from Cambridge, England.
 
Q. Is the President's proposal something you can support?
 
A. At the moment there are two fairly radical proposals about Social Security: One would create individual accounts as a substitute for defined benefits, and the other is to have the Social Security trust fund invest part of its money in stocks and bonds.
The trust fund proposal, which the President put forward, is the less radical idea of the two. I favor it, and I thought the President put it in absolutely the right context.
 Q. But don't people like Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, have a point when they say decisions about where to invest the money would fall prey to political pressure?
A. The issue here is the design of an institution to do the investing.
Mr. Greenspan is at the head of an institution that has a lot of independence to handle monetary policy. Fed governors are appointed to 14-year terms, but if the President or Congress don't like their policies, they can't remove them.
Congress could wipe out the Fed and change the rules. But to do that would obviously be a massive political step.
I believe we can create a separate institution with the same features as the Fed.
Mr. Greenspan raises the fear that investment decisions and share voting would be controlled in detail by the House and the Senate. That, it seems to me, is not a likely outcome.
 
Q. Aside from creating an independent institution, what else would you do to try and depoliticize the investing process?
 
A. I would add two other features. First, restrict stock investments to broad index funds, ones that cover a wide swath of the economy.
Second, the actual investments themselves would be done by private managers, who would commingle funds for Social Security with those from private investors.
There is very little point in considering anything but index funds, which are going to do about as well as other funds and make more sense from an economic point of view. And if you move away from them, politics starts to enter into the equation.
Q. There are all sorts of index funds. What kinds would you favor?
A. I don't think one should consider an index fund any narrower than the Standard & Poor's 500. One could actually mix a little bit, from the S.& P. out to the Russell 3000.
 
Q. Why are you indisposed to the idea of individual accounts?
 
A. There are four reasons why I think using individual accounts as a substitute for Social Security is a nonstarter.
First, high administrative costs, which eat into returns. Risk is Point No. 2. With a defined benefit program, ups and downs get smoothed out. For individuals, market moves are much more pronounced.
The third point, one that has been raised by people like Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is that a system of individual accounts would require a massive education effort, which is expensive. And the potential for fraud in that sort of a system is massive. Point 4 is that over time people are going to be living longer. Individual accounts cut benefits. When you hit the retirement age, you look at what you can tap. The longer you live, the less you get out of any fixed sum.
 
Q. You have been studying the issues surrounding Social Security for a quarter of a century. Have other countries decided to invest public retirement money in stocks?
 
A. Canada has started to implement a diversified portfolio, which I think is a good idea. The Norwegians invest some of their oil revenues abroad through the central bank. But most European countries have much worse problems with their systems than we do. They are not running budget surpluses, so they are not raising the issue.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Trial's War of Economists Pits Student Against Teacher

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
FOR the last few weeks the Microsoft antitrust trial has heard warring economists provide sweeping overviews of each side's case. These two particular economists have a history.
The Government's witness, Franklin M. Fisher of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was the thesis adviser of the chief Microsoft economics witness, Richard L. Schmalensee, also of M.I.T. Perhaps that is why Mr. Schmalensee appears to take impish delight in poking fun at his mentor. 
 Mr. Fisher challenges Microsoft's decision to imbed its browser -- the software that connects computers to the Internet -- into its Windows operating system, which has a more than 90 percent share of the market. His case, Mr. Schmalensee says, boils down to arguing that "consumers will be made better off if they are deprived, by court order, of Web-browsing functionality that Microsoft wishes to provide at zero marginal cost and that consumers are free to ignore or replace." Put that way, the Government's case does sound vapid.
Not so, counters Mr. Fisher. He traces the steps by which Microsoft crossed the line between fierce competition and illegality. Microsoft, he argues, has attempted to use its Windows monopoly to seize control of the market for browsers. The threat is not merely that Microsoft will wrest the browser market away from the current leader, Netscape Communications. Worse, he says, Microsoft might well use browser domination to eliminate competition in operating systems.
The latest browsers have the potential to replace the operating system as the platform from which computers run word processors and other applications programs. With a browser like Netscape's that can work with many operating systems, a user might eventually be able to do without Windows. Microsoft perceived the threat and, Mr. Fisher argues, pounced.
First, it bundled its browser with Windows without charge and forced computer makers to sign contracts prohibiting them from substituting Netscape's browser for Microsoft's. These contracts cut Netscape off from one large channel of distribution.
Next, Microsoft wrote contracts with Internet companies like America Online, putting short cuts to their Web sites in a prominent spot on Windows computers in exchange for the companies' tilting their customers toward Microsoft's browser. These contracts cut Netscape off from another distribution channel.
Mr. Fisher's point is that these contracts did not benefit consumers, though they did hurt Netscape. He challenges Microsoft's decision to give away its browser, labeling the zero price "predatory" -- set to lose money in the short run just to drive a competitor out of business. So what appears to be a wondrous gift to consumers is in fact a manipulative ploy to protect Window's monopoly position.
The antitrust laws permit Microsoft to prosper by selling superior products. They do not allow a monopolist like Microsoft, Mr. Fisher argues, to use expensive tactics that serve only to impose costs on potential rivals. With Microsoft behaving that way, it is hard for entrepreneurs who want to develop a rival product to find financial backing. So by crushing competition, Microsoft crushes innovation -- a dire threat to consumers.
It would be a compelling argument, except for one inconvenient fact. When asked during cross-examination whether Microsoft's tactics had harmed consumers, Mr. Fisher said, "On balance, I'd think that the answer is no up to this point." This was not, however, a devastating admission, since. under the antitrust laws, the Government doesn't have to prove that consumers have been harmed, only that Microsoft's tactics pose a substantial threat of harm.
MR. SCHMALENSEE labels his former teacher's ruminations about consumer harm "sheer speculation." Microsoft keeps the price of Windows low and steadily improves the product, he says, and its contracts have not shut Netscape off from potential customers. In fact, the number of users of Netscape's browser increased by about 20 million from early 1996 to last fall.
Mr. Schmalensee stingingly accuses his teacher of elementary error. Microsoft's zero price for the browser cannot be labeled predatory, he argues, because even at a zero price, the browser makes money by bolstering sales of Windows and other products.
Yet Mr. Schmalensee's testimony falls flat in key places, too. He breathlessly asserts that bundling the browser with Windows helps consumers. But Mr. Fisher's complaint is less with the bundling than with the no-substitution contracts and the fact that Microsoft made the technical task of replacing its browser with Netscape's needlessly difficult. Mr. Schmalensee says that Netscape enjoys ample distribution channels, but Mr. Fisher's point is that Microsoft's contracts deny Netscape the most lucrative ones.
So who wins this battle of wits? Mr. Fisher has made a compelling case that Microsoft's tactics are illegally anticompetitive. Mr. Schmalensee has made the case that the threat of harm is speculative. That may leave the court to rule cautiously in favor of the Government, but to tread even more cautiously when it designs remedies.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Phillip N. Davidson;
American Century Value

BYLINE: By WILLIAM R. LONG 

 BODY:
WHAT is a nice mid-cap value fund like this doing in an aggressive growth family like American Century?
American Century Value, managed by Phillip N. Davidson since its inception, was started in 1993 in an effort to "round out" the family of funds of the Kansas City, Mo., company, he said. "They had been incredibly successful, and just wanted to diversify their offerings to their shareholders and in the 401(k) market," Mr. Davidson added. 
 Sticking to his mandate, Mr. Davidson has followed a strict value discipline that is sharply divergent from the more aggressive style of American Century's better-known growth funds. Unfortunately, the bull market has been far more generous to large-capitalization growth stocks than to the mid-cap value category. In 1998, American Century Value returned just 5.0 percent, compared with 26.67 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500 index of large-cap stocks.
Still, Mr. Davidson can take consolation in average three-year annualized returns of 24.8 percent through Jan. 15, well above the median 22.9 percent for the mid-cap value category. And he thinks that funds like his will soon bounce back.
Mr. Davidson, 43, his co-manager, R. Todd Vingers, and his three senior analysts use computer screening to look at all American stocks with market capitalizations above $1 billion. The screens rank stock prices in relation to earnings, book value, dividend yield, cash flow and debt-adjusted cash flow. ("The more debt a company has, the more operating cash flow it has to have to be as attractive," he said.)
To qualify for consideration by the fund, he said, a company must be in the cheapest one-third of the market on at least two of the five screens. Generally, 250 or 300 stocks qualify, and most are in the mid-cap category, which he defines as a market value of $1 billion to $6 billion.
"Then you go through and start doing individual company analysis," Mr. Davidson said. He looks for companies that are leaders in their industries but that are temporarily out of favor because of, say, a temporary dip in earnings.
The fund, with total assets of $2.17 billion, usually holds 65 to 70 stocks, about 60 percent of them mid-caps. Generally, once a stock's price rises to the point that it no longer meets two of the five value criteria, Mr. Davidson sells.
A case in point is J. C. Penney. Mr. Davidson bought the stock in the spring of 1997 at about $45, then sold it last year as the price approached $70. Penney climbed close to $80 last June before it started dropping, the victim of weak sales.
Penney "didn't fall back into our own valuation screens until the low $50's" in the third quarter, Mr. Davidson said, when the fund started buying it again. The shares closed Friday at $39.875. "The primary play here is that they have the traditional department store -- it's basically no growth, but a nice cash cow -- and then they got the Eckerd drugstores acquisition" in 1997, which should bolster company earnings, he said.
Not all stocks in Mr. Davidson's fund turn over as quickly as Penney. Take the Mercantile Bancorporation, which it has owned since 1994 and is now the fund's biggest holding, at 4.9 percent of the portfolio. Mercantile is the dominant bank in the St. Louis market and No. 2 in Kansas City. It has built up its market share with acquisitions.
When Mr. Davidson started buying the stock in 1994, at $20 a share, "it was a cheap stock with a good retail deposit base," he said. "And basically, what happened is all that stuff just got better when they made these acquisitions." But the acquisitions slowed earnings growth.
As Mercantile's shares slid below $40 last summer, pulling down American Century Value's returns, Mr. Davidson bought more. The stock closed Friday at $44.8125, still down from a high near $60 early last year. The acquisitions will ultimately benefit the bank, he said.
NOTHER company whose acquisition shows promise, Mr. Davidson said, is Tyson Foods, the poultry company based in Springdale, Ark. Since completing the purchase of the rival Hudson Foods last January, Tyson controls about 30 percent of the domestic chicken market, he said.
Tyson stock rose with the acquisition, then came down as weakness in foreign economies undermined exports and higher grain prices pushed up costs. Mr. Davidson said he started buying the stock early in 1998 at $18 and $19 a share. The price fluctuated during the year, and he increased his position during the summer's general selloff. Tyson closed Friday at $20.50. Mr. Davidson expects it to rise considerably more than the stock market this year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
U.S.A. Accounts Are New Volley in Retirement Savings Debate

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
IN his State of the Union address and, again, before a roaring crowd in Buffalo, President Clinton last week floated the idea of Universal Savings Accounts, a new type of subsidized savings for low- and moderate-income workers akin to a 401(k) plan. The Government would use 11 percent of the projected budget surplus to match money the workers would save on their own in the U.S.A.'s.
At first blush, the plan appears designed to appeal to both political parties. It is intended to help workers at the low end of the spectrum who now have only Social Security at retirement. That should appeal to Democrats. For Republicans, there is the draw that these accounts would be controlled by individuals, not the Government. 
 Whether the President's plan will get bipartisan support, or any support at all, is unknown. Right now, the U.S.A. proposal is high in concept and low in details, and the Administration says it will not have more specifics for at least a month. In general, though, both liberal and conservative economists say they find such accounts an intriguing way to increase the savings rate. They also say the proposal is another volley in a larger debate about investing Government retirement funds in the market.
Still, basic questions remain. Is this the best way to spend part of the budget surplus? How would the matching formula work? What can the savings accounts be used for? How may the money be invested? And will the public support a new Government program that redistributes wealth to lower-income citizens?
"These accounts are still a very nebulous concept," said Steve Moore, director of fiscal policies at the Cato Institute, a free-market research group in Washington. "I like the idea of setting up savings accounts. We want to create a culture of savings in this country. But it's bad in the way it's done. It looks more like a new entitlement program than an I.R.A. I don't see the rationale of creating a new income distribution program."
THE Administration envisions the program, which would cost nearly $500 billion over 15 years, or $33 billion a year, as offering $100 grants to workers to start accounts. The Government would then match workers' contributions at a variable rate based on income. About 100 million Americans who earn less than $80,000 to $100,000 a year -- the precise cutoff has not been set -- would be eligible for the accounts.
"The basic idea is to get more people to do more saving on their own," said an Administration spokesman. "There are so many things to help the rich save. We think there is a big hole in savings at the low end."
Currently, 41 percent of all workers earn less than $15,000 a year; of those, only 8 percent have a retirement program at their workplaces, according to the Employee Benefits Research Institute, a Washington research group.
The match rate for the new accounts would be progressive, with the lowest-paid getting the most. The investment options would be modeled closely after the Federal employees' Thrift Savings Plan, which offers three Government-run investment funds -- a stock index fund, a bond index fund and a Treasury bill fund.
For example, the Administration said a worker earning $40,000 a year could deposit up to $600 a year. At that income level the Government would match 50 cents on the dollar, providing $300 more to the account. Counting the $100 starting grant, that comes to $1,000 in the first year, $400 of it from the Government.
Bruce Thompson, a Washington representative for Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest broker, praised the plan as "opening the door to private investments."
Still, Merrill and other Wall Street firms would prefer that the Government use a portion of Social Security payroll taxes to finance the accounts, rather than using the budget surplus, and would like the program to be open to workers of all income levels. Mr. Thompson said he was concerned about how the accounts would be financed when the budget surplus ends.
"We would rather see all people given the option of investing a portion of their payroll taxes, maybe one or two percentage points, in accounts that would be similar to I.R.A.'s, and invest that money however they see fit," Mr. Thompson said. This idea is similar to one proposed by some Republicans as an alternative to President Clinton's plan to strengthen Social Security by allowing the Government to invest in stocks.
OTHER sellers of investments had little to say, for the moment. "We don't have enough information to judge yet," said John Collins, a spokesman for the Investment Company Institute, the trade association for the mutual fund industry. In general, brokers and mutual fund companies want the opportunity to sell investment products to U.S.A.'s, but worry that a program restricted to lower-income people would result in many small accounts with low balances, which are costly for brokers to administer.
Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution, wants to see the funds less restricted in another way: what savings can be used for. "Done right, U.S.A. accounts are a very good idea," Mr. Aaron said, but the money should be available for more than just retirement -- education, medical care, down payments on first homes and and business start-ups, for example.
"This could be a device to help make savings fashionable and educate people on the power of compound interest," he said, adding that U.S.A.'s are much "sweeter" for lower-income people than are individual retirement accounts, which offer only a tax deduction.
Daniel Mitchell, a senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group, also reacted favorably to the plan, though with reservations. "I'm not sure what these accounts offer that isn't already out there in the market," Mr. Mitchell said. "I like that Clinton recognizes that private investment is the key. But it will not succeed unless we put a chunk of the payroll taxes into it, because the poor will not be able to build up a good balance. They cannot use disposable income for this because they don't have enough."

HEADLINE: Make Way For Grown-Ups

BYLINE: By MARCIA BIEDERMAN 

 BODY:
HEY, gang! Guess what kind of adult entertainment is hot -- and legal -- in New York these days. Give up? It's puppetry. Gaining more respect as an art form, puppetry seems to promise wider audiences, higher esteem and perhaps bigger money for a tight-knit group of city artists.
New productions and new marketing strategies are bringing in the grown-ups. "There are people, who, if you say 'Punch and Judy' they'll run, but if you say 'experimental theater,' they'll flock to it," said Peter Lewis, the coordinator of the Lenny Suib Puppet Playhouse at Asphalt Green, a private recreational center on the Upper East Side. 
 The buzz nowadays is about African masks and Indonesian influences rather than marionettes and hand puppets. Audiences sip wine instead of apple juice at intermission, and nobody fights for seats on the rug. After Disney's hit Broadway production of "The Lion King," whose puppets by the director Julie Taymor captivated critics and audiences, and the sellout success of four international puppet theater festivals in New York since 1992, puppet artists are sounding wired.
"There is a truly fascinating explosion of imagination in the field," said Theodora Skipitares, a Manhattan artist whose avant-garde puppet work, "Body of Crime II," a history of women's imprisonment, will be presented by La Mama Experimental Theater Club in the East Village this spring. Ms. Skipitares, a sculptor who began to work with puppets in the early 1980's, is one of many visual artists who have leaped onto the puppet stage.
From Broadway to the tiny theaters that showcase avant-garde productions, more puppets seem to be popping up. A Broadway show scheduled to open in March, "Band in Berlin," about a singing group that was persecuted by the Nazis, will include shadow puppets by Stephen Kaplin, an artist from Jackson Heights, Queens, who has worked with Ms. Taymor. A production of "Peter and Wendy" by the New York theater group Mabou Mines uses actors and puppets and explores the darker side of James Barrie's novelization of his play "Peter Pan," according to the playwright who adapted it, Liza Lorwin. The show is going to the Berkeley Repertory Theater in California. Meanwhile, members of the Crowtations, a group that has drawn crowds in Central Park for years with its crow puppets, say backers have expressed interest in an Off Broadway show they are developing.
Many people in the puppetry world link the boom to the rising fortunes of Ms. Taymor, a former member of downtown's avant-garde puppet scene who has won a Tony award and a MacArthur fellowship, which is given to people of exceptional creativity. They also credit the Jim Henson Foundation, which gives grants to puppet artists and, more importantly, has helped find new audiences for the form by using savvy marketing to present international festivals. The key, said Leslee Asch, executive director of the foundation and producing director of the International Festival of Puppet Theater, was freeing puppets of the "stigma" of "bad kids' shows."
Puppetry also has an economic appeal for nonprofit theaters with limited budgets and for artists trying to break into theater. "Puppetry allows you to enact an entire war on a tiny stage," said Ms. Skipitares, a miniaturist who has used 300 puppets in a single show. "You can do it in your room, and the sky's the limit."
Far from feeling slighted by the new emphasis on adult audiences, the traditional puppeteers -- those who work with marionettes and hand puppets -- expect to catch the wave. "It's bound to trickle down to us," said Nick Coppola, who runs a marionette theater for children in Park Slope called Puppetworks. Membership in the Puppetry Guild of Greater New York, most of whose members are traditional professionals and amateurs, is now 120, a high mark in the last two decades, said Steven Widerman, a member and past president.
Yet with all the excitement over how "The Lion King" has brought puppet art into the mainstream, the question is whether puppetry will remain there or return to the fringe. Can this form of theater, much of it created by artists without training in drama, continue to attract money and audiences? Will the avant-garde practitioners of puppetry continue to coexist peacefully with the traditional children's entertainers? Experimental and traditional puppeteers often provide work for one another. But puppetry has elevated itself largely by shoving the kids' stuff into the closet.
The war room where the fight for adult minds is planned is Ms. Asch's office at the Jim Henson Company, on East 69th Street in Manhattan. The foundation was begun 17 years ago by Mr. Henson, the creator of the Muppets, who died in 1990. Mr. Henson "didn't want people to be forced into the mold of doing work like his," Ms. Asch said. "He wanted people to find their own voices." These days, Ms. Asch is busy planning next year's festival. Many offerings are "dark and serious" works, she said, as she offered a visitor coffee in a Kermit mug. Even the lighter fare, she added, is both "playful and empowering."
The festival has sold out every event since it began, expanding from the Public Theater, its sole venue in 1992, to 12 others for last September's 28 productions, Ms. Asch said. The Henson foundation raised $1.8 million for last year's festival, which drew an audience of 28,000, she said; it raised $1 million for the first one, which attracted 13,000 theatergoers.
About half the festival's productions are American, Ms. Asch said, with New York artists "in the forefront." And, she said, theatergoers are realizing that 80 percent of the shows are aimed at adults. (To make sure they understand that, festival brochures offer the equivalent of parental advisories.)
Does the ubiquitous presence of puppetry for children make it more difficult to attract adult audiences for puppet theater? No, Ms. Asch said. A former puppet designer and builder for "Sesame Street" and "The Muppet Show," she said, "I don't think that just people who work with adults are artists, and those who work with children are not."
Nevertheless, in the past, she said, "if you said you were a puppeteer, people would do this." She formed her hand into a jabbering creature and made a high-pitched squeal. Those days seem to be ending, she noted with relief. But if Ms. Asch still harbors concerns about bad traditional puppetry undermining her painstaking work, there are those who worry about the other end of the spectrum.
"I feel the avant-garde people could use a lot more craft," said Jonathan Edward Cross, who is himself part of the avant-garde. His Cosmic Bicycle Theater, which has performed at the Henson festival, combines actors, puppets and masks in original works like "Venus Envy," about goddess worship and lust, as well as classical ones like "The Miser," by Moliere.
Mr. Cross, 30, operates his tiny Clockworks Experimental Puppetry Theater out of a storefront and basement on East 12th Street. He said he has been dismayed by avant-garde shows in which puppet pieces fly off. In one, he recalled, an electrical fire started, then was compounded by an attempt to extinguish it with water. "I feel you should make something solid," he said.
Though he and others involved in puppetry in New York expressed admiration for Peter Schumann, the founder of the Bread and Puppet Theater, which started in New York in the 1960's and later moved to Vermont, Mr. Cross is less impressed by imitators of Mr. Schumann, whose giant puppets, long a favorite on college campuses and at political protests, are often crude cardboard affairs. "I feel the anti-craft movement has gone far enough," he said.
It was partly to perfect his own skills that he worked with Mr. Widerman, a traditionalist whose Puppet Company performs on weekends at Asphalt Green for family audiences, doing shows like "Al E. Gator's Surprise Party." While that seems like a far cry from Mr. Cross's work -- one is "Thanatopsis," which he described as "a meditation on death" -- Mr. Cross said he had much to learn from Mr. Widerman, who can perform virtuoso feats with marionettes, like having one roller-skate.
Another person who straddles the genres is Jim Bowen, 28. By day he works in Brooklyn with Mr. Coppola's marionettes at Puppetworks and sometimes substitutes at Central Park's marionette theater, the Swedish Cottage. By night he often performs his own political hand-puppet show at the 37th Street Theater's open mike evenings or at ABC No Rio, a Lower East Side performance space.
"Some of the avant-garde stuff tends to get really self-indulgent," Mr. Bowen said. "People are giving you a biography of their life, not a narrative. It's like an ego out of control." He added, "There sometimes tends to be a disregard for the audience." Children, he said, would never let a puppeteer get away with that.
But both he and Mr. Cross were enthusiastic about the growing recognition of puppetry as an art form. Mr. Cross, who came to New York to study puppetry with Ralph Lee, the 63-year-old puppeteer who started the Greenwich Village Halloween parade and is still active in the field, said he thought puppet art was "where theater is headed."
New York University's Tisch School of the Arts recently began to offer a course for actors who want to perform with puppets. Initially, students could not see the reason for the course, said John Bell, who teaches it. "People said, 'If I'm going to do Mamet, why do I need this?' he said. But eventually, they realized "that if you're going to work Off Broadway, or even on Broadway, there are puppets all over the place."
Still, for all of the interest in puppetry, few places train artists from other disciplines who want to enter the field. For them, and for established puppet artists who lack studios, the Arts at St. Ann's, in Brooklyn Heights, operates a weekly puppet lab where ideas and power tools are shared.
Other types of artists who have decided to embrace puppetry have a role model in Janie Geiser, who directed the puppet lab until recently, when the California Institute of the Arts, in Valencia, recruited her to teach in its new $600,000 puppetry center. Initially a visual artist, Ms. Geiser became a big name on the New York avant-garde puppet scene, receiving many grants and awards, including a Guggenheim fellowship.
How do painters and illustrators learn theater, in which visuals are only one element and audiences expect drama? Dan Hurlin, who now leads the St. Ann's lab, said some visual artists found themselves stymied by the challenge. "I'm putting them in touch with directors and writers," he said. As for writers who have trouble making puppets, Mr. Hurlin suggested they try manipulating photocopied images. The traditional separation of actors, directors, set designers and technicians in theater doesn't apply to puppetry, at least his kind, he said.
But puppet theater's new directions sometimes require explaining. Ms. Lorwin, the playwright who adapted "Peter and Wendy" for Mabou Mines, said the play puzzled some potential backers. "We went to people who fund the avant-garde, and they didn't understand," she said. But foundations known for financing mainstream shows "instantly recognized it as experimental," she said.
Ms. Lorwin said some producers were put off because some of the puppets in "Peter and Wendy" are only 18 inches tall, so the show cannot be presented in a large theater where many seats can be sold. Yet the production is complex and expensive, she said, with seven puppeteers, a full band "and numerous people backstage."
Limited seating is an even bigger problem for toy theater, a form in which both Ms. Geiser and Mr. Cross work. Toy theater uses dollhouse-size stages and puppets, and can only be viewed in small spaces. It is a 19th-century form that has been promoted by Great Small Works, a Manhattan theater company of which Dr. Bell, the N.Y.U. instructor, is a member.
It's a safe bet that toy theater isn't headed for Broadway. But, Dr. Bell said, that should not be the measure of an art form's success. "I don't think that's the only goal of doing theater," he said, adding that he did not view the New York avant-garde puppet scene as much more active now than it has been for the last 20 years.
The difference, he said, is the mass recognition given to Ms. Taymor and Basil Twist, whose innovative puppet piece "Symphonie Fantastique" is in the ninth month of a critically acclaimed run at Here, a South Village performance space. And the popularity of puppets on Broadway has meant more work for people in the field, Dr. Bell said.
Yet many New York puppet artists still seem to be struggling. Many earn a living by making props, doing educational projects and, yes, entertaining the kiddies. Mr. Cross said much of his company's income has come from puppet festivals abroad. He recently returned from performing in France, as did Ms. Skipitares, the sculptor-turned-puppet-artist. "It's hard to come back to New York," she said, because puppetry is more widely accepted as a serious art form in Europe.
Brad Brewer, who founded the Crowtations puppet ensemble 26 years ago, said his group has performed with jazz musicians in nightclubs in Germany, where its work is considered adult fare. He is hopeful that grown-ups in New York will take the same attitude. Ten years ago, the Crowtations occasionally performed in after-hours clubs in the city, and as Mr. Brewer remembered it, the adults responded just like kids. "If you closed your eyes and listened to them," he said, "you couldn't tell the difference."

Puppeteers famous for children's entertainment have also done more highbrow work aimed at adults. Some examples:
 
Bil Baird -- His marionettes, including Charlemane the Lion, were television regulars in the 1950's and 1960's. But he also directed a 1983 puppet version of Igor Stravinsky's "L'Histoire du Soldat" at the 92d Street Y and created artistically acclaimed full-length works for puppets.
 He and his wife, Cora, founded the Bil Baird theater on Barrow Street in Greenwich Village in 1966. The theater's aim, Baird said in a 1968 letter to a friend, was "to make it a popular thing for adults to attend live puppet theater." But he also expressed concern that inferior work by other puppeteers would undercut such efforts.
 
Marty Robinson -- The performer behind Telly Monster, the anxious Muppet. He also created an hour-long puppet piece, "Jackstraws," under the name Martin P. Robinson, which was presented last week at the National Puppetry Conference in Manhattan.
 
Donald Sahlin -- The builder of Bert and Ernie, the Muppet odd couple of "Sesame Street," he did a series of baroque operas with puppets.
 
Jim Henson -- He created the Muppets, but he also directed an experimental short film, "Timepiece," with actors and objects, that preceded the Oscar-winning 1966 French movie "A Man and a Woman" in cinemas. He worked with noted movie directors on a series of folk tales that included his 1987 short film "The Soldier and Death," and he created puppet works for adults that followed the Huntley-Brinkley news programs on the NBC television network.

HEADLINE: GRASS ROOTS BUSINESS;
A Place To Please The Techies

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com.

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif.

 BODY:
AFTER just three years, the founders of the hot high-technology start-up were bumping against a familiar problem. They knew they had maxed out the potential of the backwater burg where they had founded the company. To keep attracting the number and caliber of skilled employees they needed, they had to move the company to where the action was.
Yes, it was time for Broadcom to forsake sleepy little Los Angeles and make its mark in the high-technology metropolis of Irvine, an hour's drive south. 
 "We were reaching a critical mass; we had to go somewhere that's suited to building a big high-tech company," explained Henry T. Nicholas, who with Henry Samueli started Broadcom, a communications chip and cable modem maker, in 1992 when the two men were professors at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Mr. Nicholas, Broadcom's chief executive, says he misses the city's night life and cultural ambiance. But, recalling how hard it was to recruit people to move to Los Angeles, he felt he had little choice. "It's hard to relocate techies to L.A.," he said. "It's the congestion, expensive housing -- and there's a certain stigma to it."
Irvine, on the other hand, is what you might call a nerdistan: a suburban enclave of subdivisions, shopping centers and business parks where scientists, engineers and technicians feel comfortable living and working. For technology companies, it is everything a traditional urban center should be but isn't: a strategic location where the relevant partners, competitors, money and knowhow are all close at hand.
Most nerdistans have appeared on leafy peripheries of metropolitan areas, close to major airports, universities and science-based industries but far from inner-city problems and annoyances. High concentrations of technology workers and companies have flocked together in suburbs of Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles, New York and Philadelphia, in the Research Triangle area of North Carolina, and in Silicon Valley, the original and still champion nerdistan.
Like Irvine, most nerdistans are less bedroom communities than what the Purdue University historian Jon C. Teaford calls post-suburbia -- economically and culturally self-sufficient areas that ring traditional core cities but are largely insulated from them. This pattern is clear in sprawling Los Angeles County, which leads the nation in the number of high-technology jobs but ranks 15th in technology workers as a share of the work force, according to a study by researchers at WEFA, an economic research organization; neighboring Orange County, where Irvine is, ranks seventh. A map of Los Angeles County's technology companies finds a vast majority in peripheral areas miles from the center of the city.
Similarly, despite media buzz about Silicon Alley, most technology jobs in the New York City area are in the suburbs, not in Manhattan. The periphery's share of the region's computer-related jobs grew to more than 80 percent in 1996 from 68 percent in 1982, according to a study at the University of Miami. Sections of Fairfield County, Conn., and northwestern New Jersey rank among the top 15 places in the country for most technology workers per capita; New York City ranks 80th, according to WEFA.
NERDISTANS can also be defined by what they generally do not have, said John Kasarda of the University of North Carolina. There are no ports or railroad yards, but technology work does not require them. There are no venerable art museums or symphony orchestras, but technology workers generally do not miss such amenities. And there are usually no homeless people or derelict buildings in sight.
"You get rid of the problems of the city by charging for the exits," said Mr. Kasarda, who has studied the movement of high-technology companies in the Raleigh-Durham area and elsewhere. "For these people, the city is superfluous."
Once they get started, nerdistans snowball. Richard Holcomb, president of the Raleigh-based Haht Software, said the presence of a herd of big technology companies like Data General, I.B.M. and Burroughs-Wellcome provides a pool of seasoned workers for start-ups to tap. "You can get a great job, and if this one doesn't work out, you can just go down the road," he said.
Given the technology sector's generally high pay, nerdistans are evolving into centers of wealth, with demographics to match. In Irvine, which is also home to a University of California campus, almost two-fifths of households earn more than $75,000 a year, and more than half the adult population is college-educated, compared with one-fifth for the country as a whole. Not quite as "white bread" as its reputation, Irvine has a population of 122,000 that is 70 percent Caucasian and 22 percent Asian.
Not all nerdistans are alike, though. Older, unplanned centers like Silicon Valley and southwestern Connecticut are becoming victims of their own success, plagued by congestion, housing shortages and struggling public schools. Newer planned communities like Irvine and the Research Triangle seem to be coping better, Mr. Kasarda said. And that translates into a competitive advantage in recruiting scientists and engineers, especially those with children.
"It's a very planned place," said Nancy Venable, a technology support engineer and divorced mother of a teen-age girl who moved last year from Charlotte, N.C., to take a job at Wonderware, a factory automation company based in Irvine. "You don't have to join an association to get to a pool, and everything has been placed close to where you live. The schools are good. It's safe, it's clean, it's easy to get around, and it's new. Engineers love new tools."

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
A Delicate Family Affair

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
BABY boomers seem to be focused on three economic issues: their homes, their retirements and their children's college educations. But a fourth potential drain on their resources tends to sneak up on them: their parents.
The parents of the baby boom generation are getting older, and may not be prepared for the financial strains of declining health. Last month, President Clinton proposed a $1,000-a-year tax credit for the chronically ill and, in some cases, for relatives who care for them, but that would hardly dent most such health care bills. 
 "Our generation doesn't have a clue to what caring for a parent is all about," said Virginia Morris, author of "How to Care for Aging Parents" (Workman Publishing, 1996). "I think in the next 10 years we're all going to get a shock. Not only are people living longer now, but living longer with disabilities."
How do you know if your parents have adequate insurance and savings to handle a medical crisis? And how do you ask? My parents are in their mid-70's and very independent. How much should I pry? And should a "That's none of your business" be allowed to end the discussion? True, it is none of my business right now, but it may become my business if, say, my father has a stroke and my mother is overwhelmed by the demands of caring for him. In that case, I wouldn't hesitate to open my wallet, even at the expense of my four children.
But I would like to avoid having to make such a choice. My parents tell me they're fine, and I don't doubt their sincerity. But do I know how much they have in reserve or how extensively they have planned? No, and I have never asked. For many families, it's the same: "Don't ask, don't tell."
Michael P. Mayko, 44, of Milford, Conn., never asked. His parents are in their 80's, and when his father developed Alzheimer's disease, Mr. Mayko helped his mother care for him. Then his mother had a heart attack, and overnight he became responsible for the care of both parents. Today, he spends some mornings before work and much of his time on weekends at their house a few towns away. And while his parents can still cover most of their health care costs, Mr. Mayko knows their funds are limited.
"I saw it coming, but I tried to keep it out of my mind," Mr. Mayko said. "They had no wills and made no arrangements for long-term care. Now, I'm making decisions on their lives that I'm not comfortable making."
For Angela Scott, 46, of Sag Harbor, N.Y., it wasn't so sudden. One day her mother turned to her and said, "I think I'm getting Alzheimer's disease." She was right. Her mother moved in with her, but now requires constant care. While their mother had some savings and insurance, Ms. Scott and her two siblings are still stuck with bills totaling tens of thousands of dollars a year.
"We realize we can't afford to keep her at home much longer, so we will have to place her in a nursing home," Ms. Scott said. "Financially, there isn't a choice. I'm dreading that day."
Ms. Morris, the author, says she doesn't think people realize how expensive care can be. "Average nursing home care is $40,000 a year, but you can easily spend $80,000," she said. She added that children need to discuss finances with their parents early, before they become ill, vulnerable and frightened. The best way to begin the conversation, she said, is to simply ask them about their goals.
"Ask them what are their concerns, what are their worries," Ms. Morris said. "The big issue is where are they going to live if they need long-term care. It lets them take the conversation where they feel safe. You'll have to bring it up a couple of times. You're not going to sit down in one conversation and sort this out."
SOME sensitive topics to address, she said, are whether the parents have or should buy long-term care insurance; who should have power of attorney over their affairs, if that becomes necessary; whether they have made a "living will" naming someone to make medical decisions for them when they are unable; what estate planning they have done, and what Medicare and Medicaid benefits they can expect.
Parents might refuse to discuss any of this with their children, or may be willing to talk with one child but not another. For those who prefer to talk with an outsider, suggest that they consult with a financial planner or a lawyer specializing in elder law. The Institute of Certified Financial Planners (800 282-7526 or www.icfp.org) will provide you with a free list of certified planners in your area. The National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys (520 881-4005 or www.naela.org) sells directories for $15 that list its members by region.
"Soon, our parents are going to be the dinner-table conversation," Ms. Morris said. "When we say 'day care,' we won't be talking about our children, we'll be talking about our parents."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
As Rivals Flail, Teardrop Golf Yells Fore and Makes More Deals

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
AS the depth of an industrywide slump the best time to go on an acquisition spree?
Teardrop Golf thinks so. The club maker, which is known mainly for its Teardrop putter, has been busily rolling up small golf businesses while bigger competitors like Callaway Golf and Adams Golf have been bleeding money. 
In its two years as a public company, Teardrop has acquired two well-known but ailing manufacturers, Tommy Armour Golf and RAM Golf, as well as a golf tour for aspiring PGA Tour players that now bears the Teardrop name. And it is still on the prowl. It lost out to Golfsmith International in the bidding for the assets of Lynx Golf, a bankrupt Canadian company, when the price topped $9 million. But in the process, Teardrop picked up Lynx's endorsement contract with Fred Couples, the marquee player who is now Teardrop's top spokesman.
Companies usually do not buy in slumps, in part because acquisition binges are hard to finance in tough times. Teardrop remains a small company, with estimated 1998 sales of $65 million. Its market capitalization of $27 million isn't big enough to be on the radar of major Wall Street analysts or institutional investors. Teardrop is expected to post a modest net income of $2.2 million for 1998 after a loss in 1997, and its margins suffered lately as it slashed prices on some models to clear away backlogged inventory. As a result, Teardrop's ability to finance acquisitions from its own resources is limited.
Nor is paying with common stock, the currency of choice in technology deals, so easy for Teardrop. Its stock price is stuck in a sand trap, closing on Friday at $5.25, far off its peak of $14.0625 a share last May, and the market has been unkind to both small-caps and golf stocks for months. Teardrop has included stock in several deals but has yet to make an all-stock acquisition.
That leaves borrowing, and Teardrop has loaded up on debt. At the end of the third quarter of 1998, it carried $21.265 million of debt on its balance sheet, equivalent to 34 percent of current assets and more than 127 percent of shareholders' equity -- a level of leverage that leaves Teardrop vulnerable if things do not go as smoothly as planned.
Moreover, the cash demands don't end when the ink is dry on an acquisition. Teardrop is also spending heavily on advertising and marketing to "reinvigorate the companies and recreate the ambiance that these companies are here to stay," said Rudy A. Slucker, chief executive of Teardrop, which has corporate headquarters in Morton Grove, Ill., and executive offices in Union, N.J.
Mr. Slucker says Teardrop's stock has been depressed by "the Callaway syndrome," referring to the problems of Callaway Golf, the behemoth of the $2.5 billion golf equipment industry. As industrywide club sales slid 10 percent to 20 percent last year, Callaway dismissed its chief executive, laid off 700 employees -- a quarter of its work force -- and closed several noncore ventures. Investors reacted by bidding down most golf stocks.
But Teardrop thinks it can sidestep Callaway's problems. In 1999, "we'll either lose a little or make a little," Mr. Slucker said.
"Even if the industry has a terrible year, we believe we'll have a fair year," he added.
Analysts are not so sure.
"It's debatable whether they will escape the inventory bubble in the industry," said Shawn Milne, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco. Mr. Milne expects golf club sales to grow about 5 percent in 1999 from a weak 1998 and sees a risk of swollen inventory if an expected flood of new products does not entice golfers to buy more. Beth Burnson, an analyst at ABN Amro, said that in a climate of price-cutting, golfers who favor premium brands are unlikely to switch to Teardrop's lines.
Specialty retailers say the company's products are not flying out the door. For instance, sales of Teardrop putters and Armour clubs have been mediocre at the Edwin Watts Golf Shops chain, a retailer based in Fort Walton Beach, Fla., with 46 stores, mainly in the the South, said Edwin Watts, a co-owner of the chain; delivery delays for Armour clubs have not helped.
Still, Mr. Slucker is optimistic about the prospects for his company, even in Asia, where Teardrop expects to begin selling this year despite the region's economic troubles. The reason? The roll-up strategy is beginning to bear fruit, by giving Teardrop a range of brands that can pursue complementary market strategies.
For example, Mr. Slucker has repositioned RAM as a low-priced line to sell in sporting goods chains, discounters and warehouse clubs, where competition is less fierce than in specialty shops. "They can effectively address the mass market and the green-grass market without cannibalizing themselves," said Gar Jackson, executive vice president at Par Valu, a newsletter in Carlsbad, Calif., that tracks golf stocks.
But in a business littered with high-flying small companies flattened by industry selloffs, even Mr. Slucker is hedging his bets.
"I think there may be an opportunity in 1999 for a company that's aggressive and smart and growing," he said. "I'll put my hat in the ring for that one. I'm not saying we can do it, but we'll try."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

While the golf-equipment industry was slipping into the doldrums over the last two years, Rudy Slucker was aggressively buying troubled competitors. Here is a chronology of his deals.

December

Buys Tommy Armour Golf for cash and stock.
 
December
Buys most of the assets of RAM Golf for cash and stock, and assumes some of RAM's debt.
 
1998
 
July
Acquires distribution rights for Walter Genuin golf shoes in the United States and Canada.
 
October
Withdraws a $9 million bid to acquire the bankrupt Lynx Golf but acquires its endorsement contract with the golfer Fred Couples.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
When the Government Plays Investor

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
BY investing $700 billion of the Social Security trust fund's reserves in the stock market, President Clinton hopes to generate enough high-voltage returns to keep the fund solvent into the next century. Alas, the way he wants to do it almost insures failure.
There is no doubt the fund needs some zip. It is now invested in United States Government securities -- the safest investment, but not the highest yielding. During the 1980's, annual returns averaged 4.8 percent. 
 Mr. Clinton's plan bogs down when it hands over investment decisions to the Government rather than to individuals. History shows that public investors do not behave as profitably as private investors do.
A World Bank study of government-managed retirement plans found that during the 1980's, they generally underperformed privately managed plans. Annual losses ranged from 37.4 percent in Peru's fund to 3.8 percent in Kenya's. Publicly managed funds that eked out gains included Singapore's and Malaysia's, with 3 percent and 4.6 percent, respectively.
Meanwhile, private pension funds in the United States scored average annual returns of 8 percent; Chile's were the top performers, at 9.2 percent.
Underperformance is also typical among state and local pension funds in the United States. A study by Olivia Mitchell, a professor of insurance and risk management at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, and Ping-Lung Hsin of Cornell University found that from 1984 to 1990, while bonds returned an average of 15.5 percent and stocks returned 13.9 percent, the average state or local pension plan gained 11.1 percent.
What explains the lag? The World Bank identified two culprits. One is the tendency to invest too conservatively. The other is the tendency to invest too politically.
Unlike private funds, public portfolio managers can invest in socially desirable projects that may not meet the economic criteria a private investor would demand. An example? Funding a local company, as Connecticut's state employee pension plan did in 1990, when it invested $25 million in the troubled Colt Firearms to keep 925 local jobs from being lost.
But politically charged investments are very often losers. In a study published last fall, John R. Nofsinger, a professor of finance at Marquette University in Milwaukee, compared the returns of funds that held such investments and funds that did not. During three years in the early 1990's, the funds that included politically minded investments underperformed their benchmarks by 2.1 percent on average. Those that did not came out ahead by a hair.
Supporters of the President's plan say an independent board can keep politics out of the Government's investment decisions. Dream on, says Maureen M. Baronian, a stockbroker in West Hartford, Conn., and a former state representative. She sat on the advisory board overseeing Connecticut's investments when it bought into Colt. Ms. Baronian and three other board members voted against the investment, but politics triumphed. "Political considerations are always there," she said. "They may tell you they aren't, but they have to be."
Ms. Baronian was right to object. Colt filed for bankruptcy in 1992, and Connecticut's employees lost their investment.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk
