HEADLINE: The World;
A New Big-Power Race Starts on a Sea of Crude

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

DATELINE: ISTANBUL

 BODY:
WITH the discovery of great energy reserves in countries around the Caspian Sea, a vast new region has catapulted onto the world stage. It not only offers oil companies the prospect of great wealth. It gives outside powers a place to test their strength.
The United States is waging a strong campaign to win decisive influence in the Caspian. So are Russia, Iran and other powers in the region. These grand rivalries have turned the Caspian into the world's newest stage for big-power politics. 
 "We are at the beginning of what will be a massive oil boom," said Stanley T. Escudero, the United States ambassador to Azerbaijan. "It means that Azerbaijan and this whole region are about to emerge as major players in the world energy game, and also as a vitally important area for the whole world."
Officially the United States supports cooperation in the Caspian, saying it wants every country except Iran to prosper. Some American diplomats in the region, however, sense that they are involved in a modern version of the 19th-century Great Game, in which Britain and Russia competed for dominance there.
"This is where we prove we're still the big boy on the block," said one diplomat. "China, Europe, Iran, Russia and all the others want to see if they can take us down. All of our so-called friends and all of our so-called enemies want control of this region."
Today's game is being played out in an intense competition for oil and gas pipeline routes. The nations that win will be able to help shape events in the region for decades to come.
The Clinton Administration is lobbying intensely for an oil pipeline route from Azerbaijan across Georgia and Turkey to the Mediterranean. This would tie Azerbaijan and Georgia to the West and be a boon to Turkey, a key NATO ally. American officials are applying every form of encouragement and pressure they can muster to persuade oil companies to choose it.
The companies are skeptical. They say the American-backed line is far too expensive to build without a subsidy of $1 billion or more. By their calculations, a line across Georgia to the Black Sea would cost less than half as much.
Since oil companies will pay for whatever pipeline is built, they are in the catbird seat, and governments in the Caspian area are fervently wooing them. "In a reversal of history," said Richard Matzke, president of Chevron Overseas Petroleum, "the industry today is showing its potential to drive geopolitical events, rather than be driven by them."
In Washington, meanwhile, some members of Congress warn that the United States must be wary of anti-American forces in the Caspian. They want the Clinton Administration to work with the American oil companies to establish a stronger United States presence.
These legislators support bills like the Silk Road Strategy Act proposed by Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas; it would finance programs in the region ranging from support for independent newspapers to "transfer of excess defense articles."
Critics counter that the United States should not help Caspian countries as long as they reject democracy, especially if a hidden agenda is to smooth the way for big business. Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, has suggested that the Silk Road Act be renamed "the oil and gas interests bill."
 
Russia's Back Yard
Russian leaders are highly suspicious of American ambitions in the Caspian, which they view as a naked power grab. Russia has controlled the region for more than a century and is angry at what it sees as an aggressive American campaign to wrest it away.
"We cannot help seeing the uproar stirred up in some Western countries over the energy resources of the Caspian," President Boris N. Yeltsin told a newspaper interviewer last year. "Some seek to exclude Russia from the game and undermine its interests. The so-called 'pipeline war' in the region is part of this game."
Small amounts of Caspian oil are now being shipped through a Soviet-era pipeline that runs north from Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, to the Russian port of Novorossisk on the Black Sea. Russia proposes that the main export pipeline be built along this route, rather than across Turkey as the United States wants.
A pipeline across Russia would help keep Caspian nations under Moscow's thumb. But leaders of new nations in the region are determined to break free of Russian influence. To do that, they must have an export route that Russia does not control. "I want to be the head of my family," reasoned Ahmed Zeynalov, an Azerbaijani oil executive. "Would you put your neighbor in the position of being able to control your family?"
In addition to this political problem, there are practical ones. The Russian route runs through Chechnya, hardly known for its stability. And even if Caspian oil can be brought across Russia to the Black Sea, no one is certain how it would be sent on from there.
Turkey, suddenly discovering its environmental conscience, says it cannot bear more tanker traffic through the already crowded Bosporus to the Mediterranean. Therefore, Turkish officials say, the only solution is to build a pipeline across their country. But Bulgaria, Romania and Ukraine are offering an alternative: send the oil across the Black Sea to our ports and from there to Western Europe. This option gives oil companies another card to play when they ask Turkey for billion-dollar subsidies.
 
The Lure of Iran
In their hearts, many American oil executives believe the best export route for Caspian oil is through Iran. They cannot choose that route now because sanctions imposed by Congress forbid large investments in Iran. But they refuse to write off the idea, preferring to stall in the hope that the sanctions will collapse.
"Sanctions are a drag on our business position," said Cecil Davidson, operations manager in Turkmenistan for Halliburton International Inc., a supplier of oil and gas equipment. "The competition gains strength because of it. They can operate in Iran and we can't."
Lobbyists for American energy companies are pressing for an end to the sanctions, and some prominent figures in the foreign policy establishment support them. In a speech this month, former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance urged new overtures to Iran. Graham E. Fuller, a Rand Corporation analyst and former C.I.A. official, recently called for "a process of reconciliation" based on "a remarkable number of common interests," including Caspian energy.
Iranian officials have begun courting Western oil and gas companies. "The route through Iran is the most economical, and the companies know this," said Alireza Bikdeli, Iran's Ambassador in Azerbaijan. "They know this region very well, perhaps better than the U.S. Government."
Caspian nations do not share the United States' desire to isolate Iran. They must live as Iran's neighbors, and would rather cooperate than feud. "We'll take into consideration that the United States opposes routes through Iran," said Recepbay Arazov, the oil and gas minister in Turkmenistan, "but we're not scared off."
Oil executives looking for a way to bring their crude out of Azerbaijan have only three or four main alternatives. But huge amounts of oil and gas will also be coming from two countries on the eastern shore of the Caspian, Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan. Competition there involves a much wider group of players.
Turkmenistan has huge reserves of natural gas, but its only export pipeline runs through Russia. Because Russia is itself a gas producer, it refuses to accept competing gas at fair prices. After a bitter argument in 1997, Turkmenistan turned off its spigot.
Now Turkmenistan has gone more than a year without earning a cent from its gas reserves, and it has nothing else to sell. The Government is living on bank loans, mostly from Germany. So President Saparmurat Niyazov is negotiating with Royal/Dutch Shell to build a $4 billion pipeline across Iran to gas-starved Turkey.
"This guy can't wait," said Omer Ertur, the chief United Nations representative in Turkmenistan. "He's in a financial crisis. He's up to his neck in debt and he's paying for a series of colossal projects. If there's no pipeline, there's going to be instability here."
The largest of the new Caspian nations, Kazakhstan, is also hoping to escape from Russia's shadow. Kazakh leaders have approved the construction of an oil pipeline across Russia to the Black Sea, but they also want a non-Russian option. They are pushing for a line under the Caspian to Azerbaijan, from which their oil could be shipped westward to Georgia and beyond.
"Of course Russia will not agree with this project, and will try to block it," said Ermukahmet Ertsybaev, director of the Kazakhstan Institute of Strategic Studies. "It would have a huge political impact. We have been isolated from the world system, and this would be our link to Europe. It would make our independence real, and also the independence of Azerbaijan and Georgia."
Both Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan are also pursuing the idea of building pipelines eastward to China. These lines would be long and expensive, but Chinese leaders remain intrigued by them. They know that a pipeline would pull Central Asia into their sphere of influence, and guarantee energy sources for continued expansion of their economy.
 
Arms Bolster the Claims
Some of the outside powers seeking influence in the Caspian region are using armies to strengthen their positions. Russia maintains bases in Georgia and Armenia. The United States has established a much smaller but nonetheless palpable military presence.
The United States Army has held maneuvers in the region, brought local officers to America for training, and donated patrol boats and other military equipment to friendly regimes. In May the Army and units of the National Guard will stage an international disaster relief exercise, using computers, in Kazakhstan. Azerbaijan has signed a defense cooperation agreement with the United States, and others may follow.
Russia and Iran view these steps as part of a hostile plan to establish American hegemony over the Caspian. Some American experts, however, believe there is enough wealth in the region for everyone.
"If things go well, it would be a tremendous boost to all of the surrounding powers, which are many and formidable," said S. Frederick Starr, chairman of the Central Asia Institute at Johns Hopkins University.
"It would be the best thing that could happen to Russia, because it would lay to rest their imperial hangover," he said. "It would give Iran its traditional role as a trading state. Turkey would find a position for itself among peoples with whom it has a historical connection. China would have a new strategic connection to the West. Pakistan and India would have chances to integrate themselves into an emerging region, rather than consume themselves with mutual hatred."
"If things don't go well, there will be a geopolitical vacuum, which is everywhere dangerous. They invite intrusions, and this is a highly nuclear neighborhood."

Turkey would prefer a pipeline across its land. (The New York Times)
 
Map/Chart: "The Great Game: Picking a Path for Oil"
The fabulous wealth in fossil fuels that lies beneath the Caspian Sea basin is now being developed, but no one is certain how to bring it to foreign markets. The Caspian region is landlocked, so pipelines are needed. The routes chosen will have profound political implications -- for the United States, for Russia, for Iran, and for the nations that sit atop the vast lakes of oil and gas. Here are the principal alternatives:
 
Through Eastern European ports
Romania, Bulgaria and Ukraine say they could send oil by barge or pipeline straight to Western Europe from their ports on the Black Sea.
 
Through Georgia and the Black Sea
Some American oil companies favor this route for now, since building a new pipeline here would be simpler than through Turkey, and tankers could then go straight to Eastern Europe or out the Black Sea to the Mediterranean. But Turkey objects to increased traffic through the Bosporus.
 
Through Turkey via Georgia
This route is favored by the United States Government, which sees it as a way to build up Turkey, assure delivery of oil to the Mediterranean through friendly territory, and promote as much independence as possible in the former Soviet republics. American oil companies, however, say they would need big subsidies because of the expense.
 
Through Iran
A new pipeline here might be the cheapest way to bring out oil, but American companies are forbidden from doing business with the current Iranian regime.
 
Through Afghanistan
Pakistan would like to develop these routes, but Afghanistan has been in the grip of civil war for a decade, and its current rulers, the Taliban, run what is perhaps the most radical Islamic regime.
 
To China
A feasibility study is due later this year for a natural gas pipeline that would deliver fuel directly to China through Kazakhstan. An oil pipeline is also being studied.
 
Through Russia
Soviet-era pipelines exist and could be supplemented, and the Russians are eager to do this. But American oil companies and the newly independent countries of the Caucasus want alternate routes -- partly to avoid new dependence on Russia and partly to sidestep unstable areas of Russia like Chechnya.

HEADLINE: With Switch In Heir Plan, King Hussein Stuns Jordan

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 23

 BODY:
King Hussein of Jordan is preparing to select one of his sons as his heir, Jordanian officials said today, culminating a dizzying week in which the King returned from six months of cancer treatment abroad and then dismissed his brother as Crown Prince.
The sudden ouster of Crown Prince Hassan, who is 51 and had been the King's designated heir for 34 years, has stunned even Jordanians long used to surprises from the 63-year-old King, who has made change in course a hallmark of his 47-year rule. 
 The King has not yet offered any clue as to why his brother fell into disfavor, and he has not yet signaled which of his five sons he might now elevate to the head of the line for the Hashemite throne.
Since the King returned on Tuesday to announce that he had "thoughts and ideas" about changing the line of succession, Jordan had been buzzing with speculation and disbelief. But on Friday, Jordanian officials said, the King made the news official in a meeting in which he told his brother to prepare for a royal decree that would designate a new heir.
The Crown Prince, who is described in an official biography as the King's closest confidant, had run the country as Regent during all six months of his brother's absence, as he had done countless times before.
The King was reported by Jordanian officials to have told the Crown Prince that he wanted to designate him as his deputy, albeit with limited power, but people close to Crown Prince Hassan said he had taken the news badly and might well choose to live abroad.
According to knowledgeable Jordanians who spoke on condition of anonymity, the leading candidates to succeed King Hussein are now Prince Abdullah, 37, the King's eldest son and an army major general in charge of a royal security force, and Prince Hamzeh, 18, the King's eldest son by his current wife, the American-born Queen Noor.
Prince Hamzeh, who is now attending a course at the British military academy in Sandhurst, England, has long been seen as the King's favorite. He was at his father's side through much of the grueling cancer treatment, at the Mayo Clinic in the United States, and unconfirmed talk around the Royal Court has long suggested that Queen Noor wanted Hamzeh to become King.
King Hussein, whose treatment included six rounds of chemotherapy and the transplant of bone marrow, has pronounced himself "fully recovered from the cancer," a variety known as non-Hodgkins lymphoma.
But his latest illness was his second brush with cancer in the last seven years, and it has robbed him of his hair, weight and some physical vigor. For the latter reason, diplomats in the Jordanian capital, Amman, have suggested that the King might now find it difficult to resume a full work schedule.
They say they know of no reason to doubt that the King has been cured, but they also have described his sudden attention to succession as reflecting a fresh sense of mortality.
Neither Prince Abdullah nor Prince Hamzeh has been given much of a public profile in Jordan, but both are said by people who know them to have the same charm and charisma that have helped the King to guide Jordan through turbulent times.
By contrast, Crown Prince Hassan has found it difficult to shake an image of being relatively aloof. Still, he has also has won many admirers through his long years as his brother's understudy.
That has been particularly the case within the business community, which regarded him as well-equipped to help Jordan through economic strains. And even Jordanians who have never been great admirers of the Crown Prince are shocked and confused by the move to sideline him from the succession.
"I don't think this is any way to treat a brother," said a former Jordanian official who like most people critical of the King would speak only on condition of anonymity.
The King, who is one of the world's longest-serving leaders, has a long record of surprising friends and foes, through decades of artful swerves that included his sudden embrace in 1994 of a peace treaty with Israel.
But never before has he courted so much potential discord within his family.
When he designated Hassan as Crown Prince in 1965, the King's sons were infants, and a series of assassination attempts against King Hussein had raised concern about how Jordan would fare if he were killed. The move required an amendment to Jordan's Constitution, which had stipulated that the eldest son of the reigning monarch inherit the throne.
The selection of a son as the new heir would restore that line. King Hussein was designated in 1952 and formally took power the next year, succeeding his grandfather, King Abdullah, assassinated in Jerusalem in 1951, and his father, King Talal.

HEADLINE: Social Insecurity in Brazil For Its Government Retirees

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 22

 BODY:
They have been called "privilegiados" who collect lavish pensions and benefits, and portrayed as budgetary vampires who drain the pension system and contribute nothing.
Now, millions of retired Government workers across Brazil are watching the financial crisis that is enveloping Latin America's largest economy tear the first breaches in the social contract that has shaped their lives. What else, they wonder, will be open to question in the new scheme of things? 
 "You work really hard, and what is it for? Just to worry at the end of your life?" said Djalma da Silva Rodrigues, who worked for the Federal Revenue department for 38 years, many of them at the country's borders for the customs service. "God in heaven, what is this? We gave everything for our jobs."
Brazil is financially on the ropes, with its currency plunging in value since the Government allowed it to float freely against the dollar a week ago. Hard currency reserves are dwindling. The Group of Seven major industrialized nations, the United States and the International Monetary Fund have contributed to a $41.5 billion bailout package to pull Brazil through the current turbulence.
In return, foreigners expect Brazil to show that it can carry out structural changes that strike at vested interests. The vote in Congress on Wednesday night to trim welfare benefits proved it can -- even though the markets appeared unimpressed, and the plunge in the currency and the flight of dollars continued on Thursday and Friday.
The changes will raise the pension contributions of most Government workers to just under 25 percent for the highest earners. The measures will save Brazil only $2.5 billion this year, but the plan shatters a longstanding cultural taboo against retired Government workers having to continue to pay into the pension system.
In Brazil, retired Government workers -- 905,000 -- now outnumber the 902,000 active civil servants. Government projections indicate that pensions will produce a $29 billion deficit this year.
If outsiders viewed Wednesday night's vote as a test of commitment to sound fiscal management, retired workers watched through a different lens.
Some saw it as the just end to a sweet ride. Others, like Mr. Rodrigues, were bitter and felt the Government was changing the rules not so much in the middle of the game, but after it had ended. Retirees from the private sector, who have had to buy supplemental retirement policies to collect their pensions of more than 1,200 reals a month, now some $750, said it was about time.
But for all Government workers, Wednesday's vote, which is expected to be approved by the Senate, shatters a sense of security that had shaped the lives of public servants.
"To us, this vote has been one of the biggest blows on the heads of workers," said Claudette Alves da Silva Souza, president of the municipal workers' union of Sao Paulo, which represents 147,000 civil servants. While the congressional vote itself affects only federal workers, Sao Paulo officials said this week they would apply it to state and municipal workers as soon as the federal law took effect.
Ms. Souza said she agreed with the need for reform, but noted that the Government had not struck at more powerful vested interests, like Brazil's wealthy landowners, the banking sector or multinationals operating in the country.
Even within the Civil Service, some classes have remained protected. The military, both retired and active workers, have so far been exempt from the reforms affecting the rest of Brazil's public workers, and they will not have to contribute to the pension system. Judges and teachers are also protected from some of the reforms.
"Who's being hit?" Ms. Souza said. "It's the middle class and below that's being called upon to pay for the mistakes of a Government that implemented a disastrous policy."
Brazil's pension system for Government workers remains generous by any standards. Retired civil servants receive their highest salary for as long as they live, and after retirement they continue to collect any salary increases their union negotiates, as if they were still working.
To many private sector workers, like Levy Kauffman, a former vice president of the telephone company, it was high time for Brazil's governing class to abandon its privileges. Watching the congressmen supporting the reform speak above the din of opposition critics, he said, "We're at a stage in Brazil where a minority that's organized controls a majority that's disorganized."
Mr. Kauffman, 75, nodded as he watched Roberto Jefferson, a congressman from Rio de Janeiro, defend the social security reforms as necessary for Brazil's solvency. "For each real the public servant puts into the pension system, the Government puts in 10," Mr. Jefferson intoned. "And there's no actuarial table in the world that can make sense of that."
"Finally," Mr. Kauffman said, as if at last hearing somebody who spoke his language.

HEADLINE: Ailing Asian Companies Unload Their Hotels

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Japan Airlines bought the Essex House, a grand Art Deco hotel on Central Park South, 15 years ago and turned it into a flagship for its Nikko hotel chain in a city where real estate always seems like a good bet for foreign investors.
Now that the airline is struggling with declining profits in a turbulent Asian economy, it is selling the Essex House to an American company, Strategic Hotel Capital, for about $250 million, real estate executives say. Eight blocks away, the Lai Sun Group of Hong Kong is selling the luxurious Four Seasons Hotel, as well as the Regent Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Los Angeles, for similar reasons. 
 Many of the Asian companies that have poured billions of dollars into American real estate, particularly trophy hotels in New York, California and Hawaii, are now selling out. With the hotel market booming in the United States, some foreign companies are making huge profits. Others, like Japan Airlines, are breaking even, or even losing money. But there is no question that the Asian shopping spree is over.
"A lot of Asian companies are trying to liquidate assets and convert them to cash because of problems at home," said Arthur Adler, a partner at the Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, a real estate investment bank. "And the timing's not bad, because there's a feeling that the market is peaking."
There is no shortage of buyers. At the Essex House auction, Laurence S. Geller, the chairman of Strategic Hotel Capital, which owns 26 hotels including the Marriott East Side in Manhattan and the Ritz-Carlton Laguna Niguel in California, had to fend off rivals like Marriott, Intercontinental Hotels and the Blackstone Group's Savoy Hotels. Strategic signed a contract earlier this month to buy the Essex House and is set to close the deal in late February or March.
Mr. Geller said Strategic would be spending money to "upgrade the hotel and position it at a higher level than it is today."
"The Essex House will be one of our flagship hotels in the United States," he said Friday. "We believe that lodging in Manhattan is rock solid. It's one of the few great world tourist destinations."
Most analysts say that the market for hotels reached a high point last summer, but that hotels will remain very profitable in cities like New York because business remains so strong. Even without the latest round of hotel sales, room rates have been rising swiftly. During most of the year, it is almost impossible to find an available room in New York City. As a result, the average room rate in Manhattan has jumped 36.9 percent to $213.83 since January 1996, according to PKF Consulting, a hotel consulting company. And rates are expected to rise 7 percent this year in New York, and 5 percent nationally.
"We'll see an increase in room rates in 1999, but it's a factor of demand, not the purchase price of the hotel," said John Fox, a principal at PKF Consulting. "The profits in this industry are still very good."
According to hotel and real estate executives who spoke on the condition of anonymity, Strategic is betting that it can raise room rates at the 597-room hotel and take advantage of a better reservations system. Strategic, in turn, has hired Westin hotels to manage the Essex House. Westin, which is owned by Starwood Hotels and Resorts, already runs the nearby Westin Central Park South.
Japan Airlines had lots of company on its trip to the auction block.
The Taisei Corporation of Japan sold the Sheraton Grande Torrey Pines in La Jolla, Calif., last month for $82.5 million to Hilton Hotels, which promptly renamed it the Hilton La Jolla Torrey Pines.
Another troubled Hong Kong company, Paliburg Holdings Ltd., is selling its stake in Regal Hotels, a chain that has 13 properties in the United States and Canada, including the United Nations Plaza in New York, the Biltmore in Los Angeles, the Knickerbocker in Chicago and the Regal Bostonian in Boston.
Last year, a company controlled by Ong Beng Seng, the Singapore billionaire, sold its 40 percent stake in the Pennsylvania Hotel, across Seventh Avenue from Madison Square Garden. And Sinar Mas Group, the second-largest conglomerate in Indonesia, sold a real estate portfolio that included the Pasadena Hilton in California and the Melrose Hotel in Dallas to pay off mounting debts.
The sales mark the end of what was actually the second wave of Asian investment in American real estate. Between 1985 and 1992, Japanese companies spent $77 billion on real estate in the United States, buying everything from the former Exxon Building to Rockefeller Center. No price was too high for the Japanese, who were confident of the long-term value of the office buildings, hotels, golf courses and shopping centers.
But they took a beating during the recession in the early 1990's. Since 1992, the Japanese have sold about one-third of those properties for a little more than half the original purchase prices, according to the E&Y Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group.
As the Japanese retreated, a second wave of investors from Hong Kong, Singapore, Indonesia, Taiwan, Brunei and South Korea swept into the United States between 1993 and 1996, snapping up $6.3 billion worth of real estate, most of it hotels, at bargain prices.
But even as real estate prices started skyrocketing in New York and California in 1997, the Asian economy began falling apart. Faced with steep debts and falling sales at home, many of the new investors decided to sell at what turned out to be the top of the market in the United States. During the first six months of 1998, Asians bought only $160 million worth of real estate, but sold nearly $1 billion worth.
Lai Sun will reap the benefits of the boom in recent years. The company paid $190 million two years ago for the Four Seasons Hotel on East 57th Street, one of the most lavish hotels in the world, and is now selling it for about $260 million, a relatively quick profit of $70 million.
Japan Airlines is not so lucky. The company bought the Essex House in 1985 for $190 million, closed it for two years and spent $100 million more on renovations.
The rooms at the Essex House are usually full, and it has two highly rated restaurants, but the hotel has never been an economic powerhouse for the airline, according to hotel executives. Under pressure in Japan, the company is now being forced to sell many of its hotels and resorts.
"The Essex House is a large hotel in a prime location," said Fox, of PKF Consulting. "It's a significant addition to anybody's roster."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
A Scandal Tears Apart Olympic 'Family'

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 23

 BODY:
People in international Olympic circles have for many years been fond of describing the Olympics as a "family." The term, combined with the ever-present logo of the five interlocked rings, suggested a shared mission, a unity that went beyond sports, a higher purpose.
Dysfunctional is probably the first thing most people would think of now. 
 The Olympic family, a sprawling multibillion-dollar sports entity that had seemed to own the high ground of international athletic competition -- drenched with its associations to ancient times, haughty in its superiority to mere professional sports -- has over the last week almost looked to be coming apart at the seams.
Like pop-up targets at a shooting gallery that come too fast to shoot, new allegations of impropriety, if not formal illegality, have emerged almost daily about how the International Olympic Committee, generally known as the I.O.C., has awarded its ultimate plum prize -- the granting of the great five-ring franchise to a particular city.
And that in turn has set off one of the great media chases in recent years, as news organizations all over the world -- in just about every city that has been host to the Olympics in the last few decades or wanted to -- has begun to look at how the process worked.
What began here in Utah late last year as a small brushfire, as stories began to circulate about how I.O.C. delegates were courted and wined and dined and enriched as part of Salt Lake City's efforts to win enough votes to obtain the 2002 Winter Games, has thus become, for the Olympic movement, a worldwide conflagration.
From Toronto to Brazzaville, Congo, and Nagano, Japan, to Sydney, Australia, tales have emerged -- some confirmed, others simply reported by local news organizations and thrown out onto the worldwide news net. There have been reports of petty grasping by I.O.C. delegates and of formal payoffs for votes, of free shotguns and samurai swords, of plastic surgery provided gratis as a city's gift to a delegate, of burned records and of geisha girls, of land deals that benefited I.O.C. delegates and of recitals for pianists of uncertain talent who had the right connections.
And to a great extent those reports have been considered all the more newsworthy -- if not sensational -- precisely because of the mantle of respectability and sanctimony with which the Olympic family had so long wrapped itself.
"It's the old issue -- do people's behaviors conform to their value systems? The answer is, most of the time they do and occasionally they don't," said R. Thayne Robson, director of the Bureau of Business and Economic Research at the University of Utah, and a close observer of the Olympics struggle.
"My view as an economist is that people are pretty much motivated by greed and selfishness and that given the opportunity, they will act on that," he said.
Part of the Olympics story has centered on the almost metaphysical question of how to define a gift. Is a present to gain good will from an influential decision maker really so different, many local Olympics organizers around the world have argued, from the tax breaks and giveaways that are routinely offered to corporations by states or cities -- including, notably, New York -- as they compete to keep a company where it is or induce it to move somewhere else? Why aren't those things called bribes?
But what has also emerged is how much personal power individual I.O.C. delegates possess, or were perceived to possess, by local organizers who in many cases seem to have been almost pathetically desperate to win enough votes to get an Olympic franchise for their home town.
Although most of the reports have suggested that only a small minority of the I.O.C.'s 114 delegates may have received direct financial benefits from local organizers, the overwhelming message is that almost whatever a delegate asked for could not be denied and that first-class treatment with all expenses paid was the barest minimum to be expected when a delegate came to call.
To date, two I.O.C. delegates have officially resigned: Pirjo Haeggman of Finland and Bashir Attarabulsi of Libya. Olympic officials have identified the 11 other I.O.C. officials linked with the Salt Lake City scandal as Agustin Arroyo of Ecuador, Zen El Abdin Ahmed Abdel Gadir of the Sudan, Jean-Claude Ganga of Congo Republic, Anton Geesink of the Netherlands, Louis Guirandou-N'Diaye of Ivory Coast, Lamine Keita of Mali, Kim Un Yong of South Korea, Charles Mukora of Kenya, Sergio Santander Fantini of Chile, David Sibandze of Swaziland and Vitaly Smirnov of Russia.
Japan's Kyodo news agency reported on Friday, for example, that the daughter of an influential I.O.C. executive was given a piano recital -- sponsored in part by local Olympics organizers -- shortly before the vote in which Nagano was selected as the site of the 1998 Winter Games. That report came just a few days after Olympics officials in Nagano said that financial records about the Games there had been burned.
On the same day, an I.O.C. delegate from Libya, Bashir Mohamed Attarabulsi, resigned -- the second delegate to quit in five days -- after published reports said that his son, Suhel, had gone to college in Utah, and received a $700 a month living allowance while he did so, paid for by Salt Lake City Olympic organizers.
As if that were not enough for one day, a senior official of the Australian Olympic Committee announced that he had offered tens of thousands to two I.O.C. delegates from Africa just before the vote in which Sydney won the right to be host to the 2000 Summer Games. The official, John Coates, said the money was intended to help develop sports programs in Kenya and Uganda and was not a bribe. Sydney won in the subsequent balloting, as it turned out, by exactly two votes.
And finally, a newspaper in the Netherlands this week reported that Olympic organizers had spent almost $7 million on I.O.C. delegates during Amsterdam's effort to get the 1992 Olympics. Dutch Olympic officials even brought a fleet of private buses to I.O.C. headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland to provide free transportation for I.O.C. members and guests while the vote was held. And it didn't even work. Amsterdam was first city to be eliminated in voting for the Summer Games that year, losing to Barcelona, Spain.
In Quebec, which lost to Salt Lake City for the 2002 Winter Games, local Olympic officials even began keeping a paper trail of the highly specific wishes or demands of the more than 60 I.O.C. delegates who visited the city before the vote. The Globe and Mail newspaper reported today that one asked for the city to pay travel expenses for his nation's athletes, while another wanted money for investment in a paper pulp factory. Quebec officials have previously said that they would seek reimbursement of more than $12 million in expenses from the I.O.C. if Salt Lake City's victory was found to have been improper.

HEADLINE: January 17-23;
Overtaxed? Depends on the Source

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSON

 BODY:
In Washington, there's a another whopper making the rounds. This one is about Uncle Sam and your wallet.
 In the Republican response to President Clinton's State of the Union Address, Representative Jennifer Dunn of Seattle told the story as fact.
 
 "Last year a typical mother and father who both work paid nearly 40 percent of their income in taxes," Ms. Dunn said. "That means 40 cents out of every dollar they earned went to the Government in Federal, state or local taxes."
 Not true. According to official estimates from the Clinton Administration and the Congressional Budget Office, a two-income middle class family of four pays closer to 30 percent in taxes. For a similar family in Ms. Dunn's suburban Seattle district, the figure is 28 percent.
 Even her source, the Tax Foundation, which is a nonprofit organization, disagreed with her.
 "It appears that Congresswoman Dunn's staff relied on an outdated report of ours," said Bill Ahern, spokesman for the foundation.
 In November 1997 the Tax Foundation said a family of four in which both parents work paid 38.2 percent of its income in taxes. The report was widely criticized for exaggerating the tax burden. A revised report lowered the estimate to 37.6 percent. The foundation says that number is too high for 1998, the year Ms. Dunn referred to, because Congress gave parents a $400 tax cut for each child.
 "A family of four does not pay a penny in income taxes until their income reaches $28,000," said William G. Gale, a tax economist at the Brookings Institution, "and three-fourths of all taxpayers either pay no income taxes or are in the 15-percent tax bracket for part of their income."
 At week's end Ms. Dunn was standing fast. That "40 percent is a round number that is very close to the figure that is accurate," she said. As for controversy over the Tax Foundation's methodology and the official estimates being much lower, Ms. Dunn said, "We try to be as accurate as possible. There may well be better numbers, but people are being taxed way too much and everybody knows it."

HEADLINE: DATABANK: JANUARY 18-22;
The Brazilian Bear Growls Again

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
Markets aroudn the world shuddered on Friday as Brazil's economic crisis deepened. Brazil's central bank intervened in currency markets to keep its currency, the real, from going into a free fall. Even so, the currency has fallen 30 percent against the dollar since the start of the crisis. The intervention was the bank's first since allowing the real to float last week.
 
 The Toronto Stock Exchange 300 Composite index lost 2.4 percent for the week, closing at 6,593.90. The biggest Canadian banks have $3 billion (Canadian) in loans, deposits and securities in Brazil, and share prices dropped for Scotiabank, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and the Royal Bank of Canada.
 Markets in New York, London, Paris, Frankfurt, Vienna, Madrid and Amsterdam were also reeling on Friday. Amsterdam was the hardest-hit, down 4.61 percent. One trader in Paris told Agence France-Presse that Brazil's currency "just hasn't found a floor." He added, "There are a lot of European companies with exposure to South America."
 In addition to worry over Brazil, disappointment over I.B.M.'s earnings delivered a big punch, as the Dow Jones industrial average lost 219.88 points last week, closing at 9,120.67, down 2.35 percent.
