HEADLINE: The Big City;
A Fair Trade To Find Peace: Trash for Vice

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
A statesman has finally emerged to make peace between New York City and Virginia. While politicians and journalists have been busy escalating the garbage war, Jim Spencer has come forth with a bold, diplomatic initiative.
Mr. Spencer, a columnist for The Daily Press in Newport News, Va., is one of the many Virginians offended by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent comment about their state's "reciprocal relationship" with New York. Virginians benefit from New York's cultural and financial institutions, the Mayor explained, and New Yorkers benefit by sending trash barges to landfills in rural Virginia. 
 "Besides theaters and banks," Mr. Spencer wrote in response, "New York has some crackerjack crack houses, much better than anything Virginia can offer. And despite Giuliani's attempt to clean up Times Square, his city has more whores and dirty-book stores. In the spirit of letting each place do what it does best, I say we round up all of our pushers, prostitutes and pornographers, stick 'em on a barge and float 'em up the Hudson River."
If this is the price of peace, how can we say no? The deal makes sense for both sides. Virginians could assuage their wounded pride without giving up the profits of their trash business, as their politicians threatened to do by outlawing barges from New York. And if Virginia's vice merchants moved north, New York's tourist industry would profit from the surge of Virginians desperate to continue practicing their favorite sins.
Virginia's exiled entrepreneurs might even reinvigorate New York's beleaguered vice industry, although this is unlikely. The most enterprising ones have already come here. Those determined to make it big -- to be the next Bob Guccione or Mayflower Madam or French Connection -- did not pursue their dreams by sticking around Newport News. The vice business has long benefited from the free flow of people and goods across state borders.
So does every other business, but for some reason politicians refuse to believe that's true for trash. They can't keep their hands off garbage even though they've repeatedly made a mess of things by interfering. It was public officials, after all, who built and ran the notorious old municipal dumps without linings or environmental safeguards. Then, when the dumps were forced to close by Federal regulations in the 1980's, politicians were sure that America faced a permanent shortage of landfill space, so they attacked the "garbage crisis" with recycling programs and incinerators.
But the politicians' alternatives have turned out to be embarrassingly expensive now that there's a glut of cheap space in new landfills with environmental safeguards. These privately operated landfills have been welcomed by rural communities that appreciate the economic benefits of interstate commerce in trash. Some critics argue for better enforcement of safety standards for the trucks and barges carrying trash, but that can be done without closing the border or having politicians decree how many tons of trash can enter their domain.
The chief garbage problem in need of politicians' attention is the one created by their overpriced incinerators and inefficient recycling programs. That ultimately may be why they're so upset by the brisk business at the landfills. The landfills' success raises an irritating question, as Mr. Spencer noted in his column.
"Why recycle?" he wrote. "If this state has enough landfill space to dispose of 1.6 million tons of New York City's solid waste each year, what am I doing digging up to my elbows in chicken bones, used Kleenex and grapefruit rinds to snag a No. 2 plastic jug that I inadvertently threw away?"
A similar question occurred to me several years ago, when I stood at a huge landfill in Charles City County, Va., and looked at recycling bins filled with cans and bottles painstakingly sorted by local residents. The landfill manager would have been happy to dump them in his mountain of trash, but he was required to pay a trucker to take them 20 miles away to a recycling center, which demanded a further fee to take the stuff off his hands.
I mentioned this story to Mr. Spencer during the course of our negotiations over his diplomatic initiative, and I suggested adding a sweetener to the Virginia-New York Garbage Peace Pact: Virginians, besides having the having the right to send New York bargeloads of vice merchants in exchange for garbage, would be freed of any responsibility to recycle.
"Sounds like a win-win to me," he said.

HEADLINE: Citing Drop in Welfare Rolls, Clinton to Seek Further Cuts

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.

 BODY:
President Clinton will announce on Monday that the number of people on welfare has fallen to its lowest level in 30 years, and call for programs designed to help more recipients get to jobs and encourage more businesses to hire them.
The new figures from the Health and Human Services Department also show the dramatic declines in the welfare rolls of recent years are beginning to slow in certain states. 
 Nationally, just under 8 million people were on welfare at the end of September, down 44 percent from 14.3 million in 1994. But state officials and academics have long cautioned that, at some point, nearly all the people who can move off welfare with relative ease will have done so, leaving those with deeper problems like substance abuse, domestic violence and very little education.
"With welfare reform, the more you succeed, the harder the job becomes," said Don Winstead, who heads a Florida welfare program.
Mr. Clinton hopes to make that job easier. Administration officials said he will announce proposals included in the budget he will submit to Congress next month, including:
*$1 billion to help 200,000 long-term welfare recipients in high-poverty areas move to work. It continues a two-year-old program with a new requirement that 20 percent be used for low-income fathers.
*$430 million to give 75,000 housing vouchers that help people on welfare move closer to a new job.
*$150 million in transportation money to help people get to jobs, often in suburbs not served by public transportation.
*$530 million to extend the tax credit for businesses that hire people off welfare.
As he did in his State of the Union Message, the President will trumpet the falling welfare numbers on Monday.
"On a national basis, the caseload drop has been remarkably steady," said Bruce Reed, the President's chief domestic policy adviser.
But the figures show the drops in some states may have begun to slow in the final quarter of fiscal year 1998. In at least eight states, most of which have seen sharp drops since 1993, the reductions slowed to a trickle in July, August and September 1998.
"There's a difference between the first three quarters of the year and the last quarter of the year," said Michael Kharfen, a Department of Health and Human Services spokesman.
State officials say they are preparing to serve welfare recipients with tougher problems, moving beyond the "work first" approach that helps recipients look for work and then pushes them to take any job they can find. Under that approach, states do not try to solve every problem or get people the education they may need. They simply try to find them jobs, reasoning that work experience will help them move up the economic ladder.
But that is not enough for everyone, state officials say.
"We're past the situation where someone comes in who may need a little bit of confidence building, who may need a brush-up on skills and may need a new battery for the car -- all things we can do," said John Garlinger of the Kansas Department of Social and Rehabilitation Services. "We are left with the hard-core people."
Kansas has cut its welfare rolls by 62 percent since 1993, but by the end of the last fiscal year, sharp quarterly drops of 8 percent to 10 percent fell to just 1.7 percent.
Other states seeing drops include Arizona, Arkansas, Connecticut, Florida, Massachusetts and North Carolina. New Mexico, after nearly cutting its rolls in half, experienced a 40 percent increase during 1998.
Seasonal variations may explain some changes. In Massachusetts, the rolls always stay higher near September, when the state gives clothing vouchers for every child on welfare.
But other states say they have begun to "bottom out."
"We knew that after that wave of families went off the rolls, the somewhat harder work would begin," said Joe Quinn, a spokesman for the Arkansas Department of Human Services. In Arkansas, the the number of welfare recipients fell just 2.7 percent in the last quarter after declining about 9 percent in previous quarters.
Jack Tweedie, who tracks welfare reform for the National Conference of State Legislatures, said states were financially prepared to work with harder-to-serve people because of the money saved from fewer people getting checks.

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Up 40.1% in 1998

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Japan's merchandise trade surplus with the world climbed 40.1 percent in 1998 after another jump in December from a year earlier, the Ministry of Finance said today. It said Japan's surplus with the United States rose 33.4 percent in 1998 and in December alone rose 23 percent.
The Finance Ministry said the total December surplus rose 14.4 percent from a year earlier with exports dropping 12.2 percent but imports sliding further, down 21.7 percent. 
 President Clinton warned last week that the United States would not tolerate a continued surge in Japanese steel exports. The deputy United States trade representative, Richard Fisher, is to conduct trade talks in Tokyo.
Japan's steel industry and the Trade Ministry have predicted that steel exports this year would fall enough to please the United States, although Government officials stressed that this was only a forecast and not a policy pledge.
But Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa has said the matter needs to be handled with care and that the United States trade deficit with Japan and China could become a problem in the future.

HEADLINE: As Arab League Urges Iraqis to Obey the U.N., They Walk Out of the Meeting

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
In an angry rupture with fellow Arabs, an Iraqi delegation withdrew from a high-level meeting here tonight as Arab foreign ministers were adopting a statement critical of Baghdad.
Baghdad hoped that fellow members of the 22-member Arab League would use the session to focus attention on Iraq's foes, in part by issuing an explicit condemnation of the air attacks last month on its territory by the United States and Britain. 
 Instead, the foreign ministers deliberated for another four and a half hours after the walkout but made no fundamental changes in the statement. It demands that Iraq renounce "provocations" against its neighbors and that it comply with all United Nations resolutions before economic sanctions could be lifted, Arab League officials said.
A member of the Iraqi delegation told reporters as he left the session that the resolution "did not comply with any of the Iraqi demands."
The Iraqi Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, blamed Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria for the anti-Iraq tone of the statement, which he called fruitless and negative.
At a news conference in a Cairo hotel, Mr. Sahaf warned that the United States might try to use the Arab stand as a pretext for new attacks on Iraq. But he insisted acidly that the criticism of Iraq did not represent any kind of broad Arab view, but only that of "the friends of America" among the Arabs.
The bitter outcome of the session was a fresh indication of just how much Iraq's relations with fellow Arabs have soured, particularly in recent weeks.
Most Arab leaders have opposed or expressed regret about the American-led attacks, which ended on Dec. 20. But they have not done so vehemently enough to satisfy Baghdad, prompting Iraq to respond with extraordinary venom, particularly toward Egypt and Saudi Arabia.
In a rambling speech earlier this month, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq called on Arab people to overthrow unspecified leaders who he suggested were little more than vassals of the United States.
Such attacks have not left most Arab governments in any mood to offer succor to Mr. Hussein, who Arab officials have begun in recent weeks to describe -- privately but increasingly -- as a ruler whose days should be numbered.
The walkout tonight by Iraqi officials shattered the hopes of Arab League officials that the session might somehow rebuild an illusion of Arab solidarity that was shattered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
The meeting was prompted by the American-led air strikes last month. An Iraqi account said some Arab countries, including Libya and Morocco, had favored a resolution more favorable to Baghdad. But those countries were thwarted, the Iraqis said, by the Saudis and other Persian Gulf countries, the most hawkish among the Arabs in their anti-Iraqi views.
Mr. Sahaf, the Iraqi Foreign Minister, specifically accused Egypt and Syria of having been too timid to oppose the hard-line Saudi stand. The Iraqi walkout followed more than seven hours of meetings by 18 Arab foreign ministers and four other representatives.
In public statements today, some Arab leaders hewed to a longstanding theme, emphasizing solidarity with Iraqi civilians who have borne the brunt of the sanctions.
Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa of Syria also criticized American policy, saying the only clear outcome of the four days of American strikes on Iraq last month had been "to aggravate the suffering of the Iraqi people."
But as measured by the Iraqi response, the main thrust of the Arab League statement appears to be sharply critical of Iraq, perhaps more than any similar declaration since the Persian Gulf war of 1991.
Among other things, Arab League officials said, the statement calls on Iraq to reaffirm its recognition of its borders with Kuwait. Iraq took that step in 1994, four years after invading its tiny neighbor, but in the last several weeks some prominent members of the Iraqi Parliament have urged a reversal.
The statement also demands that Iraq resolve the issue of Kuwaitis who are still considered missing or prisoners of war as a result of the invasion, the Arab League officials said.
On the question of United Nations sanctions, Iraq urged the Arab League to take the lead in the campaign for their lifting, perhaps even by unilaterally declaring them to be null and void.
But the Arab League officials said the statement was more cautious, calling for study of ways to lift the sanctions but saying they should remain in place until Iraq honored its obligations to the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Olympic Scandal Is Not Cleansed by Sacrifice of Small Fry

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
THERE is a morbid law school joke that goes: "What do you call 500 lawyers at the bottom of the ocean?" Answer: "A good beginning."
The International Olympic Committee made a minimal effort to purge itself yesterday when a special committee voted to expel six delegates who had most blatantly taken gifts during the bidding process. Three other I.O.C. delegates have resigned and another has been chastised. 
 Nine departures out of 114 delegates are a start, a token, a gesture, a bit of ballast tossed overboard to keep the I.O.C.'s cushy little balloon afloat. But lightening the load by less than 10 percent is not going to help because the selection of all recent Olympic host cities is permanently tainted.
The Olympic motto -- "Swifter, Higher, Stronger" -- is now understood to be an auctioneer's chant in a corrupt bidding system that has allowed wealthy cities like Sydney, Australia, (and Nagano, Japan, and Salt Lake City) to grease delegates with lavish presents. I would call them bribes.
So far, the real sports in this Olympic scandal have been the Chinese. They have not yet made an international uproar about the very real prospect that Beijing was cheated out of being host to the 2000 Summer Games.
Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, insisted yesterday in Lausanne, Switzerland, that he will remain in office, and he scoffed at the suggestion that he had some responsibility for this scandal, which took place right under his aristocratic nose. Where are Henry Hyde and Bob Barr when we really need them?
After yesterday's meeting, the I.O.C. announced it would implement new rules for the selection of the 2006 Winter Games, meaning that delegates will not be allowed to visit bidding cities and payoffs will not be permitted. It's a little late.
"We are not accusing any member of corruption or bribery, or suggesting that there was criminal conduct," said Richard Pound, the I.O.C. vice president from Montreal who led the inquiry into the current Salt Lake scandal, and who is one of the more forthright people in the I.O.C. "These members are guilty of breaking the oath they took and bringing the reputation of the I.O.C. into disrepute."
 Right. But there is more than a handful of delegates being caught with their hands in the caviar jar. The I.O.C. insults our intelligence and morality.
The Salt Lake scandal is at least tempered because everybody agrees that it was the best candidate for 2002. And nobody is ever going to find written proof why the 1998 Winter Games were awarded to a backwater Japanese town in a soupy climate, the closest to the equator that the Winter Games have ever been held. Officials in Nagano burned their records. Charming.
Sydney is the real loser. Cultured and beautiful and prosperous and gracious, Sydney won the 2000 Summer Games. At the time, it was cheap and easy for the I.O.C. to posture that the developed city in the democratic nation had paid its dues, and that Beijing should improve its economy and its air quality and its human-rights protection, and wait its turn.
Now it turns out the vote may have been bought. In what I find to be an astonishing mixture of candor and gall, the Australian Olympic Committee president, John Coates, has admitted giving $35,000 each to two African I.O.C. delegates in 1993 for their national sports programs, the night before Sydney defeated Beijing, 45-43.
"You have to create a sense of them having some obligation to you when they go into that room," Coates said the other day.
What is worse is that the I.O.C. vice president Kevan Gosper, one of the more cosmopolitan voices in the squalor of the 1996 Atlanta Summer Games, is pushing for a quick vote of confidence for Sydney. Did I mention that Gosper is Australian?
Gosper said he saw nothing "sinister" in the $70,000 in payments, adding, "I think there is a good case for reviewing regulations and process." Coates, the payer of the $70,000 gifts, said the system "should be changed," adding that "it is a process that we went into with our eyes wide open." He admitted, "We didn't win it on the beauty of the city and the sporting facilities we had to offer, and we were never going to." What a cynical sentiment from a man running an Olympic organizing committee.
Meanwhile, Sydney wants a vote of confidence from the I.O.C. because the international corporate sponsors are itchy about their sugar water and their gas-guzzlers being tainted with a lingering scandal.
As of now, Samaranch and Gosper and Coates hold on to their positions. They are going to try to paint themselves as reformers. They need a visit from a posse of Olympic sponsors, who are not planning to write any more checks until this thing is cleaned up. Samaranch might not want to see a delegation from Beijing on his doorstep either. With any luck at all, the Beijing sports officials are boning up on that most delightful of Western concepts, the lawsuit.

HEADLINE: Essay;
State of Unreality

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Once a year I get invited to the White House for a quick brain rinse and mindset on the State of the Union. This time I wandered in the wrong West Wing door and saw what I was not supposed to.
There was a worried-looking Betty Currie in the corner of the reception room, flanked by two grim suits offering advice, presumably not about her secretarial duties. 
 So what if White House aides were reassuring her, or even going over questions she might be asked if House managers call her to testify? They've been doing that for a year and nobody objected.
Then what was all the fuss about the House managers' talking to Monica Lewinsky? They wanted to find out if she would clarify her sometimes ambiguous testimony before asking the Senate for permission to depose her under oath.
President Clinton, contrariwise, does not want to take the chance that Monica will reveal some damning detail of their cover story, or sharpen the conflicts in perjurious testimony about his passivity.
Here's the fair, unembarrassing, history-respecting solution: depose both Lewinsky and Currie privately. If important discoveries or clarifications are made under oath to resolve disputes, call them as public witnesses. If not, send both women home and move to the verdict. This is orderly trial procedure, not rocket science.
After the presumed acquittal, should there be a vote of censure? I think not. If individual senators voting to acquit want to get well with a disapproving portion of their constituencies, let them rise in their places and excoriate Clintonian behavior to their consciences' content, railing away into the night. Those who really want to get tough may even decline to sip acquittal champagne at the White House victory rally.
But impeachment and trial are censure aplenty. In 2001, Clinton may face perjury prosecution requiring a pardon from his successor; for now, however, he will have won the right to two more years of Federal housing.
That's all he'll win. His stratospheric job approval ratings reflect mainly today's great good times, and contrast sharply with the repugnance with which most Americans tell pollsters they view him as a person. Thus, the moaning of moralists, the hand-wringing of law-and-order types and the unhappiness of culturecampers at the artful Clinton's latest dodge are at least premature.
Instant analysts were bowled over by the very fact of his State of the Union address. But this giddy gallimaufry was an appeal to detach ourselves from reality.
After they gently ushered me out of the off-limits reception area, I joined other thumbsuckers in the Roosevelt Room. There, four young Clinton aides foresaw -- with unblinking certitude -- the next generation's ever-rising surpluses, and laid out how the money will be spent.
Wait. Only a few years ago, economic sages saw huge deficits "as far as the eye could see." Wrong. Even this year's budget estimates of surplus were tens of billions out of whack. Federal budget projections are near-Malthusian in their enormous error.
Yet here were these earnest guys, each preparing his resume in case their boss gets the heave-ho next week, assuring the world that U.S. Government profit in the next 15 years would equal exactly $4.5 trillion. And Senate numbers crunchers concur.
No recession; no medium-sized wars; no S.& L. bailouts; no pandemics; no stagflation; no tax cuts or spending increases by Congresses to come -- these memory-free central planners see nothing but linear loveliness and blue skies from now on.
After predicating the salvation of Social Security on this rosiest scenario, they carved out half a trillion of Maybeland money for the biggest income-redistribution scheme in history: "Universal Savings Accounts," a new entitlement named after its initials, in which a chunk of the lifelong earnings of workers enhance retirement "savings" of the poor.
Tinsel is falling to confuse our radar. Can this lamest-duck Administration commit the President after the President after this President to a State of the Union Message in 2015 married to the Clinton model?
No, the Era of Big Government will not return on the back of an Age of Absurd Expectations. Through our ups and downs, the people and not the tax collectors will decide how to spend our earnings. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 1393 words

HEADLINE: Pope's Visit to U.S. To Focus on Future Of Church Growth

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18

 BODY:
When Pope John Paul II arrives in the United States on Jan. 26 for a two-day visit to St. Louis, his first major speech in that city will be at a rally of Roman Catholic youth, a group the Pope regards as vital to the church's future.
When he first visited this country 20 years ago, John Paul was a relatively vigorous 59, keeping a grueling schedule as he swept through the Northeast and Midwest. He returns as a historic figure, a prophet of the post-Communist world and one of the longest-reigning pontiffs in history, but also far more frail. 
 The church he will encounter here has been quieter politically than it was on his first visit and even in the 1980's, when the American bishops produced influential pastoral letters on war and peace and the nation's economy. Controversies among lay people now tend to show up in local parishes, as in Rochester last fall, when some Catholics objected to the removal of an outspoken liberal priest as their pastor.
But beneath the surface, the church is undergoing important shifts that will affect its future here well into the 21st century. Sociologists are finding that many young people are increasingly individualistic in their religious views and often divided from their elders on matters of sexuality.
"That's going to be the next Catholic constituency," said Dean R. Hoge, a professor of sociology at the Catholic University of America in Washington, who, with other academics, is conducting a study of young Catholic adults that has found evidence of sharp polarization between generations on issues like premarital sex and leadership possibilities for women in the church and society.
At the same time, the church is becoming more ethnically diverse as a result of immigration by Catholics from Asia and Latin America. They bring their own traditions and, in some cases, attitudes about church issues that sometimes differ from those of American-born Catholics.
"We're facing the many different kinds of people in our community that can't be categorized as just liberals and conservatives," said the Rev. Thomas J. Reese, editor of America, a Jesuit magazine. "We have to preach the Gospel to them and figure out how to make them one church."
Since 1979, the American Catholic population has grown through births to families here and immigration by a quarter, to 61.6 million people. The United States now has the world's third-largest Catholic population, after Brazil and Mexico.
Yet at the same time, the number of its priests has declined, the result of a plunge in seminary enrollments that began 30 years ago and has not been reversed.
The changes can be readily sensed here in the Archdiocese of New Orleans, which once encompassed a territory that included St. Louis, nearly 600 miles north of here.
Shortly before mass at Ignatius Chapel at Loyola University, a Jesuit school in the city's Uptown neighborhood, 10 undergraduates pulled chairs into a circle and leaned forward to speak avidly about what being Roman Catholic meant to them. One sophomore called the church her "centering point," while a freshman said it was her "foundation."
But on some hot-button issues, where church teachings meet social controversies, the young Catholics disagreed.
Six declared premarital sex to be always wrong, and six said homosexual activity was wrong, too, positions in keeping with church teaching. Asked whether women should be allowed to be priests, a subject the Vatican has ruled off-limits, the majority went the other way, six raising their hands to say yes, while the four others quietly looked on.
New Orleans also reflects the church's new ethnic diversity. While the city has long been home to a large African-American Catholic population, in recent years it has also been absorbing many immigrants from the Caribbean, Central America and Southeast Asia.
In a former marshland that has become a suburban neighborhood, sits the Mary, Queen of Vietnam parish, founded in 1983. During a midmorning Sunday mass, the white-walled sanctuary was packed with worshipers, its pews, built to seat 1,000, so full that ushers had to search for spots for latecomers. "It's typically this crowded," said Anh Cao, 31, a law student at Loyola.
Social issues seem to elicit a generally conservative response from younger parish members, as when the question of whether women should be ordained is raised with members of a youth choir.
"I have never thought of that," said Kim Phan, 24, a graduate student at the University of New Orleans. "I've never imagined a woman could be a priest."
Hieu Hoang, 22, a junior at Louisiana State University and a member of a parish women's group, the Daughters of Mary, offered a similar response.
Mr. Cao said Vietnamese Catholics strongly opposed abortion, in keeping with church teaching.
Such attitudes reflect the continuity of traditional Vietnamese Catholic values, said Joseph Trung, 32, a choir director and composer. "It comes from the family, it comes from the community," he said.
But sociologists are finding strong generational divisions in surveys nationwide on a variety of social issues.
A recent article in America magazine by Professor Hoge illustrated the trend with graphs from his study of younger Catholics that showed, among other things, that fewer than half of Catholics under age 30 believed homosexual activity was always or almost always wrong -- compared with a majority of those over 30 (and about three-quarters of those over 50) who thought it wrong.
One of Professor Hoge's associates in that study, William D. Dinges, a Catholic University associate professor of religion, said the study has found that 90 percent of young people confirmed in the church retain their Catholic identity, a far higher proportion than found in a similar study of young adult Presbyterians.
But, Professor Dinges said, many of the young Catholics in the study indicated that they regarded the church not as the bearer of absolute religious truths, but as a denominational "option," one form of Christianity among many.
R. Scott Appleby, director of the Cushwa Center for the Study of American Catholicism at the University of Notre Dame, said that such findings reveal the loss of an "embedded" Catholic worldview among the faithful. "I suppose what's been called radical individualism in American society is the biggest challenge to Catholic identity and to the Catholic church," he said.
But on a more positive note for the church, Professor Dinges said that the research also indicated that younger Catholics saw the church's sacraments and a commitment to social justice as vital to their religious identity.
A symbolic element of the Pope's visit will be his flight across the United States-Mexican border on a trip on which he will likely emphasize common concerns among North and South American Catholics.
Father Reese said the trip will provide the Pope his first opportunity to respond to Synod of America, a 1997 gathering in Rome of 200 bishops from the Western Hemisphere. Concerns voiced at that meeting included poverty, the debt burden in developing nations, the loss of Latin American Catholics to Pentecostal churches, and issues related to immigration.
The Pope will likely focus on "the question of new immigrants in the United States, which is a north-south issue," Father Reese said.
An estimated two million Hispanic immigrants entered the country in the early and mid-1990's, most of them Catholics. But within the American Catholic Church, other ethnic groups have grown, too, among them the Vietnamese.
Monsignor Dominic M. T. Luong, pastor of Mary, Queen of Vietnam, said the parish had about 3,000 members when it began in 1983. But now, he said, there are 17,000 Vietnamese Catholics in the New Orleans archdiocese.
He said the parish had recently contributed $7,000 to a fund for Central American victims of Hurricane Mitch.
The local Vietnamese population, he said, had produced 31 priests and 47 of its young men and women are studying to become priests or nuns, at a time when a growing shortage of priests has meant that an ever-larger number of tasks -- administering parishes, working with immigrants and teaching youth in Catholic schools, is falling to lay people, said Mr. Appleby.
"That's a structural challenge that the church needs to take more seriously," he said.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Few Details Furnished By Utah Organizers

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 24

 BODY:
In the Wasatch Mountains that dominate the landscape here, snow has been falling almost nonstop the last few days, vividly illustrating the gifts of nature and meteorology that made this city appealing as a site for the Winter Olympics. And in the packed downtown meeting room where executives of the local Olympic organizing committee faced journalists from around the world today in a news conference about the latest developments in the unfolding Olympic scandal, the display was just as vivid of all the reasons the 2002 Winter Games are in crisis.
The officials, led by the committee's chairman, Robert Garff, and Frank Joklik, its acting president and chief executive, offered little new information and declined to answer many questions. They said that because of the various investigations under way here, they could not comment on the details of the report released by the International Olympic Committee today in Switzerland about how and when Olympic officials here paid I.O.C. delegates. 
 Both men also declined to say whether they believed the remedies announced by Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C.'s president, would go far enough in addressing the problems of influence and greed that have been identified in how sites are selected for the Games, saying that that was for the I.O.C. to address. They also declined to say whether they thought Samaranch should step down.
"That's a matter for the I.O.C.," Garff said. "I refuse to be drawn into their internal politics."
And they declined to say whether the local committee might need to restructure itself, saying -- as they have for weeks -- that what happened here in the city's efforts to win I.O.C. members' votes to get the 2002 Olympics was the result of a few errant individuals whose behavior lapsed, and not of a structurally flawed system.
"We take responsibility for the actions of certain members of the former bid committee," Garff said, reading from a prepared statement. "Some of those actions taken were below the standards expected by this community. Therefore I reiterate our previously stated apology to the people of Utah."
The I.O.C.'s report, issued half a world away using information gleaned in part from the files of the Salt Lake Organizing Committee, offers many new details about how the I.O.C. says its delegates were influenced by Salt Lake organizers, including dates and amounts paid. In an unfolding story in which many of the specific facts have remained vague or unconfirmed, the I.O.C. report offers one of the first documented glimpses into the process of delegate influence. It also hints that the payments and amounts were accounted for in financial records kept by the Salt Lake committee, and not paid from some loosely controlled cash fund.
One I.O.C. delegate who was expelled, Agustin Arroyo of Ecuador, received at least four payments from the Salt Lake committee, the I.O.C. report said, including one of $6,991 on Dec. 13, 1994; one of $3,000 on Sept. 15, 1993, and two of $2,500 on May 23, 1995. Another delegate, Jean-Claude Ganga from Congo Republic, opened an account with one of the largest local banks here, the First Security Bank, for receipt of his payments, the report said. Another delegate apparently preferred his payments to be regular -- $1,000 a month for seven months between late 1994 and mid-1995.
At the news conference here today, Joklik -- who resigned recently but remains until his successor is found -- said he had confidence that the problems from the payment scandal could and would be overcome, and that the financial and public relations implications -- including at least several major corporate sponsors that have recently become noncommittal about their economic participation in the Games -- will also ease as it becomes clear that the Olympic movement is serious about cleaning up its mess.
But exactly how far that cleanup will go here or, conversely, how widely the blame may be distributed remains unknown. Samaranch has said, for example, that any I.O.C. member on the international level who knew or should have known what was happening in the site-selection process will face sanctions; today he announced the ouster of six members and continuing investigations of three others. The officials here declined today to make that blanket promise. Garff said the question would have to await the independent ethics investigation report expected here within the next week.
"When that report is finished and in our hands, we will then take decisive action," he said.

HEADLINE: Constraints Over Budget Put Pataki in a Bind

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 24

 BODY:
After the fiscal drought of the early 1990's, the last two years have been a monsoon season for New York State. Lawmakers have responded to the flood of revenue with tax cuts, record increases in school spending, higher payments to pensioners and a numbingly long list of expensive pet projects, from a sports stadium in Brooklyn to bigger purses at Saratoga Raceway.
The economy and the state's revenues are still strong, but Gov. George E. Pataki is saying that the party is over. 
 He has pledged that the 1999-2000 budget he will propose Wednesday will increase spending by no more than the rate of inflation. He has declared the state's budget surplus off-limits to spending, saying that the estimated $2 billion or more must be preserved to pay for promised tax cuts.
And while he will propose $1 billion a year in new tax cuts, most of them would not take effect for two to three years.
But a close look at the state budget shows that because of commitments the state has already made, the Governor can meet these goals only by freezing or even cutting from most areas of the budget.
There is, of course, some wiggle room on definitions, and the proof awaits the release of his budget plan. But Mr. Pataki and his aides insist that he means precisely what he says.
Most economists predict that inflation will be about 2 percent for the coming year, and a 2 percent increase in the state's $71 billion budget would be $1.42 billion, less than one-third the increase approved last year.
Just two programs already written into law -- one to pay local school districts to reduce property taxes, and another to expand prekindergarten programs and lower elementary school class sizes -- commit the state to spending $1 billion more in the next fiscal year. Contracts with state employees have built-in salary increases that will cost even more.
"The real-world effect of staying under inflation is that you would be cutting," said Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell, a Manhattan Democrat and chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee. "We have spending commitments that can't be avoided, and the Governor's idea leaves nothing left over -- less than nothing -- for the rest of the budget. So we would have to cut everything else -- schools, health care, you name it."
If Mr. Pataki's budget proposal does that, independent fiscal analysts are sure to applaud, since they have long warned that the state could be headed for a crisis if it does not slow spending. But the Legislature will take an austerity budget as a declaration of war, lawmakers in both houses and parties say.
"I don't know how he thinks he's going to do all these things and not have a revolt on his hands," said Senator Martin Connor, leader of the Democratic minority.
The Governor's aides have been tight-lipped about just what his proposed budget will contain, but some confirm that he will call for some spending cuts, particularly in health care programs, that could translate to layoffs by the state, and more likely by hospitals and contractors that rely on state money.
Over the last two years, the Assembly, controlled by Democrats, and the Senate, run by Republicans, have become used to their budget battles being not about hardship, but about how to split up the bounty of the nation's thriving economy and Wall Street's boom.
As the state ran up record surpluses in the last two years, the Governor and the Legislature eagerly spent the dividends, increasing state spending 13 percent, after Mr. Pataki had held it essentially flat in his first two years. Last year's 8 percent budget increase, as the Governor successfully sought re-election, was the largest since the mid-1980's.
Passing the budget is the main business of the Legislature, invariably setting the tone for the year's dealings with the Governor. Many lawmakers say that a nasty budget fight this year could make for an equally ill-tempered legislative session, making it harder to make deals in other important areas, like health care and criminal justice.
"If he really means this stuff about saving the surplus and keeping under inflation, he is going to have some real fights on his hands, and not just with Democrats," said a Republican state senator, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
In years past, the Governor's proposed budget, significant as it was, could be regarded as no more than the opening posture in a long dance with the Legislature, leading to a negotiated settlement. But last year's move by the Senate and Assembly to draft a budget largely without Mr. Pataki's involvement gave him extraordinary freedom to reject their choices through his veto power, insuring that the final plan closely resembled his original.
Legislative leaders say last year's process is still their model, but no one in the Capitol professes to have a clue how it will play out this year.
Democrats have signaled that they will seek another big increase in school aid and will try to protect health care from cuts. The Senate Republicans are nearly as ardent as Assembly Democrats in supporting spending on schools and hospitals, the easiest way to bring state money to their districts, and they are bent on enacting an ambitious new round of tax cuts.
But lawmakers have already spent dividends that have not yet arrived. In the last two years, they locked into place tax cuts and spending programs that are to increase in size year after year, from a current worth of $1.3 billion a year to more than $6.8 billion in 2001-02, when they are fully implemented.
Experts in academia, on Wall Street, in private policy study groups and even within state government have warned that the pace is unsustainable. Mr. Pataki was stung by charges that last year's fat election-year budget meant he was no longer a fiscal conservative, a claim that ran counter to the image he was trying to build both in New York and nationally.
Now, he appears ready to heed some of that criticism, but as he ponders a bid for a spot on the Republican Presidential ticket in 2000, he must strike a difficult balance between the need to hold the state's finances together and the need to placate New Yorkers who expect a high level of government service.
The last time Mr. Pataki insisted on tightly restrained budgets, in 1995 and 1996, labor unions, advocacy groups and Democrats in the Legislature mounted a fierce public relations campaign against him. The campaign, which included television and radio advertisements, lowered the Governor's poll ratings, and he backed off some of his most Draconian proposals.
Some groups that were involved in that campaign said they were prepared for a rerun.
"There could be blood in the water," said a prominent labor leader, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "It won't be pretty."

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 873 words

HEADLINE: Who's Fiscally Responsible Now?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Chait; Jonathan Chait is a fellow at the New America Foundation.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
No sooner had President Clinton unveiled his plan to save Social Security than it was savaged as big government run amok.
Republicans are reacting so hysterically precisely because the plan -- a solid proposal surrounded by poll-driven vacuities in his State of the Union address -- is not wild liberalism. Rather, it is fiscal conservatism -- what Republicans used to stand for before they invented supply-side economics -- devoted to progressive ends. 
 The gist of Mr. Clinton's proposal, remember, is not to spend the budget surplus but to save it. Three-quarters of the budget surplus would go to the Social Security and Medicare trust funds, which would save some of the money directly and use most of it to reduce the national debt. With the Government soaking up less private savings, more would be available for corporate investment. Most economists -- and especially conservative economists -- consider this the best way to boost economic productivity.
Indeed, Republicans do not dispute the conservative merits of debt reduction. Instead, they throw up their hands and moan that it is not realistic.
"Knowing the proclivities of democracy, and the Congress particularly," Representative Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, sighed last week, "it's very unlikely that that will happen." But the Republicans, not least Mr. Archer, are the very ones who are insuring it won't happen with their insistence that the surplus go toward tax cuts instead. It is reminiscent of the protection racketeer who sadly warns that the neighborhood is a dangerous place when he's the one who's making it dangerous.
So Republicans aren't arguing against debt reduction on economic grounds. Instead, they say the budget surplus "belongs to the American people." But what does this mean? Mr. Clinton, after all, isn't planning on giving the surplus to foreigners or setting it on fire; he wants to put it toward an end that benefits the American economy as a whole.
The Republicans, by contrast, are making a distributional argument. They want the surplus to reduce income taxes, most of which are paid by the well off. Mr. Clinton's plan, then, is concerned with enlarging the size of the economic pie, while the Republicans are more interested in how to divide it up.
According to conservatives, the most dangerous part of the Clinton proposal is investing a portion the Social Security trust fund in stocks, so that, in the long run, the higher returns help keep the program solvent. As a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, Kevin Hassett, put it, "If the Government owned all the equities, we wouldn't really be much different than the old Soviet Union." Really? The absence of free elections, the suppression of dissidents, the state-run economy, the furry hats -- all that in one seemingly innocuous accounting shift?
If the fearmongering is working, it's because it seems to make sense at first blush. Having the Government own shares of the private sector is indeed dangerous. But listen to what Mr. Clinton actually proposes to do.
He wants to take a small portion of the budget surplus and turn it over to the Social Security trust fund. The trust fund would give the money to an independent board, whose members would be insulated from political influence the same way members of the Federal Reserve are. They would hire private-sector fund managers to invest the money in passive index funds and forfeit all voting rights on those shares. Could future Congresses change the rules if they wanted to attach strings to the money? Sure, but they could do the same thing to the Federal Reserve -- a far more tempting target.
There may well be some flaws in this proposal that haven't come to light. But conservatives haven't even tried to figure out what these might be, preferring instead to dismiss it out of hand.
It's not hard to figure out why. Conservatives have never warmed to Social Security, particularly the way it redistributes wealth. Republicans thought Social Security reform would give them an opportunity to privatize the system. Their most politically potent argument was that a privatized system would allow individuals to enjoy the higher returns that the stock market historically yields. But if you can get those higher returns without privatizing, as Mr. Clinton suggests, then privatization loses its appeal to all but hard-core conservatives.
Congressional critics are making much of the fact that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, expressed his opposition to putting the trust fund in stocks. But Mr. Greenspan also said using the surplus for debt reduction -- the main element of the Clinton plan -- would be preferable to tax cuts. In truth, there is no reason to give special deference to Mr. Greenspan's views on budgets and taxes. He is responsible for monetary policy, on which we quite properly hang on his every word, but on other matters his thoughts should count for no more than those of any other conservative economist.
The political genius of Mr. Clinton's plan is that it marries good policy with good politics. This used to be what Republicans called responsible budgeting. How sad that they now see it as unacceptable. 
http://www.nytimes.com

INDUSTRY: SIC8733 NONCOMMERCIAL RESEARCH ORGANIZATIONS (50%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

COMPANY: AMERICAN ENTERPRISE INSTITUTE FOR PUBLIC POLICY RESEARCH (50%); MEDICARE (83%);

HEADLINE: 3M Reports Drop Of 4.9% in Profit

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the maker of more than 50,000 industrial and consumer products, said today that its fourth-quarter profits fell 4.9 percent.
Fourth-quarter earnings before a charge fell to $348 million, or 86 cents a diluted share, from $366 million, or 89 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected earnings of 80 cents a share. 
 Revenue rose 1.9 percent, to $3.79 billion from $3.71 billion. 3M, widely viewed as an economic bellwether because of the diversity of its products and regional markets, gets more than half its revenue overseas. United States revenue rose 1 percent, to $1.77 billion. Overseas revenue rose 3 percent, to $2.01 billion.
In the fourth quarter, the company took a charge of $99 million for production improvements and $38 million to refinance the debt of its employee stock-ownership plan. The charges resulted in net income of $211 million, or 52 cents a share. There were no gains or charges in the period a year earlier.
Shares of 3M rose $3.8125 today, to $75.125.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Banana TalksWith Europe Turn Nasty U.S.

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Prospects for a quick end to the increasingly acerbic trade row between the United States and the European Union over bananas faded today as a compromise was rejected and American efforts to move ahead with sanctions were blocked, at least temporarily.
After negotiations on Sunday, the two sides returned to the table for hours, breaking away from a scheduled meeting of the 133-member World Trade Organization to consider a compromise, but to no avail. 
 The United States argues that the big American fruit distributors Chiquita Brands International and the Dole Food Company are illegally restrained from selling Latin American-grown bananas in Europe. Backed by Latin American countries, Washington won a W.T.O. panel ruling in 1997 that European import regulations favored Caribbean nations, many of which were former European colonies. A revised European banana trade policy went into effect on Jan. 1, but the United States contends that it still violates international trade rules.
It says the European Union's failure to comply with the ruling sets off retaliatory measures.
The 15-nation European Union insists that its new regulations meet the 1997 panel's requirements. Its trade negotiator, Roderick Abbott, has called for a new panel to review compliance before any sanctions are approved. United States trade officials are seeking immediate approval for $520 million in sanctions against the European Union.
A compromise, offered by Renato Ruggiero, the head of the World Trade Organization, would have allowed the compliance-review panel to also rule on whether the proposed American sanctions were fair. Under trade organization rules, the sanctions must be equal to the amount of trade that American companies have lost from discriminatory banana imports.
When they failed to compromise, the two sides squared off in what was described as a "bad-tempered discussion" over the American request for approval of its sanctions. Two Caribbean banana-exporting countries, St. Lucia and Dominica, refused to go along and blocked the adoption of the agenda where the sanctions were to be discussed.
The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, accused the European Union of taking the "extraordinary step of shutting down the work" of the trade organization to stave off punitive sanctions.
"Fortunately, we will have another opportunity tomorrow to see if the E.U. will reconsider this drastic step and permit the W.T.O. meeting to proceed," Ms. Barshefsky said in a statement from Washington. The blocked agenda will be the subject of a trade organization meeting on Tuesday.
Diplomats fear that the dispute could escalate into a trade war and jeopardize the organization. "This dispute deteriorates the whole W.T.O. system," said Rita Hayes, the chief United States delegate. "You can't pick and choose the rules you wanted to abide by."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
American Express Net Up 7.5% in Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The American Express Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 7.5 percent as card holders spent more on their cards and as its asset-management unit collected more fees from investors pouring money into mutual funds.
The travel and financial services company said its net income rose to $530 million, or $1.16 a diluted share, compared with $493 million, or $1.04 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. That met Wall Street's expectations. 
 Shares of American Express, which is based in New York, rose $3, to $101.50.
"They did a good job considering what's going on worldwide" with troubled foreign economies, said Thomas Facciola, an analyst at Lehman Brothers Inc. "They're sticking to their knitting and doing what they do best."
Net income at the charge card and travel unit rose 16 percent, to a record $326 million, as the number of card holders rose and people spent more using their cards. Spending per card holder rose to $1,861, from $1,731 a year earlier, as the company increased the number of merchants that accept its cards and people took advantage of its rewards program.
Earnings at the financial advisers unit, historically the company's fastest-growing business, rose 14 percent, to $209 million, a record, as it increased assets under management. The unit offers mutual funds and other services to investors.

LENGTH: 1329 words

HEADLINE: For Couture, the Show Will Go On

BYLINE: By CATHY HORYN 

 BODY:
Whether because of the economy, the euro, media hype, Bernard Arnault, an infusion of new money from Germany and the former Eastern Bloc, or just the same old let-them-eat-cake attitude, haute couture doesn't appear to be a glamorous dodo bird after all.
It was eight years ago -- July 1991, to be exact -- that Pierre Berge, the outspoken head of Yves Saint Laurent, stood before a small group of reporters in the emptied ballroom of the Intercontinental Hotel in Paris and memorably said: "Believe me, it's true when I tell you these are the last days for haute couture. Maybe not tomorrow or next month, but in 10 years it will be finished." 
 That, of course, was before anyone knew what to make of Mr. Arnault, the upstart chairman of the luxury conglomerate LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, who four years before Mr. Berge's dire prediction was managing his family's real estate holdings in New Rochelle, N.Y. That was before John Galliano, who ran through investors like a small child running through a candy shop, turned up at Dior in a George Brent mustache and set Paris on its ear with swooning romance. And that was before anyone had heard of the Lebanese-born Mouna al-Rashid, a big couture customer, or the Miller sisters or, for that matter, young France Goldman of Boca Raton, Fla., who was in the front row at all the major shows last week with her husband, David, and expected to order something from each of her four or five favorite houses.
One week after the conclusion of the semiannual showings of haute couture in Paris, reports of the death of this anachronistic and outrageously indulgent institution are exaggerated.
"Listen, this is a very different world," said John Rosecrans as he waited to go into the Dior show with his wife, Dodie, who had on a pencil-thin gray suit with a pair of black Manolo Blahnik monkey-fur boots. Mr. Rosecrans, who was in the toy and sporting goods business before selling to Mattel, says he comes to couture for its sense of refinement, not to mention the frenetic social scene. And he can still recall the first dress he picked out for his wife (a cerise Balenciaga gown) right after they were married 39 years ago. "There are a lot of people who enjoy spending money on clothes," he said. "I think it's a wonderful thing to do."
In good times or bad, couture has always been the domain of a few rich nomads -- titled Europeans, Arabian princesses, the socially registered -- who don't mind spending $20,000 for a little black dress. Even onlookers, like the actress Katherine Boorman, daughter of the director John Boorman, can be caught up in couture's elusiveness. "You're inspired," Ms. Boorman said before the Chanel show. "And that's thrilling enough.
Yet, while couture seems a curiously old-fashioned pursuit for avant-garde designers like Jean-Paul Gaultier and the Dutch-born Josephus Thimister, the clients themselves have also changed with the times.
"What's different is they have no time," said Joy Hendricks, director of couture sales at Chanel, sounding the lament of every women. "Either they don't want to come to Paris for two fittings, or they want their clothes sooner than they can be made." Giancarlo Giametti, the partner of Valentino, agreed. "The clients don't want to come to Rome," he said. "You don't think of the woman who goes to Le Cirque every day for lunch. That's finished." The upshot is that most big houses now keep a sales executive on the road most of the time. Another difference is that clients are buying fewer daytime looks -- those they evidently get from ready-to-wear designers -- and more evening and special occasion clothes, particularly for weddings. A few days before Alexander McQueen's spring show last week, Caroline Grouvel, the couture sales director at Givenchy, said that she had already booked three weddings from the collection, even though the clients had yet to see it. Last year, Christian Lacroix's workrooms produced clothes for 28 weddings, an extraordinary number considering a couture wedding gown costs at least $150,000 and most clients buy for the other members of the wedding as well.
Though the fashion press still fusses over clients who have social or royal pedigrees -- and looks askance at those in the front row who wear diamonds in the afternoon -- the truth is couture has always depended on new-money customers. "I hate this word 'new,' " Ms. Hendricks said, frowning. "I mean, there are new people coming along, new money. So what?" Today, customers come not from France, but from Brazil, Mexico, Germany and the United States. Nunzio Palamara, head of couture sales at Versace, says he has a German client who buys 25 to 50 pieces a season, which represents millions of dollars. Givenchy has a male customer who buys a couple of frocks every season -- for art, you understand.
That's one thing about the couture houses -- they don't discriminate. Money is money, whether it comes from ancient aristocrats or the daughters of Russian arms dealers. "Anyway, we're not the foreign office," Dior's press chief, Bernard Danillon de Cazella, said.
Mr. Berge, in his Paris office on the Avenue Marceau, agreed that new designers have brought an excitement to couture, but he hasn't changed his stance about its doomed future. "For me, there is only one new designer," he said. "It's Gaultier. You have other people, more or less, more or less" -- Mr. Berge rolled his eyes -- "that are a joke."
Mr. Berge, who has said that he would close the Saint Laurent couture house the day Mr. Saint Laurent retired, continued: "You have to understand, haute couture is not only for fashion shows. It is not only for two rich women who can buy a rich look. That is not the destiny of haute couture. The destiny is to help with the art of living. And my question today is: What is the art of life? I'm not blind. I can see how people in the streets dress. They don't care. They are miles and miles away from haute couture."
Nor does Mr. Berge buy the conventional wisdom that the publicity that couture generates for the house, and its other lines, is enough to justify its existence. He could be right. Mr. Danillon de Cazella of Dior may point with pride to his binders of press clippings, but has Mr. Galliano -- and his employer, LVMH -- really succeeded in exploiting the attention given to couture to sell ready-to-wear and perfume? Many fashion insiders say there is a gulf between what Mr. Galliano creates and what Dior's image is in the consumer's mind.
Indeed, there were signs last week of frustration in the LVMH ranks, with designers complaining about management's failure to market their creativity. "If they don't know what direction they want, how can I give it to them?" Mr. McQueen asked. Mr. Lacroix, too, sounded weary about some LVMH strategies. "A lot of money has been spent in the wrong ways," he said over a sandwich after his triumphant show. "They have very poor follow through."
Small wonder that designers like Mr. Thimister and the Dutch team of Viktor and Rolf, who showed a strangely wonderful Victorian silhouette, are choosing a different path. "We all realize now, the marginal people, that all this publicity and image has a fake value," Mr. Thimister said. "It's what the new generation is really fighting against. It's why things have become more personal and sensible."
Didier Grumbach, the new, well-respected president of the French federation that governs couture, sees a limitless future for the institution and would like to change the rules to open the door to more designers.
"It's absolutely the trend to buy something more and more specific," Mr. Grumbach said. "Fashion will go toward smaller categories of people and taste."
And strange as it must seem for designers like Mr. Thimister, who is 35 and came of age in the Belgian avante-garde, with no aspirations of empire building, the best way to express themselves is through the individuality of haute couture.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
After 23 Years, Justices Will Revisit Campaign Limits

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
In a case that brings the debate over money and politics back to the Supreme Court's door, the Justices agreed today to decide whether the strict contribution limits the Court upheld for Federal elections 23 years ago are still constitutionally valid.
The issue reached the Court not in the context of the Federal law the Justices addressed then, in the Buckley v. Valeo decision, but as a challenge to a 1994 Missouri election law that incorporated the same limits of $1,000 per election. 
 In a Nov. 30 ruling, a Federal appeals court panel in St. Louis struck down the Missouri law on the ground that the limits were "so small that they run afoul of the Constitution by unnecessarily restricting protected First Amendment freedoms." Limits that made sense in 1976, when they were upheld by the Supreme Court in the Buckley case, have been so eroded by inflation as to stand in the way of "meaningful participation in protected political speech and association," the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit said.
In one analysis in the case, the current value of $1,000 in 1976 dollars is $2,500. The Missouri limit has been adjusted for inflation under a state legislative formula, and was $1,075 when the appeals court struck it down; there are now no contribution limits in effect in the state.
Missouri told the Supreme Court that the appeals court had placed many similar state campaign laws in an intolerable constitutional limbo.
"It would be difficult to find an issue of greater national significance that both requires and warrants some measure of legal certainty," Jeremiah W. Nixon, Missouri's Attorney General, told the Court. The constitutionality of the Federal limits is also at stake, Mr. Nixon said.
While it is by no means certain, or perhaps not even likely, that the Justices will use this case as a vehicle for a broad revisiting of the Buckley decision, the prospect is there. Inexplicably, the Court indicated today that it would not hear the case until next fall, meaning that a decision might not come until a year or more from now. The state had filed its appeal with unusual speed, in less than two weeks rather than the allowable 90 days, in the hope that the Justices would be able to hear the case in April and decide it by the end of the current term in June. April is the last month during which the Justices hear arguments, and they have scheduled only 12 arguments for a calendar that can accommodate 24.
While accepting the state's appeal, Nixon v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC, No. 98-963, the Court took no action on a companion appeal that raised more directly the continued viability of Buckley v. Valeo.
This second case, filed by a member of the Missouri House of Representatives, asked the Court to decide "whether the analytic structure undergirding Buckley v. Valeo has become so confused and unwieldy as to call for reconsideration of the relationship between the First Amendment and content-neutral efforts to regulate the financing of political campaigns." (Bray v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC, No. 98-978)
The Buckley decision has come under intense criticism recently, not for its upholding of the Federal contribution limits, but for the other half of the decision, which equated campaign spending with political speech and struck down expenditure limits. Despite the criticism that the decision has made it impossible to regulate the flow of money into politics, the Court has not displayed much appetite for revisiting it.
In fact, the action today may reflect primarily the Court's sense of obligation to clarify the contribution issue. In a 1997 case from Kentucky, another Federal appeals court, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, upheld a $1,000 contribution limit against a similar challenge, and it is now clear that the judicial unanimity that has prevailed for more than two decades is beginning to fray.
The Eighth Circuit in the Missouri case subjected the state law to an analysis that differed considerably from the approach the Supreme Court took in the Buckley decision. The appeals court said a high level of proof was necessary -- "demonstrable evidence" of "genuine problems" from large political contributions -- to justify the limits. The Supreme Court in the Buckley decision accepted anecdotal evidence and said that the Government only had to prove that the problems were "not illusory."
There were also these other actions on an extremely busy day at the Court.
 
Congressional Power
Taking up an important question of Federal-state authority, the Court agreed to decide whether Congress had the authority to make states liable to suit in Federal court for violating the Federal law that bars age discrimination on the job. In a decision last year, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, refused to allow an age discrimination suit against Florida by current and former faculty members of two state universities. The Justices accepted appeals from both the plaintiffs (Kimel v. Florida, No. 98-791) and from the Federal Government, which supported them (U.S. v. Florida, No. 98-796).
 
Police Records
Accepting an appeal from the Los Angeles Police Department, the Court agreed to decide the constitutionality of a California law under which various police records can be released to the public but may not be used for commercial purposes.
The law was challenged by a publishing service that provides names of people who have been arrested or who are victims of crime and sells the information to lawyers, insurance companies, driving schools and others. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled last year that the law violated the company's First Amendment right to commercial speech. The case is Los Angeles Police Department v. United Reporting Publishing Corp., No. 98-678.

HEADLINE: Talking Back to Greenspan

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich teaches economic and social policy at Brandeis and is writing a book on the future of work.

 BODY:
I do not believe that it is politically feasible to insulate such huge funds from a governmental direction," Alan Greenspan told the House Ways and Means Committee last week, one day after President Clinton proposed investing a portion of Social Security funds in the stock market.
Mr. Greenspan was equally forthright in criticizing the President's proposal to raise the minimum wage to $6.15 an hour from $5.15. "My own preference would be to lower it and, in fact, eliminate the minimum wage because I think that it does more damage than good," he told the committee. 
 Pundits are now declaring Mr. Clinton's stock plan to be in deep trouble, in large part because Mr. Greenspan opposes it. And a new cloud also hangs over the possibility of raising the minimum wage.
Rarely has the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board been so outspokenly critical of the White House. Rarely, in fact, has Mr. Greenspan been outspoken about much of anything.
The forcefulness of Mr. Greenspan's criticisms is especially peculiar in light of the unwritten -- yet inviolable -- rule that the President and his Administration must never criticize the policies of Mr. Greenspan. (As Secretary of Labor, I once had the temerity to suggest to a reporter that the Fed "might" pay a "bit" more attention to the unemployment rate when setting short-term interest rates -- and within an hour received a call from the then-Treasury Secretary strongly suggesting that I should be more circumspect.)
The Administration's rule of silence about the Fed is not a result of Mr. Greenspan's popularity with the public. Most Americans have no clear idea what he and his colleagues do. Nor is the rule invoked because Mr. Greenspan and the Fed have been perceptive enough or lucky enough in recent years to have kept the economy from overheating or overcooling. No one knows exactly why the economy is enjoying its longest peacetime recovery, but the Fed deserves credit for not messing it up.
In fact, the rule of silence was in place before the current recovery gained strength. It was there right from the start of the Clinton Administration. It was probably in place in 1987, when President Ronald Reagan first appointed Mr. Greenspan.
The truth is that the White House cannot criticize Mr. Greenspan because Wall Street would take any such criticism as a sign that the executive branch was not as serious as the Fed about preventing inflation. The Street's resulting "lack of confidence" would send interest rates up and stock and bond prices down.
I am not aware of any study that has verified this assumption, but that's beside the point. Like so much other lore surrounding the mysterious ways of our capital markets, it has its own prophetic power, simply because so many traders believe it, and, presumably, they are prepared to act upon it.
The result has been the muzzling of any discussion by the executive branch about monetary policy. This is doubly paradoxical because monetary policy is the only major remaining policy lever over jobs and wages -- of larger consequence than any Presidential proposal on Social Security or the minimum wage.
Decades ago, the economy could be nudged either by reducing short-term interest rates or by increasing net Federal spending, or both. But now the car has only one pedal. Fiscal policy is dead. Budgets have to be balanced. The President even wants to reduce the national debt.
So what might the President say, were he allowed to comment on Mr. Greenspan's policies with the same forthrightness that Mr. Greenspan has commented on the President's? I have no direct knowledge. (Wall Street can relax.) But here's one possibility: The President might say that Mr. Greenspan could do a great deal of good by reducing interest rates once again when he and his colleagues meet next week.
Even though short-term interest rates are three-quarters of a point lower than they were in September, there's room to lower them further. After all, inflation has now utterly vanished. It has gone largely because much of the rest of the world is in recession, but also because new information technologies have caused domestic competition to intensify so much that producers dare not raise prices. And most workers -- knowing how easily they can be replaced by technology or by global "outsourcing" were their wages to rise -- dare not demand raises.
On the other hand, consider the benefits of lower interest rates. A tighter labor market would induce employers around America to do what they have begun to do in places where unemployment has dropped below 3 percent. They are recruiting workers from central cities and from rural backwaters where joblessness continues to be relatively high, then training them and even paying them wages above the minimum.
Mr. Greenspan's forthrightness about the President's proposals also deserves a candid response.
If Mr. Greenspan does not believe the Government should try to extend the life of the Social Security trust fund by putting part of the proceeds into the stock market, he has another option. Were he and his colleagues to cut interest rates and thus reduce unemployment still further, more workers and their employers would pay into the trust fund. As a result, Social Security's day of reckoning would be delayed for years, or perhaps forever.
Likewise, if Mr. Greenspan opposes the minimum wage, let alone the prospect of raising it, he could cut interest rates and thus tighten the labor market further. That way, employers would be induced to pay people at the bottom a bit more. Presto. No need for a mandatory rise in the minimum wage.
The President's proposals are now open to public debate. Mr. Greenspan is free to criticize them, as is everyone else. Congress can ditch them, and may very well do so. That's the way democracy works. But the proposal that Mr. Greenspan makes to the Fed's Open Market Committee next week about what should happen to interest rates is not open to public debate. Not only is the President in effect barred from commenting, but Congress has no role to play. All Mr. Greenspan must do is convince a majority of the Fed that he's right.
Mr. Greenspan may be wise, but he's not always right. He, and the rest of us, need to keep that in mind.
