SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1483 words

HEADLINE: Best-Selling Author's Gloomy Future for Los Angeles Meets Resistance

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26

 BODY:
On a winter Sunday morning of the sort that only Southern California seems to produce, under a brilliant blue sky scoured clean of clouds and smog, a crowd of upper-middle-class Angelenos filed into the Skirball Cultural Center and plunked down $10 each to hear a conversation with their city's reigning prophet of doom.
In two best-selling books, "City of Quartz," published in 1990, and "Ecology of Fear," issued last fall, that man, Mike Davis, has portrayed Los Angeles as a false paradise ruled by malign elites who have stifled the poor, built a fortress downtown surrounded by a growing ring of dying suburbs, and courted environmental disaster by heedlessly encroaching on canyons and cliffsides never meant for mass habitation. 
 For this Mr. Davis, a one-time meat-cutter and now full-time Marxist urbanologist, has been hailed as something like a hero, not only by the coast-to-coast school of critics who have long looked askance at Los Angeles, but by his fellow Southern Californians whose unrelenting misery he presumes to celebrate. The winner of a $315,000 MacArthur Foundation "genius" grant, he has also won an unquestioned place on the short list of serious thinkers about a city whose prevailing culture has long been a blend of oligarchical boosterism and noir self-loathing.
When a questioner at the Skirball Center gestured to the sunny splendor of the Sepulveda Pass outside and asked if Los Angeles was really so bad, Mr. Davis, 52, acknowledged with a rueful laugh, "I wake up in the morning and look at the San Gabriel Mountains in incredible January -- even if it may be a symptom of global warming -- and I ask myself, 'Are you crazy?' "
For the first time, a growing chorus of Californians is effectively answering, "Yes!"
"Ecology of Fear" (Metropolitan Books), with its thesis that the modern megalopolis of Los Angeles has no business existing in the earthquake-ridden Southern California desert, has unleashed a pent-up firestorm of criticism over Mr. Davis's methods after 16 weeks on the local best-seller list ("City of Quartz" is No. 5 on the paperback list).
Critics have cast grave doubt on many of the obscure and startling factoids that are Mr. Davis's stock in trade, calling into question his broader argument that Los Angeles is a hopelessly damned creature of unchecked real estate speculation and the mercenary folly of its ruling class.
The debate has pitted rival camps of the city's interpreters against each other in a fight more typical of New York or Paris than of laid-back Los Angeles. Academics, alternative weeklies, business journals and The Los Angeles Times have all weighed in, with everything from Mr. Davis's birthplace (the desert suburb of Fontana, not Los Angeles, as the book jacket of "Ecology" says) to his marriages (he is on his fifth) grist for the mill. As a topic of collective conversation, he is not quite on a par with the Dodgers or the latest grosses, but he is gaining.
"In my opinion, it is a significant development in the intellectual history of Los Angeles -- and don't gasp, there is such a thing," said Kevin Starr, the state librarian of California whose own histories of the Golden State, like "Inventing the Dream" (Oxford University Press, 1985) have been hailed as authoritative. "The decade of the 90's began with 'City of Quartz' and its elegantly presented noir vision of Los Angeles as a repressive conspiracy, and sure enough, all these noir aspects came out, beginning with the riots in '92.
"At the end of the decade," Mr. Starr continued, "there's a different situation. Immigrant groups have revitalized the Los Angeles economy, the mood is better, and here comes a book that really makes us think about earthquakes and the epicycle of climatological reality.
"Davis's offering of an unmitigatedly apocalyptic point of view is now meeting with resistance. There's going to be some bad manners, some fighting back and forth. But you've got people caring about L.A. and the theory of L.A., and I think that's very important."
Mr. Davis, whose unruly shock of white hair and soft, half-swallowed speaking voice convey an aura about as threatening as Linus in "Peanuts," has been caught in some embarrassing mistakes. For starters, he has acknowledged fabricating an entire conversation with a local environmentalist, Lewis McAdams, for a cover story he wrote for L.A. Weekly a decade ago; he defends it as an early attempt at journalistic scene-setting.
In "City of Quartz" (Verso, 1990), discussing the power divisions between the city's old and new elites, he misidentified the late Howard Ahmanson, the founder of the giant Home Savings empire and a conservative Christian, as Jewish, and he also described Hancock Park, one of the city's oldest WASP enclaves, as a Jewish neighborhood.
He also acknowledges that he cannot find the source for his assertion in "Ecology of Fear" that as many as 30 bodies a year have been found in drug-plagued MacArthur Park near downtown, a claim the police dismiss as wildly off-base.
"The book is a, you know, polemic, with a lot of irony and humor in it," Mr. Davis said in a two-hour interview at a pub near his home in Pasadena. "It has sailed over the heads of some people."
But Mr. Davis's critics say he has so twisted the facts as to make honest debate impossible. The latest critique of Mr. Davis, for example, in the weekly New Times L.A., leaves little doubt that his new book's portrait of suburban Pomona as a deserted husk is at best outdated, ignoring a decade of revival.
Joel Kotkin, a fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy in Malibu and one of Mr. Davis's most vociferous critics, said, "What bothers me even as a person who was trained as a Marxist is that somebody would so bastardize Marxist theory to the point of making things up."
Mr. Davis's particular calling card has been his unearthing of obscure, even fantastic, facts about Los Angeles's experience with natural and scientific phenomena, from monsoon-intensity rain to little-noticed tornados to mountain lions that prowl the city's suburban fringe. One chapter in "Ecology of Fear," on wildfires, is titled, "The Case for Letting Malibu Burn."
But Brady Westwater, a Malibu real-estate agent and amateur local historian who has appointed himself Mr. Davis's one-man truth squad, has produced reams of material, circulated on the Internet and among publications here and in New York, questioning almost every claim he makes.
"There's something pathological about it," said Mr. Westwater, who cites, as just one example among dozens, Mr. Davis's assertion that local news organizations have long played down Southern California's experience with tornado-like storms.
"I checked the L.A. Times article he actually cites as evidence of this reluctance, and it uses the words 'tornado' or 'twister' 13 times," Mr. Westwater said. "You don't even have to check other sources to prove he's lying. He does it himself."
Mr. Davis calmly contends that any book of such length and ambition (it is 461 pages, including footnotes) is bound to contain errors. "The thing you have to understand about these books is I'm a socialist," he said. "This book has an utterly radical political agenda, no holds barred."
In fact, Mr. Davis, who has taught at the Southern California Institute of Architecture and is now on the verge of accepting a three-year appointment to teach history "deep in the faux-Colonial architecture of Suffolk County," at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, seems to slide reflexively into hyperbole.
He referred to a friend, William Deverell, a respected professor in his late 30's at the California Institute of Technology, as "the dean of L.A. historians." He mused of his recent visit to a Times Square seemingly devoid of homeless people: "What's Giuliani done? Built gas chambers in Queens or something?"
Doug Dutton, who owns the respected independent bookstore in Brentwood that bears his name, had a long list of orders for "Ecology" before it was even published. He said Mr. Davis has "an enormous following" among his upscale customers.
"I can't help but think to a certain extent that if you agree with his theories, you'll like the book, and if you don't, you won't," Mr. Dutton said. "It's a kind of analysis that's very personal, almost a grand unified theory for Los Angeles."
Mr. Davis insists he loves the city, which is why he is so hard on it, and says he is trying to inspire a new generation of labor activists, environmentalists and academics to carry on the battles for social justice that he himself fought as a civil rights protester and member of Students for a Democratic Society in the 60's.
But he acknowledged: "Some people like the book because they like the glamor of decay and apocalypse. Those people aren't the people I write for, although they probably help sell the book."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
S.E.C. Official Takes Position At Bear Stearns

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Richard R. Lindsey, the director of market regulation for the Securities and Exchange Commission, is stepping down to join a unit of the Bear Stearns Companies that is being investigated by the Manhattan District Attorney and Federal regulators.
Mr. Lindsey, 44, will become a senior managing director at the company and the No. 2 person at the Bear Stearns Clearing Corporation, which processes and guarantees the trades of small firms, maintains their customers' accounts and lends them money. He is expected to begin in March. 
 Mr. Lindsey's move to a company that is under scrutiny by regulators and the authorities is sure to raise eyebrows. At issue in the investigations is Bear Stearns's role in the demise of A. R. Baron & Company, a small brokerage firm in New York City that failed in 1996. Bear Stearns was Baron's clearing firm. Customers of A. R. Baron lost $75 million in what the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, called a criminal enterprise. Mr. Morgenthau's office won convictions against 14 Baron employees in 1997.
"This is an intriguing move by Bear Stearns," said Lewis D. Lowenfels, a securities lawyer in New York who represents a firm that lost money with A. R. Baron. "The larger question is what effect this will have on their pending investigations and litigation."
As is its custom, the S.E.C. would neither confirm nor deny that it is investigating Bear Stearns's role in the failure. Mr. Morgenthau had no comment on what effect Mr. Lindsey's hiring might have on his office's continuing investigation.
James E. Cayne, the president and chief executive of Bear Stearns, said that Mr. Lindsey's hiring was not an effort to shore up the brokerage firm's reputation or credibility. "His basic function is to come into the correspondent clearing company at Bear Stearns," Mr. Cayne said. "It is a very big part of our business. He is a visionary; he's got a terrific reputation."
According to Mr. Cayne, Richard Harriton, head of the Bear Stearns clearing unit, will remain in the top job. There is currently no second in command.
Mr. Lindsey became director of market regulation at the S.E.C. in November 1995 after serving as the commission's chief economist. He came to the S.E.C. from Yale University, where he was a professor of finance.
Before teaching, Mr. Lindsey was a research engineer for Owens Corning Fiberglas and later worked for the Certainteed Corporation, a privately held maker of fiberglass, first as manager of process engineering and then as plant manager for the company's plant in Dallas. Mr. Lindsey has a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from the Illinois Institute of Technology, an M.B.A. from the University of Dallas and a doctorate in finance from the University of California at Berkeley.
As the chief regulator of the securities markets, Mr. Lindsey has been responsible for a number of S.E.C. initiatives, including regulations developed late last year that allow for the creation of new stock exchanges through alternative trading systems. He was the first director of market regulation who was not a lawyer.
But Mr. Lindsey's biggest accomplishment was carrying out the S.E.C.'s order-handling rules in 1997, which required that customers who wanted to buy or sell Nasdaq stocks at prices in between the current bid and asked prices could have their orders displayed on the national quotation system. This rule change, which came out of the enforcement action brought in 1996 by the S.E.C. against Nasdaq for unfair trading practices, has made it easier for individual investors to meet on Nasdaq rather than having to place trades through an intermediary.
"Richard Lindsey was the catalyst for dramatic changes in the way our markets operate, saving investors billions of dollars a year," said Arthur Levitt, chairman of the S.E.C. "He really was the architect of the order-handling rules, and he went around to firms and he sold it."
Even though he was the commission's chief market regulator, people close to Mr. Lindsey said he had not been involved in the Bear Stearns matter. As a Bear Stearns employee, he must follow strict Government guidelines in dealing with his former colleagues at the S.E.C.. He cannot appear before the commission, for example, or telephone or write to former colleagues there for a year after he leaves. And Mr. Lindsey cannot ever lobby the S.E.C. on any matter that he may have worked on while he was a regulator.
Mr. Lindsey said his decision to join Bear Stearns crystallized in the last two weeks. He declined to comment on what his pay would be.
"I believe that I have a lot of things to contribute," Mr. Lindsey said. "I've had a long management history working in a lot of different types of organizations. That usually brings something to the table to see where you need to take things."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil's Currency Plunges In a Day of Wide Swings

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Brazil's currency swung wildly in foreign-exchange dealings today and briefly fell to a low of nearly two to the dollar because of growing uncertainty about the country's economic health.
The volatility in the currency, the real, came as another credit rating service lowered its assessment of Brazil's ability to repay debts. The action by Fitch IBCA, coming atop a downgrade by the Duff & Phelps service on Monday, partly reflected worries that the Government lacks the leadership to deal with an economic crisis that is growing more acute. 
 But the anxiety about Latin America's largest economy appeared to have little effect on the stock market, where the key index rose 6.33 percent on purchases by investors who thought shares were selling at bargain levels.
Brazil has been in an increased state of economic turmoil since the Government abruptly decided more than a week ago to stop defending the value of the real by buying the currency in the foreign-exchange market. It had spent billions of dollars in foreign reserves with that approach but the real's value kept falling.
The cheapened currency, in turn, has unnerved consumers and investors because it threatens the return of higher inflation and has raised the costs of servicing the country's foreign debts. An estimated $42 billion in debts is coming due in the next few months.
But with pressure growing for economic austerity measures from the Government, the central bank's president, Francisco Lopes, told the Brazilian Senate today that no new steps were forthcoming.
A team of technical experts from the International Monetary Fund arrived in Brazil to review the country's economic performance under an agreement for a $41.5 billion standby loan. The fund's approval will be needed before a second allotment of the loan, originally due to be disbursed in late February, can be released.
The main barometer of Brazil's economic slide has become the real, which fell to 1.955 to the dollar before rebounding to settle at 1.85, compared with 1.78 on Monday. At many banks, which charge foreign-exchange fees, citizens and tourists had to pay a rate of two reais to the dollar.
This week, the Brazilian Congress is scheduled to vote on 28 billion reais ($16 billion) of cuts to this year's budget, and to finish voting on Social Security reform legislation. It will also vote on extending and increasing a tax on financial transactions.
But without any more ambitious plans to cut costs, economists said, the Brazilian Government risks a repeat of the kind of capital flight and panic that has gripped the nation for much of this month.
"If you look at the events of the last week or so, you get the impression that the Government has just taken a back seat," said Philip Smith, a banking expert at Fitch IBCA. "What you've got is very much a void where people don't know what the strategy is."
President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, simultaneously facing a punishing recession and the return of high inflation, convened panels of ministers to find ways to invigorate economic growth. The Finance Minister, Pedro Malan, was not included on either of the panels. Joao Pimenta da Veiga, the Government's Communications Minister, said, however, that Mr. Malan would be consulted.
Telling the Senate Economic Affairs Committee not to expect any new austerity package, the central bank's Mr. Lopes said the votes that would be taken this week were "of the greatest importance, and are sufficient for the consolidation of the program of stability."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Warner-Lambert to Acquire Agouron for $2.1 Billion
Warner-Lambert, one of the hottest companies in the drug industry, said that it would acquire Agouron Pharmaceuticals, a small biotechnology firm, for $2.1 billion in stock.
The deal enables Warner-Lambert to add Agouron's Viracept, the nation's leading protease inhibitor, to its pipeline along with several other anti-viral and cancer drugs. Although the deal was announced after the market closed, shares of both stocks climbed steadily throughout the day before they were halted in afternoon trading. Shares of Warner-Lambert rose $1.625, to $69.125, while Agouron jumped $3.65625, or 6.9 percent, to $56.8125. Page C4. 

Earnings at four of the largest drug companies -- Merck, American Home Products, Schering-Plough and Johnson & Johnson -- met or slightly beat Wall Street expectations. C4.
 
More Instability in Brazil
Brazil's currency briefly tumbled to a rate of nearly two to the dollar as another credit-rating agency lowered its assessment of the nation's economic prospects and ability to repay debts. But the stock market rallied as buyers sensed bargains, pushing the main index up 6.33 percent. C5.
 
Mexico has weathered the worst blows of the global economic crisis and is not likely to suffer severe trauma from Brazil's instability, top finance officials said. C5.
 
Boeing Beats Wall Street Forecasts
Boeing, which released fourth-quarter results that were 3 cents a share better than expected, tried to reassure investors that it was finally turning itself around. But Wall Street remained skeptical, sending shares of the aerospace company down $1, to $35. C4.
 
Microsoft Witness on Competition
A senior Microsoft official testified in the Government's antitrust case that the company tried to persuade Netscape Communications, its main rival in the Internet software market, to become less of a head-on competitor. C2.
 
Coca-Cola Earnings Decline 27%
Confirming the bad news it had warned Wall Street analysts about last month, Coca-Cola reported its fourth-quarter earnings fell 27 percent as volume and revenue dropped in many parts of the world. C6.
 
Amazon.com, the on-line retailer, said its fourth-quarter loss widened less than expected, while sales almost quadrupled, as more holiday shoppers used it to buy gifts. C7.
 
Strong international sales and a rejuvenated United States restaurant business lifted McDonald's fourth-quarter profit 9 percent. C4.
 
Compaq Offers Stake in Alta Vista
Rod Schrock, the executive who introduced Compaq's Presario line of personal computers, was named president and chief executive of the new Alta Vista. Compaq Computer, which owns the Internet search engine, plans to sell a minority stake in it to the public as part of an effort to expand Alta Vista into a leading player in on-line advertising and shopping. The news follows the collapse of talks in which Compaq hoped to sell a stake in Alta Vista to Time Warner. C2.
 
Moody's Lowers Ratings on Mazda
Moody's Investors Service lowered its ratings on Mazda Motor's long-term unsecured debt to below investment grade, citing continued deterioration in the Japanese car market. C5.
 
British Newspaper Executive Quits
David Montgomery resigned as chief executive of Mirror Group, pressured to leave by board members and stockholders angry over his refusal to consider purchase offers for the company. Mr. Montgomery's departure opens the way for a takeover battle for one of Britain's oldest tabloid newspapers. C7.
 
Sotheby's Seeks Exclusive Deals
In an apparent attempt to undermine its archrival Christie's entry into the potentially lucrative on-line auction business, Sotheby's is asking art dealers to sign exclusive contracts that would prevent them from selling wares through other auction houses on line. B3.

HEADLINE: A Much-Shunned Terrorist Is Said to Find Haven in Iraq

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Abu Nidal, one of the world's most infamous terrorists, moved to Baghdad late last year and obtained the protection of President Saddam Hussein, according to intelligence reports received by United States and Middle Eastern government officials. The reports have raised questions about whether Iraq is pushing to establish a terrorism network, American and Middle Eastern officials say.
Abu Nidal, a brutal survivor of the Middle East's terrorist wars dating to the 1970's, had been living in Cairo for more than a year, according to Middle Eastern government officials who say they have information from inside his organization. While intelligence information about terrorist groups is hard to corroborate, American intelligence officials say they consider these Middle Eastern officials to be highly reliable. 
 Although Abu Nidal's organization is a shadow of the terrorist machine that staged airport killings in the mid-1980's and raids on Arab, Jewish and other targets, since he moved to Egypt he has been directing attacks on Islamic radicals at war with the Egyptian Government, the Middle Eastern officials said.
United States intelligence officials said he has been hard-pressed financially and has been seeking a new government sponsor since Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, looking for ways to persuade the United Nations to lift economic sanctions, backed away from him in the early 1990's.
Abu Nidal's move to Iraq, which he was forced to leave 15 years ago because of his ties to Syria, suggests that he may have renewed a relationship with President Hussein. "He could become a more significant threat again if he finds more effective state sponsorship," an American intelligence official said.
Abu Nidal still has 200 to 300 followers in his organization, and President Hussein lacks such hard-earned expertise at terrorism.
Officials caution that there is no evidence that Abu Nidal is planning to conduct terrorism on Iraq's behalf. In recent years he has not attacked American targets and thus has become a lower priority for American officials, who have focused instead on Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile who officials say ordered the bombings of embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in August.
But counterterrorism experts in the Middle East say Abu Nidal remains a significant threat. One official who has watched Abu Nidal for years said, "Osama bin Laden is a student by comparison."
About 10 days before American and British again attacked Iraq on Dec. 16, Abu Nidal traveled from Cairo to Baghdad through Teheran, Middle Eastern officials said.
Egyptian authorities have denied that he was recently in their country. But other Middle Eastern officials said Abu Nidal arrived in Cairo from Libya in 1997, and was in Egypt with the knowledge of Egypt's internal security service.
A coup attempt within his organization forced the Egyptians to take him into custody, which eventually drew wider attention to his presence in Egypt, posing a problem for the Government, the Middle Eastern officials said. Abu Nidal's move to Baghdad ended any embarrassing attention for Egypt, they added.
Though American officials had concluded that the Central Intelligence Agency and other intelligence services had blunted Iraq's previous efforts to sponsor terrorism, officials in Washington say that could change with the arrival of Abu Nidal.
Abu Nidal was once America's most wanted terrorist. A 1989 State Department report called his organization the most dangerous in the world, and a 1991 report calculated that it had been responsible for more than 100 attacks and the deaths of more than 280 people since 1974.
Abu Nidal, now about 60, is a Palestinian renegade who broke with the Palestinian Liberation Organization to launch his own terrorist campaign. He has had a long-running war with both the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and King Hussein of Jordan, accusing them of being too willing to compromise with Israel. He has vowed to kill both men, and the P.L.O. sentenced him to death in absentia in 1974.
Abu Nidal and President Hussein also have a tortured history, and their relationship is not built on mutual trust. Iraq helped Abu Nidal become an international terrorist in the early 1970's, but he left Baghdad in the early 1980's, in part because President Hussein had discovered that he was also working with Syria. "He was double dealing on Iraq," says one Middle Eastern expert.
Although he has a history of conducting terrorist acts on behalf of his hosts, Abu Nidal has also often worn out his welcome because of his willingness to betray his sponsors.
Reports last year that he was in Cairo proved awkward for the Clinton Administration because Egyptian support is vital to American policies in the region. Yet the United States has also expressed qualms about Egypt's counterterrorism, especially its ruthless tactics. The C.I.A. suspended a counterterrorism training program for a hostage-rescue unit from Egypt.
Washington did not press the Egyptians about Abu Nidal's presence: When the Administration asked about him last fall, Cairo denied that he was in the country, and Washington did not publicly protest.
Egyptian officials continue to deny that Abu Nidal was in Cairo, or that Egyptian intelligence was complicit in his terrorism. They note that Egypt was the victim of Abu Nidal in the past, and say their country would not deal with him.
"There is absolutely no foundation for any of these allegations," said an Egyptian Embassy spokesman, Abdelaleem Elabyad. "I was told to deny them in the most affirmative way."
American intelligence officials declined to comment on allegations that Abu Nidal conducted terrorist acts while in Egypt, or that the Egyptians knew of his actions. State Department officials said they were unaware of the allegations.
Born Sabri al-Banna in Palestine in 1938, Abu Nidal grew into a Palestinian nationalist. After briefly working in Saudi Arabia, he moved to Jordan and joined Fatah, the Palestinian movement that was the forerunner of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Mr. Arafat, the leader of Fatah, sent him to Sudan in 1969, and while there he apparently first came in contact with Iraqi intelligence officers. He briefly returned to Fatah headquarters in Amman, Jordan, but soon came to believe that Mr. Arafat was too willing to compromise with Israel.
Abu Nidal was next sent to be the P.L.O. representative in Baghdad, just as Iraq's relations with the Palestinian organization were souring. Baghdad refused to turn its army loose to support the Palestinians during the Black September uprising against Jordan in 1970. Abu Nidal, already out of favor with the P.L.O. leadership, allied himself with the new Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, and in 1973 he confiscated the organization's offices in Baghdad and declared that he had officially broken with the Palestinian group.
In 1973, with Iraqi weapons, training and intelligence support, he began a wave of terrorism when his group occupied the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Paris and took 11 people hostage.
Abu Nidal stayed in Iraq until November 1983, when he was forced out by President Hussein, who was seeking Western support in his war with Iran. Mr. Hussein had also discovered that Abu Nidal had established a secret intelligence relationship with Syria.
He then moved to Syria, staying until 1987 and carrying out a long string of terrorist acts against other Arab and Jewish targets, often working with Syrian intelligence. In 1986 he provided Syrian Air Force intelligence with the suitcase bomb used in an abortive attempt to blow up an El Al airliner in London, Middle Eastern officials say. A Syrian intelligence agent, Nezar Hindawi, was later convicted for trying to have his girlfriend carry the suitcase aboard an El Al plane at Heathrow.
But Abu Nidal once again had a falling out with his hosts after Syrian agents caught one of his lieutenants at the Damascus airport carrying sensitive documents and found weapons he had stored in Syria without their knowledge, according to Middle Eastern government officials.
In 1987 his organization shifted to Libya, while Abu Nidal moved to Poland for a year, where he was apparently protected by the Communist security service.
In Libya, internal feuds ripped his group apart. In 1989 and 1990, hundreds died in battles between Abu Nidal and dissidents supported by the P.L.O. who sought to take control of his operations in Libya and Lebanon.
In April 1998, after Abu Nidal moved to Egypt, a fundamentalist mosque in Sana, Yemen, was bombed. In July an Egyptian radical sheik, Mohammed Salah Abdal Mottalib, was killed at another mosque in Yemen. Al Hayat, a London-based Arab newspaper often used by militant groups, reported that one suspect in the killing was affiliated with the Abu Nidal organization.
Middle Eastern government officials also say his group was behind the mosque bombing and the attack on the sheik. In May 1998, the officials said, he met with a colleague, Rifqi al-Mahseri, and told him to plan the sheik's killing, but to act only after receiving a message from Abu Nidal.
On July 3, 1998, while living in Cairo, Abu Nidal was confronted by 10 members of his organization who wanted to end his control over the group. But the Government, tipped off to the coup attempt by a member of the group, convinced them to hold off. Two days later, on July 5, the Egyptians arrested Abu Nidal, and eventually ordered the 10 dissidents out of Egypt.
Abu Nidal was apparently able to order the murder of Sheik Salah from jail in Cairo, the Middle Eastern officials say. But his time in Egypt was limited. While it is not clear how long he remained in jail, the officials said, Abu Nidal remained in Cairo until his move to Baghdad.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Colombia Death Toll Rises In Wake of Earthquake
Rescue teams searched the rubble and survivors awaited aid after Colombia's worst earthquake in more than a century. Nearly 650 bodies were recovered after Monday's earthquake. Rescuers, in a partial estimate, said at least 2,700 had been hurt. Local officials predicted the toll would surpass 1,000. A1 

Many Colombian immigrants in the United States spent the day trying to reach relatives in cities hard hit by the earthquake. New York Colombian community leaders met at the Colombian Consulate to coordinate their efforts to send aid. A6
 
Terrorist Seeks Refuge in Iraq
Abu Nidal, once one of the world's most infamous terrorists, moved to Baghdad last year and obtained the protection of President Saddam Hussein, according to reports received by United States and Middle Eastern Government officials. They say the reports raise concerns about whether Iraq is pushing to establish a terrorism network. A1
 
Iraqi Weapons Program
President Saddam Hussein, who barred the return of arms inspectors to Iraq after American and British air strikes in December, is still actively trying to conceal past and present illegal weapons programs, the chief inspector told the Security Council in a report. A8
 
Within the last month, President Clinton has expanded military flight crews' authorization to fight back when threatened or attacked while enforcing the no-flight zones over Iraq, the President's national security adviser said. A8
 
Alarm for Jordan's Hussein
King Hussein flew back to the United States for urgent medical treatment, only hours after anointing a new heir. His return was prompted by what his doctors said were indications his cancer might be recurring. They said the King had suffered fevers and blood-count abnormalities since returning to Jordan last week. He was heading to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., where he had spent six months in treatment for non-Hodgkins lymphoma. A3
 
World Briefing A10
 
NATIONAL A12-22
 
Likely Vote on Witnesses Fuels Debate in the Senate
Fervent arguments from the prosecution and defense counsel on the highly divisive question of calling witnesses in President Clinton's impeachment trial, followed by a second evening of closed debate, moved the Senate closer to a decision to take depositions from three of the main figures in the protracted proceeding. White House lawyers warned that witnesses would prolong the trial for weeks, which prompted irked responses from Republicans. A1
 
Searching for a graceful ending to the impeachment trial, Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, named a six-member working group to examine how the Senate could vote to express its view that President Clinton committed perjury and obstruction of justice without removing him from office. A19

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Brazil Effect On Commodities;
Steel and Soybean Prices Dive (And Forget the New Tractor)

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 26

 BODY:
From a pit on the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade, Steven P. Bruce has been watching events in Brazil make the prices of wheat and soybeans swing with impunity.
"All commodity prices have been slipping," he said, shouting above a crowd of futures traders who were bidding down the long-term prices of a variety of commodities. "We will sell less wheat to Brazil and they will compete with us on soybeans; it's that simple." 
 While the overall economy remains vibrant, calculations by futures traders like Mr. Bruce are an indication that the crisis in Brazil is already reverberating in the United States -- both positively and negatively. As the value of Brazil's currency, the real, has dropped by more than a third in the last two weeks, the wholesale prices of a broad range of goods, including wheat and soybeans, have fallen 7 percent, according to key measures of commodity prices.
Indeed, the benchmark Commodities Research Bureau/Bridge index reached another recent low today, settling at 187.60, down 0.97.
All this comes on top of double-digit declines in commodity prices in the last few years. Prices for basic industrial products like steel have been similarly hit by events in Brazil. These declines are sending new shock waves through the United States' grain belt and industrial heartland.
For consumers, the drop in wholesale prices means that inflation -- which has been lower than at any time in recent decades -- is even more likely to remain in check. But economists and retailers say the lower wholesale prices will not necessarily translate into broadly falling prices at the supermarket or the auto showroom.
At the same time, bakers, benefiting from lower wheat and flour prices, will probably enjoy fatter profits. And auto manufacturers, which get just modest gains from the falling price of steel, will have a little more margin to play with.
Still, even if consumers are not reaping all the benefits of the drop in commodity prices, most economists see the outlook for inflation as extremely favorable. And as long as most Americans enjoy real pocketbook gains -- wage gains go further in the absence of inflation -- the United States economy should continue to enjoy steady growth this year.
"You'd have to go back to the 1960's to see this kind of environment," said Patrick Jackman, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which calculates the nation's Consumer Price Index. "While lower commodity prices might not generally translate into sharp declines in consumer prices, they translate into more stable prices. And viewing it from the point of view of the consumer, if you find that prices have not gone up, you're usually satisfied."
Of course, commodity prices started to decline well before Brazil stopped defending its currency earlier this month. Financial crises that began a year and a half ago and swept through Asia and Russia had already begun to dry up the demand for commodities worldwide, including some mainstays of the Midwest. And with steep currency devaluations in countries like South Korea, American exports have been competing against cheaper goods, forcing depressed prices lower. Brazil's problems have worsened the crisis abroad and the export price cycle.
"Brazil is really reinforcing the slowdown in the global economy," said James E. Glassman, a senior economist at Chase Securities.
At its simplest, Brazil's decision to devalue its currency means that the country will reduce imports while exporting its own cheaper products like iron and steel, soybeans, wheat and coffee. That could cause lower commodity prices throughout Latin America, forcing United States producers to sell their commodities for even less, and in some cases much less.
But while consumers and a lot of manufacturers have seen benefits from lower commodity prices, many basic industry- and agriculture-related companies have been suffering for months from the various foreign financial crises.
Cargill, the nation's largest private company and shipper of much of the world's grain, has lost money in the last two quarters. USX, which operates U.S. Steel, has idled one of its blast furnaces in Gary, Ind., and laid off contract workers.
U.S. Steel, which supplies galvanized steel to the auto industry that is usually sold on long-term contract, may have to lower its prices to compete with cheaper foreign imports. The price of soybeans, already down 40 percent from two years ago, may have to fall further because of decreased demand in Asia and elsewhere. In trading today at the Chicago Board of Trade, soybeans for March delivery settled at $5.14 a bushel, down 3.5 cents, a four-month closing low.
Economists say that ripples from the slowdown overseas are already causing losses for the nation's farmers. Problems are particularly acute across the northern tier of states -- from Illinois, where farmers are getting a cash price of just $2.07 for a bushel of corn, down from $3.97 a few years ago, to Idaho, where wheat is being sold at $2.69 a bushel, down from $5.49 a few years ago.
"This industry is not well," said Bill Flory, president of the National Association of Wheat Growers, noting that many farmers in North and South Dakota are putting their land up for sale. "It's a liquidation year for the industry, and there's not a lot of light at the end of the tunnel."
Many Midwestern farmers are storing their corn and soybeans in huge grain elevators, in hope that prices will bounce back. But the Agriculture Department projects that 1999 could be just as weak as 1998, with farm exports expected to decline 10 percent further from their already depressed levels.
Instead of looking ahead to next year's crops, many farmers are retrenching, holding off on fertilizer purchases or that new pickup truck, and depressing those merchants' business.
"If farmers don't make money they don't replace their equipment," said Larry Mitchell, an Agriculture Department spokesman. "It means the local equipment dealer doesn't make the sale. The people who haul the equipment don't have anything to haul. The equipment maker doesn't make the equipment. This all begins to ripple."
Deere & Company, the nation's largest maker of farm equipment, said in November that it would lay off 2,400 workers, or 7 percent of its work force after demand for its tractors and combines plummeted. Now, with recession in Brazil, the company's problems are mounting.
Fewer farmers, for instance, are lining up to purchase Deere's new, $160,000 Maximizer combine. "People are cutting back," said Dick Gady, chief economist at Conagra, the giant food-processing company. "$2 corn doesn't buy them a lot of combines."
Just about any company that makes heavy equipment for the farm is being hurt. Even Caterpillar, which is the world's largest maker of earth-moving equipment, has seen its profit growth slow.
Cargill, which has more than 80,000 employees in 65 countries, says that its once-vibrant grain trade is sagging, and there has been weaker demand for food products in emerging nations.
"People out there just don't have the purchasing power to buy more food and better food," said Linda Thrane, a Cargill spokeswoman.
Around the same time, the steel industry has asked the Government to impose higher import duties on Japan, Russia and Brazil, asserting that they are dumping steel at a loss into markets here. In the last few months, several smaller steel companies have filed for bankruptcy protection. And bigger steelmakers are reeling. On Friday, for instance, U.S. Steel reported a 50 percent drop in profit from a year ago.
"If you go back to the 1970's, when the steel industry had it tough, it looks like that all over again," said William Szakacs, 50, an employee at Gary Works, the U.S. Steel mill in Gary, Ind., that is the largest in North America. "Things are getting tighter every day. There's not a lot of steel to roll."
For other companies as well as most consumers, the commodity collapse has brought benefits. Oil prices have declined because of slowing global demand, cutting transportation costs for big companies as well as for millions of Americans filling their tanks at gasoline stations.
Other commodities are more complex. In automobiles, for example, steel is just one component. There is only $700 worth of steel in a $25,000 vehicle, so prices will not be affected sharply, steel experts say.
And when it comes to food -- coffee, sugar, corn, soybeans for cooking oil and wheat -- Americans are not seeing significantly lower prices.
Indeed, even though the commodity price of wheat has plummeted 40 percent in the last two years, bread prices have increased slightly, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Food companies and retailers contend that is because commodities make up a small part of their expenses, which include labor and manufacturing costs, as well as substantial processing, transportation and marketing expenses. Many economists say that in fact food companies and retailers, particularly those that operate on low margins, enjoy heftier profits when wholesale prices drop.
So while Mr. Flory, who grows wheat on 7,000 acres of farmland in northern Idaho, sells his grain at some of the lowest prices in a decade, a company like Interstate Bakeries, the distributor of products like Wonder Bread and Hostess Twinkies, holds prices steady.
"There's no question from a cost perspective, a bakery would benefit from lower wheat prices," said Mark Dirkes, an Interstate spokesman. "Flour is the single largest commodity we purchase."
For every $1 decline in the wholesale price of wheat, he said, Interstate plans to pass along a 1.5-cent saving to the consumer. Still, despite the windfall from cheaper wheat, he said that the bottom line slipped at Interstate in the most recent quarter, primarily because of fierce competition and higher operating costs, including labor.

HEADLINE: Commission Nears a Consensus on Redesigning Medicare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
A Federal advisory commission inched toward a fragile consensus today on a plan to redesign Medicare as a marketplace in which the Government would compete with private insurers. But Democrats insisted that elderly people get coverage for prescription drugs, raising doubts about whether the plan would save money.
No votes were taken. But it appeared that 8 Republicans were ready to join 3 Democrats in support of the basic framework proposed by Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who is chairman of the 17-member commission. 
 Today's debate, though vehement, was civil. After it ended, Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is co-chairman of the commission, said: "Nobody turned over a table and walked out. Nobody blew up the basic structure. People complained about parts of the proposal."
The panel, created by law in August 1997, is supposed to recommend ways of solving Medicare's long-term financial problems. The deadline for its final report is in just five weeks.
Commission members debated radical changes in Medicare that would affect virtually every baby boomer. Under Mr. Breaux's proposal, Medicare officials, rather than setting prices and reimbursing doctors and health care providers separately for each medical service, would offer a fixed amount of money to each beneficiary to purchase insurance from a private health plan or from the Government.
Supporters of this approach say, without definitive proof, that it could save money because beneficiaries would be more sensitive to prices and premiums, and would shop around for the best deal. For the same reason, critics say, elderly beneficiaries would be more exposed to financial risks and ruin if health costs rose more than expected, as has often happened.
Liberal Democrats on the commission -- Representative Jim McDermott of Washington, Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan and Bruce C. Vladeck, who ran Medicare for the first five years of the Clinton Administration -- denounced Mr. Breaux's proposal.
Mr. Vladeck told Senator Breaux, "You are disentitling a generation of American workers" to benefits they have been guaranteed since 1965. Mr. Dingell said Mr. Breaux assumed that "the private sector will have some wonderful mechanism, which I don't quite understand, to save money."
Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, enthusiastically supported Mr. Breaux's proposal. Two pivotal Democrats on the panel -- Laura D'Andrea Tyson, former chief economic adviser to President Clinton, and Stuart H. Altman, a professor of health policy at Brandeis University -- said they could support it if elderly people were assured of prescription drug coverage in both the original fee-for-service Medicare program and in the private health plans.
"Drug coverage is the condition of my support," Ms. Tyson said in an interview.
Administration officials, while holding back public comment till they see the panel's final report on March 1, have told the commission staff that they have many concerns about Mr. Breaux's proposal. They worry, for example, that benefits would erode and that the Federal subsidy would become less and less adequate over the years.
It became clear today that President Clinton's recent proposal to use some of the Federal budget surplus for Medicare had altered the politics of the issue.
Senator Kerrey said the President might have made the commission's work more difficult because Mr. Clinton "left the impression that there are no tough choices, that it's fairly easy" to solve Medicare's financial problems. On the other hand, Ms. Tyson said Mr. Clinton's suggestion was helpful because it "put a new source of financing on the table" -- $650 billion to $700 billion over 15 years.
Drug companies fear that Medicare coverage of prescription drugs would lead to Federal price controls, which they say would reduce their profits and the money available for pharmaceutical research. But there may be ways of limiting the Government's role, commission members said.
For example, private companies could manage prescription drug benefits for Medicare, in an effort to obtain discounts from drug makers and pharmacies and to encourage doctors to use lower-cost drugs. Moreover, economists said, thought the manufacturers' average profit on each prescription might decline, the loss of revenue could be partly offset because the demand for drugs would increase if Medicare covered them.
Mr. Breaux said his proposal was likely to succeed because it was modeled on the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program, which covers nine million people. Many lawmakers say H.M.O.'s can slow the growth of Medicare spending, but H.M.O.'s have dropped more than 400,000 Medicare beneficiaries in the last six months, saying Federal payments were not keeping up with their costs.
Under Mr. Breaux's proposal, a new Government agency, known as the Medicare Board, would supervise both the Government-run program and private health plans for the elderly. H.M.O.'s would have to provide the same types of benefits now covered by Medicare, but Congress would leave the details to be worked out in negotiations between the board and private health plans.
Commission members of both parties said they were dissatisfied with the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which now runs Medicare. Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, described it as "a huge, unresponsive bureaucracy."
Under Mr. Breaux's proposal, the Health Care Financing Administration would run the original Medicare program, but would no longer regulate H.M.O.'s. It would be given new power to negotiate prices and sign contracts with selected doctors and hospitals, so it could compete with private health plans.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Atlanta Games' Organizers Set to Face Questions

BYLINE: By JOE DRAPE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 26

 BODY:
In the Olympic family, the Atlanta Olympic organizers have often been looked on as poor relations -- the long-shot bunch from this Southern city who were, in a stunning upset, awarded the 1996 Centennial Games, then managed to make a mess of them.
Before the 1996 Summer Games, they were criticized for being too crass in seeking sponsor dollars. During the Olympics, the Games, mocked by some as the "Bubba Games," were plagued by poor transportation, problems with the athletes' living quarters and a bombing. 
 At the end, in what was perceived as an international insult, the president of the International Olympic Committee, Juan Antonio Samaranch, failed to call the $1.7 billion Games the greatest ever, a standard bouquet thrown to previous host cities.
Now, more than two years after the Olympic flame was extinguished in Atlanta, Olympic organizers here are set to face the most serious inquiry into their performance: did they do anything unethical in obtaining the Games in the first place?
The I.O.C., having uncovered widespread misconduct in Salt Lake City's effort to gain the 2002 Winter Games, has said it will investigate how each city for the last decade earned its designation as an Olympic site. For the moment, the Atlanta organizers have been almost defiantly confident.
"No cash, no scholarships, nothing illegal, unethical, inappropriate or untoward," Billy Payne, the chief architect of the Atlanta Games, said of his organization's efforts to win the Olympics. "We are more than delighted and willing to show that all that is good about the Olympic Games can be acquired following the bid rules and doing something as simple as making friends."
The Atlanta organizers are particularly defensive about their behavior during the bid process because winning the bid in 1990 was a rare and, by their telling, pure moment of euphoria. By their account, they began the bid process as a core of seven to a dozen civic-minded lawyers and bureaucrats who, on a relatively small budget of $7.4 million, traveled to more than 40 countries, befriending Olympic committee members through Southern charm and hospitality. Athens reportedly spent more than $30 million in its failed effort.
They say the gifts they gave ranged from the gimmicky -- pillowcases stitched with "Georgia on My Mind" -- to the more personal. When the late committee member from Cuba, Manuel Gonzalez Guerra, admired a ceramic bulldog on Payne's desk, the former football star at the University of Georgia bought a live bulldog and made sure the dog had its shots and was waiting on the plane when the Cuban member left.
Charlie Battle, the bid committee's roving ambassador, said he was aware of the so-called agents, or vote brokers who claimed they could deliver members, but said he was never approached by them. He joked that the worst indignity he suffered was having to brave the icy, polluted waters of the Danube River to swim with a granddaughter of a Slovak I.O.C. member.
"I can say that I never asked anyone if they were going to vote for us," said Battle, who traveled to more than 40 countries to enlist support for Atlanta's bid.
There were other actions, however, that perhaps pushed at the margins of appropriateness and that ultimately spurred others to speak of what became known as the "Atlanta model."
This past weekend, Australia's Olympic chief, John Coates, said that Andrew Young, the former United States Ambassador to the United Nations and an Atlanta bid committee member, had toured Africa dispensing aid commitments in exchange for support for Atlanta's successful bid for the 1996 Summer Olympics. Coates's remarks came as he explained why he pledged $35,000 each to the Olympic committees of two I.O.C. members from Africa in a last-ditch effort to ingratiate himself with voters. Sydney was awarded the 2000 Summer Games by 2 votes over Beijing, 45-43.
"I drafted the original strategies, and early on had identified that we had to do something in Africa," said Coates, who offered no evidence of his allegation against Young. "I came to grips with that because I knew that's how Atlanta had achieved it, so I didn't feel uncomfortable."
Through a spokesman, Young denied the allegation. "It was an irresponsible comment by John Coates," said Lee Echols, the spokesman. "It really upset Andy. It was an insulting comment to make." Young has been traveling, and has not returned several telephone calls.
The former Atlanta mayor, who has maintained ties to Africa throughout his life, has a long relationship with one of the key figures in the Salt Lake City scandal -- the I.O.C. member from the Congo Republic, Jean-Claude Ganga. He was one of six committee members expelled Sunday by the organization's executive board after it found he had accepted direct payments, free medical care, gifts and travel subsidies amounting to $216,010 from Salt Lake City's organizing committee.
Young has acknowledged that in August 1990 -- a month before the bid vote -- he went to the Congo Republic with sports equipment. Doug Gatlin, executive director of the committee then, said he was with Young when they delivered 50 soccer balls, 100 handballs and 200 pairs of gym shorts, all of it donated.
"We handed it out directly to kids in the villages," Gatlin said. "He has enormous respect in Africa because he helped put Africa on the U.S. radar scope while serving for President Carter. He helped make human rights in Africa part of the theme of the Administration. He never needed to bribe anyone."
Gatlin said Young never promised foreign aid on their trips to Africa. Referring to himself, Gatlin said he made calls to international sports organizations to inquire about coaching and athletic exchange programs, but nothing more. He said he shared Young's belief that their work fell under humanitarian aid and not under vote buying.
Many African nations benefited from Young's and the Atlanta organizers' attentions, but the Atlanta organizers emphasize that it was after the Games were awarded to the city. When told by Mozambique officials that their female marathoners couldn't afford proper foods, for example, Young helped send food and protein supplements to the country.
After getting the Games, the Atlanta organizers helped set up a training center for African athletes in LaGrange, Ga. With funds from local residents and the I.O.C.'s Olympic solidarity program, the training center hit full stride in 1994, with 20 athletes from Africa and the Mideast. They also allowed an association of African nations, headed by Ganga, the unusual privilege of marketing its own merchandise during the Games. Host committees are usually vigilant about honoring licenses to the paying rights holders.
"We had told every country that we intended to set up a training center for weather acclimation, and that we'd help in whatever way we could to make sure teams and athletes got here," Battle said. "We wanted every country to have an opportunity to compete in the games. But it was never a 'vote for us and we'll do this' kind of deal."
As soon as Atlanta won the 1996 Games over Athens, the Atlanta organizers said they contended with the rumors about how they did it. The Greek news media charged that Coca-Cola -- one of the Olympics oldest sponsors -- bought the Games for its home city. "That's one of the biggest myths," Battle said. "Heck, Coke would rather have them in Beijing, where there's 400 billion potential Coke drinkers."
Coca-Cola's Olympic spokesman, Ben Deutsch, said the company policy was not to provide financial support to any host-city bid.
In 1991, the German magazine Der Spiegel reported that Atlanta Olympic officials offered I.O.C. members gold credit cards, free heart surgery and scholarships for their children, as well as cash. The Atlanta organizers vigorously deny the charges. Two incidents involving two of the I.O.C. members implicated in the corruption scandal, however, have been acknowledged by Payne.
David Sibandze, a member from Swaziland, had a heart attack while visiting during the bid process. Atlanta organizers paid for part of his treatment while Piedmont Hospital absorbed the rest. Sibandze resigned from the I.O.C. over the weekend after it was discovered that his son was given a job at the Salt Lake City Economic Development Office.
And Payne said he made calls in 1991 to the University of Georgia on behalf of the stepson of the I.O.C. member from Russia, Vitaly Smirnov. The stepson was enrolled at Georgia from 1992 to 1994, but received no scholarship money from the school, according to university officials.
"It was nine months after the vote, and all I did was make some calls like I often do when asked by friends," Payne said.
Several Atlanta officials say they were approached in a subtle fashion by certain members "to meet privately" or to discuss Atlanta's "chance of winning," including once before the vote in Tokyo.
And so the Atlanta organizers insist that they will answer fully and honestly a letter expected to arrive any day from the I.O.C. asking for details. They are currently reviewing documents chronicling the two years spent chasing and entertaining Olympic committee members across the globe. But they have refused to make those records public.
For Payne, this last look at Atlanta's Olympic experience offers a chance for, if not vindication, some reclamation of the Atlanta Games' legacy. "Hundreds of thousands of Georgians spared no effort in welcoming the world into our state and community," Payne said. "I represented them and they should know, as I do, that we shouldn't bow our heads. We should all feel good about it."

HEADLINE: State Will Increase Aid to Most, but Not All, Schools

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The Whitman administration announced today that it would budget $5.2 billion in state aid to public schools for the coming fiscal year, the highest allocation ever in a state that already spends more per pupil than any other in the nation.
While not all school districts will benefit, the new budget represents a $330 million increase in education money from the previous year, and more funds for special education, early childhood programs and improved technology. 
 Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said the increased spending in education is possible largely because an improved economy has driven up tax receipts and the windfall from the nationwide tobacco settlement has provided an additional financial cushion.
"The state's economy is in excellent shape," the Governor said, "and I can think of no more important place to invest our resources than in the futures of our children."
Under the education spending plan for 1999-2000, 405 of the 596 districts in the state will get more money. But it will mean less money for 191 districts, and it revives a perennial debate in New Jersey over how best to finance public schools.
The state provides aid to all districts to help with transportation, special education and bilingual education programs. Most districts are also given additional aid on a per-pupil basis, depending on need, while wealthier districts must carry more of the burden through property taxes.
Last year, in an effort to close the financial gap between rich and poor districts, the state began relying on data from 1995 state income tax forms instead of information from the 1990 census to determine a community's local wealth. In some districts, like Randolph Township Schools, the income tax data showed greater wealth, which meant a decrease in state aid.
"We've become wealthier overnight, but we can't seem to find the money," said John Battles, the Superintendent of the Randolph Township Schools.
Initially, based on the new data, Randolph's allotment of per-pupil aid would have been reduced to $3.57 million in the next fiscal year from $6 million in the current year. But to help soften the blow, the state decided to cap the loss of per-pupil aid at 2 percent. For Randolph, that means a cut of $892,000.
Dr. Battles said his district, with a growing enrollment that now stands at 5,000 and the highest SAT scores in Morris County, also happens to have very little industry, so it depends mostly on residential state property taxes for its education dollars.
"Any aid formula that penalizes a growing district, where we have low costs and high academic performance," Dr. Battles said, "is an aid formula that is flawed."
Dr. Battles said the district had formed a committee to examine how to reduce costs. So far, district officials are considering dropping one period from the high school day. With eight periods rather than nine, the district would need fewer teachers and would save about $500,000. Randolph is also considering the elimination of a team-teaching concept in the middle school that allowed teachers, in groups of four or five, to take time out to discuss curriculum plans and meet with parents. Putting those teachers back into the classrooms for the period would save another half million dollars, Dr. Battles said.
Also new this year, school districts will be receiving their state aid allocation based on more accurate enrollment figures. For districts that have grown in the last few years, there will be an additional infusion of cash, in some cases canceling out losses from the new income data.
But for the Toms River Regional District, which has a growing enrollment, the new provision will not help, because of the extent to which its income and property wealth has increased, and because the district has fewer special education students. The district will lose $2.9 million.
Cherry Hill will lose $1.9 million, also because of income increases and a decrease in the number of special education students. And Middletown Township, in Monmouth County, will lose $1.8 million because of an increase in its property wealth, even though enrollment has remained flat.
Lynn Strickland, executive director of the Garden State Coalition, which represents the state's wealthiest districts, pointed out that already, about 240 of the state's districts, or about 40 percent, receive no per-pupil aid. Only a third of districts were in the same category in 1991, she said, but this year, as another sign of the growing wealth in the state, another handful have joined their number.
"It means more communities are relying primarily on their property taxes to fund schools," Ms. Strickland said. "And that means that property tax rates go up in those communities every year to pay for schools."
Frank Belluscio, spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, said the new financing formulas were unfair to many districts.
"We've never believed that income should be used as a factor to determine state aid," he said. "Property values, yes, but if income is going to be used, it has to be phased in very, very slowly. Too many districts are losing a significant amount of money under these new formulas."

HEADLINE: Budget Offers Rise in Municipal Aid

 BODY:
Aid to New Jersey's 566 municipalities would rise $16.3 million for the fiscal year that begins in July under the state budget proposed Monday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the state announced yesterday.
Newark tops the proposed list, at $100.9 million in aid, while Pine Valley, with all of 21 residents, is to get $2,546, according to figures from the State Department of Community Affairs. In all, state aid would total $1.6 billion, The Associated Press reported. 
 The figures are calculated assuming passage of legislation that pegs aid to a Government cost index derived from, but lower than, the rate of inflation. The index, known as the implicit price deflator, is 1.5 percent for the coming budget year. The legislation is scheduled for a vote by the Senate and Assembly tomorrow.
William Dressel, executive director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, said he would welcome the use of an inflation index as a long-term way to help local governments meet rising costs.
But Mr. Dressel said he was disappointed by the proposed budget's 14 percent increase in municipalities' annual contributions to the statewide police and firefighters pension fund. Mr. Dressel said, "I see where pension increases are going to eat up most of those increases, and you say, 'Where's the relief?' "

HEADLINE: THE POPE'S VISIT: THE OVERVIEW;
POPE SETS FORTH A MORAL AGENDA IN ST. LOUIS VISIT

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Ignoring the moral lapses of President Clinton, Pope John Paul II flew to St. Louis today and addressed the broader moral issues facing the nation.
In a crowded airport hangar, the Pope referred to the Dred Scott decision upholding slavery in 1857. He called the case, which was heard here, a "time of testing" that the United States failed.
"America faces a similar time of trial today," the Pope said. "Today, the conflict is between a culture that affirms, cherishes and celebrates the gift of life and a culture that seeks to declare entire groups of human beings -- the unborn, the terminally ill, the handicapped and others considered 'unuseful' -- to be outside the boundaries of legal protection."
The President and Mrs. Clinton greeted the Pope, who shook hands with them briefly before turning his attention to the cheers and outstretched hands in the first row of seats. There, he blessed about 2,000 people -- mainly Roman Catholic families with young children selected by their parishes -- and bent over to pat a small child.
 Mr. Clinton, who guided the fragile Pope down a red carpet with a protective hand on his elbow, smiled broadly and introduced him to people in the audience like a solicitous host.
Many people throughout the world had been tut-tutting about the uneasy juxtaposition of the highest moral authority of the Roman Catholic Church shaking hands with an American President on trial on charges related to extramarital sex. Mr. Clinton looked completely at ease. And the Pope was unlikely to have been shaken by Mr. Clinton's noisy scandal.
The Vatican's main concern seemed to be that the Pope's message to Americans not be drowned out by the awkward iconography of the moment. A year ago, the breaking Clinton scandal overshadowed coverage of the Pope's visit to Cuba.
"Only a higher moral vision can motivate the choice for life," the Pope said to strong applause. "And the values underlying that vision will greatly depend on whether this nation continues to honor and revere the family as the basic unit of society."
Afterward, the two leaders sat on white armchairs posing for photographs before their 20-minute meeting. They exchanged a few words, and Mr. Clinton told reporters that he, following the Pope, was planning his own trip to Mexico soon.
"We want to increase the involvement of the United States," Mr. Clinton said, words that seemed intended to please his guest, who throughout his stay in Mexico had repeatedly reminded the United States of its responsibility to poorer nations in Latin America. "I am looking forward to hearing what the Holy Father has to say about his trip."
The Vatican has often expressed its opposition to some areas of United States policy including abortion, the death penalty, the bombing of Iraq and the Clinton Administration's delay in signing the international treaty banning land mines.
John Paul's prepared text had references to those issues, but the Pope skipped over them in his speech. Vatican officials said that even in private the Pope was unlikely to raise issues where the disagreements between Washington and the Vatican were deep, longstanding and well known.
Instead, the White house said the two men discussed the need for continental solidarity and stressed the role of the United States. The Pope praised American efforts to help victims in Central America, as well as United States efforts to promote religious freedom in totalitarian countries. The Pope alluded to abortion by emphasizing the need to protect all human life. They also discussed Mexico and Cuba. The Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Vals, said they did not discuss the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
The White House said the Pope told Mr. Clinton he "and all American leaders" were in his prayers.
The Vatican was fully aware ahead of time that the State of Missouri had decided to postpone the execution of a death-row inmate while the Pope was in St. Louis. The Pope apparently did not mention it. On the plane from Mexico, the Pope's spokesman described the postponement as a "mockery."
For John Paul, who spent four days in Mexico engulfed by adoring crowds who lined up by the tens of thousands along his motorcade routes, camped out overnight in front of the Vatican's diplomatic residence in Mexico City, where the Pope stayed, serenading him all through the night, the thin welcome at the St. Louis airport was starkly different.
For security reasons, crowds had been discouraged from going to the airport, and the sidewalks along the motorcade route into the city were empty. When his plane left Mexico, thousands of people climbed onto rooftops for miles all over the city and flashed mirrors to glint like stars in farewell.
By the time the Pope reached Kiel Center in St. Louis, a huge indoor sports arena, to address a raucous, strobe-lit youth rally, the mood warmed up.
The crowd of 20,000 teen-agers waved yellow scarves, screamed and chanted "We love you" as the Pope drove into the arena in a white golf cart blessing the crowds. Before the Pope entered the arena, he was greeted by Mark McGwire, the St. Louis Cardinal, who is a Catholic.
John Paul urged the youths to train for their vocation as Catholics the way McGwire and Sammy Sosa would train for the World Series.
"Christians are always in training," he said. "Freedom is not the ability to do anything we want," he warned. "Rather, freedom is the ability to live responsibly the truth of our relationship with God and with one another."
Sean Asher, 15, who drove to St. Louis from Springfield, Mo., to see the Pope along with his Catholic youth group, said, "He's a really awe-inspiring guy. You've got to see him in person; pictures just aren't enough."
Mr. Clinton did not attend the rally, and instead flew back to Washington.
The Pope has met with President Clinton three times, always cordially, but neither Washington nor the Vatican claims their relationship to be anything more than that. If anything, it may be less; Mr. Clinton dismayed the Vatican when he took communion at a Mass in Soweto, South Africa, in March last year. The Pope never said anything publicly, but John Cardinal O'Connor, Archbishop of New York, expressed his disapproval openly and firmly.
Vatican officials have never publicly discussed the Lewinsky affair or Mr. Clinton's impeachment trial. The Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano ran a neutral article on the scandal the day the President was impeached.
Privately, Vatican officials make the same kind of jokes about the scandal as officials and diplomats in other European capitals. But church leaders have not entirely hidden their disapproval from their followers. Avvenire, the daily newspaper of the Italian Catholic bishops' conference, has printed regular reports. A few have quite vividly expressed deep disapproval of the American President and the voters who continue to support him.
A columnist for Avvenire, Romanello Cantini, wrote last July: "Unfortunately, the average American, converted by widespread permissiveness and complete indifference to what goes on in the private domain, no longer seems to be shaken by old-fashioned puritan indignation. The majority of Americans believe that Clinton has lied but that he is above all a simpatico Pinocchio who must be forgiven that his nose is growing at least as long as the economy grows alongside it."

HEADLINE: Retirement Plan Includes Guidance on the Market;
Raise Lending Rates

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As details begin to emerge regarding President Clinton's proposal to invest a portion of the Social Security reserves in the stock market (letters, Jan. 26), I was struck by the fact, mentioned in a Jan. 20 news article, that the plan assumes an annual rate of return of 6.75 percent, which would be 3.8 percent more than the average for Treasury bonds, which is where the reserves are invested now.
The Government has been getting a good deal from this arrangement, borrowing money at very low interest rates and lowering its interest burden by not having to go to commercial sources to borrow. 
 It seems to me that if the Government paid more reasonable interest rates for its access to the Social Security reserves, the whole idea of having to go to the stock market, with its inherent risks, would evaporate.
 
KEITH B. MCCALL
East Lansing, Mich., Jan. 26, 1999

HEADLINE: As Expected, Coca-Cola Reports a Weakened 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Confirming the bad news it had warned Wall Street about last month, the Coca-Cola Company reported its fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, which showed that the global soft-drink giant suffered significant declines in volume and revenue in many parts of the world.
Even though much of the damage had been expected, Wall Street seemed unsettled by the details. Shares of Coca-Cola fell 37.5 cents, to $62.5625, after losing about 3.5 percent at one point during the day. 
 Net income fell 27 percent, to $597 million, or 24 cents a diluted share, compared with $817 million, or 33 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The earnings were in line with analyst expectations, which had been revised after a meeting with Coke's senior managers last month.
Coke's revenue for the quarter was $4.46 billion, down 5 percent from $4.7 billion. While its costs declined by 11 percent, its selling, administrative and other expenses rose 7 percent. Operating income declined by 20 percent, to $937 million from $1.17 billion, and the company posted a $71 million loss in equity income, largely from the company's selloff of some bottling operations and losses encountered by some bottlers that it still owns.
The company's spending on marketing and other expenses rose to $2.22 billion in the quarter, nearly 50 percent of its revenue. Case volume sales fell 1 percent worldwide in the quarter, but individual countries revealed more drastic declines.
Volume dropped 3 percent in Brazil, the company's second-largest international market, and rose just 1 percent in Japan, the source of 20 percent of Coke's profits. Volume in Japan for the full year was flat, the company said.
"Japan is crucial to their near-term and long-term outlook," said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, who added that the situation there remained "sticky" for the foreseeable future.
Volume fell 1 percent in Germany, Coke's fifth-largest market, in the fourth quarter and was down 2 percent for the year. South Africa sales fell 14 percent for the quarter because of deteriorating economic conditions that began with the devaluation of the rand in May, a Coca-Cola spokesman said.
The bright spots included the United States, where sales increased by 5 percent in the quarter; China, where sales grew by 24 percent, and India, which posted growth of 26 percent. Worldwide, Coca-Cola's volume rose 3 percent for the year, compared with 10 percent in 1997.
Earnings for the full year were $3.5 billion, or $1.42 a share, compared with $4.1 billion, or $1.64 a share, in 1997. Annual revenue was $18.81 billion, down slightly from $18.87 in 1997.
The company's full-year earnings statement highlighted various bottler acquisitions and investments, including an acquisition in Russia, the spinoff of Coca-Cola Beverages from Coca-Cola Amatil, another anchor bottler, and investment in bottling businesses in India.
Full-year results were affected by the fourth-quarter performance. In Latin America, volume grew just 7 percent, compared with 12 percent in 1997. In the Middle East and Southeast Asia, operating income declined 7 percent for the year, primarily because of currency devaluation.
"The key driver for 1999 will be how well will key profit centers like Japan and Germany perform," said Andrew M. Conway, an analyst for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. He expects currencies to stabilize, which should benefit the company, which he estimates lost 12 cents a share in earnings for the year because of currency devaluations.
"There's not an awful lot they can do," Mr. Goldman said. "Sometimes, they're not the master of their own destiny."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 2, 1999, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Jan. 27 about the Coca-Cola Company's fourth-quarter earnings misstated the worldwide percentage increase in its soft-drink sales by volume last year. It was 6 percent, not 3.
