HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
The Last Gasp For the American Living Room

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
WITH the nonchalance of Zeus and Hera leaning over the balcony of Olympus, Chris and Vivian Tai, two prospective house buyers visiting a model home in Mount Kisco, N.Y., peered down from a landing and hurled a few thunderbolts at the living room below.
 "Who needs it?" said Mrs. Tai, 33, a computer programmer, although she conceded that a living room might come in handy on occasion -- "so that my kids can practice the piano and they'll be far enough away that I won't have to hear them." 
 Let us consider the dwindling circumstances of the American living room, once so central to the domestic universe that Tom Wolfe, in "Bonfire of the Vanities" (1987), described it with acid admiration as "this gloriously stuffed little planet."
Yet, during a recent visit to the Mount Kisco model home, not one person in a steady stream of visitors stepped across the threshold into the living room. Instead, they made a beeline straight back to the double-height family room, a congenial open space adjacent to the kitchen, where they chatted amiably on Dumbo-size sofas or gathered about its unlit fireplace as if it were a 51-inch television screen.
Pity the living room's polite suite of sofas and armchairs. In matching white brocade, they looked as coolly unapproachable as a museum diorama. The telltale sign of customer indifference: No cushion bore a single dent.
"The living room is gasping its last breath," said Wayne Foley, a builder in Great Falls, Va., and a member of the design committee of the National Association of Home Builders. It is shrinking in size as well as prestige: in 1978, the living room in a typical model by Toll Brothers -- builders of upscale houses, including the present one in Mount Kisco -- measured 20 feet by 13.4 feet. The one the Tais viewed last week had shrunk to 15 feet by 13 feet. Its decline has fed the voracious family room, which in the 70's was a youth Siberia south of the mudroom: here it has ascended and grown to 20 feet 8 inches by 15 feet.
Last summer, when Country Home magazine built a show house at the World Financial Center based on an informal reader survey, it had no living room at all. "It just didn't appear on anybody's wish list," said Dennis Wedlick, the architect. Taking its place were a double-height medieval "great hall," which ran the length of the house with two huge chandeliers and a cyclopean fireplace, and a family "gathering room," with kitchen, at the rear.
Carol Sheehan, Country Home's editor in chief, was thrilled when she saw no living room in the floor plans. "I thought, 'Hurray!' " she recalled. "There's no life, no living there. I could live without it. In fact, I already am." She added that in her own home, a Cape Codder in Ashfield, Mass., everyone tends to congregate around a wood-burning stove in the kitchen. "When I pulled in a love seat, the kitchen became the most comfortable room in the house," she said.
Mr. Wedlick's design for the Country Home show house attracted a developer, Gerald Hines, who commissioned him to design similar houses with loftlike plans and, Mr. Wedlick said, "no rooms defined in the traditional sense." The 2,800-square-foot homes will be constructed this summer in Carbondale, Colo.
Mr. Foley in Virginia, way ahead of the curve, eliminated the living room in his own house back in the 70's and now finds customers telling him they don't want one, either. He said: "For years, you heard people saying, 'My parents never used it and I'm not using it.' And finally they're confident enough to say, 'So don't give me one.' "
And when it comes time to renovate, the family room is again the winner. Kermit Baker, an economist at Harvard University's Joint Center for Housing Studies, said, "It just makes a lot of sense that the family room would grow at the expense of the more formal living room." He added: "Most of the renovations in the last 10 to 15 years have been generated by baby boomers making more livable space for their growing families. The last thing they need is more formal space -- they need space for playing around."
A BRIEF history of the post-World War II suburban home, the aspirational archetype for housing all over the world, shows how inextricably the living room's fortunes have been bound to the ever-expanding family room. The living room in America was a 19th-century invention, evolving from a small parlor reserved for "at home" receptions into a large gracious space with a fireplace meant for the entire family to enjoy. After World War II, parents found they needed to put some distance between themselves and their baby-boom children. So the "rec room" was born, tucked away in the basement where ritual games of Twister could be enacted without wreaking havoc on the rest of the house. A precedent was established: the family room was fun; the living room, its furniture frozen in Scotchguarded perfection, was serious, the place to face the vacuum-cleaner salesman.
No surprise, then, that the television set, at first a welcome novelty in the living room, soon followed the children out. But the most serious blow to the living room's sense of purpose came when the family room hitched up with the kitchen to be crowned grandiloquently by builders as the great room or gathering room. This movement started in the 70's (the Toll Brothers were building them even then), but it really took hold in the 80's. The combination of television and easy access to the fridge was hard to beat: soon, even the fireplace turned cold on the living room. Today, those Electrolux meetings happen in cyberspace.
"We hardly know what purpose the living room is supposed to serve anymore," said Akiko Busch, the author of a forthcoming book, "Geography of Home." "We don't need it. As the rest of the house becomes much less private, the living room has fallen through the cracks."
Changes in the family are also having an impact on the shape of the home. According to the 1990 United States Census, half the households in America consist of married couples without children, while one-quarter of the population live alone. Traditional three-bedroom family home life has given way to houses for two-career couples, empty-nesters, the remarried with children, gay couples and the extended family with in-laws at home.
With demographic change has come the breakdown of the need for rooms at all, a notion of informality popularized by television shows like "Friends" and "Home Improvement," which hint at the kind of open-plan living so beloved by early modernists.
"What we're seeing is a reconfiguration not only of the demographics of the home but of the very notion of public and private domains and appropriate spaces for work and leisure," said Gwendolyn Wright, author of "Building the Dream: A Social History of Housing in America" (Pantheon, 1981). She sees families moving farther away from artificially segregated, sex-related zones -- the men's den, the women's parlor -- toward an entirely open, multifunctional space.
Without children at home, "the need for acoustic and visual privacy is less compelling," said Terence Riley, curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art. This summer, Mr. Riley is planning to examine the impact of all the new forces shaping the architecture of the home in his exhibition "The Un-Private House." The show will cover everything from a loft for Wall Street traders furnished with little more than trading screens and television sets, to a house where digital screens replace walls, to kitchens where recipes (even images of chefs) are projected on the backsplash, to dining rooms inhabited by virtual guests -- all places where one can be alone but always connected.
But the brave new home, Mr. Riley said, owes a lot to the past, namely "the medieval hall where spaces were essentially loftlike, in the sense that they were large and open and used for multiple functions." These great halls were not even specifically domestic in nature but were public as well, in the manner of today's living-and-working arrangements.
As revolutionary in conception as in looks, a new home designed by Preston Scott Cohen, a Boston architect, for Eric Wolf, an artist, is true to the medieval order. "Eric wanted to be able to see everything all at once," Mr. Cohen said. "We didn't discuss the space as rooms at all, but as places to sit, places to eat and places to sleep." Mr. Wolf, who lives alone and wanted as few walls and furnishings as possible between himself and the landscapes he paints, said he planned "to haul furniture in" as occasions arose.
IT'S not necessary to go to a museum to see radical change. Steven Harris, a co-editor with Deborah Berke, of "Architecture of the Everyday" (Princeton Architectural Press, 1997) and a professor at the Yale University School of Art and Architecture, notes that even that model of decorum Celebration, the town created by the Walt Disney Company near Orlando, Fla., has homes with a futuristic spin. He points out that behind those classic Southern verandas and beyond small vestigial living rooms "decorated like a mausoleum," the rooms are giving way to generic space. "You realize people are actually living in a vast warehouse," he said.
David Weekly, a Texas developer who designed several models at Celebration, deliberately put realistic interiors behind nostalgic facades. "The notion that people would come visit you to be entertained and to be served in the living room just doesn't happen anymore," he said.
Defenders of the living room say that its obituary is premature. "The 'death of the living room' reminds me of the 'death of the theater' -- it's not going to happen," said the architect Robert A. M. Stern. "Where are you going to entertain the in-laws when they come to meet you? As you climb the corporate ladder, where are you going to bring your associates? You can't take them into the family room, where your 9-year-old is eating dinner and playing video games. Give me a break."
Back at the Toll Brothers show house in Mount Kisco, Marcia and Michael Cooney, both 52 and relocating from Michigan, liked the living room, however tiny, for their antiques. "Even if it's a room that will never be used, it's nice to have for display," Mrs. Cooney said.
But the living room may have a value beyond its image-conscious displays, said Bill Stumpf, author of "The Ice Palace That Melted Away" (Pantheon, 1998), a book of essays about design and society. Mr. Stumpf, the designer of the first ergonomic chair, has seen his own children and grandchildren abandon the living room. Yet, he praises its civilizing influence, calling it "the most photogenic room, the home of the Christmas tree, of taking family portraits, holding weddings and, historically, funerals."
But perhaps it is the designer Kitty Hawks who most adroitly taps into the subconscious desire to hold on to the living room, for a while at least. Asked to describe a great living room, she recalled one in the Dakota on Central Park West that once belonged to the glamorous Amanda and Carter Burden. "It was when they were impossibly young and rich and beautiful," she said, already sounding dreamy. "Their living room had pale blue glazes on the wall and the curtains were pink silk. I remember the rug as an Aubusson, or at least a very good Oriental. It was like they were playing grown-up, but the gentleness of the pastel colors was so welcoming. Mostly, I remember that the room made everyone look great."
Now how many glorified kitchens can you say that about?

HEADLINE: China's Suicide Rate

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Suicides Reveal Bitter Roots of China's Rural Life" (front page, Jan. 24) exposes the shockingly high suicide rate of rural Chinese women, but does not mention one important factor partly responsible for these tragedies: 
 The lack of social security in rural China has made living with one's extended family the most common living arrangement for the elderly and the young. In such families, the young daughters-in-law have the lowest status, bear the greatest burden and are in frequent conflict with their mothers-in-law. For some of them, committing suicide is not only a way to escape suffering, but also a way to exact revenge, since many Chinese people believe that the dead can return to life to get even with their enemies.
 
LING LI
Towson, Md., Jan. 25, 1999
 
The writer is an assistant professor of economics at Towson University.

HEADLINE: Euro Hits 2-Week Low Against Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The euro fell to a two-week low against the dollar yesterday on expectations the United States economy's growth will keep growing at a faster rate than those of the 11 nations that have joined Europe's single currency.
Traders said the chances of an interest rate reduction in Europe had increased, which would make assets denominated in euros less attractive. 
 The euro fell to $1.14300 in New York, from $1.15530 on Wednesday.
The economy of the euro region "is clearly weaker than people thought," said Paul Brain, who helps manage more than $17 billion at Investec Guinness Flight in London.
The German Finance Ministry appears to agree. It said the European Central Bank may have to exert an "economy boosting" influence on the German economy this year, hinting the Government anticipates the benchmark interest rate -- currently 3 percent -- will be cut. The ministry forecast growth in Europe's largest economy would slow to 2 percent in 1999 from 2.8 percent in 1998.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Blue Chips Decline 124.35 In a Profit-Taking Session

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stocks fell for the first time in three sessions yesterday as investors took profits before Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Selling was particularly pronounced in computer and bank shares. But it was another good day for Internet stocks, which were lifted by better-than-expected earnings reports from Amazon.com and Ebay. After the market closed, America Online released fourth-quarter figures that also beat estimates. 
 Still, two stocks fell in price for every one that rose on the New York Stock Exchange. On the Big Board, volume was 894 million shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average gave back all its gains from Tuesday, falling 124.35 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,200.23. Declines in I.B.M., J. P. Morgan and Chevron were the biggest negative influences on the blue-chip index. Computer-generated sell programs were responsible for virtually all the Dow's decline.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 9.14, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,243.17. And the Nasdaq composite index, which has been on a torrid pace this year, declined 26.27, or 1.1 percent, to 2,407.14. The Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks fell 4.21 points, or 1 percent, to 421.12. But Thestreet.com's index of 20 Internet stocks gained 14.51, or 2.8 percent, to 534.60.
Despite the broad-based selloff, analysts said the decline was orderly and understandable.
"The market is at price levels that concern me, but there is no sense that this is anything beyond profit-taking and hesitancy ahead of Mr. Greenspan's remarks and what people are certain is going to be a strong report on the economy on Friday," said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. This morning, Mr. Greenspan is scheduled to testify before the Senate Budget Committee. And on Friday, the Commerce Department is expected to release its first report on fourth-quarter economic growth.
"It was a great day for Internet and some technology stocks and not much else," said Karl Mills, executive vice president at Junka & Voyles, a firm based in Oakland, Calif., with $5 billion under management.
It was a particularly good day for Ebay, the on-line auction company.
Ebay, which reported its fourth-quarter results after the market closed on Tuesday, soared 82 5/8, to 303 1/2. The company said it earned 7 cents a share in the fourth quarter, comfortably beating consensus estimates of 4 cents a share. It also said it would split its stock 3 for 1.
But the session was a dismal one for First Union and other bank stocks. First Union led bank shares lower after it said higher expenses and an accounting change would cut into its profits this year. The stock fell 4 7/8, to 52 3/16, after the report.
BankAmerica lost 2 13/16, to 62 1/8. J. P. Morgan slipped 4 3/16, to 100 1/16. And Mellon Bank fell 2 3/16, to 64 15/16.
I.B.M. and Compaq Computer led computer shares lower. I.B.M. lost 7 5/16, to 178 5/16. And Compaq, which has seen its stock price more than double since early October, fell 1 3/4, to 47 1/2, despite posting fourth-quarter results that were better than expected.
 
Treasury Prices Rise
By The Associated Press
Bond prices rose slightly yesterday, halting a two-day retreat, as new worries about Brazil's economy again sent traders looking to the relative safety of Government securities.
The price of the 30-year Treasury rose 2/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.12 percent, from 5.13 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Lawmaker Says Americorps Workers Can Help With Census

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
To help count Americans for the 2000 census, a House Republican leader said today that he would call on volunteers from Americorps, the national service program that, as a favorite of President Clinton, House Republicans have tried to eliminate.
The proposal was in a package of measures that Representative Dan Miller of Florida, the census subcommittee chairman, said would help insure an accurate count, now that the Supreme Court has ruled that the census must reflect a head count, not statistical sampling, for the apportionment of Congressional seats. 
 Republicans and Democrats disagree over whether the court ruling allows for sampling methods to be used for other purposes, like determining state legislative districts. The prospect of a second count has led to the possibility that the census will produce two different population numbers for some places.
Speaking at a forum sponsored by the United States Conference of Mayors, Mr. Miller said the Americorps volunteers would be part of an additional 100,000 counters who should be hired to work in communities where accuracy had been most difficult to achieve. For the 1990 census, the Government used more than 500,000 counters at one time or another.
"When a Republican proposes to expand the Americorps program," Mr. Miller said, "you know something is different. But if we're going to have Americorps, I can think of no better civic service than helping count America."
Americorps was created in 1993 with $365 million from Congress for its first year of operation, 1994, when 20,000 volunteers were placed in jobs. Since then, the program has endured attacks from many Republican House members who have favored ending the program. But with Democrats joining Republicans who support it, Americorps has generally emerged each year from the budget process in better shape than before. The current appropriation, $435 million, represents a third straight year of increases, and there are now more than 40,000 volunteers.
Harris Wofford, a former Democratic Senator from Pennsylvania who is Americorps' chief executive, said in an interview that he was "delighted that Congressman Miller has joined the chorus of people who were skeptical about Americorps coming to see its value and need."
Mr. Wofford acknowledged a paradox in Republicans' seeking Americorps workers for the census after passing legislation in 1966 that barred their securing positions from Federal agencies. To have them collect census data, he said, would require new legislation.
"I don't really want to be the one who says it's ironic," Mr. Wofford said. "I'm out fishing for more support to make national service non-partisan."
To insure greater accuracy in 2000 -- capturing people hardest to find, including low-income families in urban and rural communities, members of minorities and homeless people -- Republicans have favored improving the counting techniques while Democrats have supported the use of statistical sampling. Both parties believe that the people hardest to find tend to vote Democratic.
Mr. Miller said his plan would go a long way toward achieving a fuller and more accurate count. Besides enlisting Americorps volunteers, he proposed allowing local leaders to review data, expanding school programs that raise awareness of the census, sending a second questionnaire to households that did not respond the first time and increasing to 33, from 5, the number of languages in which census forms are printed.
Mr. Miller said he could not predict how much his measures would cost. But "if more is needed," over projections of $4 billion to $6 billion, he said, "I will support it all."
John Feehery, a spokesman for Speaker Dennis Hastert of Illinois said Mr. Hastert was "totally supportive" of Mr. Miller's proposals but had not reviewed the plan's components.

HEADLINE: Turmoil Fazes Philip Morris Only a Bitas Revenue Rises

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Despite domestic price increases for cigarettes and weaker demand from overseas, revenue at the Philip Morris Companies increased 6.4 percent and underlying earnings rose 9 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, the company reported yesterday. Full-year earnings for 1998 grew by 8.9 percent, to $3.17 a share.
The earnings were in line with Wall Street expectations. Nevertheless, the company's share price fell yesterday by $1.8125, to $46.4375, on a day when the stock market declined. Several analysts said jitters about more lawsuits against tobacco companies caused the stock slide, although it appears increasingly unlikely that the Federal lawsuit President Clinton mentioned in his State of the Union address will go forward. 
 One analyst, Emanuel Goldman of Merrill Lynch, said the company's cigarette sales in the United States were off only about 1 percent, even though Philip Morris raised its prices by more than 20 percent, or 45 cents a pack, in November. The company was the first to raise prices after the tobacco industry reached a $206 billion settlement with 46 states, although other companies quickly followed suit.
"They seem to be managing their pricing reasonably effectively," Mr. Goldman said of Philip Morris executives. "They are offering discounts to minimize the sticker shock and phasing in the net price increase. What they have in mind is minimizing the trading down by consumers from Marlboros to minor brands, because the lion's share of the money this company makes is from Marlboros."
The company said that its market share rose to 52.6 percent and that Marlboro sales rose to 37.6 percent, their highest level ever. At the same time, the company's sales costs, general and administrative costs went up almost 45 percent in the quarter, suggesting deep promotions and other expenses, said Marc Cohen, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Philip Morris said net earnings were down 79 percent, to $274 million, or 11 cents a diluted share, mostly because of $3.8 billion in tobacco litigation settlements. Without those considerations, the company said, its earnings rose 9 percent in the quarter. By contrast, net earnings were $1.3 billion, or 53 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1997.
Operating revenue in the recent quarter reached $18.4 billion, up from $17.33 billion.
The company's Kraft Foods division increased revenue by 7.2 percent, to $3.1 billion, in the quarter, although profits were pinched by higher costs for cheese and other dairy ingredients. The company said sales of such products as frozen pizza, Lunchables meals, Post cereals and Maxwell House coffee all grew. Altoids mints turned in double-digit growth, the company said.
Kraft announced a voluntary retirement program for 600 employees yesterday and said it would take a $150 million pretax charge for it in the first quarter of this year. The program is expected to generate $50 million in pretax savings annually.
Overseas, income from tobacco sales rose 10 percent, though volume fell 3.2 percent in the fourth quarter. Marlboro sales grew 3.8 percent in markets ranging from Western Europe to Japan. Sales declined in Eastern Europe and Russia, reflecting weakened economies there.

HEADLINE: Social Security: The Basics, With a Tally Sheet

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
When President Clinton unexpectedly used his State of the Union Message last week to propose vast changes in the way Social Security is financed, he touched off what may become the hottest policy debate of the year.
No other Government program has ever been relied on by so many people. Nor has one been so popular or so expensive. And probably no other measure affecting the general public is so complicated and so misunderstood. 
 As a guide in following the debate, here is a primer describing the basics of the program, its problems and its politics and what the President and the Republicans in Congress want to do about it.
 
Social Security And How It Works
A payroll tax is imposed on almost all workers and their employers -- 6.2 percent each on all wages below $72,600. (The workers and employers pay an additional 1.45 percent each in Medicare taxes.)
Nearly 90 percent of the money is now used to pay monthly benefits. Most of the money goes to retirees and their widows and widowers. A much smaller amount is paid to the survivors of workers who died before they retired and to disabled people.
Today's workers are taxed to pay retirement benefits for their parents' generation. When today's workers retire, their benefits will be covered by their children's generation. The principle is different from an investment or an insurance policy, in which individuals pay premiums and the income from those premiums is used to pay their benefits later.
When, as is now true, the Government receives more money in Social Security taxes than it must pay in benefits, the reserves are credited to a trust fund. The money is invested in Government bonds. The interest on the bonds is credited to the fund.
The trust fund is no more than a bookkeeping entry, a collection of Government i.o.u.'s promising to pay benefits to future retirees. This obligation will be fulfilled only to the extent that politicians are willing to raise the necessary money through taxes or borrowing. But as a political matter, it is an obligation that would be hard to ignore.
For years, the surplus in the trust fund has been used to meet part of the operating expenses of the Government and to offset part of the overall budget deficit. But this is no longer necessary because, for the next 15 years, the Government is expected to run a total budget surplus of $4.4 trillion.
 
The Problem: Graying of the Babies
Despite today's surplus, the future is far from rosy.
The ratio of workers paying taxes to retirees drawing benefits has long been shrinking. In 1950, there were 16 workers for each Social Security beneficiary. Today, there are slightly more than three. By the second or third decade of the next century, when most baby boomers will have retired, actuaries project there will be only two people at work for each person receiving benefits. When that happens, unless changes are made, the trust fund will go into the red.
The latest estimate is that Social Security taxes will continue to exceed benefits until 2013. Because of interest payments owed on the bonds credited to the trust fund, the income in the fund will be more than what is paid out until 2021. After that, the trust fund will begin to shrink rapidly year after year until the money runs out in 2032.
Economists and politicians agree that the sooner the problem is addressed, the less painful and abrupt the solution will be.
 
The President's Proposal: Surplus, Stocks and Savings
The President's plan would keep the Social Security tax and benefit structure. He has proposed giving 62 percent of the budget surplus over the next 15 years to the Social Security trust fund, $2.7 trillion of the $4.4 trillion projected surplus. (The rest would be spent on Medicare, the military and other programs.)
Of the $2.7 trillion, Mr. Clinton proposed that the trust fund invest $700 million in the stock market. The White House insisted that steps would be taken to insulate the investments from political tampering, but no details were offered.
The other $2 trillion would be used to buy Government bonds from the public to lower the outstanding public debt -- the sum of all the annual budget deficits over the decades -- from nearly $4 trillion to less than $2 trillion. As a proportion of the total economy, the national debt would fall from about 45 percent today to 10 percent in 2014, the lowest level since the nation entered World War I.
Mr. Clinton sees three advantages for Social Security in this approach:
*Historically, the average return on stock investments over a long period has been much higher than the return on Government bonds. The return on stocks is about 7 percent above the rate of inflation, as against 3 percent for bonds. Over the next 50 years, based on the long-term average return of stocks, investing $700 billion in the stock market instead of Government securities would extend the life of the trust fund by five years, the White House says.
*Paying off $2 trillion in public debt over the next 15 years should strengthen the economy by lowering interest rates and opening the way for more productive private investments. A stronger economy would increase the number of people working and the size of their paychecks and make it less painful for workers to pay the taxes needed to support Social Security.
*The interest on the $2 trillion in additional bonds would be credited by the Treasury to the Social Security trust fund, increasing the amount promised for retirement benefits.
These proposals, the President believes, would extend the life of the Social Security trust fund until 2055.
In addition, the President would allow people ages 65 to 69 to continue to work and receive full benefits. Under the existing law, their benefits are reduced by $1 for each $3 earned. And the President would improve benefits for widows. But he offered no means of paying for these additional benefits.
Outside of Social Security, Mr. Clinton would set aside $500 billion from the surplus to create "universal savings accounts." To encourage workers to save and invest, the Government would give low- and middle-income Americans seed money to invest in their own accounts in financial markets. Then the Government would match a portion of people's own money that they invested, similar to the way that many companies match their employees' contributions to 401(k) plans.
The White House concedes the plan would not fix Social Security's problems for good and that ultimately, to keep the program solvent for the next 75 years, taxes will have to be raised or benefits cut. But Mr. Clinton avoided dealing with this question. For the present, his proposal would not require any sacrifice by taxpayers or retirees.
 
The G.O.P. Position: A Work in Progress
The Republicans, who control Congress, have not developed a single proposal of their own. But they are united on three points:
*The Government should not invest in the stock market.
*The Social Security system should be overhauled so that workers could themselves invest in financial markets some of the money they now pay in taxes.
*The 62 percent of the surplus that the President wants to use for Social Security is the proper proportion, but much or all of the rest of the surplus should be used for tax cuts.
Republicans say Government investments in financial markets would be a mistake as a matter of principle and of economics. They say it would give the Government too much control over private companies. And they argue that the return on investments would be reduced because politicians could not be prevented from abandoning fiduciary responsibility and voting, for instance, to prohibit investments in companies that make cigarettes or firearms or contraceptives.
One approach considered by Republicans would allow workers to invest part of what they now pay in Social Security taxes. Guaranteed Social Security benefits would have to be reduced accordingly.
Another Republican approach would be to maintain the current Social Security tax and benefit structure but give workers an income tax cut if they invested the money in retirement accounts. This would eventually cause the Federal deficit to rise again if other taxes were not raised or spending cut to offset the income-tax cut.
 
The Politics: Tinkering With an Icon
Social Security was born in 1935 over Republican opposition, and Democrats from Franklin Roosevelt through Bill Clinton have trumpeted it to their political advantage.
Whenever Republicans have tried to tinker with the system, they have suffered politically. For instance, Republican support for a cut in benefits was seen by many as a reason the party lost control of the Senate in the 1986 elections. In the 1995 budget struggle with Congress and in his 1996 race for re-election against Bob Dole, President Clinton made headway with his accusation that Republicans wanted to cut Medicare, Social Security's close cousin, in order to give a tax cut to the wealthy.
The President and Republicans in Congress agree that sooner or later a solution must be found and that it must be bipartisan. But given this history of political mistrust and the added divisions arising from the President's impeachment, it will be extraordinarily difficult to reach an accord this year.

HEADLINE: Gun Liability Suit Is Built On Poor Data, Analyst Says

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
In a lawsuit seeking to hold gun manufacturers liable for shootings with illegally obtained handguns, an economist testified yesterday that the plaintiffs' main contention was based on flawed statistics.
The economist, Gustavo Bamberger, attacked the plaintiffs' case that the manufacturers oversupply dealers in states with weak gun-control laws, particularly in the South, and that many of the excess guns end up in the hands of illegal traffickers who resell them in states with tough gun laws, like New York. 
 His testimony formed the heart of the companies' case in fighting the potentially precedent-setting suit, now in its fourth week of trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.
The plaintiffs -- relatives of six people killed with illegally obtained handguns in the New York City area, and a seventh person severely wounded by such a gun -- maintain that the gun makers are collectively liable for the shootings, even if it cannot be proved which company's gun was used in a particular shooting. They argue for such liability because, they say, the companies market and distribute handguns so negligently that they foster illegal trafficking in the weapons.
But Mr. Bamberger, a specialist in statistical analysis, told the jury that the plaintiffs' "whole measure of oversupply is unreliable."
Reviewing figures offered earlier by the plaintiffs' economic consultants, Mr. Bamberger said that even if some states were oversupplied with guns, oversupply explains "virtually nothing" regarding why guns go from one state to another.
Mr. Bamberger noted that the plaintiffs' consultants, from National Economic Research Associates, a New York company, had estimated oversupply of newly manufactured handguns in various states by estimating the difference between the sales of such guns in the states and the "legitimate demand" for them. But the way they calculated the estimates of sales and legitimate demand was flawed because it was based on data that were too limited, said Mr. Bamberger, the vice president of Lexecon, an economic consulting company in Chicago.
He said the plaintiffs' consultants had projected the sales of new handguns in various states largely by using figures on sales that eight wholesalers made to dealers over the last decade. But considering that there have been an estimated 3,000 wholesalers in this period, and that the 8 accounted for only about 11 percent of such sales nationally, the sample was too limited to be valid, Mr. Bamberger said.
He also maintained that the sample had led to an exaggerated estimate of sales to dealers in the South because one of the eight wholesalers did most of its business in the South.
The plaintiffs' lawyers have said they used whatever sales figures they could pry out of an industry reluctant to provide the information, and the plaintiffs' consultants have defended their projections from the data.
Mr. Bamberger also contended that the estimates of legitimate demand in the various states were unreliable, and probably too low, because they were based on warranty cards filled out by buyers of guns made by Smith & Wesson. He said many buyers did not return such cards to the manufacturer. Smith & Wesson is among the defendants.
On cross-examination, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, Michael S. Feldberg, got Mr. Bamberger to admit that he did not challenge the plaintiffs' estimate, based on Federal data, that 90 percent of handguns used in crimes in New York State in recent years were originally sold in other states, often in the South.
"I just challenge the explanation behind it," he said of the plaintiffs' case.

HEADLINE: Pataki Presents A Tight Budget, Despite Surplus

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 27

 BODY:
After a two-year detour into government largess, Gov. George E. Pataki today returned to the conservative path of his early years, proposing a $72.66 billion state budget with substantial cuts in health care and education. He proposed eliminating programs aimed at expanding prekindergarten classes and lowering class sizes.
Though the state is flush with money, with a surplus expected to top $2 billion, Mr. Pataki called for a spending increase of just 1.8 percent in the fiscal year that begins April 1. That follows a 13 percent increase in spending, in part on education and Medicaid, during the two previous years, which helped enhance the Governor's popularity and propel him to a second term last November. 
 Mr. Pataki proposed deep cuts in Medicaid, the health care program for the poor, and in tuition assistance for low-income college students. Anticipating a continued decline in welfare rolls, he asked for a sharp drop in welfare spending.
The Governor called for an increase of barely 1 percent in aid to schools, to $11.9 billion. He sought to back away from a 1997 agreement that called for several years of spending increases to make kindergarten and prekindergarten available in every community, and to reduce class sizes in the early grades.
"This plan chooses smarter government over bigger government," the Republican Governor said in his annual budget address. "It commits to smart ideas that work. It better meets the needs of our citizens. And it does all this at a cost the people can afford. Not one nickel more."
The plan, the opening salvo in the Governor's annual budget struggle with the State Legislature, drew venomous responses from Democrats, who declared it dead on arrival, and from legions of interest groups predicting dire consequences.
Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, asserted that the budget had less to do with New York than with Mr. Pataki's ambitions for national office. He said the Governor had tailored his policies to appeal to conservative Republican primary voters in other states.
"In one stroke of this budget, he eliminated everything that we stood up for," said Mr. Silver, who was the chief sponsor of the 1997 deal to expand school programs. "It's unacceptable, this budget."
Medicaid, the largest part of the budget at $28 billion, has long been the Governor's favorite target for cuts. New York spends more on the program than does any other state, and its costs have tended to rise faster than those of other programs.
Hospital groups estimated the full impact of Mr. Pataki's latest proposed Medicaid cuts at $727 million to $850 million, most of it in lower payments to hospitals and nursing homes. Mr. Pataki contended that when a tax cut for medical institutions that he is proposing is included, they will lose less than $600 million.
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said: "He's creating a dire fiscal situation for hospitals and nursing homes throughout New York. If these policies go forward, there will be layoffs, service reductions and significant reductions in the quality of the health care system."
Mr. Pataki's $11.9 billion school aid proposal set off a sharp exchange between his aides and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's surrogates. Under the Governor's plan, New York City schools, with 38 percent of the state's public school students, would get 12 percent of the additional aid.
Joseph J. Lhota, Deputy Mayor for Operations, linked the budget and the Governor's appointment of a commission last weekend to investigate mishandled school construction contracts in New York City, and possible fraud in attendance figures at some city schools. "It appears that the commission is cover for the cut that they want to have for the New York City schools," he said.
Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's communications director, said state support for city schools has grown much faster in recent years than the city's contribution.
In only a handful of areas would Mr. Pataki significantly increase spending: the Office of Children and Family Services, a much-criticized agency that is supposed to monitor and prevent child abuse and run the foster care system; the state prison system, which would get more operating money and a new maximum-security prison, and school construction, which would continue a strong three-year rise in state support.
The Governor also proposed a $120 million increase, to $580 million, in state support for child care programs for the poor, including people trying to leave welfare. And he would dedicate $200 million to a new job-training effort for welfare recipients.
Most areas of spending, like school aid, would essentially be frozen, with increases too small to keep up with inflation.
As he promised, the Governor's budget would not spend any of the state's huge surplus, instead salting it away to help pay for tax cuts that are already law, but have not taken effect. He also mentioned two programs he had announced recently: steps to rein in the state's rapidly growing debt, including using money from the nationwide tobacco settlement; and almost $1 billion annually in new tax cuts, most of which would not go into effect for a few years.
So far, Mr. Pataki's fiscal policies have been like a roller coaster ride, and the reactions have been no less head-swerving. In his first two years, to close budget gaps and pay for tax cuts, he held spending essentially unchanged by cutting health care and other programs. He was widely excoriated as an unfeeling conservative, and his popularity plummeted.
But as Wall Street boomed, the state found its coffers overflowing with tax revenues. State spending rose more than $3 billion in 1997-98, then more than $5 billion this fiscal year, even as the state continued to cut taxes. Mr. Pataki's standing soared, and he cruised to re-election.
The new budget may be more restrained, but it is a reflection of the last two years' free-wheeling ones. In addition to pouring record sums into popular programs, the 1997 and 1998 budget deals included tax cuts that have barely been felt yet, but whose sizes would climb yearly, to almost $4 billion a year in 2001. It is because of that combination of spending increases and promised tax cuts that Mr. Pataki now feels that he must be more restrained.
The Governor scoffed at the notion that any plan that built on those increases could be called austere. The spending increases are small, he said, but "one of the reasons is that we've done so much."
Many analysts said the last two budgets set a course for fiscal collapse, but they praised today's plan as a correction. "We think that the Governor deserves support for standing up for fiscal prudence," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission.
The 1997 budget agreement centered on one large trade. The Republicans, including the Governor, got a cut in property taxes levied by school districts. It started at $700 million this fiscal year and would grow to $2.7 billion in 2001-02.
In return, the Democrats won a commitment to make all-day kindergarten, and prekindergarten classes for 4-year-olds, available in every system in the state, and to lower class sizes in kindergarten through third grade. It also included an increase for school construction. All told, the package promised a series of increases, over and above any increases in basic school aid, reaching $1.3 billion in 2001-02.
Only the construction money would survive Mr. Pataki's budget. He eliminated more than $300 million in promised increases for the other parts of the program.
The Governor asserted that he would replace the program with $200 million in block grants to school districts, but that money could be used for almost any purpose. Not counting those grants and the program they replaced, aid to schools would actually decline in Mr. Pataki's plan.

HEADLINE: Crowd of 200 Greets Suspect In the Slaying Of an Officer

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 27

 BODY:
Police dogs lunged and growled, officers and dispatchers wept with relief and citizens applauded as detectives led a homeless Hartford man into the police station here today where he was charged with murder in the shooting of an East Hartford police officer on Saturday night.
The suspect, Noel Sostre, 23, was led through the gantlet in the handcuffs that once hung on the belt of the 26-year-old policeman he is accused of killing, Officer Brian Aselton. 
 Mr. Sostre was delivered to the police station in the police cruiser that Officer Aselton had driven. He was led past a framed photo of the officer and through a door draped in a black shroud.
Mr. Sostre was charged with 10 crimes, including capital murder, which carries the death penalty. Bond was set at $5 million.
The killing and search had drawn hundreds of officers from central Connecticut and hours of live coverage on local television. The suspect had been questioned first in the Hartford police headquarters, and the crowd in East Hartford, across the Connecticut River from the capital, built to about 200 over several hours as word spread that he was being transferred.
Gov. John G. Rowland said at a news conference later in the afternoon that Mr. Sostre had provided "a full written confession." Late this afternoon, the police charged two women with helping with the crime, and officials said they, too, had given statements admitting involvement.
For four days officers from the Connecticut State Police and 23 local departments had searched ponds, roofs, fields and culverts in search of evidence, using dogs, a helicopter and metal detectors. Young officers checked nightclubs and areas known to be frequented by drug dealers, looking for someone who knew something.
A reward fund grew to $80,000.
The break came on Monday night, an unexpected tip from what amounted to a random encounter. A car was stopped for speeding on Main Street in Hartford, and when the officer decided not to give the driver a ticket, a grateful occupant volunteered information that led officers to the three suspects, said an official involved in the investigation who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Police Chief James W. Shay said the reward offer had played "a significant role" in encouraging the tipster.
Officials said Mr. Sostre, also known as Alex, came to the United States from Puerto Rico about 10 years ago, and had been living with his wife in Hartford. But he told officials that for the last four months, he has been homeless. He is unemployed, prosecutors said. He has been convicted of a felony in Connecticut, and has a criminal record that includes using a vehicle without permission, larceny, assault, and failure to appear in court.
In an effort to protect the informant, very little information about the arrest was released today and officials sealed the affidavit for the arrest warrant. At a bond hearing for Mr. Sostre in Superior Court in Manchester, prosecutors agreed to release the document to Mr. Sostre's court-appointed lawyer, but insisted that it not be shown to him.
Bond was set at $3 million each for the two women, who live in adjacent apartment buildings in Hartford. Nency Forty, 29, was charged with capital murder and six other crimes. Erica Vilchel, 23, was charged with felony murder and four other crimes.
When Mr. Sostre was brought to the police station, he was wearing a plaid shirt, black pants and low-topped boots without laces. He kept his head down and did not answer shouted questions. When he was arraigned four hours later, he spoke to Judge E. Curtissa Cofield of Superior Court through a Spanish translator. Four rows in the cramped courtroom were filled with East Hartford officers, wearing black bands on their badges.
Mr. Sostre was on probation in an assault conviction at the time of the shooting, the authorities said. He is to appear in court next on Feb. 2. The two women are to be arraigned on Thursday. The police said that more arrests were possible, but that "the main players" were now behind bars.
Officer Aselton was killed on Saturday night when he came upon what authorities believe was a robbery and assault while he was investigating a complaint about noise in an apartment building. Investigators said that Officer Aselton was shot in the forehead at close range and that a resident of the building had just been beaten and robbed.
A backup officer found Officer Aselton, mortally wounded, and the building resident near him. The beating victim, who has since been released from the hospital, was able to give the police an assumed name of one of his assailants, but not the real name.
Relatives and officers said they could take some comfort in the arrests as they gathered for a wake for Officer Aselton tonight. State troopers plan a ceremonial two-mile march to his funeral in South Windsor on Thursday.
Bouquets, some with red, white and blue ribbons, continued to pour into the police station, along with a teddy bear in a Harley-Davidson sweater in tribute to Officer Aselton's interest in motorcycle racing.
A letter from a couple who called themselves "average citizens" was posted on the window of the dispatch center. "As my husband and I rested, safe and comfortable in our East Hartford home on Saturday night, this young man gave his life to keep us that way," the woman wrote. "I wish I could have thanked him."

HEADLINE: Straying Fiscal Conservative Returns to His Roots

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In presenting a spartan budget, Gov. George E. Pataki sought today to reclaim his reputation as an unwavering fiscal conservative and to expunge the memories of a spending surge during his re-election campaign that caused some of his most faithful supporters to grouse that he was as eager to sign checks as any old Democrat.
Other Republican Governors eying their national standing, including Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and George W. Bush of Texas, are trying to make their marks in this year of good economic times and swollen government coffers by advocating innovative spending programs, particularly for education. But Mr. Pataki seems to have concluded that he can cement his statewide popularity and burnish his image around the country largely by promoting tight-fisted fiscal practices, including significant tax cuts. 
 "In a state where the guiding principle is respect for the people," he said in today's budget address, "big government and big government taxation simply does not compute."
Mr. Pataki may feel that he has to propose a lean budget, at least if he wants to hold up his tenure nationally as a model of prudent management that turned around a state many in his party thought was foundering because of that liberal icon, Mario M. Cuomo.
In the current budget, spending is slated to rise by 8 percent, an amount that left many conservatives cringing and questioning Mr. Pataki's commitment to their beliefs. In the next one, which begins April 1, he proposes growth of 1.8 percent, less than the rate of inflation. He is also calling for Albany to keep in reserve a current surplus that is expected to top $2 billion to insure that the state's finances are not battered by an economic downturn.
If the Governor had again sought a large spending increase -- even before the Legislature pushed its own new programs -- he would essentially be undoing the work of his first two years in office, when he kept a tight rein over the budget. The signal would be that last year was not an election-year aberration but a fundamental shift in course. Mr. Pataki would also be raising the alarms not only of conservatives, but also of many fiscal monitors, who contend that the current rate of growth is unsustainable.
New York State has for decades had one of the worst fiscal records in the nation, including the largest debt of any state by far. Mr. Pataki's proposal would for the first time seek to check the increase in debt.
"He's returning to his fiscally conservative roots," said Thomas Carroll, president of Change New York, an advocacy group that had long backed Mr. Pataki, only to upbraid him over last year's increases. "He had a consistent record from his days in the Assembly and Senate and his first two years as Governor of being very hawkish on keeping spending under control and cutting. In the run-up to the election, that obviously was suspended. It is clear that he is going back to positions that he has held a long time."
Still, the Governor is taking pains not to flaunt his agenda as overtly conservative, mindful that New Yorkers are generally hostile to the style of Republicanism symbolized by the party's southern wing. In his speech and in comments later, he rarely if ever used ideological terms or the word "conservative," relying instead on phrases like "achieving fiscal balance."
His budget was also not as provocative to the Legislature and some advocacy groups as his first one in 1995, which called for sharp cuts and led to months of vitriol between the two branches of government.
When asked today about complaints from some lawmakers that his proposal was too austere, Mr. Pataki repeatedly noted that in the last two years he had spearheaded sizable increases in education and other spending. "Last year we were criticized because we provided so much more help to local governments and schools," he said at a news conference. "This year, they're saying, 'Why didn't you do enough?' Well, one of the reasons is that we have done so much last year -- record school aid increases for the second year in a row."
Whatever the Governor's overall record, Democratic lawmakers are certain to try to portray this new budget as part of an insidious plan to court Republicans nationally by using the state as a laboratory for archconservative policies.
"More than ever, we can see now that this is more of a national political agenda than it is doing the right thing for New York State," said Michael J. Bragman, a Syracuse-area Democrat who is the Assembly majority leader.
The Governor dismissed such criticism, though he declined to say how the budget might play to the party. "My budget is guided by my view of the best interests of the future of the people of New York," he said. "It is focused on New York. And that is the motivation, and that is what I hope the Legislature focuses on, so that we can meet the needs of the people quickly and move forward."

HEADLINE: Highlights From the Governor's Spending Proposal

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's $72.66 billion spending proposal would increase the size of the state budget by 1.8 percent, or $1.3 billion, figures that include Federal aid for programs like Medicaid and welfare. The total derived from the state's own money would also increase by 1.8 percent, to $49.3 billion.
Here are some highlights of the plan: 

MEDICAID -- Without any changes, the program would have grown to almost $29 billion next year, because of built-in increases to account for inflation. But Mr. Pataki is calling for a $266 million reduction in state spending for the program. When matching Federal and local contributions are factored in, his proposal means that there would be at least $727 million less next year for the program than the level it was on course to reach. That money would come mostly from cuts to hospitals, nursing homes and home-care providers. Mr. Pataki's plan would lower Medicaid reimbursement rates by $374 million for hospitals, $239 million for nursing homes and $114 million for home-care providers.
The Governor is seeking to eliminate, in part, a complex reimbursement system that in most cases pays hospitals, nursing homes and home-care providers based on the rate of inflation and the cost of specific procedures. He proposes to replace that system with set fees for each patient. The Pataki administration believes that such an approach would encourage health care providers to lower their costs, because they would be permitted to keep any Medicaid dollars that they did not spend.
 
SCHOOL AID -- After two years in which the Governor and the Legislature have approved record increases in spending for primary and secondary education, Mr. Pataki has proposed a more modest, 1.3 percent increase for schools next year -- worth $154 million to a proposed $11.91 billion. Of the total increase, $17.5 million would go to New York City schools.
Mr. Pataki also backed away from a deal that he made with the Legislature in 1997 to finance a program that would pay for all-day kindergarten and prekindergarten in communities across the state, and decrease the size of classes in the first, second and third grades. Mr. Pataki instead proposed to provide school districts with a more modest cash grant that they could use for programs of their choosing.
Mr. Pataki called on the Legislature to provide slightly more than $2 million to help community groups and others pay for the costs associated with opening so-called charter schools, which operate outside of local school boards' control. He also renewed his call for overhauling the state's program for educating disabled children.
He said the current system provides educators with a financial incentive to classify children as disabled, even when those children could be taught in regular classroom settings.
WELFARE -- The bulk of Mr. Pataki's proposed $345 million decrease comes from a sharp decline in the welfare rolls, which have fallen by more than 600,000 recipients since the Governor took office in 1995, a 36 percent decrease. But unlike in previous years, Mr. Pataki is not proposing cuts in cash grants or other services for the poor.
Instead, Mr. Pataki would increase spending on child care for the poor, mostly welfare recipients -- by $120 million -- to $580 million. Mr. Pataki also proposed setting aside $200 million in a reserve fund that counties could use over the next three years to cope with increasing demands for child care.
 
HIGHER EDUCATION -- The proposed $135 million of savings in this area -- to a total of $4.87 billion -- would come from cuts to the state's Tuition Assistance Plan. Mr. Pataki has proposed reducing the financing for the plan to $501 million for next year from this year's $633 million.
Mr. Pataki's proposal would wring most of that savings by reducing the maximum grant from 90 percent of annual tuition costs to 75 percent. The proposal would change the income eligibility for the program so that fewer students would qualify and reducing awards to students who do not take a full course load, which is expected to hurt poorer students because they must often take fewer classes to leave time for work. The Governor's plan also essentially freezes spending for the state and city University systems.
 
CRIMINAL JUSTICE -- Of the $70 million increase the Governor is proposing for criminal-justice agencies -- to a total of $1.83 billion -- Mr. Pataki is setting aside $21 million to operate a new 1,500-bed, maximum security prison in Franklin County, near the Canadian border. The proposed increase also includes $18 million to replace aircraft in the New York State Police Department's aging fleet.

HEADLINE: Working (Too) Hard for Less

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas Geoghegan (Op-Ed, Jan. 24) relies on anecdotal evidence rather than statistics to argue that American employers steal increasing amounts of their employees' leisure time. 
 By insisting that most of unpaid labor is off the books, Mr. Geoghegan would reject statistics like those gathered by researchers at the Dallas Federal Reserve Bank that show that the number of hours worked each week by a typical American worker fell from 39.8 in 1950 to 36.9 in 1973 and to 34.4 in 1996 -- a particularly noteworthy trend, since it corresponds with a period of decreased labor-union power.
In fact, there is ample evidence indicating that American workers enjoy more leisure time today than at any time in the past. For example, the amount of inflation-adjusted dollars that Americans spend on recreational activities has more than tripled since 1970.
 
KAROL BOUDREAUX
Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y.
Jan. 24, 1999
 
The writer is director of programs, Foundation for Economic Education.

HEADLINE: Working (Too) Hard for Less;
Shaky Union Connection

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas Geoghegan (Op-Ed, Jan. 24) argues that workers work more hours for less pay because, among other reasons, unions cover only 10 percent of the private work force. 
 However, unions have been declining in power since the mid-1950's. Moreover, during the mid-1980's, nonagriculture union membership was already quite low (17 percent), but concurrently, there were strong wage increases followed by higher inflation. Mr. Geoghegan's argument also does not explain why many European countries with much higher rates of union membership have also recently experienced low inflation.
 
GENEVIEVE PHAM-KANTER
Chicago, Jan. 24, 1999
 
The writer is an associate economist, Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

HEADLINE: Nafta Invoked to Challenge Court Award

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
Some business executives have argued for years that large jury verdicts against big companies show that American courts are out of control.
Now a Canadian company that lost a huge case against a competitor in Mississippi is using a novel legal tool to seek at least $725 million from the United States Government. 
 Legal experts say the claim, the first against the United States under a little noted provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement, will encourage other companies to try the new tactic. And critics say the precedent could provide a potent back-door way for corporations to challenge the American legal system.
Loewen Group Inc., a Canadian funeral home company that lost a $500 million verdict in a 1995 Mississippi suit over fraudulent business practices, announced last fall that it had filed an international arbitration claim against the Government.
But Loewen's specific assertions and the large sum it was seeking were secret until this month. Among other things, Loewen, which is based in Burnaby, British Columbia, said the verdict against it was "infected by repeated appeals to the jury's anti-Canadian, racial and class biases."
Some legal experts said the Loewen claim advances a creative but plausible legal argument. Other experts said the case would test whether international trade agreements will be a new forum for business discontent with the American court system.
"It is an important case because it raises the question of the extent to which domestic civil judicial proceedings will be subject to international re-examination," said David W. Leebron, an expert on trade law and the dean at Columbia Law School.
The claim asserted that the Government should pay Loewen damages for what the company said was unfair treatment in the suit it lost to a Mississippi funeral home entrepreneur, Jeremiah O'Keefe 3d. Loewen settled the Mississippi case for $175 million in 1996.
In its claim, Loewen is seeking compensation not only for what it paid under the settlement but also for damage to its business.
The North American Free Trade Agreement promises fair treatment to foreign investors. Loewen said the court proceedings against it breached that promise, and argues that the Federal Government is responsible for the damage it says it suffered. But even some of those who were most involved in the debate over the trade agreement five years ago say they did not anticipate claims based on court verdicts.
Loewen's settlement with Mr. O'Keefe would stand no matter what happened in the arbitration panel designated under Nafta, the International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes, which is a division of the World Bank. Under Nafta's rules, the arbitrators are to be selected from a roster of international trade and investment specialists. Each side is to select one arbitrator with a third to be chosen by agreement of the two sides. The panel is likely to be named soon, with proceedings to follow within a few months.
If the United States loses, public funds would be used to pay Loewen. The case does not involve the Canadian Government.
In its claim, Loewen attacked the Mississippi verdict, which involved a jury finding that Loewen used fraudulent practices to try to drive Mr. O'Keefe out of business. Loewen called the Mississippi court action an "uncompensated expropriation" of its property.
A Justice Department spokeswoman declined comment except to say the Government was fighting the claim, which she said lacked merit. But in the months since Loewen disclosed the existence of its case, critics have been warning about what they say are the dangers of it.
A victory by Loewen "would completely undermine the American civil justice system," said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, a watchdog group that has been critical of Nafta. Forcing American taxpayers to pay Loewen for its losses, she said, would erode the aim of American courts to punish and deter wrongdoing.
James A. Wilderotter, a lawyer for Loewen, declined to respond to critics in detail. But he said, "Nafta is part of the American legal system and the right to bring the action we have brought is clearly found within Nafta."
In its claim, Loewen included statements from political and legal authorities who, the company said, agreed that its treatment in the Mississippi courts should be considered a violation of the trade agreement.
Among others, Loewen quoted Mississippi's Governor, Kirk Fordice. "The O'Keefe verdict," Governor Fordice wrote, "represents to me everything that is wrong with the court system." Critics of Loewen say several of its experts, including Governor Fordice, have long records of criticizing the American court system.
But some trade-law experts said the case was a sign that the United States would come under increasing pressure in trade battles to moderate jury verdicts as the world economy grows more unified. "This is the globalized economy we've all been talking about," said John H. Jackson, an expert on trade law and a professor at Georgetown University Law Center in Washington.
Mr. Jackson and Mr. Leebron both noted that business leaders in other countries have for years complained that America's large jury verdicts make investment here unpredictable. They both said those assertions were much like the worries of American business executives about other countries' expropriations.
Nafta, like most agreements that use arbitration in business disputes, permits the handling of cases in confidential proceedings. Under those confidentiality rules, Loewen's case is to be heard in closed hearings by an arbitration panel unless Loewen and the Government agree to public proceedings.
Some critics of Loewen's filing say they are especially troubled by the fact that a case with large legal and financial ramifications could be decided in a closed proceeding.
"This is wrong and harmful to America because it substitutes for our judicial system a confidential arbitration panel that's not open to public scrutiny," said Mark S. Mandell, the president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America.
Under the confidentiality rules, Loewen's claim documents were not publicly released until this month. Mr. Wilderotter acknowledged that Loewen released its claim documents only after it learned the Government was preparing to release them because the documents had been requested under the Freedom of Information Act.
The Mississippi court battle, which drew national attention, involved a bitter fight between Mr. O'Keefe and Loewen, a publicly traded funeral home chain with a reputation for hardball tactics.
After a hard-fought trial in Mississippi, Mr. O'Keefe's lawyers succeeded in arguments to jurors that Loewen tried to drive Mr. O'Keefe from business, sought to monopolize the regional funeral-home business and planned to raise prices to the bereaved.
Jurors said that they were angered by Loewen's tactics and awarded Mr. O'Keefe $100 million in compensatory and $400 million in punitive damages. In its Nafta claim, Loewen said Mr. O'Keefe's lawyers unfairly suggested to the jury. which included blacks, that Loewen was biased against blacks. The company said the plaintiff's lawyers also inflamed xenophobic passions by analogizing Loewen's move into Mississippi to the Japanese "sneak attack" on Pearl Harbor.
Loewen contended the verdict, the largest in Mississippi's history, was out of proportion to any losses Mr. O'Keefe might have suffered. And it said it was put at a disadvantage by Mississippi law governing appeals.
Mississippi, like many states, required a losing party to post a bond to appeal. Based on the $500 million verdict, the bond, too, would have been huge: $625 million. Loewen fought the bond requirement. But the Mississippi Supreme Court ruled that the $625 million bond was required.
Loewen said it could not post such a large bond. "Loewen," it said, "was forced to settle the case under conditions of extreme duress."
Mr. O'Keefe's lawyer, Michael S. Allred of Jackson, Miss., said in an interview that the verdict against Loewen was fair and that Loewen should have pursued its appeal if it felt it had been wronged. In addition, he argued that Nafta's confidentiality provisions attack the integrity of the American court system.
Although the settlement Mr. O'Keefe received from Loewen would be beyond the reach of the Nafta arbitration panel, Mr. Allred said he and his client were offended that the jury's effort to punish Loewen would be nullified if the Government was forced to compensate Loewen in a proceeding that took place behind closed doors.

HEADLINE: No Currency Devaluation, China Reiterates

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Jan. 27

 BODY:
With world markets once again jittery about a possible devaluation of China's currency, the yuan, the governor of the Chinese central bank said today that there were no plans to do so, pointing out that there is even less pressure on the currency, also known as the renminbi, than there was last year.
"As the person in charge, I can say the renminbi will not be devalued," the bank chief, Dai Xianglong, said at a news conference in Beijing. "During the Asian crisis, the renminbi was not devalued and at the moment it is not necessary for the renminbi to be devalued." 
 Mr. Dai's comments touched off a strong rally in China-related stocks in Hong Kong, where there is deep concern that a possible devaluation would force Hong Kong to shift its currency's link to the United States dollar. Hong Kong's index of H-shares, or China-based companies, surged more than 7 percent, while the broader Hang Seng index rose 209.83 points, or 2.21 percent, to 9,719.66.
Mr. Dai also said China would move ahead with plans to tighten regulation while gradually liberalizing its financial industry practices. All large cities will be opened to foreign banks, which were previously limited to Shanghai and Shenzhen, the city in southern Guangdong province that borders Hong Kong.
The central bank will also relax control over the interest rate allowed on foreign loans, Mr. Dai said, giving commercial banks more freedom to attract borrowers.
At the same time, Beijing plans to continue attacking irregularities at banks and other financial institutions, cracking down on improper foreign-currency dealings to protect foreign-exchange reserves and to deter the smuggling of goods into the country.
Last year, Mr. Dai said, the central bank discovered $6.42 billion in fraudulent purchases, and adding, "A number of underground markets and illegal money exchanges have been eliminated."
He said as well that many of China's trust and investment companies would be reorganized. These financial institutions have been blamed for fueling wild speculation in stock and property markets, often creating liabilities that far outweigh assets.
Yet Mr. Dai was vague about plans, described by other bankers in recent weeks, to reduce the number of trust and investment companies to about 40 from 240. "Some will be preserved; some will be merged," he said. "The restructuring will be based on commercial principles."
International bankers were recently surprised by bankruptcy proceedings against the Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corporation, or Gitic, where local officials said loans might not be repaid at all.
Gitic was shut down in October with $4.3 billion in debts and assets of $2.6 billion, and the Government placed the company in bankruptcy earlier this month. The move put foreign banks at the end of a long line of creditors seeking repayment.
Yet Mr. Dai said Beijing would like to see Gitic reorganize its debts rather than face its creditors in court. "If they can, through negotiation, agree on a restructuring scheme, the central bank would be very glad to see that," he said.
He added that creditor claims would be decided by the Guangdong Supreme Court, though in China most courts take advice from Beijing on important cases.
But it was Mr. Dai's comments about China's currency that drew the most attention from traders and analysts in markets around the world. Only when China faces a large international payments deficit, Mr. Dai said, would the authorities be forced to consider a devaluation.
China currently runs a healthy balance of payments, even though exports are faltering and foreign investment is slowing. The trade surplus last year reached a record $43.6 billion, while foreign-exchange reserves are still at a robust $145 billion.
Mr. Dai said a devaluation would hurt foreign investment, increase the country's foreign debt burden and cause instability in other Asian financial markets. He also reaffirmed Beijing's support for the Hong Kong dollar's peg to the United States dollar.
Surveying China's larger economic situation, Mr. Dai said that the economy was likely to grow around 7 percent this year. In 1998, the economy grew by 7.8 percent.
China's consumer price index, he predicted, would increase by 4 to 5 percent this year. The index fell eight-tenths of a percent last year.
