HEADLINE: Microsoft Official Defends Company's Strategy at Trial

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR and AMY HARMON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
A senior executive of the Microsoft Corporation delivered a forceful defense of the company's actions in the Internet software market today, saying it had acted mainly in the pursuit of a "Holy Grail of software development" by making its products more powerful, easier to use and seamlessly integrated.
The executive, James Allchin, the second company official to appear as a witness at the Microsoft antitrust trial, also argued that other software makers have done what the Government says is anticompetitive in Microsoft's case and presented a detailed history of his company's product plans for the Internet. 
 In his 139-page written testimony, Mr. Allchin repeatedly struck the theme that the Justice Department and the 19 states suing Microsoft are making an ill-advised effort to tamper with innovation and product design in a leading high-technology industry.
"I am not a lawyer or an economist," Mr. Allchin wrote, "but I do not understand how a company's efforts to improve its products can ever be 'anticompetitive.' "
The testimony of Mr. Allchin, a senior vice president in charge of the technical development of the company's Windows operating system, is a salvo in Microsoft's legal fight with the Government over how the lawsuit is framed, which is crucial to the outcome of the case.
Microsoft says its decision to bundle its Internet Explorer browser with its industry-standard Windows operating system and give the browser away free was a straightforward product-design decision that benefits consumers.
But the Government contends that those moves represent the abuse of Microsoft's monopoly power to thwart competition.
Most antitrust experts say that Microsoft's strongest defense is to frame the case as a debate over its product decisions.
Indeed, in a related case, a Federal appeals court ruled last June that Microsoft had the right to bundle its browser with Windows, warning of "the undesirability of having courts oversee product design."
But the Government views Microsoft's bundling decision as simply one step in a pattern of what it regards as predatory business practices intended to stifle competition.
The prosecution case, according to antitrust experts, is strengthened by framing the courtroom debate around Microsoft's business practices and contracts.
At the trial today, the Government kept that focus in its third day of cross-examining Microsoft's first executive witness, Paul Maritz, trying to show that the company pressured the Intel Corporation to stop developing technology that conflicted with Microsoft's plans.
Intel is mainly a producer of the microprocessor chips that serve as the "electronic brain" of most PC's, but it also develops software. Microsoft's conflict with Intel in 1995 centered on Intel's work on multimedia software called "native signal processing," or N.S.P.
Intel wanted to distribute its N.S.P. software to PC makers, but it pulled back after protests from Microsoft. The Government contends that Microsoft muscled both Intel and the computer makers not to adopt any software that conflicted with Microsoft's plans.
Microsoft replies that Intel stepped back on its own, after realizing that there were problems with its N.S.P. software.
The Justice Department pointed to internal Microsoft E-mail to try to show that the big software maker did pressure Intel and the industry. An Oct. 18, 1995, E-mail to Mr. Maritz, written by William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, said that Intel felt PC makers were resisting Intel's software because of "our N.S.P. chill." Later, Mr. Gates added, "If Intel is not sticking totally to its part of the deal, let me know."
"Did you ask Mr. Gates: 'What bargain are you talking about? What deal are you talking about?' " David Boies, the Justice Department's lead trial lawyer, asked Mr. Maritz.
Mr. Maritz, the senior executive in charge of most software development and marketing at Microsoft, replied that he had not.
But he maintained that Intel ultimately abandoned N.S.P. because it was technically flawed and would not work with recent versions of Windows.
In what Mr. Boies portrayed as another example of Microsoft's attempting to co-opt or pressure potential competitors, he also questioned Mr. Maritz about the company's investment in Real Networks Inc., a developer of software that allows audio and video to be transmitted over the Internet.
Mr. Maritz acknowledged that executives from Real Networks, then known as Progressive Networks, told Microsoft in 1997 that if Microsoft invested in the company, it would shift its business to other kinds of software and services to avoid competing. But Mr. Maritz noted that Real Networks continues to compete with Microsoft nonetheless.
A Real Networks spokesman said yesterday that the company never agreed to get out of the streaming media business.
Microsoft is in the process of selling its 10 percent stake in Real Networks.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
It's hard to tell who won in the High Court local phone ruling.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
JUDGING from reactions, it was hard to figure out exactly who won this week's decision by the Supreme Court to uphold Federal rules designed to open up the local telephone market to competition.
The AT&T Corporation and other long-distance carriers declared victory, saying the decision would allow them to go after local customers as the Telecommunications Act of 1996 had intended. The Federal Communications Commission, which issued the rules, declared vindication. Even some of the losing plaintiffs, the local phone companies, pointed with glee at the part of the decision that would require the commission to reconsider part of its rule making. 
 But no matter what the parties to the dispute say, the big winner, according to many economists and consumer advocates, will be ordinary phone customers. Gene Kimmelman, a top official at Consumers Union, said, "This decision will help small companies to come into the local market and take on the reigning monopolist." Robert Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, said that "on balance, I'm happy that the court erred on the side of the commission rather than the local Bell companies."
The commission's rules were designed to create competition in local phone service, breaking the monopoly of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the other regional Bell carriers. The Bells struck back and found a Federal court willing to throw out the rules on the ground that the commission had strayed beyond its legislative mandate. This week the Supreme Court overturned the lower court decision, voting to let competition unfurl.
The idea behind the 1996 act was to give consumers a choice by inviting long-distance carriers like AT&T and cable and wireless concerns to enter the market for local phone service. In return, after opening their sanctuary to competition, the local Bell companies would be allowed to enter long distance.
Congress left it up to the commission to figure out the rules. The problem was that no company was in a position to provide local service using only its own equipment. Entrants would need to use, at least initially, some or all of the Bell network, including wires into homes, switching equipment and operator services. The threat was that the Baby Bells would overcharge for their network or deny access to key components entirely, blocking entry into local service even as they drove hard into the long-distance market. That posed the danger that the Bells would exploit the 1996 act to dominate telecommunications markets, making a mockery of Congress's will.
In surprisingly short time, about six months, the commission came up, in Mr. Kimmelman's judgment, with "smart rules that compel the Bell companies to compete on fair terms with potential rivals." The commission set down two key principles. There would be one national pricing policy, with 50 state variations to take account of regional cost differences, making it easy for companies to enter any and all states at once. And the regional Bells would be required to rent all their network or any important component of the network. AT&T might need to rent wires into the home, but not signaling equipment. A wireless company might not need the wires, but might need to rent directory assistance.
Second, the commission ruled that the Bells could charge only enough to cover the costs that an efficient concern would incur to provide the switch, wire, operators assistance, or whatever other equipment or service the entrant needed to rent. Said another way, the Bells would not be allowed to pass along the bloated costs that they had actually incurred as an inefficient, government-protected monopolist.
Some state commissions have set prices at levels well above the commission's efficient-provider rule. But under the commission's rules, the Baby Bells would charge enough to cover legitimate costs -- the costs of a low-cost provider -- and not one penny more. That way, entrants could enter and drive down prices to the level of the lowest-cost producer.
The Bells challenged the rules, arguing that the 1996 act did not empower the commission to set prices. Though their position might not make a lot of economic sense, they could point to ambiguities and contradictions in the statutory language of the act that made their interpretation plausible. A Federal appeals court sided with the Baby Bells. The Supreme Court sided with the commission. Whatever the pros and cons of its legal reasoning, the Supreme Court's decision gives, after more than two years of legal deadlock, long-distance and other potential entrants a fair shot at the local phone market.
The Court did accept one part of the Baby Bell argument. It ruled that the commission had forced the Bells to rent a long list of components and software services without determining that entrants truly needed those components and services in order to compete. The commission was instructed to reconsider its list, dropping items, perhaps like operator assistance, that entrants could provide themselves or rent from non-Bell companies.
The GTE Corporation points to this provision of the High Court's decision as grounds to declare victory. Others say that this order for re-examination will delay efforts to open the local phone market. But these claims appear exaggerated. The commission took only six months to issue its entire package of rules in 1996. It surely needs less time to revise a small portion of those rules. So, at worst, the Court has imposed a delay of a few months.
Besides, delay is of tertiary importance. If the Court had gone the other way -- permitting states to set rental prices according to historical costs or permit the Bells to deny access to key parts of their network -- it would have risked putting some of the Bells in charge of telecommunications until Congress took up another bout of reform. Here, history is sobering. The 1996 act revised legislation dating back to 1934.
Waiting a few months while the commission revises its rule making hardly matters if the result is to create a competitive maelstrom from which consumers should reap benefits for decades to come.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ford Said to Be in Deal For Volvo's Car Business
Ford Motor plans to announce today that it will acquire the passenger car operations of Sweden's Volvo for $6 billion to $7 billion, people close to the talks said last night.
Ford's deal, which beat a rival bid from Italy's Fiat and strengthens its position as the No. 2 auto maker in the world, marks the latest step in the consolidation of the global automotive industry. Car makers worldwide are rushing into deals because they fear a coming shakeout in the industry, in which the only survivors will be the lowest-cost producers with the greatest economies of scale. Page A1. 

Yahoo in Deal to Buy Geocities
In a move meant to defend its position as the world's leading site on the Internet, Yahoo Inc. has agreed to buy Geocities, another popular site, for an estimated $3 billion, financial executives close to the deal said. The deal could be announced as early as today. C4.
 
Compaq Profit Beats Forecast
Compaq Computer said that its fourth-quarter results reached a record $758 million, surpassing Wall Street estimates. But investors were not impressed. Shares of Compaq fell $1.75, to $47.50, after rising 5.5 percent on Tuesday when the company announced that it planned a public offering of a stake in Alta Vista, its Internet search engine. C4.
 
America Online posted a profit of $122 million for the quarter ended Dec. 31, surpassing Wall Street expectations. C21.
 
Stocks Decline on Profit-Taking
Stocks fell for the first time in three sessions as investors took profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 124.35 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,200.23. The S.& P. 500 slipped 9.14 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,243.17. And Nasdaq declined 26.27 points, or 1.1 percent, to 2,407.14. One of the big winners was Ebay, which rose $82.625, to $303.50. C9.
 
Analysts Decide to Be Advocates
A group of analysts has decided to use National Presto, a publicly traded company that makes pressure cookers, corn poppers and microwave bacon cookers, as an example of how investors may be able to benefit from shareholder advocacy. Market Place. C10.
 
Nafta Invoked in Court Challenge
A Canadian company that lost a huge case against a competitor in Mississippi is seeking $725 million from the United States Government under a little noted provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement, a move some say could provide a way for corporations to challenge the American legal system. C6.
 
China Vows No Devaluation
With world markets once again jittery about a possible devaluation of China's currency, the yuan, Dai Xianglong, the governor of the Chinese central bank, said that there were no plans to do so, pointing out that there is even less pressure on the currency than there was last year. Mr. Dai's comments touched off a strong rally in China-related stocks in Hong Kong. C6.
 
Insider Trading Charges Brought
A group of Long Island stockbrokers has been charged with insider trading in a scheme involving obtaining advance copies of Business Week's "Inside Wall Street" column and then making securities purchases based on the information. C21.
 
Executive Defends Microsoft
A Microsoft executive defended the company's actions in the Internet software market at the software giant's antitrust trial. He also argued that other software makers have done what the Government and 19 states say is anticompetitive in Microsoft's case. C2.

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8. 

Now Playing
 
 * "AFFLICTION," starring Nick Nolte, James Coburn, Willem Dafoe, Sissy Spacek and Mary Beth Hurt. Directed by Paul Schrader (R, 114 minutes). Mr. Nolte is devastating in the performance of his career, as Wade Whitehouse, a New Hampshire loner fighting a losing battle with demons from his past. Foremost among them: Mr. Coburn, terrifyingly authentic as the drunken, abusive father who long ago cowed his sons into submission. As directed by Mr. Schrader, this pure, unfettered adaptation of Russell Banks's novel starts on a deceptively ordinary note, then escalates into inexorable fury. Every little detail matters. Ms. Spacek and Ms. Hurt expertly play the women who trigger Wade's crisis (Janet Maslin).
 
 * "ANOTHER DAY IN PARADISE," starring James Woods and Melanie Griffith. Directed by Larry Clark (R, 101 minutes). From the director of the bruising and ominous "Kids," this vibrant, unapologetically seedy road movie is a virtual day at the beach. Mr. Clark's second feature may not have the sting of his first, but it comes closer to establishing him as William S. Burroughs with a swooping, pivoting movie camera, bringing bizarrely innocent enthusiasm to material that might otherwise ooze druggy shock value, and making decadence as basic as the weather. Mr. Woods, as a junkie, thief and absurdly unlikely father figure, revels in this full-throttle role (Maslin).
 
 "AT FIRST SIGHT," starring Val Kilmer and Mira Sorvino. Directed by Irwin Winkler (PG-13, 128 minutes). In this overlong and often desperately banal version of a case study reported by Dr. Oliver Sacks, Mr. Kilmer plays a man whose nearly lifelong blindness was suddenly alleviated by surgery. Ms. Sorvino plays the bright-eyed New York career woman who falls in love with him, then urges him to change his once-peaceful life. But the film brings little more than case-study data to communicating how this man's restored sight affected him, or what made it a mixed blessing. Sample dialogue: "Have you ever listened to the rain? I mean, really listened?" (Maslin).
 
 * "CENTRAL STATION," starring Fernanda Montenegro, Vinicius de Oliveira and Marilia Pera. Directed by Walter Salles (R, 115 minutes). In this quiet, luminous Brazilian gem, a joyless older woman crosses paths with an orphaned young boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling. As these characters develop a fractious bond, then embark on a road trip that takes them vividly to Brazil's hinterlands in search of the boy's father, Mr. Salles brings great tenderness and surprise to the events that punctuate their journey. Ms. Montenegro's tough bravura performance was one of last year's very best (Maslin).
 
 * "A CIVIL ACTION," starring John Travolta, Robert Duvall and William H. Macy. Directed by Steven Zaillian (PG-13, 120 minutes). This story of a David-Goliath lawsuit against industrial polluters, with Mr. Travolta first rate as an ambulance chaser who develops a conscience, could have been business as usual in the legal thriller genre. But Mr. Zaillian's keenly observed, beautifully acted film, based on Jonathan Harr's nonfiction best seller about a case in Woburn, Mass., doesn't follow familiar formulas. It follows all the surprises and frustrations of a story that was never black and white and is all the better for its shades of gray. Mr. Duvall is outstanding as a corporate lawyer full of wily tricks (Maslin).
 
 * "THE GENERAL," starring Brendan Gleeson and Jon Voight. Directed by John Boorman (not rated, 125 minutes). Mr. Boorman's best and most stylish film in years is the deftly told story of Martin Cahill. Nicknamed "the General" for his crime-plotting strategies, this Irish gang leader and master thief is played with splendid brio by Mr. Gleeson. Photographed gorgeously in black and white, the film tells of his elaborate art and jewel heists, his unusual domestic arrangement with his wife's sister and his singular difficulties with the I.R.A. and the law. Mr. Voight is outstandingly good as the police detective who knows all of Cahill's tricks (Maslin).
 
 * "HILARY AND JACKIE," starring Emily Watson and Rachel Griffiths. Directed by Anand Tucker (R, 121 minutes). The parallel biographies of the brilliant cellist Jacqueline du Pre (Ms. Watson), who contracted multiple sclerosis at the height of her career, and her slightly older sister, Hilary (Ms. Griffiths), a talented flutist who gave up a professional career to marry and be "ordinary," is one of the most insightful studies of sibling rivalry ever filmed. Jacqueline may have won fame and glory, the movie says, but she remained a desperately needy emotional child who had to have everything Hilary had (including Hilary's husband). The film is structured like a concerto, in three movements, the last of which ends with Jackie's harrowing death in her sister's arms. The drama is deepened by a soundtrack that makes expert use of Jacqueline's signature piece, the Elgar Cello Concerto in E minor. Ms. Watson's Jacqueline flames with an almost scary intensity (Stephen Holden).
 
 "IN DREAMS," starring Annette Bening, Aidan Quinn and Robert Downey Jr. Directed by Neil Jordan (R, 112 minutes). At heart this is just a campfire story, and a pretty loony one at that. But Mr. Jordan directs it furiously a la "Interview With the Vampire" with a lush, insinuating visual style that gets right under the skin. Working with the inventive cinematographer Darius Khondji, he stirs up a nightmare brooding and intuitive enough to recall at times the richly textured mysteries of Nicolas Roeg's "Don't Look Now." Ms. Bening plays a psychic plagued by the thoughts of a serial killer, whom Mr. Downey makes as bizarre and disturbing as he can, in a performance that makes this story's craziest dreams come true (Maslin).
 
 * "MY NAME IS JOE," starring Peter Mullan and Louise Goodall. Directed by Ken Loach (R, 92 minutes). A splendid, feisty performance by Mr. Mullan energizes this film about a recovering alcoholic trying to rebuild his life. With humor and scrappy intensity, Joe throws himself into coaching young athletes and embarking tenuously on a love affair, only to find the expected challenges to his new sobriety everywhere. Mr. Loach's commitment to delineating social issues is accentuated by the way his star breathes life into Joe and makes viewers root for his success. Special bonus: this film breaks the brogue-and-burr barrier by including helpful subtitles for the overlapping, heavily Scottish-accented dialogue (Maslin).
 
 "PATCH ADAMS," starring Robin Williams and Monica Potter. Directed by Tom Shadyac (PG-13, 110 minutes). As a maverick doctor intent on making terminal patients laugh, Mr. Williams delivers a little clowning and a lot of maudlin feel-good sentiment, along with vulgarity left over from the filmmaker's "Ace Ventura" days. He also spends a lot of time being congratulated for his good works, as the film's minor players are kept busy marveling at his antics. The real-life story of this doctor may sound like a fine excuse for Mr. Williams to cut loose, but the film version proves narrow and predictable. Ms. Potter, with a nostrilly resemblance to Julia Roberts, figures in a romantic subplot with a bizarre twist (Maslin).
 
 * "THE PRINCE OF EGYPT," starring the voices of Val Kilmer, Ralph Fiennes, Sandra Bullock and Michelle Pfeiffer. Directed by Brenda Chapman, Steve Hickner and Simon Wells (PG, 93 minutes). First came the great expectations for this animated magnum opus from Dreamworks. Then came reality, in a film struggling mightily to balance animated whimsy and biblical stature. The upshot is an admirably worthy rendering of the Exodus story, even if Moses must initially be seen as a playful young scamp. Biblical plagues and miracles serve as special inspiration for the animators' reality-bending ingenuity (Maslin).
 
 * "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE," starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow, Geoffrey Rush, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench. Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile, this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today, and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
 * "A SIMPLE PLAN," starring Bill Paxton, Billy Bob Thornton and Bridget Fonda. Directed by Sam Raimi (R, 120 minutes). This onetime cult horror director makes a flawless transition to mainstream storytelling with a quietly devastating thriller. And its fine cast plays out the consequences of a harmless-sounding error in judgment that winds up leveling everything in its path. The catalyst is $4.4 million that literally falls out of the sky, and Scott Smith's story proves how deadly the morality of expediency can become. When you get the shivers watching this wintry tale, which features an especially memorable performance from Mr. Thornton, it won't be from the cold (Maslin).
 
 "STEPMOM," starring Susan Sarandon, Julia Roberts and Ed Harris. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG-13, 120 minutes). A man's ex-wife and new girlfriend lock horns over who can be nicer to his two children, in a sudsy story made livelier by its two female stars, both in appealingly high gear. Ms. Roberts plays the nicest person ever to wear black to a downtown photo shoot, while the especially fiery Ms. Sarandon plays the suburban mother as mama lion. Even when the prospect of mortality looms, the story manages to maintain its big, lavish look and peculiar (under the circumstances) sense of fun. As in "Home Alone," Mr. Columbus directs with sunny indifference to reality, medical, economic or otherwise (Maslin).
 
 "STILL CRAZY," starring Stephen Rea, Billy Connolly, Bill Nighy and Jimmy Nail. Directed by Brian Gibson (R, 96 minutes). Twenty years after they last dropped acid in a Druid circle, an over-the-hill English rock band tries to reunite, and the results are meant to be both funny and heartwarming. Not an easy mix, unless Spinal Tap really is your idea of a band that needs a second chance. Despite an extremely likable cast that fits right into the spirit of things, the director of "What's Love Got to Do With It" and the writers of "The Commitments" don't drum up enough drama or sustained humor to make the most of their premise. The cast is cheery and game, the material hit-or-miss (Maslin).
 
 "THE THIN RED LINE," starring Jim Caviezel, Ben Chaplin, Nick Nolte, Sean Penn and Woody Harrelson. Directed by Terrence Malick (R, 166 minutes). From the first frame of this huge, drifting war epic loosely derived from James Jones's Guadalcanal novel, it's viscerally clear that Mr. Malick is back. The exquisite, oddly detached visual style that made "Badlands" and "Days of Heaven" the most beautiful films of the 1970's is instantly apparent here, even if the narrative vagueness and brooding voice-overs are also familiar. The film sprawls, gets lost and occasionally delivers visual poetry, the kind that could have been greatly helped by tighter editing. Bottom line: no one who admired Mr. Malick's early work should miss this. But those expecting anything simple will not find it here (Maslin).

 "REVOLUTION AND BEYOND: A SURVEY OF CUBAN CINEMA." Cuban peasants wielding machetes fight for independence in 1868 against Spanish soldiers in "First Charge of the Machete." At 2 P.M. today, this film by Manuel Octavio Gomez will open a retrospective of some 30 films spanning the last 40 years of Cuban filmmaking. A presentation of the Film Society of Lincoln Center in collaboration with the Cuban Film Institute, the series provides an opportunity to discover unfamiliar films made after the Castro-led overthrow of the Batista dictatorship in 1959 as well as familiar hits like "Strawberry and Chocolate" (1994) by Tomas Gutierrez Alea. Two films about Cuban slavery are also on the opening day schedule, Mr. Alea's "Last Supper" (1976), at 3:45 P.M., and "The Other Francisco" (1974), by Sergio Giral, at 8:45 P.M., as is Juan Carlos Tabio's political allegory "The Elephant and the Bicycle" (1995) at 6:30 P.M. The series continues through Feb. 25 at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. Admission: $8.50; $5 for Film Society members; $4.50 for the elderly at weekday matinees. Information and screening schedule: (212) 875-5600 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: Patriot Games

BYLINE: By Frank Cammuso and Hart Seely; Frank Cammuso and Hart Seely are, respectively, a cartoonist and a reporter for The Syracuse Post-Standard.

 BODY:
Lured by a $350 million stadium, guaranteed revenue from luxury seating and a $1 billion riverfront redevelopment, the National Football League's New England Patriots will move to Hartford beginning with the 2001 season.
"We want to redefine Hartford's place on the map," Connecticut's Governor, John Rowland, said when the move was first announced. 
 What could they have in mind?
MEMPHIS, Jan. 29, 1999 -- Graceland, the Memphis-based home of Elvis Presley, will move to Hartford, Conn., beginning in 2002, officials announced today.
With the ranks of departed celebrities growing, Graceland executives said, they needed to "find a new place to dwell" to compete with larger market shrines.
The Graceland ownership has been threatening to leave since April, when Tennessee voters rejected a proposed $400 million Hyatt-Regency Heartbreak Hotel Convention Center.
To get Graceland, Hartford agreed to build the 70,000-seat mausoleum-theme park, to be called Graceworld, which will be financed through a 5 percent surcharge on velvet portraits.
"Elvis has left their state!" Gov. John Rowland of Connecticut gloated. "Viva Hartford!"
PAGE, Ariz., June 22, 2000 -- Grand Canyon officials announced plans today to move the popular national park to Hartford, Conn., where it will co-anchor a $30 billion downtown redevelopment, beginning in fiscal year 2003.
After failing last May to renegotiate its two-million-year lease with Arizona, the Canyon made no secret of its plans to seek a larger media market. Ever since, Arizona officials have sought a suitable replacement, rumored to be Knott's Berry Farm.
The new, 700,000-seat Grand Hartford Canyon will feature a retractable dome, artificial turf, an Imax theater and the Trump Palace Casino. The 30-year agreement calls for Hartford to guarantee $200 million annually from canyon wall advertising.
"The future looks grand!" Gov. John Rowland said. "Hartford is gorges!"
WASHINGTON, July 4, 2001 -- Government officials confirmed today that the United States Congress has signed a memorandum of intent to move its headquarters to Hartford, Conn., beginning with the 2004 term.
The proposed $900 million "Hartford District of Connecticut" includes a domed Philip Morris House Voting Chamber, the N.R.A. Atrium Lobby and the Impeachment Hall of Fame/Planet Hollywood.
The move fulfills Hartford's 213-year quest to obtain a nation's capital. Last May, efforts to lure Moscow fell through after Russian voters rejected relocation in favor of a plan to construct a 600,000-bed retail/residential collective on their home soil, to be called "Creme de la Kremlin."
Officials in the District of Columbia are said to be seeking a replacement for Congress, possibly a petting zoo.
To lure Congress, Hartford will guarantee $270 million annually in soft-money campaign contributions.
"We, the people, love Hartford!" Gov. John Rowland proclaimed. "This land is our land!"
MILKY WAY, June 23, 2004 -- Officials said today that the Center of the Universe will move to Hartford, Conn., beginning in 2009.
"I always believed that the world revolves around Hartford," Gov. John Rowland said. "Now, if only the Patriots could win a Super Bowl. . . ."

HEADLINE: Report Finds Banks Failed To Oversee Big Hedge Fund

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

 BODY:
A handful of the world's largest commercial and investment banks failed to adequately oversee lending and trading activities with the hedge-fund giant Long-Term Capital Management, a regulatory study has found.
William J. McDonough, the president of the New York Federal Reserve, oversaw the study and said that the banks had been blinded by what he called the "magic" of the once high-flying firm's vaunted reputation, a situation he suggested could recur if banks did not tighten their monitoring of such funds. 
 Mr. McDonough's comments accompanied the release yesterday of a lengthy international review on the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital in September, which Mr. McDonough said would have posed a threat to the stability of the global economy.
The report detailed many lapses in judgment by banks in their dealings with Long-Term Capital and similar hedge funds, but it noted that such funds were still very difficult to regulate and that the most effective way of preventing potential disasters was for lenders to be far more circumspect. The report said that banks had become better attuned to the dangers posed by lax supervision of their dealings with hedge funds since the Long-Term Capital debacle.
But denizens of Wall Street, even the very largest and brightest, never have been known to possess particularly good memories, a fact Mr. McDonough was quick to note again yesterday. "Financial institutions can learn lessons well, but the question is how long they continue to remember them," he said.
Chase Manhattan; Citigroup; J. P. Morgan; Merrill Lynch; Morgan Stanley; Goldman, Sachs; Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers were the nation's financial services firms with the closest lending or trading relationships with Long-Term Capital. Foreign firms close to the hedge fund included UBS, Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse, and Societe Generale.
Hedge funds are largely unregulated, private investment pools typically open only to wealthy individuals and large institutional investors. The most free-wheeling hedge funds borrow huge sums of money to make complex trades in stocks, bonds, currencies and more exotic financial products known as derivatives.
Yesterday's report was issued under the auspices of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, which consists of senior representatives of the world's leading central banks. Mr. McDonough is the committee's current chairman. The report was compiled with the help of other United States banking regulators, including the Comptroller of the Currency.
Asked whether the problem arose because banks failed to review Long-Term Capital's borrowing and trading enough or because the hedge fund failed to disclose sufficient information when queried by lenders, Mr. McDonough said "some of both."
"The competitive pressure kept banks from asking basic questions and getting fundamental information in some cases," said Michael L. Brosnan, head of risk evaluation for the Comptroller's office. "That should never happen."
The report also noted that commercial and investment banks relied too much on the day-to-day value of Long-Term Capital's assets when deciding if they had enough collateral to cover any losses.
In extremely volatile financial markets, such as the panic that followed Russia's decision in August to devalue its currency and declare a debt moratorium, the value of assets, and thus collateral, can plunge. Because of that, banks had less secure collateral at Long-Term Capital than they believed. The report said that banks need to "stress test" their exposure to hedge funds more regularly, taking into account the likelihood of financial meltdowns.
The report said more stringent public regulation of hedge funds may be required, but it noted the challenges of carrying out such a task in a world of computerized, nearly borderless financial transactions.
Because most hedge funds "are registered in offshore centers, any direct regulation would therefore have to extend to those jurisdictions in order to be effective," the report said. "Such an extension would require a high level of political initiative and would involve consideration by political, legislative and judiciary bodies."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
1924 Building Is Restored in Midtown

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
After a $3.5 million yearlong modernization and restoration program, a 75-year-old building at 40 West 55th Street in midtown Manhattan, used mainly for offices and clothing showrooms for the last three decades, has been returned to its original role as a rental apartment building.
The Macklowe Organization completed the work last month, transforming the inside of the building, just west of Fifth Avenue, from a maze of commercial spaces into 36 apartments, including two penthouses with wraparound terraces. That is the same number of units with virtually the same layouts originally contained in the 10-story structure, which was built in 1924 and designed by the noted architect Rosario Candela. The architect, recognized for his spacious interior layouts, designed many grand apartment houses on Fifth and Park Avenues. 
 Because the building at 40 West 55th Street was for years a commercial property, including a period as the headquarters for Ralph Lauren Polo, "50 percent of it was changed beyond recognition," said Dan Shannon, a principal at Moed de Armas & Shannon of Manhattan, architects for the restoration project. The suspended ceilings and the walls installed to reconfigure the interior for commercial use were removed. The space was redesigned in accordance with the original layouts, Mr. Shannon said, adding that "we could work forever and never get layouts as nice as these."
Of the 36 apartments, 35 have two bedrooms, and one has one bedroom. The apartments range from 1,100 to 1,400 square feet; all have nine-foot-high ceilings, entry galleries, separate service entrances, windowed kitchens and baths, and fireplaces. Half of the units also have formal dining rooms.
The project also involved modernizing the building's mechanical systems, installing new windows and upgrading its lobby, including restoring its terrazzo flooring and adding a Venetian-style fresco to its oval-shaped ceiling. The building's red brick and stucco exterior, featuring decorative terra cotta trim around the windows and cornices, has also been cleaned.
The Macklowe Organization acquired the building for $8 million to $9 million in 1997 from Emigrant Savings Bank, which had taken it back from the previous owner, who had defaulted on the mortgage. The company did so because "it is in an exceptional location in the heart of midtown and there is a strong demand for spacious prewar rentals, which are in limited supply," said Jessica Schick, the company's director of sales.
The building is adjacent to the Rockefeller Apartments, a landmarked 138-unit co-op, and shares the same block with La Cote Basque and La Caravelle restaurants and the Peninsula and Shoreham hotels.
At the time of the purchase, the building housed fewer than a dozen occupants, most of them commercial tenants but including three apartment dwellers. Since then, all but two residential tenants have relocated. Those tenants lease rent-regulated apartments and by law are allowed to remain in their units at regulated rents; the developer is challenging the validity of one tenant's lease.
The building opened for leasing last month, during the traditionally slower winter rental season and when there is a larger supply than usual of luxury apartments available, including six recently built or converted buildings, brokers said. The supply is partly the result of the stock market's slump last August, which slowed the pace of leasing and in turn "kept the lid on rental price increases at the end of last year," said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a rental brokerage in Manhattan.
A report by her concern showed that at the end of 1998, asking rents for apartments in doorman buildings on the Upper East and Upper West Sides have risen by 8.9 percent, compared with the end of 1997 -- about the same increase recorded in 1997 over 1996. The report put the average monthly rent at the end of last year at $2,568 for a one-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side and at $2,550 for the same size unit on the Upper West Side.
But Ms. Packes said she expected the larger than usual supply of available rentals to be short-lived. "In the last two weeks, leasing activity has been strong, indicating a pent-up demand for rentals," she said. "And if the economy continues to expand and people's salaries increase proportionately, rental rates will resume their rise." That will be reinforced, she added, "by the limitations on new supply."
The Macklowe Organization is offering the incentive of a month's free rent on a 13-month lease, Ms. Schick, the company's sales director said, noting that the offer is to be discontinued next month. So far, she said, 12 apartments have been leased at monthly rents of $3,650 to $4,650, which brokers said was competitive with apartments in buildings in the 40's and 50's. Monthly rents for the penthouses are $4,500 for the 1,100-square-foot one-bedroom and $6,000 for the 1,150-square-foot two-bedroom.
Ms. Schick said the building has drawn mainly renters from Europe as well as some business executives who want a Manhattan pied-a-terre and who are attracted "to the intimate old-world character of the building and its convenient address."
That is what appealed to Yuri Bohaievsky, the Consul General of Ukraine, who next week will move, with his wife and adult son, into a two-bedroom apartment in the building.
"We like that the building is not very big, offering a close environment, and that the apartment has enough room to receive guests for small parties," Mr. Bohaievsky said. It is also close to Central Park and just a 15-minute walk to his midtown office, he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
70.20 Rise on Nasdaq Leads Gains Across the Board

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Buoyed by Intel's fourth split since 1993 and other evidence of prosperity for high-technology companies, the Nasdaq stock market rocketed to a gain of nearly 3 percent yesterday, pacing a broad market rally.
Prices gathered strength throughout the session, exhibiting less of their recent volatility as investors digested fresh news of a strong, low-inflation economy, more upbeat earnings reports and some big takeovers along with Alan Greenspan's latest remarks about valuations. 
 In comments before the Senate Budget Committee, Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, did not repeat warnings about irrational exuberance but did compare investing in Internet stocks to playing the lottery. His remarks did little to dampen enthusiasm.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index, resuming its sharp advance that now amounts to 13 percent so far this year, climbed 70.20 points, to 2,477.34.
"Techs are the sector," said John F. Snyder, executive vice president of John Hancock/Sovereign Investors. "The feeling among many people is that if they're underweighted there, they've got to get in."
But lesser strength was found across a broad front, reflected in a hefty 1.53 percent advance for the Wilshire 5000 and a 1.79 percent advance for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which rose 22.20 points, to 1,265.37.
The Dow Jones industrial average finished with a gain of 81.10 points, or nearly nine-tenths of 1 percent, though close to half of the increase was the result of surges in two stocks: AT&T, up 4 5/8, to 89 15/16, and J. P. Morgan, up 4 5/16, to 104 3/8.
"There's a lot of good news out there today," said Peter Cardillo, research director at Westfalia Investments. "We're on our way to Dow 10,000."
Analysts cited among other things Government reports of a surprisingly big jump in orders for durable goods and of contained employment costs, the latter likely to reassure Federal Reserve policy makers, who meet next week, that inflation remains well in check.
America Online, which late on Wednesday announced strong earnings and a stock split, climbed 8 15/16, to 174 7/16, but many other computer-oriented companies did even better. Yahoo, which said it was buying Geocities, rose 31 7/8, to 367 3/4; Geocities soared 42 1/4, to 117 1/4. Infoseek rose 12 1/2, to 83 15/16, and Lycos shot up 11 5/8, to 123 1/8. .
Intel rose 4 7/8, to 137 3/16, as the company announced a 2-for-1 split and a 50 percent dividend increase.
Ebay, however, slumped 10 7/8, to 292 5/8, as it responded to news reports about possibly fraudulent items sold by other companies on its auction site, and Amazon.com eased 2 3/4, to 122 7/8.
The relative sluggishness of the Dow industrials, still up only 1.09 percent in 1999, and other traditional market favorites was said to reflect their big run-ups over the last four years.
"Investors may still be around to buy the dips," said Christine A. Callies, chief strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "But they're clearly having second thoughts about chasing high valuations."
Pfizer stood out in the drug group, rising 5 5/8, to 127 9/16. It said directors would vote on a 3-for-1 split.
On the New York Stock Exchange, 852.4 million shares changed hands, with advancing issues holding only a small margin over declining ones, 1,561 to 1,454. New 52-week lows outnumbered new highs by 86 to 65.
Overseas, stocks rose 3.9 percent in Sao Paulo, 2.5 percent in Paris and 0.8 percent in Frankfurt. Prices were 3.7 percent lower in Hong Kong, 0.7 in Tokyo and almost 0.1 percent in London.

Treasury Prices Rise
 By Bloomberg News
 Bond prices rose as a Government report on labor costs fueled optimism that inflation would stay low and as the Federal Reserve bought Treasury securities.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury rose 10/32, to 10 28/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.10 percent, from 5.12 percent on Wednesday.
Bonds received a boost when the Fed bought $615 million of Treasuries maturing between February 2019 and November 2021. The central bank makes these purchases periodically to add money permanently to the banking system.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Crash Course InEconomics;
Rethinking What's Driving The Emerging-Markets Crisis

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Among the movers and shakers gathered here for the World Economic Forum, a striking metaphor is helping to frame the debate over the global financial crisis that began in Asia and has spread to several other developing countries. The debacle, some say, brings to mind a slick stretch of highway, scene of a half-dozen recent auto accidents. So is it careless driving or the highway that is the cause of the accidents?
Substitute free-wheeling worldwide capital flows and unrestricted lending for the slippery, fast-moving highway. Make South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, Russia and Brazil stand-ins for the drivers and their cars. The accidents are the panics and recessions -- the crackups -- that have devastated each of these countries. And the question now so widely debated is simple enough: Are the countries mostly to blame or the unrestricted capital flows, or both? 
 After the first accidents, the countries came in for almost all the blame. It was because of crony capitalism, bad banking and overleveraged real estate investments, many experts said. Fix the sloppy financial practices and also make enough bailout money available when a country gets into trouble -- basically the current strategy of the International Monetary Fund for Brazil -- and the accidents will be avoided or, at worst, will be mere fender benders. But spectacular wrecks have occurred with alarming frequency and severity the last 18 months, even in Brazil, and some who had mostly blamed the countries have begun to argue, here and in earlier interviews, that the system needs serious fixing, too.
The Clinton Administration had mostly blamed the countries, and still does. But its view, like that of the I.M.F., is starting to reflect a more nuanced appraisal. "We have seen that countries need to pursue sounder policies and avoid lurching for short-term capital, as Mexico and Thailand did," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary. But in a phone interview this week from Washington, he also called for "more prudence on the part of the lenders."
And in the Administration's most direct acknowledgment so far that it is not necessarily always committed to unrestricted capital flows, he added, "Where countries have controls that restrict short-term lending, we have not in general sought to dismantle them."
Some on Wall Street are similarly shifting ground. "It is appropriate to certainly consider fixing the system," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. Morgan Stanley normally makes more money when capital flows freely and the firm can lend where and how it sees best.
But the recent string of crackups has given Mr. Roach second thoughts. "I am not completely convinced that restrictions on the system are necessary," he said, "but unstable capital flows have clearly been a precipitant of these crises."
At the top of many lists for fixing the system are proposals to limit the flow of short-term foreign loans to developing countries, loans that often contributed to more rapid growth but which piled up in huge amounts in Asia, Russia and Brazil. Then, at the first hint of trouble, investors, both at home and abroad, pulled their money out, precipitating and worsening a full-scale financial collapse.
But other systemwide suggestions are winning favor as well. Pursing flexible exchange rates, for example, to avoid sudden, frightening devaluations. Introducing bankruptcy laws that let companies deep in foreign debt borrow and resume operations even before they pay off the old debts. And standstill provisions in lending agreements that would temporarily prevent a foreign lender from withdrawing loans from a South Korea or a Brazil in the midst of a crisis.
What they have in common is an effort to put more of the burden on international banks and other lenders to evaluate risks more carefully early on and suffer more of the consequences later if things go bad.
"The banks don't like this; they value liquidity of lending," said Barry Eichengreen, an international economist at the University of California at Berkeley. "But if they had a provision in their loan agreements that they cannot pull out their money right away when a crisis is developing, maybe they would not lend the money in the first place."
Some experts now favor rules that prevent not only foreign lenders, but also wealthy nationals -- Brazilians, for example -- from canceling their short-term loans and investments, then converting this money from local currencies into dollars and taking the dollars out of the country. Wealthy Brazilians, many of them already moving chunks of capital abroad, hold more than $150 billion in their Government's debt and rushing this money out of the country would quickly exhaust Brazil's dollar reserves.
"My view is that basically all short-term debt constitutes potential capital flight," said Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Brazil is at risk not only from foreign lenders, but from anyone who can take money out of the country."
Perhaps some of these measures would make the highway safer for ordinary drivers. But before the dangerous stretch of road is rebuilt in hopes of preventing future accidents, the smashed cars of the last 18 months have to be repaired and put back in operation. There is little agreement on how to do that. Rather there are two diametrically opposite, so far unyielding, approaches.
The current practice, carried out at the insistence of the Clinton Administration and the I.M.F., is to require countries in trouble to adopt policies intended to limit devaluations of a country's currency and restore the confidence of international lenders. If currencies plunge too far, the argument goes, then foreign loans become much harder to repay and inflation sets in as imports shoot up in price.
"The mainstream view would still be that the key solutions to crises remain policy adjustments within the countries themselves," said William Cline, chief economist at the Institute for International Finance, which represents lenders. "Once you restore confidence in a country's financial system then you can get its economy growing again."
The chief tools in this approach are sharply higher interest rates and cutbacks in public spending. But the high rates and spending cutbacks invariably produce recessions.
The Clinton Administration argues that once confidence in a financial system is restored, interest rates can then come down, as they have in South Korea and Thailand, and nations can begin the long climb out of recession. But even Thailand and South Korea are still on the side of the road, their economies spinning their wheels rather than moving forward again. "It is too facile to say, 'Look at Korea and Thailand, they are turning around,' " said Dani Rodrik, a Harvard economist. "Their economies have taken bigger hits than either country has experienced in the last 30 years."
Like the East Asian countries, Brazil, the latest victim of a financial panic, is hewing to policies that are plunging that country into recession. And as the hobbling of giant Brazil slows economic activity everywhere in Latin America, the odds rise that even the United States and Europe could be caught in the spreading global crisis. That would not happen so much because of recession in Latin America, but because some new blow -- a major bankruptcy, for example, or a sharp decline in American stock prices -- undermines confidence in an American financial system still nervous about Asia and Brazil.
The contrasting view is argued most vehemently by Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard, who insists that high interest rates and austerity measures are bringing disaster to many emerging markets. He would keep interest rates down to encourage economic activity and let exchange rates find their own level. A growing economy is more likely to restore investor confidence, he says, than a recessionary one burdened by high interest rates.
"The Treasury and the I.M.F. have driven a large part of the developing world into recession," said Mr. Sachs, who directs Harvard's Institute for International Development. "And the Brazil case makes absolutely clear that the first step is not to defend overvalued currencies. The punishing cost of this is overwhelmingly high. This is a lesson that the I.M.F. and the Treasury have continued to ignore. I don't understand why."
For all the disagreement over how to repair the damaged East Asian and Latin economies, much of the debate centers not on the present, but on how to avoid financial crises in the future. And here the proposals increasingly involve a mixture of fixing the system and fixing the countries -- repairing the highway and making the drivers more cautious and skilled.
On the country side, several proposals have been made to set up a super central bank that would make huge amounts of money available to bail out a country in the event of a crisis. George Soros, the speculator and philanthropist, has offered one version, and another comes from Stanley Fischer, the I.M.F.'s first deputy managing director. But to qualify for such bailouts in the future, the countries would have to strengthen their banking and financial systems.
"You would shore up the international system by providing a more meaningful lender of last resort," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics.
Those who focus mostly on the system would require, among other things, that banks put aside extra money in a reserve fund if they lent into emerging countries heavily burdened with foreign debt. "Putting aside money in that fashion reduces the profitability of a loan, which in turn makes lenders more cautious," said Ricardo French-Davis, a Chilean economist who works in Santiago with the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America.
Mr. Krugman goes further in blaming the system and in arguing that the need to fix structural problems in individual countries should not stand in the way of broader macro-economic measures, particularly those designed to stimulate growth in hard times.
In the current issue of Foreign Affairs, he writes that over the last 25 years, much of the global economy has returned in many ways to a "pre-Depression free-market capitalism," with its virtues but also its vices -- the main vice being a vulnerability to spectacular crackups.
"It is hard to avoid concluding that sooner or later we will have to turn the clock at least part of the way back," he writes. "To limit capital flows for countries that are unsuitable for either currency unions or free floating; to reregulate financial markets to some extent, and to seek low, but not too low, inflation rather than price stability. We must heed the lessons of Depression economics, lest we be forced to relearn them the hard way."

More Weakness in Brazil
 SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 28 (Bloomberg News) -- The Brazilian currency fell for a seventh day today, as two failed bond auctions increased concern the Government may be unable to repay its ballooning debt.
The real fell 2.1 percent, closing at 1.9450 to the dollar. The currency has declined 37 percent since a devaluation on Jan. 13.
"Banks are reducing their holdings in Government debt as they are not so sure that the Government will be able pay them back," said Joaquim Kokudai, money market trader at Lloyds Bank in Sao Paulo.
Brazil failed twice today to auction Government bonds, rejecting yields of up to 35 percent demanded by investors concerned that the Government may be unable to repay its debts.
In the stock market, however, the currency's depressed value was viewed as a further reason to buy Brazilian shares. The Bovespa index rose 3.9 percent, its third consecutive gain.

HEADLINE: Nine West Plans To Cut More Jobs

 BODY:
Nine West Group will cut 144 jobs in its corporate offices, the latest attempt by the struggling maker of women's shoes to reduce costs and improve its profitability.
The layoffs announced yesterday come two months after Nine West said it would eliminate 700 jobs, close two factories and reduce the number of shoes it makes annually. 
 Including the latest cuts, the White Plains-based Nine West has eliminated about 6 percent of its work force of 13,000 since November.
The company will take a charge of $3.2 million in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 1998 to cover the costs.
It has been a difficult year for Nine West, which estimates it sells about 20 percent of all the women's shoes sold in the United States.
Women's footwear sales have been weak, leaving Nine West with excess inventory that it has had to sell at reduced prices. The company closed 20 stores in the second quarter and has become more aggressive in promoting its other products, including sunglasses and handbags.
Nine West was also named earlier this month in a price-fixing lawsuit, which accused the company and several large retail chains of keeping prices artificially high for years on 12 brands of women's shoes.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A generation shaped by digital media presents fresh marketing challenges, a study finds.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere

 BODY:
TO effectively reach the youngest generation of Americans, whose lives are being shaped by digital media, marketers must deliver smarter, more sophisticated messages and build brands with them rather than for them, a new study by Saatchi & Saatchi suggests.
Saatchi & Saatchi, a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., based its study on interviews by child psychologists with 84 people ages 6 to 20 across the United States. They were asked what they thought about digital media like personal computers, the Internet, CD-ROM's, video games and cellular phones and other communication devices, and how these media affected their lives. Cultural anthropologists also observed 10 families at home for 50 hours each. 
 According to the agency, the digital media serve several functions for the 80 million Americans born since 1977, the largest generation in the nation's history. The media serve as toys for these young people but also provide developmental challenges. Digital media also function as a virtual hearth at home, the study said. It found that "most families have their digital media set up in a public room of the house; consequently, a lot of digital activities are shared by the family, making these media a center of family life."
In addition, the study found that the new media could function as a "cool library" for the new generation, known as Generation Y. "Generation Y uses digital media as an extension of self socially, intellectually and emotionally," the study said. "By extending the self in these ways, the new media help young people find their identity." And it concluded that digital media act as "power tools" for Generation Y, giving them tremendous access to knowledge.
According to Saatchi, digital media have collectively made Generation Y members more positive and optimistic than Generation X, instilling in the former greater confidence in mastering their destiny. The agency thinks digital media also enhance Generation Y's intellectual and social sophistication by increasing its access to information.
Thus, the study found that Generation Y's values include "connexity," which Saatchi defines as the importance of staying connected to the outside world in order to grow; "coolness" of knowledge, and the importance of self-reliance. "It's the death of the nerd," said Myra Stark, senior vice president at Saatchi. "Knowledge is power for Generation Y, who know that people like Bill Gates rule the world."
The study also found that "kids are still kids and fun is still what matters most," said Anne Adriance, executive vice president at Saatchi. "Being a kid is still about fun, even if it's an edgier fun today."
To respond to this new sense of fun, Saatchi recommends that marketers "advertise up," by pitching Generation Y more adult messages. "If advertising sounds too young, they will tune out," Ms. Adriance said. One campaign that effectively delivers such a message to children and teen-agers, the Saatchi executives said, is the television campaign by Arnell Group Brand Consulting last fall for Tommy Jeans, a division of the Tommy Hilgifer Corporation. "The advertising speaks to kids in an adult fashion, and Usher, the rapper who appears in it, is a teen icon," said Johann Wachs, a Saatchi & Saatchi vice president.
Successful marketing to Generation Y will also challenge their intellectual abilities, the study said. Good examples of this, according to agency executives, include Home Depot Inc.'s "Homer's Workshop," a syndicated how-to television program for children, and its in-store children's workshops, as well as the public television program "Where in Time Is Carmen Sandiego?"
Not surprisingly, Saatchi also recommends that advertisers create campaigns that speak Generation Y's language, which is visually and verbally sophisticated. One example they cited was a 1998 television spot by Thomas & Perkins for the Denver Zoo. The ad featured a "gigapet," a portable computer some children treat like a digital pet, footage of live zoo animals, and the tag line "Denver Zoo, interactive by nature."
Finally, the agency urges marketers to build connexity brands. "These brands go well beyond a simple product, they facilitate who the child wants to be," Ms. Adriance said. "Nickelodeon's 'Big Help' volunteer program and 'Kids' Choice' awards envelop and empower children. These validate them and give them tools to be what they want to be. Nickelodeon doesn't speak down to them."
Besides stimulating what many consider positive social changes, Saatchi said digital media had also created a potential "digital divide," a division between families and schools that can provide high technology and those that cannot.
According to Mediamark Research Inc., in 1993, 18.6 percent of United States households had computers, while 24.3 percent of households with children younger than 18 had this equipment. In 1998, 35.3 percent of households had computers, including 46.4 percent of households with children younger than 18. However, as of last year, more than one-half of all households with children did not have a computer.
Although the Saatchi study raises the possibility of two-tier marketing to children -- one set of messages for children with access to computers and a second for those without -- agency executives declined to make any definitive conclusions about the need for this.
"We're in a wait-and-see mode," Ms. Adriance said. "Part of it depends on the economics of technology and what technology manufacturers can do to drive their prices down."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Asked About Internet Issues, The Fed Chairman Shrugs

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
He has made a habit of worrying in public that stock prices are getting out of hand, but when Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, was asked today about the highest-flying investments of all, Internet companies, his answer was tinged as much with fascination and even enthusiasm as with caution.
Mr. Greenspan hardly suggested that he had become a day trader, one of a new breed of investor who goes on line to trade technology stocks on rumor and whim. He left no doubt, though, that he sees more good than bad in a phenomenon that has driven the market value of America Online higher than that of General Motors and pushed the share price of a new company like Ebay from $18 to more than $300 in just four months. 
 The upward march of Internet stocks continued again today. Reaction to better-than-expected earnings from America Online, the dominant Internet access provider, and an announced acquisition by Yahoo, the largest World Wide Web search engine, of Geocities, the biggest provider of personal Web pages, pushed technology indexes and many company shares to new highs.
Asked during a Senate Budget Committee hearing this morning by Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, about the attention surrounding Internet stocks, Mr. Greenspan cited not irrational exuberance but the very real prospect of success for at least some companies.
"First of all, you wouldn't get hype working if there weren't something fundamentally sound under it," Mr. Greenspan said. "The issue really gets to the increasing evidence that a significant part of the distribution of goods and services in this country is going to move from conventional channels into some form of Internet system -- whether it's retail goods or services or a variety of other things."
The potential market is so big, he Greenspan said, that there are "pie in the sky" growth opportunities for many companies.
"And undoubtedly some of these small companies, which have stock prices going through the roof, will succeed and they very well may justify even higher prices," Mr. Greenspan said. "The vast majority are almost sure to fail. That's the way the markets work in this regard."
Lest he come across like an analyst promoting a hot sector, Mr. Greenspan quickly added that he viewed the entire Internet-stock phenomenon as another example of human willingness to bet on a long shot.
He compared buying Internet stocks to playing the lottery. For centuries, he said, people have been willing to pay more for a lottery ticket than their chances of winning would justify, simply because they are captivated by the possibility, however remote, of a big score.
"What that means is that when you are dealing with stocks -- the possibilities of which are it's going to be valued at zero or some huge number -- you get a premium in that stock price which is exactly the same sort of price-evaluation process that goes on in the lottery," Mr. Greenspan said.
There has always been a certain dissonance between Mr. Greenspan's libertarian faith in the market and his fretfulness about the ability of investors to gauge risk. And there has been a disconnect of late between Mr. Greenspan's concerns that Wall Street could be in for a downturn and the policy of interest-rate cuts he pursued last fall, probably the single biggest factor in the market's latest rise.
But today Mr. Greenspan sounded downright sanguine.
"Of course, there's some hype," he said, but the securities markets seemed to be doing a good job of funneling capital to promising ideas even if they had not yet proved profitable.
"That's good for our system," Mr. Greenspan said. "With all of this hype and craziness, that is something that at the end of the day probably is more plus than minus."

Durable Goods Orders Rise
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (Bloomberg News) -- Factory orders for big-ticket goods increased in December for the sixth time in seven months as demand for industrial hardware, electronics and electrical equipment accelerated, the Commerce Department said today.
Total orders for durable goods rose 1.9 percent, more than expected, to $192.68 billion last month. In November, orders rose a revised three-tenths of 1 percent, to $189.08 billion.
For 1998, orders rose 3.5 percent after increasing 7.1 percent during 1997, the Commerce Department said. That was the smallest annual gain since 1991, when the economy was emerging from recession.
In another report today, the Labor Department said wages and salaries in the fourth quarter grew at their slowest pace in two years. The employment cost index -- the broadest measure of wage, salary and benefit costs -- rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter, less than the third quarter's rise of 1 percent.
In addition, first-time jobless claims fell 15,000 in the week ended last Saturday to a seasonally adjusted 301,000, the lowest level in more than a month. The four-week moving average, a less volatile measure of claims, fell to 333,250, from 351,000 a week earlier.

HEADLINE: Inflated Stocks Cushion Pitfalls Of Net Mergers

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
A handful of leading companies will come to dominate cyberspace.
That snippet of rhetoric has become all the analytical underpinning there is to justify the unprecedented stock market values of the prominent Internet companies like Yahoo, America Online and Amazon.com.
On the face of it, that well could be true. On the other hand, the Internet may make it easier for new competitors to constantly challenge the leaders. 
 Yet one of the byproducts of the irrational exuberance in Internet stock prices is that the prophesied greatness of certain companies becomes self-fulfilling. Their huge market values allow them to grow by acquisitions.
Look at the $3.6 billion purchase announced yesterday by the investors' darling Internet site, Yahoo, of Geocities, the leading creator of electronic communities organized around people's hobbies, passions and peccadilloes.
Geocities is, in fact, an extreme example of the sort of tantalizing potential implicit in many Internet companies. It is the fifth- most-trafficked Web site, on which 3.5 million people have created home pages that were viewed 53 million times a day in December. Geocities has the right to put advertising on or next to all of those pages, but in all of 1998, its revenues totaled a meager $18.4 million. (Profits? Nah. It lost $19.8 million last year, double the loss of a year before.)
Those modest (to be generous) fundamentals did not stop investors from valuing Geocities at $2.2 billion on Wednesday, before the acquisition was announced. With that price tag, Geocities was essentially too expensive for any company, no matter how big, for which traditional rules of finance applied.
But Yahoo, which has a market value of $38 billion, an infinite multiple of its just more than break-even earnings, was easily able to exchange its shares for those of Geocities without breaking a sweat. Indeed, Yahoo's offer of stock worth $113.66 for each Geocities share, was a 52 percent premium over the company's share price Wednesday.
Nonetheless, because Yahoo's value is so high -- and the price it paid represents only about 10 percent of its shares -- Yahoo is telling investors that the deal will have no effect on its per-share earnings after it closes in the second quarter. Indeed Yahoo is promising that it can turn around Geocities and make it add to earnings next year.
As is usual with Internet stocks, investors leaped at any sign of motion. Yahoo's stock surged by $31.875, to $367.75. Normally, companies' stocks fall when they announce expensive acquisitions.
Thus the market is in many ways encouraging the big companies like Yahoo to buy up other Internet companies. The same economics has been behind the other Net deals recently, including the purchase of Excite by At Home and of Netscape by America Online. And many analysts expect Amazon to make some big acquisitions, as well.
But while the mystical multiplication of the stock market limits Yahoo's risk from buying Geocities, the potential rewards from turning the site's huge audience into profits will come much harder.
"Yahoo's plans to seek incremental revenue from Geocities are difficult to see," said Brian C. Oakes, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. "If I have a Web page that says I love the New York Jets, who will want to advertise there if they don't control the content?"
Yahoo does have a bigger advertising sales staff than Geocities does and has technical resources that can cut that company's costs.
Moreover, Jeff Mallett, Yahoo's president, says the company sees two areas beyond advertising on the home pages for growth at Geocities. First, it hopes that people who publish home pages will include links to related stores on their pages. For example, a page on cooking would have a link to a kitchen supply site, which in turn would pay a commission on any sales that would be split by Yahoo and the creator of the site.
In addition, Yahoo sees Geocities as a great source of information about the interests of both the creators of the home pages and the people who look at them. It hopes to use this information to expand the profiles it is creating about people's interests -- profiles it uses to send people electronic mail with advertising customized to their particular interests.
Yet whether or not Geocities ever produces much in incremental profits for Yahoo, the acquisition may well pay for itself simply by bolstering Yahoo's perceived "leadership" in the market. Most important, Geocities will substantially strengthen Yahoo's position in the highly watched Media Metrix rating of how many people visit a Web site at least once in a month, a measure they call reach.
Yahoo's sites now rank third, reaching 48.2 percent of the Internet audience. All of America Online's properties combined reach 54.5 percent of the audience, while Microsoft's sites reach 48.4 percent. Geocities, by itself, reaches 33.4 percent of Web users.
Though Yahoo's reach has mostly been flat, Lycos, another Internet service known as a portal because it is a gateway to other on-line services, has been climbing the rating charts. The main reason is that it has been buying up other sites including many of the community sites that compete with Geocities. All of the Lycos sites in December had a reach of 46.5 percent of the audience.
Even amid constant speculation that Lycos will soon be acquired, it is worth $5.3 billion, a huge number but a small fraction of the value of Yahoo. Many Lycos investors, as well as its management, were hoping that if it were able to surge past Yahoo, it might well gain some of the market value accorded to leaders.
"You can never have too much cash or too much reach," said Chris A. Kitze, the chairman of Xoom.com, a community site that competes with Geocities.
No such luck, Lycos.
With Geocities, Yahoo says its reach will increase to 58 percent of the Web audience, an undisputed top position, for now. And that will allow the magic multiplication of Internet stock values to keep working and let the company make even more acquisitions, just maybe allowing it to fulfill the prophecies of its cyber-dominance.

Yesterday, Yahoo agreed to buy Geocities for $3.6 billion. Last week, At Home agreed to pay $6.7 billion for Excite. And late last year, America Online agreed to pay $4.2 billion for Netscape.
