HEADLINE: A New State for Inuit: Frigid but Optimistic

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: IQALUIT, Northwest Territories, Jan. 22

 BODY:
The day the map of Canada is redrawn and native people in the frigid north start to govern themselves is still more than two months off. But this frontier city, which will become North America's newest capital on April 1, is already undergoing a strange Arctic boom.
The new territory has a name, Nunavut. But streets do not, which means that houses do not have addresses, just haphazardly assigned numbers like items in a catalogue. 
 Yet Iqaluit (ee-KA-loo-eet) has its third bank, which will start taking cash deposits as soon as the ice clears and a cargo ship can deliver a safe. And by the end of the month it will be the northernmost community in Canada to have cellular telephone service.
Many of the 4,200 residents still have to flick on a red light at the side of their houses to signal the water-delivery man that their tanks need refilling. But there are now two tanning salons in this new capital, which used to be called Frobisher Bay, and a Chinese restaurant, a local Internet service provider and a Kentucky Fried Chicken outpost.
All over town construction crews are working 10-hour days where the wind-chill sometimes sinks to minus 94 Fahrenheit to finish commercial buildings, dozens of apartments and the new Nunavut legislative building by April 1.
"I try not to get too involved emotionally over what's happening," said Tagak Curley, president of the Nunavut Construction Corporation, an Inuit enterprise that is building the igloo-shape legislative chambers for the Nunavut government. "Otherwise we might lose our focus, eh?"
Mr. Curley, 55, an old Inuit warrior in the battle for native rights, said he felt a great sense of accomplishment now that the vision of an Inuit homeland is taking shape.
"We used to be nervous wrecks, many years ago, worrying about what was going to happen to us," he said. "Now I'm not worried about tomorrow."
What is happening to the people of Nunavut is the latest and biggest example of a trend across the hemisphere. Native groups are demanding self-determination and achieving it.
Indian tribes in the United States have largely won the power to run their reservations. Eskimos in Alaska govern municipalities where they form majorities.
Last year the Nisga'a Indians of northern British Columbia signed a treaty with the Canadian Government that gave them the right to govern themselves in an area more than half the size of Rhode Island.
Nunavut dwarfs them all. But despite optimism as boundless as the sea ice, the capital is uneasy. The extra money of boom times has brought extra problems. Teen-agers' sniffing gasoline for a high last month set fire to and destroyed seven new town houses that were being built for employees of the new government.
The growing mound of trash in the town dump has attracted a huge flock of ravens, whose mad heckling pierces the howling wind. And Inuit lured from the countryside by the possibility of jobs stand in ever longer lines for the night's allotment of vouchers to buy beer and a drink called the paralyzer at the Tulugaq Bar here, one of the few places in Nunavut that serve alcohol.
"We have been anticipating the negative effects of the economic boom," Mayor Jimmy Kilabuk said through an interpreter. "And now they're here."
Nothing but the core functions of the new government -- legislators, courts and tax collectors -- will be up and running by April 1. Other services have been temporarily contracted from the old Northwest Territories government because it has proved impossible to hire enough Inuit with the training to fill new management positions.
About 200 workers have been hired to work for the executive branch. But the goal of having Inuit fill 85 percent of the hundreds of jobs has been reduced, for the time being, to 50 percent.
And no one has yet come up with anything but a vague promissory response to the most nagging question about the future of Nunavut: Will the new territory always be a financial drain on the well-meaning but sometimes resentful rest of Canada?
"Of course there is a danger that Nunavut will end up as a perpetual welfare state," said Graham White, a professor of political science at the University of Toronto who specializes in northern politics. "But it would have been worse to leave things as they were."
The challenges for Nunavut loom like icebergs in these final frantic months before the new territory is created from the eastern 60 percent of what today is the Northwest Territories.
The two current territories in Canada -- the other is Yukon -- have their own governments. But because of their small populations, they rely more on the Federal Government than do the 10 provinces.
Nunavut will be enormous, 770,000 square miles of snow and ice roughly the size of western Europe, without more than a few scrub trees and a few miles of paved roads. Caribou outnumber the 25,000 residents more than 25 to 1.
There are 28 communities within the boundaries of what will become Nunavut on April 1, and most are no bigger than a few hundred hardy souls.
Then there are what the Inuit call the "high statistics." Nunavut will rank among the leaders in unemployment, births, teen-age suicides, spousal abuse and sniffing gasoline and solvents. All are troubles that existed before the Nunavut government was created. All will be dumped in the new government's lap.
And yet Nunavut remains a bold experiment. Its first official step was early this decade, as part of the largest land-claim settlement in Canadian history. Like other native groups, the Inuit sought control of their traditional hunting and camping grounds, as well as demanding compensation for land that the Federal Government had long ago confiscated.
A result was a complicated settlement in which Inuit ownership was recognized over 137,000 square miles, including 14,000 square miles where Inuit also owned subsurface mineral rights. The rest of the land in Nunavut will be federally owned. There was also a settlement of $1 billion to be paid out over 14 years.
Part of the land-claim settlement called for splitting the Northwest Territories in two. The eastern part, Nunavut, would be governed by the Inuit simply because Inuit make up 85 percent of the population.
"This will be a public government with popular elections," said Simon Awa, executive director of the Nunavut Implementation Commission, which studied and then recommended the form of the new government. "We are respecting the Canadian Constitution and Parliamentary system and marrying them with the Inuit traditional knowledge and way of dealing with things."
A result is a government unlike any other in North America. Even though they chose not to restrict the right to vote or run for office to native people, the Inuit of Nunavut will be the first indigenous people in the Americas to govern themselves so completely. It will be something akin to Utah, where the Mormon people, by their numbers and not by law, tend to run things.
There will not be one official language in Nunavut, but three -- English, French and Inuktituk. Many Nunavut planning documents are printed in all three.
Nonpartisan elections for the assembly on Feb. 15 will determine the first 19 members of the legislature, and those lawmakers will select the first premier.
Under a proposal that was narrowly defeated in a referendum, each legislative district will have had two representatives, one man and one woman.
"It was something never tried anywhere in the world," Mr. Awa said. "It may have been too radical an idea to start with. But we may come back to it in two or three elections."
Although the legislature will meet in Iqaluit and the Premier's office will be located here, many of the remaining 10 departments will be spread out over 10 far-flung communities. By decentralizing the government, the Inuit hope to distribute the obvious economic benefits more widely.
Nunavut will have Canada's first Department of Sustainable Development, and a Department of Culture, Language, Elders and Youth. Managers throughout the government will be instructed to take a more flexible approach to time and will be expected to allow workers time off to pursue traditional activities like seal hunts, which do not always fit into a five-day workweek.
Inuit leaders like Mr. Curley know that many people are ready to declare the folly of Nunavut. "There are a lot of doubters, I know that," he said.
Although he acknowledges that some criticism might be fair, he points out that Nunavut has not enjoyed the advantages that Canada provided to develop other regions.
"They didn't build us a railroad," he said, referring to the supportin the 19th century that built a transcontinental railroad that opened the West. "Economic development in this part of the world is an ongoing challenge."
For now the birth of the government is providing jobs and economic opportunities, especially in Iqaluit. Officials hope that the boom is bigger and longer lasting than earlier ones.
The first flurry of activity was in World War II, when the United States Army, with permission from the Canadian Government, built an airstrip here.
Canadian officials once seriously considered building a dome over the settlement. But when the Northwest Territories were established as a separate government almost 30 years ago, the government constructed a hideous complex on the hill that combines housing, offices, a hotel and even a pool so the government workers would not have to brave the cold.
Although he worries that some poorly qualified people have been put in management positions just because they are Inuit, Kenn Harper, a local entrepreneur who settled here and was for several years involved in the plans to establish Nunavut, remains optimistic. He is building dozens of apartments and plans to build even more next year.
"People are calling me all the time asking about housing," Mr. Harper said. "There will probably be 7,000 people in Iqaluit in a few years."
For Canadians from provinces stuck in economic downturns, Nunavut is a beckoning opportunity, a frozen rainbow. "There's tons of work here," said Terry Charter, a contractor from Nanaimo, British Columbia, who is working on one of the many residential construction sites here. "The creation of Nunavut is great for the people of Nunavut, and it's great for us, too, because it puts us to work."
Mayor Kilabuk, who was born in a native camp 60 miles from Iqaluit, said that as an Inuk, the term for an individual Inuit, he was proud that Nunavut would soon be a reality.
Though he is confident about the town's future, he remembers a story that the elders of his community, now long gone, had told him as a child.
"What I can tell you," he recounted, "is that they said Iqaluit will become a big center and have a lot of problems and a lot of challenges that would come from outside. I don't know how they were able to predict that so accurately, but they did."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Ford-VolvoTie: Europe Rivals at Risk

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS with JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company's victorious bid for Volvo A.B.'s car business increases the pressure on other European automobile companies to either buy or be bought, industry executives and analysts say.
Those with the most precarious futures are middle-sized companies like Renault S.A. and PSA Peugeot Citroen of France and, as it clearly recognized by trying to buy Volvo itself, Fiat S.p.A. of Italy. Each of those companies lacks the size to compete with the giants like DaimlerChrysler A.G. or the General Motors Corporation. On top of that, they remain bogged down in brutally competitive markets for midsized and small cars. 
 Today's agreement was a particularly big defeat for Fiat, which had openly courted Volvo and was reported to have offered about $7 billion for the entire company. Besides the car business, Fiat executives were also entranced by the idea of combining the two companies' truck and construction equipment businesses.
"Needless to say, the bid failed," said a discouraged Fiat executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Volvo decided to sell exclusively its car-making activity and to hold on to the other businesses, which were, I might add, of greater interest to us."
But analysts said it also marked a setback for Renault and Peugeot, which remain heavily dependent on the French market and on lower-priced and less profitable mass-market vehicles.
"Ford has taken a very appealing brand out of the market, and that is bad news for almost everybody else," said Chiara Tirloni, an automobile analyst at Paribas Capital Markets in London.
Ever since Daimler-Benz and the Chrysler Corporation announced their $36 billion merger last year, European car manufacturers have been engaged in a frenzy of mixing and matchmaking.
"In the European and in the global automobile market, it's not just fusion but also confusion that you're seeing," said Bernd Gottschalk, the president of the German Automobile Industry Association.
Though Volvo is a small player, producing fewer than 400,000 cars a year, it has important strengths, the most important being its strong appeal to affluent consumers who are willing to pay comparatively higher prices for family cars. In addition, Volvo has a well-established distribution network in the United States.
Europe's automobile industry is divided into several different camps that face somewhat different pressures. DaimlerChrysler is essentially in a league of its own, a goliath with a huge mass-market presence in North America and an equally strong base in high-priced luxury cars in Europe.
BMW A.G. and Porsche A.G., meanwhile, have continued to be successful as smaller producers of more expensive sedans and sports cars. BMW has been the subject of repeated takeover rumors, but the company has adamantly denied any interest in selling.
But most of Europe's other producers are struggling to bridge the gulf between mass and class. Thanks to global overcapacity and a reluctance by European consumers to spend money, competition has been brutal for the last several years among producers of midsized or small cars.
Volkswagen A.G., which has cut costs and streamlined its production, has been one of the biggest sources of pressure for companies ranging from Fiat and Renault to G.M.'s Opel subsidiary.
After a painful reorganization in the early 1990's, Volkswagen's sales and profits have surged in the last year. But even though its Audi subsidiary has been successful as a producer of upscale sedans, a few of which compete with DaimlerChrysler's Mercedes, the company is still searching for ways to move beyond mass-market sedans.
Unlike most of its European peers, Volkswagen is already big enough to compete in today's environment. It produces more than four million cars a year and has about $11 billion in cash to make additional acquisitions.
The situation is considerably grimmer for French and Italian car companies. Though Fiat has a significant international presence, it has far less cash than Volkswagen or Ford and has been under increasing competitive pressure.
Fiat's profits were depressed last year by the end of Government-sponsored rebates in Italy, and weakening in two big overseas markets, Poland and Brazil.
And after announcing its intention to invest $400 million in Russia, the company had to put plans on hold when that nation's economy collapsed last summer.
Fiat had at least a half-dozen meetings with Volvo officials, most of them near Fiat's headquarters in Turin.
But Fiat executives said their real target was Volvo's truck-making unit, which produces heavy trucks that might have complemented Fiat's line of smaller trucks.
Volvo surprised many of its suitors two weeks ago when it bought a 12.8 percent stake in a rival Swedish truck maker, Scania A.B., and said it wanted the two companies to merge their truck operations. But the relationship is still in doubt because it has provoked strenuous objections from Scania's majority shareholder, the investment firm Investor A.B.
Renault of France had a strong year in 1998, thanks to the success of its new Scenic minivan in Europe. But it still produces fewer than two million cars a year, and Peugeot Citroen is only slightly bigger.
Analysts say both companies are in a poor position to keep up with the accelerated pace of developing new models at low prices. The heightened competition means that all companies are under pressure to spread research and development costs over a much wider array of cars.
While companies like BMW and Porsche can avoid the problem to some extent because they charge premium prices, mass-market producers like Renault and Peugeot have no such maneuvering room. And the pressure is intensifying: Toyota is building a $700 million factory in France to make its small Yaris car for the European market.
But the French companies face political in addition to financial challenges. The French Government has traditionally blocked attempts by foreign companies to acquire major French corporations in almost any industry. The Government owns more than 40 percent of Renault and is not likely to relinquish control any time soon.
To be sure, Renault has made its own overtures abroad.
It has held talks about acquiring a minority stake in the Nissan Motor Company of Japan, which is in dire financial straits and needs a new partner. But DaimlerChrysler is also in formal talks with Nissan.
Georg Sturzer, an automobile analyst at Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank in Munich, said that the easiest solution for the French companies would be to merge them.
"But I am not at all sure that would be sensible, in part because they are both in the same market and wouldn't gain that many advantages," he said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Ford Buys Volvo Car Unit in Bid To Lift Profile of Luxury Models

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company, by agreeing yesterday to buy the car operations of Volvo A.B. of Sweden for $6.45 billion, has taken its biggest step yet toward becoming a large-scale seller of high-profit luxury cars as well as more humble vehicles like the Escort and pickup trucks.
Ford has already bought Jaguar and Aston Martin in recent years, but the acquisition of Volvo, a favorite of affluent urban families in the Northeastern United States and northern Europe, represents a far greater bet on the luxury market. Sales of luxury cars are rising in the United States and Europe while auto makers' profits on less expensive cars have evaporated as low-cost manufacturers in places like South Korea flood markets in the United States and elsewhere with ever- cheaper cars. 
 Jacques A. Nasser, Ford's chief executive, said that the auto maker sold 200,000 luxury cars last year but wanted to sell a million annually within several years. Volvo sold 399,700 cars worldwide last year while Ford sold 6.6 million cars, sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks, plus a small number of heavy trucks.
Mr. Nasser and William C. Ford Jr., Ford's chairman, said that they liked Volvo's current lineup of cars and were not planning immediate changes. Both men also said that they admired Volvo's tradition of paying attention to safety and environmental issues.
"It was very important because it fits very nicely with the social values at Ford," Mr. Ford said.
Ford has increasingly emphasized the same issues as Volvo in recent months, making its sport utility vehicles pollute as little as cars and announcing plans to offer side air bags on all cars. The shift has come as Mr. Ford has reasserted family control over the auto maker in recent months and begun imposing the Ford family's longtime tradition of public service, best shown by the creation of the Ford Foundation.
Ford's purchase of Volvo, while costlier than many auto analysts had predicted, was well received on Wall Street yesterday. Shares of Ford rose $2.1875, to $62.50, while Volvo's American depository receipts fell 81.25 cents, to $26.5625.
While Volvo's popularity among affluent baby boomers may be useful to Ford now, some auto industry experts questioned whether Ford's long-term strategy truly required Volvo.
Susan Jacobs, a consultant in Rutherford, N.J., noted that Lincoln recently introduced its LS cars to appeal to the same market -- sporty vehicles costing $30,000 to $45,000 -- while Jaguar will soon start selling its new S-type cars in the market.
"Lincoln and Jaguar are both evolving toward the market of Volvo," she said.
Mr. Nasser said that Volvo's car business was attractive because it filled gaps in Ford's current lineup. Volvo has a much higher proportion of women buyers than Ford has for its existing luxury brands, Lincoln and Jaguar. Volvo sells 60 percent of its cars in Europe, while Ford sells only 24 percent of its cars there. And Ford has an extensive distribution network that can be used to sell Volvo cars more widely, Mr. Nasser said.
Mr. Ford said that the auto maker also thought it could learn from Volvo's techniques for assembling the main structural parts of cars and for achieving high customer loyalty and customer satisfaction ratings.
Leif Johansson, Volvo's president, said that his company would use the 50 billion Swedish kronor from the sale of its car division to strengthen its huge and more profitable commercial truck and bus division. Volvo took a 12.8 percent stake earlier this month in Scania A.B., its Swedish archrival in the commercial truck industry, and has expressed an interest in taking control of it.
Volvo shareholders will not vote on whether to approve yesterday's agreement until March, which leaves time for other auto makers interested in the company, notably the General Motors Corporation, to decide whether to make hostile bids topping Ford's friendly agreement.
International auto mergers have a history of producing ruinous culture clashes. So Ford executives took great pains yesterday to try to reassure Swedish workers and managers that the change in corporate control would not mean an immediate imposition of American managers and production techniques.
"We've been in Sweden since 1924 -- they know us and they know how we operate," Mr. Ford said. "I don't think we've ever been viewed as a parochial company."
Volvo tried to merge with France's Renault in 1993, but the deal collapsed when midlevel Volvo managers complained publicly that their French counterparts were too bossy. After Renault took control of the American Motors Corporation in the early 1980's through a series of stock purchases, cultural differences produced managerial chaos, and American Motors was eventually sold to the Chrysler Corporation.
When Daimler-Benz A.G. acquired Chrysler last autumn, it tried to avoid cultural differences by leaving virtually all of Chrysler's senior management in place, although Germans still outnumber Americans by 9 to 2 in the top tier of management at the new DaimlerChrysler.
Ford has been unusually successful at international mergers, having bought Jaguar a decade ago and made it profitable while fixing the chronic quality problems that long tarnished Jaguar's reputation. Probably not by coincidence, Ford has also been more aggressive in promoting foreign-born executives to top jobs: Mr. Nasser was born in rural Lebanon and grew up in Australia, while his predecessor, Alexander Trotman, was British.
By contrast, all of the top 16 executives at General Motors, the world's largest company, are American men. G.M. owns half of Volvo's main rival, Saab A.B., and has an agreement to buy the other half, but Saab is still struggling, and its brand image remains murky despite G.M.'s efforts to clarify it.
Ford's success at Jaguar and its international staff were the main reasons why Volvo chose Ford's bid over a slightly higher offer from Fiat S.p.A. of Italy, people close to the negotiations said.
Fiat said yesterday that in any case, it had only been interested in buying all of Volvo, including its big business in heavy trucks and buses.
Mr. Nasser said at a news conference yesterday in Volvo's hometown of Goteborg, Sweden, that Ford would use its experience with Jaguar as a model for its management of Volvo's car operations.
Ford has begun replacing inconspicuous Jaguar parts like suspensions and electrical systems, which it can buy at much lower prices because of the economies of scale available to it as the world's second-largest auto maker.
Ford has also started encouraging dealers to own both Ford and Jaguar dealerships, although seldom selling both kinds of vehicles side by side so as to avoid blurring distinctions between the vehicles.
But even 10 years after Ford's purchase of Jaguar, the biggest savings are still several years away. Ford plans to build the next Ford Thunderbird and Jaguar S-type car on the same underbody it already uses for the Lincoln LS cars.
Unlike Jaguar, Volvo is profitable and has a fairly wide selection of modern car designs. As a result, Ford will only move gradually toward using common parts and building Ford and Volvo cars on virtually identical underbodies.
Ford will pay the $6.45 billion price tag entirely in cash, which will be easy for a company with $23.8 billion in cash reserves.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Define Deviancy Up

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
On just one condition, journalists and lesser Americans have every right to deride the way the Senate is conducting the trial of President Clinton. If they don't, they should.
The senators wear their nonpartisan clothes, walk, talk and probably sleep in them. But when it comes to voting and maneuvering they strip right down to their partisan buff.
The senators cannot stand the strain of their trial regulation forbidding all of them to speechify inside the chamber. So they run outside during the day to line up for TV time; right away they feel better.
The senators are supposed to use any ponder power they possess and however long it takes to come to a decision on whether the President should stay or go. But most act as if their real job is to rid themselves of the whole thing right away and return to more important matters, unspecified. They keep waving their hands, hoping the teacher, or anybody, will let out school.
And they pass up the critical witness on influencing a witness, the President's secretary. She is a nice woman, and understandably nervous. Do you expect them to take the chance of her breaking into tears?
All Democrats and many Republicans decided long in advance of the trial that although they thought Mr. Clinton terribly naughty, his lying and obstructing justice are not grounds serious enough to be convicted.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, one of my very favorite politicians, goes along with them. In 1993 he warned America against "defining deviancy down" -- acceptance of actions we once regarded as acutely offensive, immoral or illegal.
Derision time right enough -- on that one condition: Remember who got us here, who forced the trial, who put the country brain-deep in his own muck. Forgetting that is like forgetting that Judge Ito did not kill O. J. Simpson's former wife.
Bill Clinton gambled the moral, political and historic reputation of the Presidency -- showing what he thought of the office and himself.
He lied. He lied in private and in public, with or without oath. He lied to friends, enemies, subordinates. He proved what the Democratic Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska once said about him -- "Clinton is an unusually good liar, unusually good."
If perjury aggravated by repetition is not enough, examine damage to government. He captured and tied up the entire White House in his lies. He lied directly to some of his government employees, used others as shields, and kept some theoretically ignorant so they could say sorry, we cannot inform the public.
Impeachment is a political and moral matter, as well as legal. Nobody I know except senators even pretends "nonpartisanship" about the trial results.
I voted for him twice -- first with great hope, the second time because near Election Day I thought he might be better equipped than Bob Dole. I was wrong, trapped in the remnants of old hopes about Bill Clinton.
A guilty verdict would repair the Presidency and country. The voters would for at least two years retain the political and economic continuity so many want. The man Mr. Clinton picked would be in the White House.
Republican leaders, in terror of the public, say there is no chance of a two-thirds majority for a guilty verdict, so let's quit trying and get out of here. That is nullification of law by jury, openly and during the trial.
Censure: The Constitution makes no place for any decision on impeachment but guilty or not guilty.
But, atoning for my second Clinton vote by laying down my status as a constitutional expert, temporarily, I sacrifice opposition to censure if the move to convict fails.
Censure must be plain and tough enough to leave a reminding bite mark through history. In The Washington Times of Jan. 15, Jim Guirard Jr., a Washington attorney, proposes one such. The motion of censure, passable by simple majority, would consist of the impeachment articles already approved by the House of Representatives but deleting reference to trial or verdict.
The President would not have to agree or sign -- a demand that would guarantee insipidity. But both Houses would support and preserve the validity of the perjury and obstruction of justice charges.
There would be no punishment but history's. And deviancy would be defined upward.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Greenspan Tells Congress Not to Rely on Surpluses
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told the Senate Budget Committee not to count on Government budget surpluses to solve Social Security's problems. Instead, he suggested that benefits may have to be cut or taxes raised to insure the retirement system's future.
Last week, President Clinton proposed shoring up the system with $2.7 trillion of the $4.4 trillion in surpluses anticipated over the next 15 years. But Mr. Greenspan pointed out that budget forecasts have been notoriously unreliable in the past and are likely to remain so in the future. Page A1. 

Some of the high-flying Internet stocks are fundamentally sound and will succeed, Mr. Greenspan said in response to a question from Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon. Others, however, will fail, he said. He attributed the entire Internet-stock phenomenon to human willingness to bet on a long shot. C6.
 
Nasdaq Index at Another High
The Nasdaq composite index gained nearly 3 percent to close at another record. The index finished up 70.2 points at 2,477.34, spurred by a 2-for-1 stock split of Intel. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 81.1 points, or nearly nine-tenths of a percent, to 9,281.33. The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index increased 22.2 points, or 1.79 percent, to 1,265.37. C6.
 
Niagara Mohawk May Sell Plant
Niagara Mohawk Power is in talks to sell its holdings in the Nine Mile Point nuclear plant to Amergen Energy, which last year bought the only functioning unit at Three Mile Island, site of the nation's worst nuclear accident. C2.
 
Microsoft Must Provide Document
The Federal judge in the Microsoft antitrust case has ordered the company to give the Justice Department an internal document that Government lawyers said could undermine one of the software giant's defenses. C2.
 
Study Finds Not Enough Oversight
William J. McDonough, the president of the New York Federal Reserve, headed a study that concluded a handful of the world's largest commercial and investment banks failed to adequately oversee lending and trading activities with the hedge-fund giant Long-Term Capital Management. He said that the banks had been blinded by what he called the "magic" of the once high-flying firm's vaunted reputation, a situation he suggested could recur if banks did not tighten their monitoring of such funds. C3.
 
TRW Set to Acquire Lucas Varity
TRW, the maker of automobile air bags, agreed to buy Lucas Varity for $6.6 billion, outbidding Federal-Mogul with the largest offer ever for an auto-parts company. C4.
 
Privacy Advocates Want Chip Recall
Privacy advocates who object to Intel's plan to put identification numbers in its next generation of computer chips have asked the Federal Trade Commission to recall all Pentium III chips. C3.
 
Funds Continue to Flow Into Stocks
Mutual fund investors put just $3.4 billion into stock funds in December even as the market continued a steady climb back from its late-summer selloff. But industry officials say that January, historically a strong time for mutual fund sales, is shaping up much better than the previous month. C7.
 
Genamerica to Be Owned by Public
Genamerica, one of the first mutual life insurance companies to sell shares to the public under a controversial hybrid structure two years ago, expects to become a company owned completely by stockholders. C5.

SECTION: Section D; Page 4; Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1503 words

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Scandal Touches African Athletes

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN

DATELINE: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In the West African nation of Senegal, there is one all-weather running track, one indoor basketball court and one Olympic-sized pool, filled with seawater and located not at a training center, but at a hotel.
"We have to arrange for the training of our athletes," said Lamine Diack, the president of the Senegal Olympic Committee. "Now, we are building our first swimming stadium. Our problem is one of having not enough facilities, equipment and coaches. Our dream is to have the same sports system in our schools that the United States has. Then we will raise a lot of champions. But without facilities and coaches, it is impossible." 
The International Olympic Committee, under its president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, has made the Games a truly global event. Athletes from 197 nations took part in the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, a wholesale reversal from the boycott-tainted 1970's and 1980's.
But the far-reaching Olympic corruption scandal could threaten the long-term participation of athletes from developing nations, particularly from Africa, which already struggles to support sport while contending with more urgent problems of poverty, disease and war. In these developing nations, a decent pair of training shoes can be a luxury. Some of the teams arrive at the Olympics without so much as uniforms.
Seven Olympic committee members from Africa -- more than a third of the continent's representation on the world's most influential sports body -- have been dismissed, resigned or remain under investigation in the Salt Lake City bribery scandal. An eighth member linked to the scandal died last year. One of those ousted by Samaranch, Jean-Claude Ganga of Congo Republic, was perhaps the most influential of Africa's I.O.C. members, serving as president of the continent's association of national Olympic committees. Replacements for the ousted members will not necessarily come from Africa.
Potentially more devastating than a decimated leadership is the threat to aid programs operated by the I.O.C. that provide training scholarships, coaching clinics and equipment and are funded by corporate sponsorships and television fees. If corporate sponsors begin pulling out of the Olympic movement, and television rights are devalued, the financial drought will begin to dry up aid to developing nations that need it most, Olympic officials said.
"The real losers will be millions of kids and athletes who won't be funded," said David D'Alessandro, president of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance, one of a dozen worldwide corporate sponsors of the Olympic movement. "This scandal, if not handled right, could force governments all over the world to have to take over the funding of these programs, and the quality of athletic programs could be set back 30 years."
The international committee operates a little-known but much appreciated program called Olympic Solidarity, which is budgeted to spend $122 million from 1997 through the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia. The money, generated by television rights fees, is earmarked for the 198 national Olympic committees worldwide and contains 12 programs designed to train and develop athletes, coaches and administrators. The program has proved especially vital in developing nations.
In Africa, for instance, Olympic Solidarity is funding sprinters at a training center in Senegal, and distance runners at a center in Kenya, while negotiating to train athletes in judo and wrestling in Ivory Coast and boxers in Tunisia. Among other things, Olympic Solidarity pays at least $40,000 a year to each national Olympic committee, and pays travel and accommodation costs for up to six athletes and two officials from every country to attend the Games.
Funds from Olympic Solidarity will be bolstered by another $110 million in corporate sponsorship money distributed by the I.O.C. to international sports federations from 1997 through 2000. Beyond that, the financial pipeline is dependent on continued belief by corporations and television networks in the ideal that the Olympics can contribute to world peace through sport. This notion faces tremendous skepticism at the moment.
"If corporate sponsors pull back, you should see far fewer athletes from underdeveloped nations in Athens in 2004," said John Lucas, an Olympic historian and retired professor at Penn State University.
A decline in Olympic participation by athletes from developing nations, particularly in Africa, would seriously erode one of the pillar achievements of Samaranch's presidency. He took over in 1980, four years after African nations boycotted the 1976 Montreal Games, rebuilt the continent's commitment to the Olympics and has been commended by President Nelson Mandela for his role in edging apartheid toward final collapse by readmitting South Africa into the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain, after an absence of three decades.
Because NBC has agreed to pay $3.5 billion for the five Winter and Summer Games to be held between 2000 and 2008, Olympic officials said they are confident that Olympic Solidarity will continue to grow. Michael Payne, the committee's marketing director, said the funding for Solidarity is expected to rise to $200 million for the quadrennium between 2001 and 2004.
But while he has attempted to create a global appeal for the Games, Samaranch was also the one who appointed all eight committee members from Africa who have been connected to accepting cash gifts, medical treatment, tuition aid and lavish gifts from Salt Lake City Olympic officials. Other African officials have joined in the call for a housecleaning of the international committee, although no one has called for Samaranch to step down.
For some, there remains the outside chance that the scandal and the expulsions of African members might ultimately prove beneficial. The Salt Lake City revelations could spur the I.O.C. to offer more training programs to developing nations, said Sam Ramsamy, an I.O.C. member and president of the South African Olympic Committee.
"If more programs were in place, maybe these inducements wouldn't be necessary," he said.
Despite an insatiable need for more financing and training programs, African athletes distinguished themselves at the 1996 Atlanta Games, winning both the men's and women's marathons, the men's 1,500-, 5,000- and 10,000-meter runs, the 3,000-meter steeplechase, two women's swimming events and the men's soccer competition.
Elite athletes earn extravagant salaries and endorsement deals, but they do it largely by leaving the continent. Soccer players go to Europe. Distance runners, courted by agents and shoe companies like Fila, Puma and Nike, have dispersed, at least part of each year, to racing circuits and training camps in England, the Netherlands, Italy, the United States and Japan.
"I think it's better to get rid of these officials," said Jos Hermens of the Netherlands, the manager of Ethiopia's Haile Gebrselassie, the world's top distance runner, who won a gold medal in the 10,000 meters in Atlanta. "Corruption is a big problem. Money always goes to the wrong people, ends up in private bank accounts. It can't get any worse."
But the neediest countries are the most vulnerable to financial inducements, said Keba Mbaye, an international committee member from Senegal, who was on the six-member commission that investigated the Salt Lake City bid committee. It is not clear whether the removal of a number of members will automatically improve the situation.
For instance, Charles Mukora, dismissed last Sunday as an I.O.C. member from Kenya for allegedly receiving payments of $34,650 for his personal benefit, remains the head of his country's national Olympic committee.
Federico Rosa, a sports manager from Italy, whose family represents such Kenyan athletes as Moses Tanui, a two-time winner of the Boston Marathon, said he believed that Mukora had done a commendable job in welcoming sports agents and shoe companies into the East African nation.
"He understood that the more companies were there to get athletes, the more money there would be for everybody," Rosa said. "It is not possible to know that if he loses power it will be better."
In Senegal, Diack said he appreciated the $50,000 or so per year his Olympic committee receives from Olympic Solidarity, but that he could use four times as much. Senegal has taken a common approach of cobbling funds from a variety of sources. The Senegalese Government pays for travel expenses, he said. China built the national track stadium in Dakar, the capital. The French Government and the world governing body of track and field, of which Diack is a senior vice president, constructed a national training center for sprinters and jumpers.
"The money from the I.O.C. must go to the countries to develop sport, not to cities organizing the Olympics," Diack said. "My Olympic committee gets $40,000 or $50,000, and Athens is guaranteed $1 billion to organize the 2004 Summer Games. Something is wrong."

HEADLINE: Global Computer Industry Grew 15% in '98

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 28

 BODY:
The worldwide personal computer industry grew 15 percent last year, led by strong demand in the United States, where 37 percent of all households are now connected to the Internet, according to preliminary statistics being released Friday by Dataquest Inc.
"Affordability and growing relevance of Internet content is sustaining double-digit PC growth in the U.S.," said Bill Schaub, vice president for Dataquest's personal computing and peripherals group. 
 Worldwide, the Compaq Computer Corporation remains the No. 1 seller of personal computers, shipping 12.8 million computers in 1998 to gain 14 percent of the market. I.B.M. kept the No. 2 position with 8.2 percent of the market, but the Dell Computer Corporation decreased the gap, growing 65 percent in 1998 to account for 7.9 percent of all personal computers shipped.
"Dell now has posted 13 consecutive quarters of 50 percent-plus growth, leveraging its business model to insure that they are the price leader in the professional market," Mr. Schaub said.
The Hewlett-Packard Company finished the year as the fourth-largest shipper of personal computers, with 5.8 percent of the market, and Packard Bell NEC Inc. was fifth with 4.3 percent.
A separate report released by the International Data Corporation based on preliminary calculations showed slightly different figures for personal computer sales and market share but concurred with Dataquest as to the top five vendors in 1998.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Sees Hard Choices To Preserve Social Security

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned Congress today not to count on projected Government budget surpluses to solve Social Security's problems, and he suggested that the two parties would still have to cut benefits or raise taxes to insure the retirement system's future.
Appearing before the Senate Budget Committee, Mr. Greenspan was clearly trying to interject a dose of hard reality into the debate over Social Security, which for the last week has centered on President Clinton's proposal to shore up the system with $2.7 trillion of the $4.4 trillion in surpluses the White House anticipates over the next 15 years. 
 Relying on the surplus reduces the sacrifices that would be necessary from today's workers and tomorrow's retirees, and for that reason Republicans, too, have generally endorsed allocating a big portion of the surplus to Social Security.
Mr. Clinton has alluded in general terms to the need for measures in addition to using the surplus, but has avoided specifics, while Republicans have been silent or called for solutions that require neither tax increases nor benefit cuts.
Last week and again today, Mr. Greenspan criticized one element of the White House's Social Security proposal, saying that its call for the Government to invest $700 billion in the stock market would result in political meddling in the free enterprise system. But Mr. Greenspan was supportive again today of Mr. Clinton's call for a large portion of the surplus to be used to bolster Social Security by paying down the national debt.
Mr. Greenspan's main message today was that budget forecasts have been notoriously unreliable in the past and are likely to remain so in the future, making 15-year surplus projections a rickety structure on which to base a solution to Social Security's long-term financial gap.
The country should be wary of assuming "extraordinarily large projected surpluses as far as the eye can see," Mr. Greenspan said. "I use that term advisedly, because it was originally used on the deficit side, and it was obvious that as far as the eye could see wasn't all that far. And I suspect that we may find the same characteristic of nearsightedness re-exhibiting itself in the current period."
Mr. Greenspan noted that the Congressional Budget Office had predicted in February 1997 that the Government would run a deficit in 1998 of $121 billion. The actual outcome was a surplus of $70 billion.
It is unclear how receptive Congress will be to Mr. Greenspan's message. Just hours after he spoke, the Congressional Budget Office gave Congressional leaders a new budget forecast showing a total surplus over the next 11 years of nearly $2.7 trillion.
The budget office projections, which appeared to be roughly in line with the $4.4 trillion, 15-year surplus projected by the White House, show the overall surpluses mounting rapidly, from $107 billion in the current fiscal year to $381 billion in 2009.
They projections include $794 billion in surpluses over the eight years starting in 2001 that are beyond those that come from excess payroll taxes nominally earmarked for Social Security -- in other words, a true surplus derived from annual spending being lower than annual revenues from general tax collections. Republicans have been counting on the emergence of a true surplus to finance their plans for an across-the-board reduction in income tax rates.
Assuming that the overall surpluses materialize and are not used for new spending programs, Mr. Greenspan said, Mr. Clinton's strategy of using the surplus to bolster Social Security by paying down the national debt is the soundest policy option available.
Reducing the debt held by the public would be the best way to strengthen the economy in the long run, Mr. Greenspan said.
But given the risks that a downturn in the economy or the stock market could cause the surpluses to evaporate, Mr. Greenspan said, Congress and the Administration need to keep looking for ways to increase the amount of money available for Social Security or to decrease benefit payments. Mr. Greenspan led a commission in the early 1980's that pushed through both tax increases and benefit cuts.
Raising taxes now or altering the Social Security system to require increased savings and investment through private accounts might prove too politically "burdensome," Mr. Greenspan said.
As a result, he added, the country would have to examine a long menu of potential benefit cuts, in the form of changes like an older retirement age, a reduction in cost-of-living increases or a less generous formula for calculating lifetime earnings.
In his State of the Union address last week, Mr. Clinton said his plan, which also called for the Government to invest a portion of Social Security's reserves in the stock market, would keep the system afloat until 2055, compared with 2032 if no changes are made.
Because of the huge numbers of baby boomers who will begin retiring over the next several decades -- 76 million in all -- Social Security will be able to pay only 75 percent of promised benefits starting in 2032, unless changes are made.
But the benchmark for financial health in Social Security is solvency for 75 years, and Mr. Clinton acknowledged that the two parties would have "to make hard-headed but sensible and achievable choices" to meet that goal.
But he did not lay out the possibilities, much less endorse any of them, and most Republicans have avoided the subject altogether.
Asked about Mr. Greenspan's comments, Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said the Administration "could not agree with him more" about the need for further bipartisan steps to insure the system's solvency.
A senior House Republican aide said the issue was a "crucial question" facing both parties, and was part of a broader debate over whether Congress and the Administration should settle for a partial solution on Social Security and defer the hard choices for another day.
Before it became apparent that the budget surplus could ease much of the pain of addressing Social Security's woes, the two parties had been circling warily around a variety of options.
Mr. Clinton had ruled out increasing the 12.4 percent payroll tax rate that finances Social Security. But liberal Democrats were advocating other ways of increasing revenues, including an increase in the wage level subject to the payroll tax, currently $72,000.
Republicans, however, have been adamant that they will not accept any kind of tax increase. They have been more open to other options, including an increase in the retirement age, which is already scheduled to rise gradually to 67 over the next several decades. But organized labor has promised a ferocious effort to block any further increase in the retirement age.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony today came as Republicans continued to question whether Mr. Clinton's plan to use the surplus for Social Security was anything more than an accounting gimmick. And it came at a time when members of both parties are increasingly pessimistic that there will be enough bipartisan trust in the aftermath of the impeachment trial for Congress and the Administration to reach a deal on Social Security.

HEADLINE: CBS Granted More Tax Cuts to Stay Put

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Six years after New York City granted CBS Inc. nearly $50 million in tax breaks to stay in Manhattan until the year 2008, the city has given it an additional $10 million in subsidies -- after being told the company was considering relocating to New Jersey.
Under the old deal, the company had pledged to spend $300 million to upgrade its studios on West 57th Street with digital equipment. But it only started doing so 18 months ago. The new deal extends the company's commitment to Manhattan for an additional 10 years, until 2018, and city officials said it contains new assurances that the network will make the investment that it had earlier promised. 
 CBS told city officials last spring that it was considering moving its studios to the Newport Office Center, on the waterfront in Jersey City. That apparently sent the city scrambling to keep the CBS jobs from heading to New Jersey.
Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said yesterday that the city agreed to provide the additional benefits because there was a real danger that CBS would have moved to New Jersey, despite the company's 1993 pledge to remain in Manhattan until 2008.
"The threat was very real," Mr. Levine said. "We made this deal competitive with the offer from New Jersey that they were considering. The fact that we can secure their presence for the next 20 years is very good for the city." CBS also committed itself to keeping its corporate offices, now at 51st Street and the Avenue of the Americas, in Manhattan.
Critics of such corporate retention deals said that the new subsidies amounted to a reward for a company that was threatening to break its original agreement with the city.
"There are no standards" for granting such subsidies, said Ronnie Eldridge, a City Councilwoman in whose West Side district the CBS studios are situated. "They're just giving away benefits to large companies. If we were as tough on corporations as we are on poor people, the city would have more to spend on schools, bridges and subways."
Dana McClintock, director of communications at CBS, said that the latest agreement, which he called an "amendment" to the original deal with the city, recognized that CBS had undergone many changes in the last six years.
Real-estate developers and economic development officials in Jersey City said they doubted that CBS was serious about relocating
Thomas Gallagher, director of economic development in Jersey City, said that Jersey City officials had met with CBS last spring. But, he said, nothing came of it, and no offer was made to give CBS any benefits.
"We had some conversations," Mr. Gallagher said. "I wouldn't say they were negotiations. At some point, we moved on to other prospects. In their case, a New York location is probably better for them."
City officials have come under increasing criticism for granting tax breaks to a multitude of companies that have threatened to flee New York without assessing whether the threat is real. Critics say the subsidy packages shift the city's tax burden to small and medium-sized companies and rob the city's treasury of desperately needed funds.
The threat of moving is not always illusory, though, and some companies will move, for business reasons, no matter what. Indeed, CIGNA Healthcare and U.S. Trust Company announced yesterday that they would move about 1,000 employees from Manhattan to the Newport Center in Jersey City.
Under the Giuliani administration, the city had given 43 companies, including Conde Nast, Bear Stearns and Reuters, a total of more than $1.5 billion in tax breaks, cash and subsidized electricity. The New York Times received a similar tax break, for a printing plant in College Point, Queens, during the Dinkins administration.
"Now the city has embarked on a potentially costly path of rewarding companies that already have a lucrative retention deal," said James Parrott, chief economist for the Fiscal Policy Institute, a private research organization.
In CBS's case, for nearly a year the company's executives have said that they were considering a variety of options, including moving the 35-year-old studios to a new building at Donald J. Trump's Riverside South project and the Jersey City waterfront. If the company had moved across the river, Martin Franks, a senior vice president at CBS, acknowledged that CBS would have had to pay back the city for the tax breaks it has received since 1993 if it abandoned Manhattan.
"It's no secret we were being courted by people outside the city," Mr. Franks said. "Had we moved outside the city, we would have made whatever refund was appropriate."
According to city records, between 1993 and July 1997 CBS made use of more than $23 million of the property and sales tax breaks and electricity subsidies that it was allowed.
Under the terms of the 1993 deal, CBS was to invest $300 million in upgrading its studios with digital technology for high-definition television broadcasts. But the installation of equipment at the CBS studios has gone more slowly than the company anticipated in 1993. It only began in 1997, after the Federal Government established standards for the new broadcasting method.
Mr. McClintock also noted that since the original agreement with the city, CBS had acquired Infinity Broadcasting and American Radio Systems, and was acquired itself by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
"Our existing agreement with the city was amended to better reflect the structural changes that have formed the new CBS corporation," Mr. McClintock said.
The new deal with CBS requires the network to maintain at least as many employees in New York City as the 1993 agreement: a minimum of 3,862 full-time employees.
Six years ago, Mayor David Dinkins hailed the $49.5 million deal with CBS as a breakthrough that would encourage private companies to remain competitive by investing in new technology. The subsidy package included $31 million in sales tax exemptions, $6.5 million in property tax credits and about $12 million in subsidized electricity.
After that package, Capital Cities/ ABC immediately demanded its own subsidy package and eventually received $26 million in tax breaks and other incentives for its studios, near Lincoln Center. NBC, which got a $100 million tax break for its studios in Rockefeller Center in 1987, received an additional $7 million benefit in 1996.
After reaching the CBS deal, Laurence A. Tisch, then the chairman of the company, vowed to turn the low slung, red-brick broadcast complex on 57th Street into "a facility for the 21st century."
Mr. Tisch also tried to draw a distinction between CBS and other large companies who routinely threatened to leave Manhattan in order to obtain tax breaks. "We never threatened to leave the city," Mr. Tisch said at the time. "I just wanted us to be treated like everyone else."

HEADLINE: Mayor Says Adding Officers Is Key to City's Health

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY

 BODY:
For Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, every aspect of the city's revitalization -- from the demonstrable growth in tourism to the impressionistic sense that residents feel better about their hometown -- can be attributed to its dramatic crime reduction. And that is the reason he gave yesterday to justify his plan to add as many as 1,500 officers to what is already the largest police department in the nation.
Mr. Giuliani acknowledged that increasing the police force to more than 40,000 officers, which he said would cost $32 million, might appear "counterintuitive" given that the crime rate has plummeted to the lowest levels in two generations. But he said the city needed more officers to maintain the reduction in violent crimes, continue a campaign against drugs, and focus on domestic violence and property crimes like automobile thefts and burglaries. 
 "It is going to be difficult for us to continue to reduce crime," the Mayor said, pointing out that New York City had 629 homicides last year, the lowest number since the mid-1960's and fewer than in Chicago, a city less than half its size. "But the further down that we drive them, the more all the other things that it helps to produce" will grow exponentially.
The proposed increase comes at a time when New York City already leads the country's 10 most populous cities in its per-capita complement of police officers. According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the city had 5.1 officers for every 1,000 residents in 1997; Chicago had 4.9 per 1,000, followed by Philadelphia with 4.4 per 1,000.
In addition, some of the second-tier crimes that the city plans to tackle with the increased complement of officers have declined in recent years. Auto thefts have fallen 61 percent in the last five years, while burglaries have declined 53 percent.
"This strategy is working," the Mayor said. "Why back away from it now?"
Eli Silverman, a professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice who recently finished a book about the reorganization of the New York Police Department, gave qualified agreement. "If your expectations are to continue to drive down crime, you can't lose momentum," he said. "The truth is, I don't know when we'll hit diminishing returns until we hit it."
The Mayor's proposal, presented as part of his annual discussion of the administration's financial plan, concerns matters of politics as well as that of the city's overall well-being. The Police Department has bolstered its highly touted drug task forces with officers drawn from the precincts, a practice that has annoyed the City Council. The Mayor's plan, which would send replacements to those precincts, seemed yesterday to mollify some Council members.
In addition, the public identity of the Mayor is primarily defined by his reputation as a former Federal prosecutor who reined in a crime-ridden metropolis. That persona has served him well in recent trips to other states, and he is expected to exploit it if he decides to run for the United States Senate or another higher office. Any increase in crime might compromise that get-tough reputation, said Jay Severin, a Republican campaign strategist.
If the crime reduction "disappears, or if it is compromised, then the New York story -- which is the Rudy story -- becomes like Cinderella at midnight," Mr. Severin said. "He turns back into a big-city mayor instead of the knight that led the biggest, most dangerous city in the world into a new heyday."
The Mayor has attributed some of the city's success in fighting crime to the increased number of police officers, although he emphasized the importance of "strategic deployment." The average head count has grown from 36,703 in fiscal year 1994 to a projected number this fiscal year of 39,397, the Mayor's office says. By fiscal year 2000, city officials estimated, the average count will be 40,078. Reminded yesterday that he had proposed cutting the force three years ago -- an action he never took -- the Mayor said simply: "I was wrong. That was a mistake."
Mr. Giuliani explained that the 850 cadets who graduate from the Police Academy next month will be used to expand the antidrug activities, particularly in Queens and the Bronx. Then, in April, about 1,300 cadets scheduled to graduate "are going to be used to backfill precincts that have lost some police officers because of the drug initiatives," he said.
The administration has touted those drug initiatives as major successes, but they have come at a cost: fewer police officers have been available to work in neighborhood precincts. As a result, critics point out that citywide response time -- the average time it takes the police to respond to a 911 call -- rose in fiscal year 1998 to 9.8 minutes, from 9.2 minutes in fiscal year 1997.
City Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler, the chairman of the Council's public safety committee, said yesterday that he was pleased that more officers would be sent to the precincts. "Before, with the emphasis of the Giuliani administration on drug initiatives, the community policing beats have not been staffed to the extent that we'd like," he said. "This is a time when one should simply say thank you."
Glenn Pasanen, the associate director of City Project, a liberal public-policy organization, was not as willing to offer gratitude. He said that Mr. Giuliani was clearly favoring the Police Department at the expense of other city services, from education and health care to social services. "The Mayor is throwing money at the Police Department, just as he accused other past mayors of throwing money to social services," he said.
The larger question presented by the Mayor's plan was raised by Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council. "The question now is, 'Is the Mayor doing too much?' " he said. "We don't know. We'll take a look at it."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI BROADENS SPLIT WITH PATAKI WITH BUDGET PLAN

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stepped up his criticism of Gov. George E. Pataki's spending practices yesterday as he proposed a $35.4 billion budget for New York City, setting the stage for a rancorous battle with Albany over school aid.
The centerpiece of Mr. Giuliani's spending plan is a proposal to build new schools using $2.5 billion of the city's anticipated share of the settlement with the tobacco industry. The city is to receive $6.7 billion from the settlement, in installments over two decades. Mr. Giuliani said the city would borrow the money to build the schools over the next three years, then pay off the debt with its annual payments from the tobacco industry. 
 Mr. Giuliani also proposed hiring up to 1,500 new police officers, which he said would help the city expand antidrug efforts.
While the Mayor called for cuts in a number of areas, including libraries and youth programs, he also proposed using several hundred million dollars to expand art and reading initiatives, put computers in every middle school and start an experimental tuition voucher system.
He accused Mr. Pataki, a fellow Republican, of providing insufficient state aid for such initiatives.
The Mayor was angered last week when the Governor ordered a state investigation into the city's school construction practices. And Mr. Giuliani used the opportunity of his budget address to amplify a complaint that he has raised daily since Mr. Pataki announced the investigation: that Albany repeatedly sends New York City less school aid than it is entitled to.
The city has about 38 percent of the state's schoolchildren, according to the Mayor, yet it receives about 35 percent of total state aid to schools.
New York City mayors have long complained about state school aid, but Mr. Giuliani himself took the position early in his tenure that a more serious problem in the city's schools was poor management, not a lack of state funds. More recently, though, he has expressed confidence in the leadership of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and added his voice to the familiar complaint about school financing from Albany.
"In the budget that the Governor released," Mr. Giuliani said, "that disparity would grow, particularly with new dollars, very, very substantially." Such an approach, he added, "doesn't make much sense if you're really interested in children being educated more effectively."
By loudly disparaging the Governor's spending plan, Mr. Giuliani could be putting himself in an awkward political position. He has expressed interest in running for the United States Senate in 2000, and his chances of winning the Republican nomination could be significantly weakened without the support of Mr. Pataki, who has emerged as the unquestioned leader of the state's Republican Party.
Mr. Giuliani could lobby the Legislature to reject Mr. Pataki's spending plan, but in doing so, he would be in the odd position of joining forces with the Democrat-led Assembly when he is hungry for statewide Republican support.
As with previous budget plans, the Mayor was generally conservative in his proposals for new spending yesterday despite a strong local economy that has enabled the city to build a $1.6 billion surplus this fiscal year. He wants to use the surplus to reduce budget shortfalls, which are expected to rise in coming years because of tax cuts and labor settlements that have already been approved.
Mr. Giuliani called for $591 million in program cuts, including $37 million from the budget for public libraries, $23 million from museums and other cultural organizations, and $19 million from youth programs. Among the affected youth programs is an after-school program that the city started last year with help from the financier George Soros. The Mayor recommended cutting $5 million for that program, a move that City Council officials vowed to fight.
The Mayor also proposed $338 million in new tax cuts, including $51 million from eliminating the sales tax on all clothing and footwear, which would require approval from Albany, and $166 million from extending a tax relief program for owners of co-ops and condominiums. He also called for setting aside $100 million for future tax cuts while a newly formed commission comes up with recommendations.
Besides pressing for money for art classes in the schools, Mr. Giuliani said he and Dr. Crew were discussing new funds for school sports programs, which have fallen on hard times recently. He offered no specifics, but his aides later said the Mayor envisioned increased funds for playing fields, uniforms and equipment.
He said during his address at City Hall that the city had every reason to be optimistic about his proposals, which he said held spending virtually flat. "We are proposing a budget next year that in essence, in terms of city funds, will be a no-growth budget," he said. "New York City is now setting the way for fiscal responsibility."
But independent budget monitors said the Mayor's spending plan was actually 2 percent to 3 percent larger than last year's. The city is not projecting a spending increase because under its own accounting rules, the surplus is counted as being spent in the current fiscal year, even though the Mayor is using it to cover next year's anticipated shortfall.
Independent monitors criticized his plan for the surplus yesterday, saying the city should use the $1.6 billion to reduce its heavy debt load.
"Despite the strong economy, the city is using that money to balance the budget," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private organization. "He is missing a perfect opportunity for the city to show some fiscal discipline and use the surplus to pay down its debt."
But fiscal monitors and Council leaders appeared receptive to Mr. Giuliani's plan to use tobacco money for school construction, saying it was a good alternative to raising the city's debt burden. The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who led the Council in rejecting Mr. Giuliani's spending plan last year, said yesterday, "We are really delighted that the Mayor selected our main priority -- schools and the building of schools and our children -- as his main priority in the budget."
But the Speaker, a Democrat, said he would not allow Mr. Giuliani to make cuts to libraries and youth programs. And he expressed discomfort with another of the Mayor's proposals: to squirrel away about $800 million in revenue from the commercial rent tax over four years, for future stadium construction.
"We are not against using government resources to help build stadiums," said Michael Clendenin, a Vallone spokesman. "But the Speaker has serious reservations about keeping the commercial rent tax around to fund that kind of project."
While the Mayor might skirmish with the Council on certain proposals, he suggested yesterday that Mr. Pataki would be his primary opponent in this year's budget battles. While he praised Mr. Pataki's plan to cut Medicaid, he said several times that the education spending that the Governor announced in his budget message on Wednesday was unfair to New York City.
Under the Governor's budget plan, the city would receive $17.7 million of the $154 million increase in statewide education spending, or about 12 percent. Mr. Giuliani said the city had been expecting at least $300 million more than it got in state education aid and now faced a shortfall.
Mr. Pataki did not respond to Mr. Giuliani's comments yesterday, but his spokesman, Michael McKeon, disputed the Mayor's arithmetic, saying the city was to get 38 percent of the proposed increase in school aid. But the spokesman was counting only the largest category of aid. The city also receives several smaller categories of state aid, which Mr. Pataki has proposed cutting.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
2 Companies to Move Offices to Jersey City

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Eight months after he began construction of an office tower on the Jersey City waterfront, the developer Richard S. LeFrak has lured two companies and almost 1,000 employees from Manhattan to the building.
Cigna Corporation and the United States Trust Company of New York have signed leases for more than half the available space in the 14-story building at the Newport Office Center, Mr. LeFrak said yesterday. 
 With rents rising dramatically in Manhattan, tenants have begun looking for less expensive space in New Jersey for the first time since the office boom that preceded the recession in the early 1990's. New Jersey also offers tax breaks for tenants.
Mr. LeFrak, president of the Lefrak Organization, said that he expected the entire 567,318-square-foot building to be leased by the time it opens at the end of this year.
Early next year, United States Trust will move about 300 employees to Newport Center from several buildings in Manhattan. Cigna, an insurance and financial services company based in Philadelphia, will move its health care division and about 660 people to Jersey City from 770 Broadway, at East Eighth Street, in Manhattan.
"It's about economics," said Josh N. Kuriloff, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield and a leasing agent at Newport Center. "You can get space here at potentially half the cost of first-class office space in Manhattan." CHARLES V. BAGLI
