HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting;
Cars With Star Quality, Rat Pack to Fab Four

BYLINE: By KEITH MARTIN

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

 BODY:
THIS may be the biggest weekend of the year in sports, but for car collectors, the Super Bowl has come and gone.
In a four-day buying spree here last weekend at the 28th annual Barrett-Jackson auction, nearly 600 highly desirable cars changed hands at prices ranging from the expected to the extraordinary. Size alone assures Barrett-Jackson a position of prominence among aficionados. But beyond that, over the last four years the event has accurately gauged the prevailing winds driving collectors and investors, serving as an indication of the health of the collector market. 
 Barrett-Jackson has also evolved from a simple auction into a spectator sport that draws a bigger on-hand audience than the Super Bowl. This year, some 125,000 car buffs watched, at various times, as more than 2,000 bidders vied in sometimes heated competition to take home some of the world's most interesting and coveted cars. A total of 734 cars were offered and 567 were sold. That 77.2 percent selling rate compares with 65.5 percent a year earlier.
Total sales reached $20 million, plus $1.7 million from the big-ticket cars in the Exposition Tent, a separate area where cars are sold one-on-one, allowing for more complicated transactions, including trade-ins. Expo sales ranged from $126,500 to $1.2 million, for a 1931 Duesenberg Model J LeBaron Special Phaeton.
"America's economy is booming, America is where the money is, and Americans are buying the dream cars from their youth," Craig Jackson, owner of the Barrett-Jackson Auction Company, said in summarizing this year's results. "There were plenty of Europeans in the audience, but unlike four or five years ago, when they could cherry-pick through the cars they wanted and take home the best ones at bargain prices, this year they just couldn't match up to what the Americans were bidding."
The highest auction-block sale of the weekend, at $304,500, was a 1973 Ferrari 365 GTS/4 Daytona Spyder, one of 124 built by the factory. Authenticity plays a big part in the market value of Daytonas; coupes were often converted to open cars by after-market specialists; one such Daytona "chop job" sold here for $127,050.
The loudest cheers of the weekend went to the buyer of an immaculately restored 1957 Chevrolet Bel Air convertible who paid $89,250, at least $30,000 above the normal price for this model. Painted turquoise with a white top, it had a 283-cubic-inch V8 and a rare factory fuel-injection setup, a three-speed manual transmission and a limited-slip (positraction) rear end.
Bidders were willing to ante up for vehicles with celebrity ties, like three cars once owned by members of Hollywood's Rat Pack. In their heydey in the 1960's, Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis Jr. and Dean Martin indulged their automotive desires as freely as they flaunted their pursuit of wine, women and the good life. A car formerly owned by each crossed the block here.
A 1956 Ford Thunderbird two-seat roadster originally owned by Frank Sinatra brought $159,600, easily $130,000 more than a standard '56 T-Bird. The custom-colored metallic gunmetal-silver car was laden with options, including a factory hardtop, wire hubcaps, fender skirts, an external spare tire mounted in a Continental kit on the back bumper, a spotlight and dual rear antennas.
Among car collectors, Old Blue Eyes commands the kind of premium that "dot com" adds to common stocks. Last August, Christie's got $178,500 for an ordinary 1989 Jaguar XJS coupe at Pebble Beach, Calif. Without Sinatra's name on the title, such a car would be worth barely $10,000.
The cars of Sinatra's cohorts didn't do as well. A 1962 Dual-Ghia L6.4 coupe once owned by Dean Martin, in slightly disheveled condition with custom-fitted luggage, chrome wire wheels and distinctive appointments including a gun holster under the driver's seat, sold for $63,000 to the Blackhawk Collection in Danville, Calif. Though it was among only 26 Dual-Ghia coupes built, the selling price was in line with those of cars that lack a celebrity connection. These exotics combined Italian coachwork with a powerful 383-cubic-inch Chrysler V8; they were built by Ghia in Italy and distributed in the United States by Dual Motors.
The most impressive of the Rat Pack cars did not find a new home. Davis's 1964 Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud III convertible -- what the British call a "drophead coupe" -- failed to sell despite a bid of $305,000. With a body by Mulliner, the English coachbuilder, and exquisitely restored with maroon paint and a tan leather interior, this is one of fewer than 30 left-drive Silver Cloud III convertibles built. A car in similar condition sold for $247,500 in December 1997 at an auction in Greenwich, Conn.
While Davis's and Martin's cars failed to move bidders' paddles, Elvis and the Beatles set the crowd rocking. An enormous 1965 Rolls-Royce Phantom V limousine -- with a rare left-hand-drive configuration -- brought $115,500, more than twice what these behemoths normally fetch. The car's providence was extraordinary, however, in that it had a double-Beatle history. John Lennon, the original owner, sold it to Richard Starkey -- better known as Ringo Starr.
Two cars once owned by Elvis Presley also did well. A mundane four-door 1976 Cadillac Seville, two-tone blue with a custom grille and garish gold trim -- typical of Elvis's cars -- sold for $30,450 to the 120-car Klassix Auto Attraction in Daytona Beach, Fla. "We'd been looking for an Elvis car to go in our celebrity section," said David Murray, the winning bidder. "We already own the Batmobile, the Munsters' Dragula, and the Flintstones movie car driven by John Goodman."
Mr. Murray conceded that a seller "would be lucky to get more than $7,000 for the same Cadillac without the Presley history."
The second Elvis car brought more. A 1969 Mercedes-Benz long-wheelbase 600 sold for $72,400, although its air suspension seemed to have collapsed. That flaw was perhaps offset by the gold-lettered "TCB" on the doors -- for "taking care of business." These cars have a reputation for being exceptionally difficult and expensive to repair; $20,000 would be considered a generous offer for a regular 600 in like condition.
Several Mercedes-Benz 300SL Gullwings, with their trademark flip-up doors, did well. A recently refurbished '55, in silver with a black leather interior, sold for $189,000. The same car had sold last March at an auction in Las Vegas, Nev., for $138,600, demonstrating that even for high-end collector cars, fresh paint and a wax job pay dividends.
Of the many Corvettes sold, the most unusual was a 1963 coupe that was customized by the General Motors styling staff and presented to their long-time boss, the legendary designer Harley Earl, in his retirement. Festooned with 16 gauges and adorned by external exhaust pipes that resembled a bundle of snakes, it brought $152,500. "We've sold this same car four times now," Mr. Jackson said. "And each time we get more money for it."
After the last car had crossed the block, the elaborate auction tents had been taken down and tumbleweeds were again blowing across the Sonoran Desert, Mr. Jackson reflected on the prospects for the market.
He said he saw collectors moving into cars that are not necessarily perfect, but offer good times. "I'd keep an eye on mid-50's Chevys in driving condition," he said. "People want cars they can take to cruise-ins, relive the past and enjoy themselves.
"The buyers we get at Barrett-Jackson, especially the first-timers, aren't looking for show cars to pamper and admire. They just want something they can have fun with."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 15, 1999, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption with the Collecting column on the Automobiles page on Jan. 29, about an auction of cars once owned by celebrities, referred incorrectly to one of two Rolls-Royce limousines associated with the Beatles. HEADLINE: A Credit Card for Every Occasion

BYLINE: By Michael Rosenbaum; Michael Rosenbaum is an investor relations consultant.

 BODY:
Every January, inch-thick credit card statements clog the mailbox, the unwelcome aftermath of year-end celebrations. But it could be worse -- $5.7 million worse.
That's how much debt my family would have if we had taken advantage of all the credit cards and home-equity loans offered to us in 1998. Even at low, low introductory rates of 3.9 percent, the interest on $5.7 million comes to a mind-boggling $222,000 per year, or a little more than one minute's income for Bill Gates. 
 Trying to decipher all the offers is a full-time job. We received 150 offers -- and that was just by mail. An equal number came by phone or on the Internet.
Most cards are named after metals, usually gold, platinum or titanium. But companies have added their own spin to names in a hopeless attempt to help customers differentiate among the products. Mastercard comes in nearly a dozen flavors, including Platinum, Platinum Plus, Platinum Edge, Universal Platinum, Purchase Rewards Gold, Platinum Select and, just to be different, Select Platinum.
Mastercard edged out Visa in the total number of cards offered us, 62 to 61, but Visa is the champ in the battle of affinity cards. Most affinity cards came from companies trying to win customers by playing to buying habits or professional interests. As a high school teacher, my wife, Jill, qualified for the $100,000-limit Platinum Edge Mastercard for Educators, offered by invitation only through Advanta. Of course, educators don't really get a special deal: she received the same offer from Advanta without any reference to her status as a teacher.
The most unusual affinity card came from Capital One, whose British Heritage Visa Platinum Card includes a Union Jack on the card, apparently offered because we toured England a year earlier. Otherwise, it appears to be identical to every other Platinum Visa.
Apparently, credit card marketing is much like professional sports and computer programming: signing bonuses are offered everywhere.
The University of Illinois and Northern Illinois University gave us identical offers for Visa cards, but one offered a bonus of a windshirt (a $60 value!!!), and the other enticed us with a free gym bag ($80 value!!!). Ringling Brothers dangled four complimentary tickets to the circus as an inducement to take their Mastercard, and Montgomery Ward offered a mini boombox -- but that deal expired in August 1997, at least four months before the mass mailing reached us.
Interest charges on credit cards must be incredibly profitable these days, because almost every card offered came without an annual fee. More than half the offers cited interest rates in the 3.9 to 5.9 percent range, but those usually applied only to balances transferred from other cards. The lowest fixed rates were in the 8 to 10 percent range, and we were offered that rate three dozen times.
There's no clear pattern to credit limits, at least none apparent to this recipient. AT&T offered us $25,000 and $50,000. Citibank offered us a card with a $1,000 limit; then the limit jumped to $50,000 in a subsequent offer. Twice, Sears offered us a credit line of $4,032. How did the company arrive at that number? Why weren't we good for at least $4,050?
Showing a clear lack of awareness of how money is spent in America, my wife received only 53 offers, while I got 82. Our two teen-aged daughters, Susan and Stephanie, received four offers each -- a dubious honor, since it placed them in a three-way tie with Current Resident.
Three of the offers to Current Resident originated with Unicor Funding, which dangled $25,000 in mortgage money in front of us without any apparent review of our finances. We received 24 such blind mortgage offers in all, from Bank One's offer of up to $250,000 at an attractive rate of 7.74 percent to the more discerning Capital One's offer of $10,768 at an 11.9 percent rate.
Unfortunately, we don't know how much of the $5.7 million we could have added to our credit lines before the pre-approved offers would have stopped or our applications would have been rejected. That's something we could test this year.
This year we've already received a half-dozen Platinum Visa offers and an ill-timed mailing from Discover ("Just in time for the Holidays!") with an increase in our credit limit. At this pace, we'll hit the $6 million mark in no time.

HEADLINE: Value-Free Economics

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I was surprised to find the Austrian economist Joseph A. Schumpeter cited in support of a multidisciplinary approach to economics (Arts & Ideas page, Jan. 23). He repeatedly stressed that economists should refrain from annexing the territory of the philosopher, the psychologist or the politician. His goal was an economics on the model of a value-free science. 
 Schumpeter took a dim view of Keynes's concept of social engineering and his proposed use of monetary policy to smooth out the business cycle. Schumpeter believed that to do so would be to rip the motor out of the capitalist economy, as capitalist growth required those "waves of creative destruction" that could land a society in a trough like the Depression.
 
BENJAMIN HETT
Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 23, 1999
 
The writer is a graduate student in European history at Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Several Major U.S. Airlines Lift Fares Across the Board

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Several major airlines made across-the-board increases in their fares yesterday, sending stock prices in the industry soaring as investors apparently believed that a price increase would finally stick after numerous abortive attempts in recent months.
If the increase does stick, it would be the first industrywide since the fall of 1997. But a number of major airlines, including United Airlines and Trans World Airlines, had not gone along with the price increase as of late yesterday, indicating that its success was far from assured. 
 The increase was initiated by Delta Air Lines, which raised its last-minute, unrestricted business fares 2 percent and advance-purchase, restricted leisure fares 4 percent. Northwest Airlines, which has foiled recent attempts to increase fares, quickly matched Delta, leading many to believe that the other carriers will go along.
"It looks good that this one is going to stick," said Kevin C. Murphy, an airline analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York.
Northwest, which saw its traffic fall as a result of a pilots' strike in September, had been discounting heavily in order to woo back business travelers. "They said that they would be back to status quo in the first quarter," Mr. Murphy said. "Here we are one-third the way through the first quarter, so it makes sense that they have appetite for a fare hike."
The airlines have raised prices on various routes and in various classes over the last year but a systemwide price increase has proved elusive.
Though flights are full and demand is strong, industry revenues fell 3 percent in the fourth quarter of 1998 compared with the comparable period in 1997, indicating that pricing had weakened. With recent economic indicators for the national economy stronger than previous estimates, many investors believe that the airlines are poised to surpass profit estimates if they can raise prices.
News of the fare increase sent Northwest stock soaring 18 percent yesterday, or $4.125 a share, to close at $27.375. Shares of the other major carriers also rose sharply: Delta increased $4.4375 a share, to $54.5625; the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, gained $4.25 a share, to $58.75, and the UAL Corporation, the parent of United, closed at $62.25, up $3.875.
The airlines can change their fares several times a day by filing them with an electronic clearinghouse. If even one carrier decides not to match a general fare increase, the others will usually back down for fear of losing passengers.
"It only takes one," said Terry Trippler, who closely follows air fares as a columnist for a Web site, 1Travel.com. "T.W.A, even though they aren't one of the big ones, if they don't do it, it will fail."
But an industry executive who insisted on anonymity said that if T.W.A. were the only holdout, the other airlines might simply raise fares on all routes but those flown by T.W.A. That was not possible when Northwest did not go along because it is too large.

HEADLINE: Gore Seeks to Protect Trade From World's Fiscal Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore warned today that the world had to "prevent the financial crisis of 1998 from becoming the trade crisis of 1999," and said the United States would seek the "outright elimination" of the huge and politically sensitive subsidies that European nations provide to farmers.
Mr. Gore's statement was his first detailed speech on the fragility of the world economy. It came at his debut appearance at the annual gathering here of the world's richest industrialists and the top government officials who are trying to right the world economy after 18 months of market plunges and currency upheavals on three continents. 
 While his audience was from all over the world, his message was intended for farmers and others at home who have been demanding that Washington relieve the effects of extraordinarily low commodity prices that have depressed exports.
In a half-hour speech that leapt from the economic tumult to a new strategy for easing the debt of impoverished countries, Mr. Gore sought to offer a middle ground that would anger neither the labor unions suspicious of the Clinton Administration's trade policies nor the executives suspicious of Mr. Gore's relationships with environmentalists and unions.
But Mr. Gore stopped well short of tackling the most divisive questions being discussed, especially how governments might stem the huge outflows of short-term investment capital that destabilized Asia, Russia and now Brazil.
Instead, he declared that "the global capital market itself needs to be better and more cooperatively managed, not through new global bureaucracies, and not through the laissez-faire approach that has caused so many of today's problems, but through more information, more openness, more cross-border reviews and cooperation."
One executive whom Mr. Gore's staff consulted on the speech said later, "They couldn't decide where to come out on what to do, so they came out in favor of doing more but not too much."
Mr. Gore also met for 90 minutes today with Russia's Prime Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, discussing conditions that Russia must fulfill before the largest Western industrial nations and the International Monetary Fund will resume payments.
But the two men appeared to have made little progress. A senior Administration official, describing the session, said the United States and I.M.F. are still doubtful that Russia has a plan in place to collect taxes and raise sufficient revenues to make its new budget "credible."
Officials familiar with recently resumed negotiations between the fund and Moscow say it will be months before Russia receives additional funding. And if further loans are forthcoming, the first since Russia defaulted on debts last August, they may be designed chiefly to allow Russia to repay debts on older loans.
The two leaders also addressed Russia's export of missile expertise to Iran, with Mr. Gore reiterating Washington's threat to suspend cooperation on commercial space launches until Russia curbs technology sales to Teheran.
In his speech, Mr. Gore said the budget that the Administration sends to Capitol Hill on Monday will include "significant new U.S. funding" to pay off the debts of poor and highly indebted nations, many in Africa.
He was critical, however, of the subsidies European nations pay their farmers, saying they "cost the average European family about $1,500 a year." He also attacked Europe's efforts to restrict sales of beef raised using biotechnological products, a regulation that European officials say is motivated by concerns about public safety, and that Washington says is driven by protectionism.

HEADLINE: Council Puts Strict Limits on Fishing to Save New England Cod

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The New England Fishery Management Council voted on Thursday to reduce the daily cod catch in the Gulf of Maine to 200 pounds per boat from 400 pounds and to ban fishing within 30 miles of shore off a 180-mile stretch of the United States coast from Maine to the top of Cape Cod Bay.
The restrictions were imposed in hopes of saving the cod, once a cornerstone of the fishing industry. 
 The restrictions would ban all gear capable of catching ground fish, including cod and flounder. Scallopers and lobstermen are exempt from the ban. The new limits will be phased in starting in May, pending approval from the Commerce Department in Washington.
Fishermen said the changes could cost thousands of people their jobs.
"If there are varying degrees of death, this is one of them," said Paul Cohan, president of the Gulf of Maine Fishermen's Alliance.
The restricted area will be divided into four sections to be closed one at a time on a rolling basis in May, June, October and November, said Teri Frady, a spokeswoman for the National Marine Fisheries Service.
In the past, restrictions have been imposed to rebuild stocks in the fishing area between Cape Cod and the tip of Maine.
But after scientists in December released a report that the cod population was at its lowest in 30 years, the council determined that the cod catch should be cut by 80 percent.
Testimony was heard from dozens of fishermen on Thursday in a hotel in Portsmouth, N.H. Some said the restrictions would hurt fishermen from Massachusetts and New Hampshire with smaller boats, but would be easier on those from Maine, who typically have larger ships and can fish farther out at sea.
The restrictions could inflict regional economic losses of $19.9 million to $21.8 million, according to an estimate in a draft analysis completed this week.
As many as 2,500 fishermen could be out of work and 700 boats could be grounded, according to an estimate from Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Fishermen said they would look for other jobs, and fish brokers said they would look to Canada, Iceland and the Pacific to fill orders. Some predicted that prices for the fish will rise.
"We know this will seriously impact small-boat fishermen," said Chris Kellogg, a council officer. "But unless there was a substantial reduction in fishing levels, the cod stocks would have continued to drop."

HEADLINE: About New York;
Trash Piles Up On Hopes Of Parolees

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
SEVERAL years ago, a pristine plaza sprang up on Second Avenue near East 118th Street, attracting crowds for free food, weddings, parties and revival meetings. The plaza, built by a group of ex-convicts who lived next door at the United Christian Prison Ministry, was a luminous sight in East Harlem. What was once a dumping ground for junk and junkies became a haven lined with skinny palm trees, murals of dreamy clouds and elegant arches. Hovering above it all -- O.K., bolted to the side of an adjoining building -- was a big wooden dove.
Now the bird looks like a cartoon character frozen in flight by a frightful sight: the plaza is a heap of wood, plaster and broken glass. The very men who built it took it apart a month ago when the city -- which had leased the land to them for $150 a month -- auctioned it to a private buyer for $100,000. Soon, illegal dumpers returned at night to turn the lot back into an eyesore. 
 "Forget about it," said the Rev. Ramon Cabrera, the ministry's founder, who is scrambling to raise more than $100,000 to buy the lot. "I have to turn my head when I walk by there."
Ashes to ashes, dumps to dumps was not exactly what Mr. Cabrera expected when he first leased the lot. A weapons charge landed him in prison for eight years. A jailhouse conversion guided him to East Harlem, where in 1992, he and his wife, Mercedes, took in paroled convicts who slept on the floor of the couple's apartment. Later, the ex-convicts roomed in the basement of a Pentecostal church. Finally, Mr. Cabrera rented a building next to the Second Avenue lot, fixing it up with castoffs scavenged in nightly Dumpster raids. He also signed a monthly lease with the city for the lot.
"We wanted to show people that we were not a threat to anybody," he said. "To show everybody we can clean this place up."
Mr. Cabrera planned to turn the plaza's site into an expanded residence and training center for the ex-convicts who arrive there after years upstate. He was preparing a proposal to seek state financing to buy the site and build on it. Some 40 men now live in a hodgepodge of rooms above the ministry, sharing one bathroom per floor and hanging their clothes on bunk beds packed into barracks-like rooms. Although officials ranging from Representative Charles B. Rangel to the local community board members supported him, their pleas did not prevent the auction.
"I understand they didn't have the funds on hand to purchase the property at auction and that although they had tentative plans for development, they didn't have funding secured," said Denise Collins, the spokeswoman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, which ran the auction. "But that's not our primary issue. For us it is the fact that this property is surplus, and we have as our priority the disposition of surplus property for which there is no city use."
MEMBERS of the ministry reply that the government has no use for paroled convicts looking to stay straight.
"What makes all this hard is that it is politically correct for politicians to use prisoners as their platform to build up their power base," said an ex-convict in the ministry, Henry Rivera. "Look at the Governor. He's talking about doing away with parole. But it's not politically correct to take a public stance in favor of a program helping ex-offenders."
Assemblyman Nelson Denis, whose district office faces the ministry, said city officials overlooked the ministry's long-term ability to prevent repeat offenses in favor of short-term financial gains.
"The city is divesting itself of any property it can to bolster the balance sheet so they'll look good now," Mr. Denis said. "That looks good financially, but it won't really accommodate the needs of a community like mine." With tens of thousands of dollars spent a year to house an inmate, he said, "it's an ill-founded way of demonstrating economic leadership when you are disemboweling local communities."
While Mr. Cabrera embarks on a fund-raising drive, he has put on hold much of his group's charitable work: without the lot, they have no place to distribute fruits and vegetables from a food bank. The basement chapel is cluttered with chairs and other equipment that used to be in the plaza. It's an obstacle course all around.
"I saw somebody's dream in this place," said Alberto Paez, who arrived at the ministry on May 18 last year. "When you have a dream to do something and you want to set things right, so many obstacles get put in your way. It's crazy."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Passes 2,500 as G.D.P. Rise Revives Profit Hopes

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks advanced yesterday on news of a surprising surge in United States economic growth, which raised confidence in the outlook for corporate profits. The Nasdaq composite index wrapped up its biggest monthly gain in 24 years.
The Commerce Department's report that gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 5.6 percent in the fourth quarter was far above the 4.5 percent analysts expected. Prices rose at the slowest pace in 40 years, quelling concern that faster growth would incite inflation and drive up interest rates. 
 "The concern has been, will earnings come through?" said Art Micheletti, chief investment strategist at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, a money manager in Foster City, Calif. "And when investors saw the stronger number, they interpreted it that maybe we can hit earnings targets."
The Nasdaq index surpassed 2,500 points for the first time, rising 28.55, or 1.2 percent, to 2,505.89. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 77.50, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 9,358.83, with I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard accounting for almost half the gain. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 14.27, to a record 1,279.64. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by 1,705 to 1,332 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Government report also contributed to a rally in the bond market, even though signs of economic strength are frequently regarded as a reason to sell bonds. Traders said the evidence of benign inflation in the report was viewed positively.
The 30-year Treasury issue rose 11/32 , to 102 19/32 , and its yield, which falls when the price rises, declined to 5.08 percent from 5.10. "We're seeing a pattern here," said John Boritzke, who helps oversee $9 billion at M&I Investment Management in Milwaukee. "That pattern is one of low inflation."
The rally in stocks was strongest among computer makers, which derived strength from a report by the research firm Dataquest that shipments of personal computers rose a greater-than-expected 15 percent last year. I.B.M. rose 4 9/16 , to 183 1/4; Hewlett-Packard rose 4 1/2, to 78 3/8, and Dell Computer rose 5 13/16 , to a record 100.
Computer-related shares sent the Nasdaq up 14 percent in January, the third-biggest monthly advance in its 28-year history and a reflection of the voracious investor appetite for high-technology and Internet companies.
Shares of food companies declined. Those companies lose appeal when the economy is accelerating because they tend to underperform those that do well in expansions. Kellogg fell 1 7/16 , to 40 5/8, after the world's largest cereal maker said fourth-quarter profit fell 41 percent, matching forecasts. Unilever, producer of Lipton tea and Good Humor ice cream, dropped 1 5/8 , to 40 5/8 .
Among other strong performers yesterday, Amgen, the world's biggest biotechnology company, rose 8 1/4, to 127 13/16 , after reporting earnings of 90 cents a share, beating expectations, on strong sales of its anemia drug, Epogen, and plans for a 2-for-1 stock split.
Stocks overcame an early decline caused by a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago that Midwestern manufacturing, a bellwether of broader trends, declined in January.
Investors were also concerned that a renewed slump in Brazil's currency might yet undermine North American financial markets. Brazil's currency dropped for an eighth day, reaching its lowest level since its Jan. 13 devaluation.
Airline shares gained after Northwest Airlines raised full and discount fares, a move that other carriers were expected to follow. Northwest gained 4 1/8, to 27 3/8. Continental Airlines rose 3 3/8, to 34. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, gained 3 7/8, to 62 1/4. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, gained 4 1/4, to 58 3/4.

HEADLINE: Mayors Applaud President and His Urban Proposals

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
President Clinton took advantage of a meeting with mayors from more than 200 cities today to announce that he is seeking a hefty raise for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Mr. Clinton's proposed increase of $2.5 billion would give the agency a record $28 billion at a time the Administration was using every bit of good news to draw attention from the impeachment trial in the Senate. 
 In a meeting that lasted more than an hour in the East Room of the White House, the President thanked the mayors for their role in helping drive down crime rates, expand job growth and improve the living conditions for many low-income Americans. But he emphasized that more work remained.
"The present prosperity is an opportunity and a responsibility to make sure that opportunity and prosperity reaches every person in every corner of this country, into every neighborhood in every city of this country," he said. "If we cannot do this now with what some people believe is the strongest overall economy in our history, believe me, we will never get around to doing the job."
Mr. Clinton's address was the first of several the mayors heard here on the third and last day of the winter meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors. Over lunch in a hotel ballroom, they listened to speeches on different urban issues by Senator Trent Lott, the Mississippi Republican who is the majority leader; Attorney General Janet Reno, and the President's wife, Hillary.
The original speaking schedule included only Mr. Lott and Mrs. Clinton, a plan that left open the possibility that Mrs. Clinton would share a dais with the man who is controlling the impeachment proceedings against her husband.
But other commitments assured that the two would not even be in the hotel at the same time. Mr. Lott, who spoke for 25 minutes, finished at 12:10 and quickly returned to Capitol Hill for meetings. Mrs. Clinton arrived shortly before 1:30 and spoke for half an hour. An aide to the mayoral conference said she had asked to speak last and had told officials that she could not arrive any earlier.
Joined by members of his Cabinet, Mr. Clinton used much of his time with the mayors highlighting aspects of the urban agenda he discussed in his State of the Union address last week. He said the housing increase would help pay for a second round of community empowerment grants to 20 cities, which were announced two weeks ago, and for 100,000 new vouchers for poor and low-income people.
A spokesman for Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Suffolk County Republican who heads the House subcommittee on housing, said the Administration was certain only to get an increase of $2 billion and faced a fight for the remaining $500 million.
After his remarks, Mr. Clinton took questions. Mayor Linda Lawrence of Wausau, Wis., rose and took aim at the impeachment trial, saying, "I want you to know what on behalf of everybody I know, especially my parents who are so damn conservative that I had an 11 P.M. curfew all my life, that they want Congress to stop this to allow you to get on with the business of the country."
At that point, Mayor Lawrence said later, the other mayors stood to applaud, "and I couldn't finish."
Mr. Lott's appearance before the mayors was his first after two previous invitations. Assuring the mayors that the Senate was eager to get busy on a spectrum of issues that affected cities, he made only veiled references to the impeachment trial, saying he was grateful to be away from the Capitol, where he has been "tethered to the floor" of the Senate for three weeks.
"This year we have a particularly difficult responsibility, given to us under the Constitution, to carry out, and we're going to carry out that responsibility," Mr. Lott added. "But it will come to a conclusion, and when it does, it's important that we have a burst of activity to work on those problems that Americans really do care about."
Mr. Lott won respectful applause before and after his remarks. But it was nothing like the ovation showered upon Mrs. Clinton as she walked down the ballroom aisle toward the dais. The mayors stood and clapped loudly; some cheered.
Mrs. Clinton spent the first half of her speech reviewing Administration programs that she portrayed as "tools this President has provided" to help cities and urging the mayors to build support for the President's next budget.
She closed by promoting the Millennium Communities Program, an effort by the White House to encourage communities to plan celebrations that "honor the past and imagine the future."

HEADLINE: In the Red. No, Black.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Republicans leaders are accusing President Clinton of budget gimmickry, saying his plan to shore up reserves in the Social Security trust fund is an accounting trick.
Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, says the President's plan "appears to double count the Social Security surpluses," somehow extending the life of the trust fund "without doing anything." 
 Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire accuses the President of relying on an "accounting trick."
Critics are right that Mr. Clinton's plan double counts surpluses in the Social Security program. But these surpluses have been double counted in the budget for years, so the President's device is no new trick.
Political posturing aside, the real difference between the President's plan and that of his critics is not double counting. Some critics want to use the surplus to cut taxes. Many Republicans want to use it to create individual retirement accounts, which would serve the purpose of raising national savings if individuals did not offset the new accounts by reducing their other forms of private savings. Raising the national savings is widely embraced by economists. Liberal Democrats want to use the surplus to create universal health insurance or for education and other discretionary programs.
The President wants instead to drive down the Federal debt, now about $4 trillion. These are honorable differences in the positions. But, economists point out, most of these proposals double count the surplus in the Social Security program.
The Administration expects Social Security payroll taxes over the next 15 years to exceed outlays by about $2.7 trillion, a surplus that initially goes into the program's trust fund. Mr. Clinton proposes to add $2.8 trillion to the fund, for a total of $5.5 trillion, extending its life by almost 20 years, to 2049.
But most of the $2.8 trillion is the same money that comprises the $2.7 trillion already in the fund. Mr. Clinton, his critics say, proposes adding the first $2.7 trillion twice. To see through the dispute, trace the path of a surplus dollar, a dollar of Social Security payroll taxes that is not currently needed to pay retirees.
Speaking loosely, the dollar passes from a taxpayer to the Social Security trust fund and then on to the Treasury. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin makes the trust fund whole by sending it a $1 bond. He then spends the dollar on public housing, tanks or any other public purpose. Note the double use of the dollar. It is credited first to the trust fund and then to another program.
Under the President's plan, the path is initially the same. Surplus dollars would flow into the trust fund and back out to Mr. Rubin. Mr. Rubin continues to send the fund a $1 bond. But, under Mr. Clinton's proposal, Mr. Rubin would no longer use the surplus dollar to buy tanks or housing. Instead, he would buy back one dollar of Federal debt from the public in the form of a bond. Then he would deposit the repurchased bond into the Social Security trust fund.
The Republicans look at this process and cry double counting: Mr. Clinton has deposited two dollars worth of bonds into the fund from a single dollar of excess payroll taxes. In describing the process, they are correct.
But Administration officials point out that nearly any use of excess Social Security taxes would involve double counting. Indeed, several Republican proposals to reform Social Security would use the surplus to create private retirement accounts, another version of double counting.
So, if the President is guilty of accounting tricks, why aren't his critics?
"All they would change is the use to which the surplus would be put," says the President's chief economic adviser, Gene Sperling.
Behind the Administration's thinking is the assumption that, without the President's program, Congress would spend the surpluses on other Federal programs or, if the Republicans get their way, on a large tax cut. Mr. Sperling estimates that buying back Federal debt would instead reduce Federal debt as a percentage of economic output from about 45 percent today to about 7 percent by 2014.
"It is hard to believe," he says, "that a plan that virtually pays off the nation's publicly held debt in 15 years could be criticized as an obtuse Government accounting trick."
The immediate purpose of buying back debt from the public, the Administration contends, is to pump trillions of dollars into the bank accounts of individual investors. These investors would then be able to lend the money to businesses for investment in new plants and equipment. The process would increase the nation's savings rate, channeling less money into consumption and more into investment.
Mr. Sperling repeats the economists' mantra that the only real way to prepare for the retirement of the baby boomers is to save and invest, thereby building up the capacity of the economy to produce food, clothing and shelter.
Mr. Clinton could have slipped the charge of double counting if he had proposed doing nothing with the expected surpluses other than to buy back debt. That would be the preference of many other economists.
But the Administration believes that Congress would never sit back and let trillions of dollars slip by without siphoning them away for public programs or tax cuts. So Mr. Clinton devised a backup plan, channeling most of the surplus to Social Security. That would commit those dollars to support the elderly sometime in the future. And it would block their use for tax cuts or programs.
Mr. Clinton's choices are not the only responsible ones. They may not even be the best. But they raise no issue of budget deceit.

HEADLINE: T. C. Mann, 87, a Maker of U.S. Latin Policy

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Thomas C. Mann, a career diplomat and an architect of a switch to an American policy in Latin America in the 1960's that emphasized free enterprise, died last Saturday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 87.
Mr. Mann's appointment by President Johnson to a high State Department post shortly after the death of President Kennedy was seen as a signal to Kennedy loyalists that the new Administration was going to switch to policies in Latin America that focused on the interests of American and local businesses. Former policies had emphasized the promotion of democracy. 
 On Dec. 14, 1963, just three weeks after Kennedy's assassination, Johnson named Mr. Mann as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Johnson's first major appointment. Four days later Johnson named Mr. Mann to the additional post of special assistant to the President.
The historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., a Kennedy adherent, praised Mr. Mann for one aspect of his Latin American policy, his opposition to the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961, recalling that "he thought it was nonsense."
But Mr. Schlesinger faulted him for the way he carried out Johnson's policies in Latin America.
Under Johnson and Mr. Mann, Mr. Schlesinger wrote in "Robert Kennedy and His Times," many of the political and social components of the Alliance for Progress, a program aimed at helping Latin American countries attain democracy and improve living conditions, were removed. Much of what remained, he wrote, was converted "into an instrumentality for North American corporations."
Robert M. Sayre, who served on the National Security Council and was Ambassador to Uruguay, Panama and Brazil, defended his friend and colleague against some of Mr. Schlesinger's statements.
"I don't think he was Tex-Mex," Mr. Sayre said, explaining that the term was once used in the Government to describe those who had a low opinion of Latin American capabilities. He pointed to Mr. Mann's bilingual upbringing along the United States-Mexican border at Laredo and his experience as Ambassador to Mexico and El Salvador as evidence of his affection for the area.
Prof. Walter LaFeber, a Cornell University historian, wrote that Mr. Mann's career "is a case study of how the United States moved from Good Neighbor to the overt use of military power in the hemisphere."
"Mann was by no means primarily responsible for the devolution," Mr. LaFeber wrote, but said it illustrated the way a Washington policy shift originated and developed.
Mr. Mann played important foreign policy roles involving many countries. In 1964 he arranged help for Eduardo Frei Montalva, a moderate, in defeating Salvador Allende Gossens, a Socialist, to become President of Chile. Mr. Allende won the next election, in 1970, and died in a Washington-backed coup that overthrew his Government in 1973.
Also in 1964, Professor LaFeber wrote, Mr. Mann supported military officers after they overthrew the President of Brazil, Joao Goulart, whom he viewed as "an inept President, easily influenced by leftist advisers and cronies."
In 1965, Johnson, at Mr. Mann's urging, sent 22,800 troops to the Dominican Republic to put down what Washington regarded as a Communist threat. That action led to opposition in Congress and Mr. Mann's replacement in the inter-American post in 1966. By then, Mr. LaFeber wrote, "Thomas Mann's policies were the future of U.S. policies in Latin America."
Mr. Mann once said in an interview that he had learned Spanish before English. In high school he stood out as a scholar and quarterback, taking Laredo to an undefeated season in 1927.
Mr. Mann's son, the Rev. Clifton A. Mann, said his father graduated from Baylor University in 1934 with a bachelor's and a law degree and practiced law in Texas until the United States entered World War II.
"After Pearl Harbor he went to take his physical and flunked it because of his eyes, and was despondent," Father Mann said. At that point Mr. Mann saw an advertisement recruiting Spanish-speaking lawyers and wound up working for the Office of Economic Warfare, posted in Uruguay. Professor LaFeber said one of Mr. Mann's jobs had been to monitor Nazi shipping in the South Atlantic.
At the close of the war, Mr. Mann transferred to the Foreign Service, where he spent the rest of his government career, retiring in 1966. He was president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association from 1967 to 1971.
Mr. Mann's wife of 64 years, Nancy, died in 1997. He is survived by his son, Father Mann, an Episcopal priest in Lubbock, Tex.; six granddaughters, and three great-granddaughters.
"My dad was Lyndon Johnson's first appointment, and that caused him a lot of pain," Father Mann said. "He was perceived to be a political figure when he was, in fact, a diplomat."

HEADLINE: Linwood P. Shipley, 93, Investment Banker

 BODY:
Linwood Parks Shipley, a partner in the investment banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, died in Summit, N.J., on Tuesday. He was 93.
Mr. Shipley, who was born in 1905 in Cockeysville, Md., graduated from the University of Maryland. He began his banking career in 1927 at the National City Company, the forerunner of Citibank. He joined Brown Brothers six years later as a research economist and was made a partner in 1953. 
 Among other things, Mr. Shipley supervised the lending business of Brown Brothers and its operations in such far-flung locales as East Asia, the Middle East, Scandinavia and Ireland.
He was a member of several corporate boards, including that of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company.
Mr. Shipley had lived in Hightstown, N.J., since 1990. His wife, Emily, died in 1993.
He is survived by four children: L. Parks Shipley Jr. of St. Michaels, Md.; Frederick H. Shipley of Ripley, W. Va.; Emily Shipley Davis of Ottawa, and Walter V. Shipley, the chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, of Summit, N.J. Mr. Shipley is also survived by 10 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: L. C. Lewin, Writer of Satire Of Government Plot, Dies at 82

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

 BODY:
Leonard C. Lewin, whose Vietnam-era satire of a supposed secret Government study on the dangers of peace, "Report From Iron Mountain," resurfaced nearly 30 years later as proof of Government conspiracies for right-wing paramilitary groups, died on Thursday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 82 lived in Guilford, Conn.
"Report From Iron Mountain," supposedly the work of a topsecret 15-member study group that concluded that even if lasting peace "could be achieved, it would almost certainly not be in the best interests of society to achieve it," caused a sensation when it was published in the fall of 1967. By the next year, it was on the best-seller list of The New York Times. 
 Peace would be catastrophic, the report said in deadpan bureaucratese, unless there was extensive planning to replace the many benefits of war. It was possible that a "sophisticated form of slavery," together with "blood games" might have to be introduced.
Deliberately poisoning the atmosphere, the parody went on, "in a politically acceptable manner" or inventing enemies from another planet might be necessary to maintain social cohesion. The end of war would require some other form of wasteful spending to support the economy, possibly an unlimited space program aimed at reaching unreachable points in space.
The hoax that would not die began one day in 1967 when Victor Navasky and a few other editors of Monocle, a humor magazine that is now defunct, noticed a short newspaper report describing how the stock market had tumbled because of a "peace scare."
It was the height of the Vietnam War. Savoring the Swiftian implications, Mr. Navasky, now the editor of The Nation, and the others began tossing around the idea that Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and the other famously hard-nosed intellectuals brought into Government by President John F. Kennedy had commissioned one of their studies -- research organizations like the Rand Corporation and the Hudson Institute were all the vogue then -- on the threat of peace.
Mr. Lewin, an accomplished political satirist, produced the supposed report, complete with footnotes, most of them from other reports by the Government or research organizations, and a tribute to the "methods" of Herman Kahn of the Hudson Institute that allowed thinking about war without "getting bogged down in questions of morality."
Other plotters included E. L. Doctorow, then an editor at Dial Press, later the author of "Ragtime" and other novels, and the publishing house's president, Richard Baron, who listed the 109 page work as nonfiction and was to turn aside questions about its authenticity by citing the footnotes.
Debate immediately raged about whether the "Report From Iron Mountain" was real.
"One informed source confirmed," U.S. News and World Report said in its Nov. 20, 1967, issue, "that the 'Special Study Group,' " as the book called it, was set up by a top official in the Kennedy Administration. The source added that the report was drafted and eventually submitted to President Lyndon B. Johnson, who was said to have 'hit the roof' -- and then ordered that the report be bottled up for all time."
Trans-Action, an influential journal of the period, devoted an entire issue to the debate over the book. Esquire published a 28,000-word excerpt. John Kenneth Galbraith got into the act with a book review in The Washington Post under a pseudonym vouching for the book's authenticity and the validity of its conclusions but expressing reservations about releasing it "to an obviously unconditioned public."
But in 1972, Mr. Lewin finally confessed that he had made up the report. The "Pentagon Papers," the secret history of the Vietnam War, had been published, Mr. Lewin wrote in The New York Times Book Review, and were "as outrageous, morally and intellectually" as his own invention,
"The charade is over," he wrote. "Some of the documents read like parodies of Iron Mountain, rather than the reverse."
Mr. Lewin, a graduate of Harvard University, came to writing after stints as a labor organizer in New England and work in his father's sugar refinery in Indianapolis.
His marriages to Iris Zinn Lewin and Eve Merriam, a poet, playwright and children's book author, ended in divorce. He is survived by his daughter, Julie Lewin of West Hartford, Conn., a son, Michael Z. Lewin of Frome, England, and his longtime companion, Lorraine Davis of Manhattan.
"Report from Iron Mountain" went out of print in 1980, but a few years ago Mr. Lewin was startled to get a request from a white supremacist group in Arkansas wanting to buy any old copies. Then he discovered that the Liberty Lobby, a far-right group, was offering copies of the book as a genuine Government report. His insistence that he had written the book only reinforced the belief among the paramilitary groups that it was a real secret document.
Mr. Lewin successfully sued the Liberty Lobby, which asserted that that there was no copyright for the book because it was a Government document. Neither side would reveal the full terms of the settlement, but Mr. Lewin received more than a thousand copies of the bootlegged version.
Pirated copies -- some of a new edition published by Simon & Schuster's imprint, Free Press -- are still in circulation, along with a six-hour videotape version. Simon & Schuster has been trying to stop right-wing groups from posting versions of the book on their Internet sites under the guise of a Government document.

HEADLINE: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT FAST 5.6% RATE AT THE END OF '98

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
A year of pleasant economic surprises ended with the biggest one of all: a last-minute burst of growth that surpassed even the most bullish predictions.
America's gross domestic product -- the total of goods and services produced -- surged at a 5.6 percent annual rate in the final quarter of 1998. That is the fastest pace in two years and made 1998 the third consecutive year that the economy had expanded at a nearly 4 percent pace. For all of 1998, the G.D.P. increased 3.9 percent. 
 Despite the go-go growth, inflation was reminiscent of the 50's. After running around 1 percent earlier in the year, it slipped to eight-tenths of a percent -- the lowest in more than 40 years.
"We keep getting stronger growth and less inflation pressure," said John Williams, chief economist at the Bankers Trust Corporation. "At the moment there seems to be nothing to get in the way."
As recently as last October the talk was about a possible recession -- financial markets were quaking, growth in many parts of the world was slowing, or nonexistent, and America's farm and energy industries were slumping. But amid these negative signs, American corporations were pouring billions into new technology, consumers were buying cars and other expensive products, and exporters, who had been struggling all year as markets in Asia and Latin America headed south, saw their overseas sales snap back.
To be sure, some of the fourth-quarter's strength reflected one-time events -- the General Motors Corporation catching up after its strike, the Boeing Company making aircraft deliveries, construction crews taking advantage of unseasonably warm weather -- and most economists expect the latest figures to be trimmed a bit when more data become available and the G.D.P. report is revised next month. But with sales soaring, inventories lean and no sign of inflation, there seemed little question that the economy barreled into the new year with terrific momentum.
"I don't see anything that could trigger recession in 1999," said William Dunkelberg, chief economist at the National Federation for Independent Business, who noted that business spending and hiring plans remained strong.
Christopher Low, the chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets, said, "Typically, when we have inventories weaker than expected and demand stronger than expected, that portends stronger growth down the road."
As usual, consumers accounted for most of the growth last year. Consumer spending rose at a strong 4.4 percent in the fourth quarter and 4.8 percent for the year, even though unseasonably warm temperatures meant lower heating bills. Purchases of cars and big-ticket items for homes soared at a 21 percent annual rate. Earlier this month, G.M., the Ford Motor Company and other car makers reported that December sales were running at an annual rate of more than 17 million cars and trucks a month, up 7 percent from a year earlier. New home construction rose at a 10 percent annual rate. Consumers and home buyers have not spent this freely since right after the 1981-82 recession.
There's no sign that they are flagging either. Unemployment and interest rates are at the lowest level in decades, after-tax income jumped 4 percent last year after inflation, and a rebounding stock market is swelling household balance sheets once more.
Consumers are feeling pretty good, too. The University of Michigan reported yesterday that its consumer confidence index, based on surveys of consumers, rose to a lofty 103.9 at the end of January from 100.5 in December. The index reflects consumers' positive assessment of current economic conditions and their optimism about the future.
Less expected was the big bounceback in business spending for new equipment, especially computers and other high-technology products. Capital goods spending, which had leveled out last summer, soared at a 21 percent annual rate as businesses, facing the tightest labor market in a generation, scrambled to improve efficiency and keep costs under control. Meanwhile, businesses increased their stocks at a slower rate than in the third quarter as they struggled to keep up with sales, a favorable development that suggests they will not be cutting production in the months ahead.
The drag from America's $263 billion trade deficit proved less potent than one might expect. While imports shot up in the fall, so did exports. The trade deficit worsened last year, with imports shooting 10.8 percent higher and exports growing only 1.5 percent, the weakest in 15 years.
In retrospect, it seems clear that the economy's surprising stamina, particularly the strength in consumer spending, reflects at least three developments that few forecasters could have predicted a year ago: a sharp decline in inflation from 2 percent to 1 percent; another big run-up, more than 25 percent, in the stock market, and the Federal Reserve's willingness to reduce interest rates last fall in response to global financial turmoil when the domestic economy was showing few signs of slowing. All three factors bolstered incomes and spending power. "We were getting this injection of adrenalin," said Robert Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University.
Investors agreed, sending stock and bond prices higher yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 77.5 points, to 9,358.83, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index hit a new high of 1,279.64 after climbing 14.27 points.
And President Clinton, speaking at a meeting of the nation's mayors, cited the strong economy, noting that it continued to defy conventional economic wisdom, and that even his own advisers had once again proved too pessimistic.
The Commerce Under Secretary, Robert J. Shapiro, proclaimed these "the best economic times in living memory."
In fact, in December the economic recovery that started in April 1991 became the longest in peacetime history. The only expansion to last longer was the 60's boom, from 1961 to 1969, which coincided with the Vietnam War buildup and which was accompanied by large Federal deficits and mounting inflationary pressures, both of which are now absent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Surge in 1998's G.D.P. Pushes Market Gauges Up
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 14.27 points, or 1.13 percent, to a record 1,279.64, after the Government announced a surprising surge in United States economic growth.
Other market gauges also soared. The Nasdaq composite index surpassed 2,500 points for the first time, increasing 28.55 points, to 2,505.89, and wrapping up its biggest monthly gain in 24 years. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 77.50 points, to 9,358.83, with I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard accounting for almost half of the gain. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.08 percent, from 5.10 percent on Thursday. Page C3.
 
The nation's gross domestic product increased at a 5.6 percent annual rate in the final quarter of 1998. This marked the fastest pace in two years and made 1998 the third consecutive year that the economy had expanded at a nearly 4 percent pace. A1.
 
Several Airlines Increase Fares
Several major airlines, including Delta and Northwest, announced across-the-board fare increases, which if successful would be the first in more than two years. But some airlines had not gone along with the price increases as of late yesterday, indicating that their success was far from assured. C2.
 
Microsoft Data Public, Court Rules
A Federal appeals court has decided that all the deposition transcripts and videotapes in the Microsoft antitrust trial must be made public. That includes the 20 hours of taped deposition testimony of William H. Gates, the chairman of the software giant, as well as about 100 other depositions taken by the Government or the company. C2.
 
Breakthrough in Banana Fight
After five days of intense wrangling, members of the World Trade Organization reached a compromise in a politically charged dispute over bananas between the United States and European Union, averting a major rift at least for now. C2.
 
Vice President Al Gore told the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos, Switzerland, that the financial crisis of 1998 could become "the trade crisis of 1999," and said the United States would seek the elimination of enormous subsidies that European nations provide to their farmers. A5.
 
S.E.C. Halts Trades of USA Talks
The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in the shares of the start-up Internet telephony company USA Talks.com after they almost quadrupled in less than a month, to a market value of $1.3 billion. The agency said questions had been raised about "the accuracy and adequacy of public information" about the company, including questions about the status and extent of its business operations. C3.
 
Kellogg's Earnings Drop 40%
Shares of Kellogg fell $1.4375, to $40.625, after it said fourth-quarter profit excluding one-time adjustments fell more than 40 percent, reflecting stiffer competition and less consumer appetite for cereal. The results were in line with analysts' estimates, which had been revised downward more than once. Kellogg's chief executive, Arnold G. Langbo, conceded that "our financial results are disappointing." C2.
 
Nokia Profits Rise 72% in Quarter
The cellular phone maker Nokia reported a 72 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings, topping analysts' expectations. The Finnish company's profit rose to 3.474 billion markkaa ($666 million), or 6.09 markkaa a share. Analysts had expected a net profit of 3.2 billion markkaa. C2.
 
Sony May Sell Music on the Internet
Sony Music Entertainment is studying a plan to allow Internet users to download music for a fee and record it onto minidisks. C2.

HEADLINE: For Radio City Restoration, a $2.5 Million Sales Tax Break

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
As a part of Rockefeller Center, where the rents for prime retail space are now on a par with Madison Avenue, Radio City Music Hall may not seem to be situated in a blighted neighborhood.
Recently, however, the Empire State Development Corporation approved a sales tax exemption of up to $2.5 million for the operators of the landmark theater as an incentive for them to spend $66 million on renovations. 
 A report from the development agency said the tax break was justified, in part, because the "area in which the project is to be located is a substandard or unsanitary area, or in danger of becoming" such an area.
The size of the sales tax break is minuscule in comparison with the total $111.7 million in real estate tax exemptions that the city has given Madison Square Garden since 1983 to keep the Knicks and Rangers from leaving New York. But some local officials have questioned why Cablevision Systems, the parent company of Madison Square Garden, which also manages Radio City Entertainment, deserves this latest gift from the state.
"Cablevision is not saying that it will move Radio City to the Meadowlands," said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Democrat of Manhattan. "This is a prize property that is going to become much more profitable for them when they do the technological upgrade. They don't need any incentive to do this job."
Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for the Empire State Development Corporation, said the sales tax exemption was appropriate because the company was making a major investment in a national landmark. She also said that at least 50 new jobs would be created at Radio City, which already employs 1,800 people. The tax relief plan was developed after Radio City's operators requested state assistance, she said.
"We look at these projects on a case by case basis," Ms. Quartararo said. "In the case of Radio City Music Hall, you have a private company investing tens of millions of dollars in a landmark theater. It's appropriate for them to receive some assistance."
She said the reference to "a substandard or unsanitary area" was a reminder of harsher times two decades ago when Radio City was nearly closed. "That's why we're being proactive in this case," she said.
Cablevision also defended the tax break on economic grounds and said it would probably not amount to more than $1.6 million. The project will include the restoration of the theater's blocklong marquee and its backstage hydraulic system.
"A restored Radio City Music Hall will be a showplace for the world while generating tens of millions of dollars in state and local taxes as well as hundreds of millions of dollars in associated economic spinoff," Kenneth W. Munoz, an executive vice president of Madison Square Garden, said in a statement. "This is the very kind of project in which the city and state economic development agencies regularly and properly participate." He declined further comment.
Under the plan, approved on Nov. 18, Radio City Music Hall would be leased to the Empire State Development Corporation, which in turn would sublease it back to Radio City Entertainment during the renovation and for 10 years afterward. The construction materials and equipment, fixtures and furniture acquired for the renovation would be exempt from sales tax, for a saving the state development corporation estimated would amount to $2.5 million.
This type of arrangement permits a private company to be treated as a tax-exempt government entity, said Frank J. Mauro, the executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Latham, N.Y. He questioned whether it was appropriate to favor one theater over its competitors. "This is clearly government interfering in the free market," Mr. Mauro said.
In addition to the sales tax exemption, Radio City Entertainment may also get a discount of as much as 20 percent on its electric bills. The New York Power Authority is holding talks with the company and the city to determine whether the discount should be offered because new jobs would be created, said Laurence W. Frech, a spokesman for the power authority.
When its property taxes were eliminated, Madison Square Garden was also given a break on its electric bills from Consolidated Edison, amounting to $200,000 to $500,000 a year, a Madison Square Garden official said.

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
U.S. Would Send Troops To Help Kosovo Cease-Fire
President Clinton's top national security advisers decided that the United States should commit several thousand ground troops to an international force in Kosovo to monitor an eventual cease-fire there, according to Administration officials and members of Congress. The tentative plan would involve 2,000 to 5,000 American troops in a NATO force of more than 20,000 ground troops. A1 

The United States, four Western European nations and Russia, in an unusual show of unity, summoned the warring sides in Kosovo to a peace conference in France next Friday and suggested that if they did not reach agreement within two weeks, air strikes would follow. NATO is expected to vote today to authorize air strikes against the Serbs if they do not agree to a political settlement of autonomy for Kosovo. A6
 
Serbian police killed 24 ethnic Albanians in a raid on a suspected rebel hideout, adding urgency to an international demand that the antagonists settle the Kosovo crisis by mid-February or face NATO action. Later in the day, Yugoslav army tanks began firing on rebel Kosovo Liberation Army positions near a village of a half-dozen homes nine miles north of Pristina, the capital of Kosovo. A6
 
Riots Slow Colombia Recovery
Army and police units clashed repeatedly with bands of looters in Armenia, slowing the delivery of relief supplies to tens of thousands of residents made homeless by the big earthquake on Monday. The gangs, composed almost entirely of young men, struck early and often until the authorities were able to restore order through a show of force and numerous arrests. Away from the downtown area, scarred by dozens of damaged and collapsed buildings, relief efforts finally appeared to be moving into high gear, after four days of confusion and complaints. A3
 
Warning on the World Economy
Vice President Al Gore warned that the world had to "prevent the financial crisis of 1998 from becoming the trade crisis of 1999," and said the United States would seek to negotiate the "outright elimination" of the huge and politically sensitive subsidies that European nations provide farmers. Mr. Gore's statement was his first detailed speech on the fragility of the world economy. A5
 
U.S. to Toughen Libya Policy
Clinton Administration officials say they are planning to seek tougher sanctions against Libya because there has been no sign of cooperation a month before an American deadline for Libya to hand over two suspects in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in 1988. A3

Ms. Woodward, 20, may not profit from selling her story, and any money she gains in connection with the case must go to UNICEF, the charity of her choice. Several major airlines made across-the-board increases in their fares. Industry stock prices soared on the apparent belief that a price increase would finally stick. C2
