HEADLINE: SPRING-SUMMER CRUISES;
Cruise Lines' Mantra: More, More

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL; EDWIN McDOWELL, a business reporter for The Times, covers the travel industry.

 BODY:
DURING the Persian Gulf war almost a decade ago, cruise lines hastily improvised alternative itineraries while moving their ships as fast and as far away from the war zone as possible. Within days, the Mediterranean was being referred to in cruising circles as the Dead Sea. But last month's bombing of Iraq by the United States and Britain created scarcely a ripple.
This time most ships had already moved from the Mediterranean to the Caribbean for the start of the winter cruise season, and the sustained bombing of Iraq lasted only a few days. If peace prevails, a record number of cruise ships are expected in the Mediterranean and elsewhere in Europe this year, including the 2,600-passenger Grand Princess, the 2,000-passenger Norway, the recently lengthened 1,748-passenger Norwegian Dream and the 1,800-passenger Legend of the Seas. And if the economy cooperates, the industry is likely to achieve its 10th consecutive year of ever-increasing numbers of passengers. 
 Indeed, even taking into account the recent stock market jitters, a recent forecast by cruise analysts at Bear, Stearns & Company estimates this year's passenger growth at 10 to 11 percent. If that turns out to be the case, that would put the number of passengers at about six million -- and within hailing distance of the seven million passengers in 2000 forecast by the Cruise Lines International Association.
Still unclear is what effect the several setbacks last year will have on the industry this year. These included a fire aboard Carnival's Ecstasy last summer (in which there were no casualties), the Monarch of the Seas' striking a reef in St. Maarten harbor in mid-December and having to cancel 12 cruises (she is scheduled to resume sailing March 14) and postponement of the inaugural voyage of the Disney Wonder, Disney's second ship, from March to Aug. 15, toward the end of the traditional summer cruise season. (Delivery of the first Disney ship, the Disney Magic, was postponed twice last year, forcing cancellation of 40 cruises.)
The industry was also shaken by two recent articles in The New York Times. The first, published in November, examined the growing concern about crime -- particularly allegations of sexual assaults by crew members -- aboard cruise ships, which operate largely outside the laws of any one country. The second, published early this month, detailed how Royal Caribbean knowingly broke the law by dumping oily waste into the ocean, then argued (to no avail) that a private company doing business in the United States was immune from criminal prosecution because its ships fly foreign flags.
"There were six months of bad news," said Michael Driscoll, editor of Cruise Week, which is widely read by travel agents. "The industry is worried, and I'm curious to see what impact that will have on the cruise business this year."
On the positive side, passengers continue to give cruising high marks. And many travel agents, who collectively book more than 90 percent of all cruises, have vowed to redouble efforts to sell even more berths, to offset income lost by the latest round of commission caps imposed by the airlines last November.
In addition, the popularity of each new big ship seems to confirm the decision by cruise line officials to compete with resorts, amusement parks, beach towns and ski resorts. Most new big ships, for example, have elegant restaurants and boutiques, luxury spas, high-tech fitness rooms, water slides, conference and meeting rooms, theaters featuring large-cast productions, pubs, playrooms and computer rooms, as well as casinos as glitzy as some in Las Vegas.
And there is more to come. Royal Caribbean's 142,000-ton Voyager of the Seas, scheduled for delivery this fall, will have a full-sized basketball court and ice-skating rink, a rock-climbing wall, a minigolf course, a theater five decks high, a $1 million sea-water aquarium, a wedding chapel and the world's biggest roulette wheel. The Cunard Line's first new ship in about 30 years, tentatively promised in about 2002, will have many of the above amenities plus a microbrewery and the world's biggest maritime museum.
Because cruise ships have not yet figured out how to equip their vessels with actual golf courses, Crystal's Symphony and Harmony have a total of nine cruises this year ranging from 11 to 16 days that provide guaranteed tee times at 21 notable golf courses in the Mediterranean, the British Isles, Central America and the Caribbean. (The first cruise was scheduled to sail Jan. 25; the remainder, including six aboard the Symphony, will sail beginning Aug. 10.)
Still, many cruise passengers prefer smaller ships, including the smaller ones still in the fleets of Carnival, Princess and Royal Caribbean, the three cruise lines that have led the big-ship boom. Holland America's largest ships, including three scheduled for delivery by next year, do not exceed about 1,400 passengers. Crystal's three ships carry about 850 passengers, while Renaissance Cruises plans to build five 690-passenger ships in the next two years.
Silverseas Cruises is building two ships of 290 passengers, while Radisson Seven Seas, only one of whose five ships carries more than 320 passengers, plans to add four more by 2004. Its 320-passenger Paul Gauguin, which went into service last year in French Polynesia, had a 90 percent year-round occupancy, an especially high percentage for a first-year operation and doubly so for a luxury ship with luxury prices. All three Seabourn luxury ships have a capacity of just 204 passengers.
Meantime, other small-ship cruise lines including Windstar, American Canadian Caribbean, Windjammer Barefoot Cruises, Classical Cruises and Clipper Cruise Line offer wide-ranging itineraries for the growing niche markets. Classical's 48-passenger Halcyon, for example, is offering the first and only cruise dedicated to Tunisia, from the Mediterranean to the Sahara, while the 122-passenger Clipper Adventurer will tour both the "bottom of the world," including Antarctica, South Georgia and the Falklands, and the "top of the world," including Greenland, the Arctic and Maritime Canada. Linblad Special Expeditions, a pioneer in out-of-the-way cruising, is offering year-round 10-day voyages from Guayaquil, Ecuador, to the Galapagos Islands aboard the 80-passenger Polaris.
The Caribbean (including Bermuda, which is really in the Atlantic) remains the most popular cruise destination, attracting 46.2 percent of the market. But its share has fallen from 50.5 percent in 1996, in part because the industry has expanded its range and itineraries, while the combined share of European and Caribbean cruises has climbed steadily into second place with 19.6 percent, followed by Alaska with 8.4 percent.
More than 20 cruise lines will sail the Mediterranean and elsewhere in Europe this year, some of them from April to November, about a month longer than in most other years. Celebrity will visit the Mediterranean for the first time, its 1,750-passenger Century sailing 11-night to 14-night cruises between April and October.
Many Americans who choose European cruises have previously sailed the Caribbean, often several times, and readily pay fares 35 to 40 percent higher than for Caribbean cruises of comparable length. Most of them seek the rich cultural mix readily available in European ports or through land packages sold by the cruise ships.
While often criticized as overpriced, the land packages have made more of Europe available to more cruise passengers. Princess, for example, is enhancing its seven 12-day Mediterranean sailings this year with pre- and postcruise tours covering Germany, Austria and Switzerland; Paris, Bordeaux and the Loire Valley, and Italy and the Swiss Alps, including Venice, Milan, St. Moritz, the Matterhorn, Montreux and Geneva. Classical Cruises' 12-day Mediterranean cruise, departing Lisbon on April 11, has a two-night precruise package tour of Lisbon and a two-night postcruise extension in Athens. Orient Lines and Costa Cruises also have extensive Mediterranean cruises and land packages.
Alaska, too, is drawing more passengers. The number of passengers expected to sail on cruises in Alaska is 568,000, up from 373,000 in 1994. This year Holland America and Princess Cruises, the industry leaders, will each sail six ships to Alaska, with 118 and 104 departures respectively, one more than their combined total of 221 last year last year. Norwegian Cruise Line's two ships in Alaska this year will depart from Vancouver, as do most cruise ships, but next year its Norwegian Sky, currently under construction, will become the first big ship with regular cruises to depart from Seattle.
A half-dozen small ships will also sail to or within Alaska this year, including seven from Alaska Sightseeing/Cruise West and two 12-passenger ships from Alaska Yacht Safaris. Although Holland America's Noordam will start the large-ship parade north when she departs Vancouver May 7, three small ships will depart in April. The first of those, Alaska Sightseeing's Spirit of Glacier Bay, will set sail April 10 on an 11-day Seattle to Juneau cruise.
Finally, while southern Florida remains the home port for most major cruise lines, occasional or seasonal cruises are steadily increasing from a variety of other ports. Celebrity will have 11 cruises this spring and summer from Charleston and Newport News, Va., and will replace its Celebration in Tampa with the 2,600-passenger Carnival Sensation, which will sail weekly to Grand Cayman, Playa del Carmen, Cozumel and New Orleans. The Norwegian Majesty will sail from Boston to St. George, Bermuda, every Sunday from April 11 through Oct. 17, while the Norwegian Sea is offering year-round seven-day cruises from Houston to Cancun, Cozumel and Roatan, a Bay Island off the coast of Honduras. One or more major cruise ships will also sail this season from New York, New Orleans, Galveston, Honolulu, Palm Beach and San Diego.
For passengers within driving distance of those "satellite ports," such cruises can be a great convenience. For the cruise lines, which are not likely to loosen their ties to south Florida anytime soon, they are a way to generate interest in cruising among the estimated 89 percent of American adults who, according to Bear, Stearns, have not yet signed on.

HEADLINE: Cuba Draws the Curious, Despite the Law

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO; MIREYA NAVARRO is chief of the Miami bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
AT the Marina Hemingway, a complex of hotels, restaurants and shops in Havana, the grocery store's shelves are stacked with Kellogg's Corn Flakes and Rice Krispies, Nestle chocolate bars and American cigarettes. English is spoken along the aisles. The sights and sounds are so familiar that Americans may have to remind themselves that they are in Cuba.
A popular playground for Americans before the revolution, Cuba has been off limits to tourists from the United States for most of Fidel Castro's four-decade-old rule. Under restrictions imposed by the American economic embargo, now in its 37th year, only certain travelers -- including journalists, Government officials and those visiting close family once a year for humanitarian reasons -- can visit Cuba, spending up to $100 a day for living expenses. In addition, travelers can apply for a specific license to go if they have a religious or educational purpose, for example. 
 Anybody else is banned from spending money under the Trading with the Enemy Act, which in practice deters travel. But while the embargo has minimized American tourism, more Americans have found ways to visit since limited free-market reforms adopted by Cuba in the 1990's legalized the dollar.
Since Pope John Paul II's visit last year, the number of American religious and academic groups wanting to visit has skyrocketed, some travel agencies say. Bob Guild, program director for Marazul Tours in Weehawken, N.J., said his agency has booked 45 such groups just this month, which are traveling legally under Federal licenses, compared to five or six groups during the same period in past years. Neither Cuban nor American officials have estimates of American visitors, saying the number is difficult to gauge because of unauthorized travel.
At any given time, 9 out of 10 boats at Marina Hemingway come from the United States. Americans traveling through third countries like Jamaica on package tours can often be found at the Tropicana, the legendary outdoor nightclub where Las Vegas-type chorus girls dance with chandeliers on their heads to Cuban rhythms. In Varadero, Cuba's premier tourist beach area, the high-end hotels also draw American visitors seeking respite from the decay and hardship that are now staples of this socialist country of about 11 million people.
"Curiosity -- that's what brings everybody," said a 55-year-old boater and construction worker from Key West anchored at the Marina Hemingway for two months, on his third visit since last year. He refused to give his name. "You just want to go visit places and see what it's like."
What Cuba is like can best be described as a time warp. The ride from the Jose Marti International Airport into Havana offers a surreal sight: roads populated by bicycles and 1950's Cadillacs, some decrepit but many in mint condition; billboards filled with revolutionary slogans; the utter absence of fast-food franchises or chain hotels.
In Old Havana, unpainted, sometimes crumbling colonial architecture remains magnificent. And an excursion to the countryside, to places like the Vinales Valley in the Pinar del Rio Province and to beaches and mountains unspoiled by development, makes a visitor feel just plain lucky.
Travel throughout the island is unrestricted; visitors can get around by bus, train, airplane and car. Public transportation is overwhelmed by demand, but tours are available and visitors can also rent a car, or hire a driver with a car.
Some Americans visiting for the first time say they are struck by the friendliness of people and the lack of abject poverty they have found in places such as Africa and India.
"Everyone had shoes, everyone had clothes on their backs," said a 32-year-old Miami woman who traveled illegally through Nassau recently and stayed with the family of a Cuban-American friend. "We didn't see starving people."
But there is also the economic need that makes Cuba ration rice, sugar and other staples for residents and that leads even professionals to moonlight as drivers and "jineteras," Cuba's prostitutes, who are the draw for a thriving sex tourism industry. A heavy-handed Government provides amenities for tourists that the Cuban people can only dream of.
This can all translate into deeply unsettling experiences for a visitor. It is not uncommon, for instance, to dine at a nice restaurant next to kissing couples, teen-aged girls and men three or four times their age, or to have Cuban friends suffer the humiliation of being denied entry to hotels, even to the lobby for a visit. American officials call it "tourism apartheid," but Cuban officials say they are trying to promote equality among Cubans by not allowing special privileges to those with dollars (sent by relatives in the United States or earned by working for tourists).
Dollars, however, are sometimes of no use in the face of shortages. Meat and fresh vegetables can be hard to come by even at better restaurants, and many items taste as if they were cooked in lard.
Havana has a wide range of restaurants and fast-food cafeterias, and outside the capital most hotels have restaurants, all catering to the dollar-carrying customer.
The quality of service varies wildly, with hotel staffs ranging from efficient and friendly to slow and surly. Worn-out carpets and mismatched furniture can be found in some of the highly-rated hotels in Havana, such as the Capri, and hours-long power outages are not uncommon. One hotel in Matanzas, near Varadero, shuts off the water for most of the day. By comparison, Varadero's luxury resorts, the product of Government joint ventures with private companies from countries such as Spain, Germany and Canada, seem like a step into the First World. Almost everything is imported, from fruits and meats to tools, and the feeling is one of pampered comfort.
Cuba is relatively cheap; the most expensive hotels often charge less than $200 a night, depending on the season. Prices can be even lower if a visitor sidesteps the Government infrastructure and deals directly with Cuban solo entrepreneurs. Unauthorized drivers, for instance, charge much less than metered taxis, although many of the cars are not air-conditioned and some seem to be falling apart. Lodging with a family and taking meals at "paladares" -- private restaurants in the owners' homes -- can offer higher quality at lower prices than hotels and bigger restaurants. And because of a thriving black market, it is possible to get Cuban cigars at bargain prices. (Almost every Cuban one encounters claims to know somebody at a cigar factory, but the product can be junk, and tourists are often warned to buy tobacco only at Government stores.)
Before the Communist revolution, Americans made up the largest tourist bloc visiting Cuba. Now Canadians and Europeans have filled the void. Tourism, which the Government began building up in the 1990's, has steadily increased to 1.4 million visitors in 1998, according to officials of Cuba's Tourism Ministry. If an ambitious target of two million visitors by the year 2000 is reached, they said, Cuba will have nearly doubled its tourism since 1996.
"We're bringing more tourists and the tourism infrastructure is also growing," said Manuel Garcia-Crespo, a tourism spokesman. The infrastructure is key at this point for an industry that is still in its infancy but that has become the largest source of foreign currency for Cuba, contributing about $1.8 billion a year to the island's economy, officials said. To accommodate the two million visitors Cuba hopes to attract at the turn of the century, it needs to increase hotel rooms to 34,000 from the current 28,000, Mr. Garcia-Crespo said.
Among the earliest and biggest private investors in Cuba's tourism industry is Spain's Sol Melia hotel chain, which co-owns with the Government four upscale hotels and manages several others; its investment on the island surpasses $55 million. Carlos Pereda-Navarro, general manager of Melia Las Americas in Varadero, considers Cuba an attractive investment because of Government support and the potential for growth. He said this more than compensates for such extra costs as having to import most goods.
"We're just beginning," said Mr. Pereda-Navarro, who has worked in Cuba for the past nine years. The potential would be even greater, he added, if Americans were free to travel to the island.
Mr. Garcia-Crespo said American travel was up but still relatively negligible.
Under regulations enforced by the Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control, travel to Cuba without a specific license is generally limited to Government officials and representatives of international organizations, journalists and those visiting close relatives. (Cuban-Americans on family visits make up the largest group of visiting Americans, numbering about 30,000 a year, United States Government figures show.) Since American carriers do not fly to Cuba, travelers usually go through third countries like Mexico, Canada and the Bahamas, although since last year many have been able to depart from Miami on authorized charter flights that reach Havana in about 40 minutes. In new steps announced this month, the Clinton Administration said it would authorize charter flights from additional United States cities to destinations in Cuba other than Havana.
For those traveling legally, there is a limit of $100 worth of goods such as cigars and rum brought back from Cuba. Because transactions are in cash -- Americans cannot use credit cards issued by American banks -- visitors often go over the spending limit with little risk of being caught. And Cuba enables illegal travel by waiving boating fees at marinas and not stamping passports at airports.
American officials say a big problem is illegal travel through third countries where weekend tour packages in Cuba are commonly offered. Also, they say, some United States-based organizations make travel possible under the guise of educational or cultural trips that are mostly tours.
"The policy is no tourism," an American official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said. "There are people who violate the law and a lot of people in the travel industry who promote this."
Although sailing to Cuba itself is not prohibited, paying for meals, transportation, lodging and mooring fees is, and returning passengers by air or vessel can be the subject of investigation by the United States Customs Service, Federal officials said. While enforcement has been lax, officials say it has become progressively easier over the years for the Government to penalize people for violations. In 1992 civil fines of up to $55,000 for each violation were instituted. The presumption is that a United States citizen traveling to Cuba has spent money there unless he can prove otherwise.
Criminal penalties for violating the travel restrictions are up to 10 years in prison and $250,000 in fines for an individual. There have been only 16 criminal prosecutions for Cuba travel violations under the Trading With the Enemy Act since 1983, officials said. But the Treasury Department has collected nearly $1.9 million in civil penalties for embargo violations in 379 separate cases over the last four years as of last September, most related to travel.
"The result is, this can ruin your vacation," the American official said. The United States Interests Section, the American diplomatic mission in Havana, does not refuse consular services such as replacing a lost passport to Americans traveling here illegally (unless the American was born in Cuba, in which case Cuba treats the person as a national and does not allow the Interests Section to get involved). But the diplomatic mission would also refer the case to Treasury for enforcement.
United States Government officials said their policy responds to concerns that override the desire American tourists may have to visit Cuba. "We're trying to get Cuba to make the reforms needed to avoid a chaotic transition when Castro falls, that would create a massive migrant wave," the American official said. But American officials also acknowledge that people almost invariably become more conciliatory toward Cuba, and opposed to the embargo, once they visit. "It creates a constituency," the American official said.
Some of those who flout the law say they do not care about politics. "People can come over, go out fishing and have a good time and it doesn't cost them a fortune," said the boater from Key West at Marina Hemingway, where boats from 30 to 50 feet long sport satellite dishes and American flags and sometimes anchor for months at a time. The American said he stood ready to defend his rights in court if ever prosecuted, arguing that it is unconstitutional for the United States to restrict Americans' right to travel.
"A lot of Americans come here basically because it's a beautiful country," he said.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
At Sea, Extras Can Add Up Fast

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
AS for the all-inclusive cruise: there is no such creature. No matter how high up the caviar chain is a cruise line, with Silversea and Seabourn probably at the top, there is always something to be paid for at the end.
A woman in the industry who took a seven-day Carnival cruise with a companion for $2,300, air fare included, paid $450 for extras. A reporter who took a $2,267 cruise of seven days on the Grand Princess, air fare included, paid $208 in extras, among them a $47.50 phone call, a $50 pedicure and $2.50 milkshake. 
 Whether the number of extra costs is increasing is a matter for debate. Readers have written that they believe more things aboard are for sale. Charges for ice-cream sodas aside, passengers' complaints often focus on pressure to buy: racks of cruise-logo jackets and other clothing are placed in the lobby, one letter-writer said; alcoholic beverages are offered at every turn, another said, and spa employees embarrass passengers into buying expensive products, according to still another. Two cruise-takers, Stanley and Arlene Harris of Brooklyn, spoke unhappily of a "bargain basement" atmosphere aboard one cruise.
Rick James, Princess Cruises' senior vice president for customer services, was asked about the Haagen-Dazs milkshake bought aboard the Grand Princess for $2.50 plus a 15 percent service charge. Mr. James thinks that the changing taste of customers is creating more of such extras aboard -- "boutique items," he calls them. "We always have free ice cream in our dining rooms," Mr. James said, "but if people want Haagen-Dazs, that's a specialty item."
"It's the same thing if you go into a hosted bar ashore," he said. "If you want a standard drink, it's free, but if you call for a brand, you will be paying something extra."
Stewart T. Chiron, vice president of the Cruise Line, a cruise-only agency in North Miami Beach, discussed whether on-board shops and boutiques, whose wares have never been included in the basic price, were flogging their merchandise too vigorously. "The gift shops must handle hordes of people," he said. "So rather than create a pile-up inside, they push racks outside. But it's not intrusive."
 
'People Love It'
Several people in the cruise business noted that shopping was a major part of travel these days. Fran Wenograd Golden, the cruise reporter for Travel Weekly, interviewed while aboard the Sea Princess, said that every day, the ship newsletter carried ads for things to buy. "But people love it," she said.
In a business that is increasingly competitive, the extras are important to cruise companies. Bob Dickinson, president of Carnival Cruise Lines, in his 1996 book "Selling the Sea," said the cruise lines added 10 to 20 percent to their bottom lines with on-board activities, including shore expeditions. And what is the biggest category on the list? Not the casino, Mr. Dickinson said in an interview, estimating that only about 30 percent of passengers visit casinos. Liquor and soft drinks, which cost extra on all but a couple of lines, are the biggest revenue producers.
In her new book "The Complete Idiot's Travel Guide to Cruise Vacations" (Alpha Books-Macmillan, $16.95), Ms. Golden said that typical prices were $1 for a soda and $2.95 and up for an alcoholic drink. In the interview, she said that every ship had a daily special cocktail, often a pina colada or other tropical choice, for around $3, and that prices for premium brands or at martini bars were much higher.
Mr. Dickinson said that his company's "sanity check" on its prices was to compare them with what was charged by on-shore resorts. "On our three- and four-day product," he said, "we compare prices with Disney and Universal Studios."
But cruise lines have a big added starter, Ms. Golden said, in ship-to-shore calls, which can run $7 to $15 a minute.
Other usual extra-cost items are baby-sitting; haircuts, facials and massages; dry-cleaning and laundry, and photographs. A new one, supporting Mr. James's contention that customer tastes are creating change, is cappuccino. Carnival has now added espresso bars. Aly Bello, a Carnival spokeswoman, sent along a menu for Cafe on the Way, with espresso at $1.50, cappuccino at $1.95 and a chocolate-covered strawberry at $1 (three for $2).
 
Day of Plastic Reckoning
Like Carnival, most cruise lines give the passenger a card that enables extra expenditures, including gambling, to be charged to the cabin. Charging gambling losses, like charging liquor, is a process that worries organizations that treat addictions, but it is markedly easier for the cruise ship to operate as a cashless society. The reckoning comes on the last day, when the charges on the card must be cleared, often on a credit card.
Usually, Mr. Chiron of the Cruise Line said, the passenger gets a leaflet on boarding that tells what is going to cost extra, particularly the shore excursions. The Travel Company, the Cruise Line's parent organization, has published "Guide to Family Cruising," a leaflet giving information on activities for 10 major lines and sometimes, their baby-sitting fees. Fees for sitting, where quoted, range from $8 an hour for two children in a family to $10 an hour a child. To get the booklet, call (800) 777-0707 on a touch-tone phone.
One thing is standard: There is no standard set of charges in any price category. Room service (from the regular dining room fare) is always included. Caviar seldom is, but all Seabourn cruises include it. Caviar is also free on the two Sea Goddesses, owned by Cunard, and for grille-class passengers aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2.
Silversea advertises an all-inclusive price, including liquor, tips, port charges, transfers, porter charges and economy air fare. Dale DiBello, a spokeswoman, said that there was one free shore excursion on particular cruises, a total of 27 out of 62 this season.
Haircuts and massages cost extra, as do dry-cleaning and laundry, Ms. DiBello said. Photographs are free for previous cruisers. There are no extra charges for aerobics classes, deck chairs and towels.
Ernie Beyl of the Cunard division of Carnival said the prices on Seabourn, another division, included "stocking liquor in the suites and in bars throughout," as well as wine. That is, with the exception of very expensive brands. For instance? "For example, Johnnie Walker Blue, and an $800 brandy called La Tasche," he said.
Tips are covered. And that caviar, too. Some excursions are covered, particularly those in Southeast Asia "where there is no place else to go," he said. "But not ballooning over Stockholm," he added. Haircuts and massages must be paid for separately. There is a charge for photos.
Baby-sitting? Pause. "This is not an ideal cruise for children, although on occasion we have them," he said. "Those parents must make their own contacts with the staff members."
Yes, dry-cleaning and laundry must be paid for, he said, "although we have free laundries on board."
As a free activity aboard a cruise ship, watching the spin cycle does not do it for me. Waiter, please bring strawberries. Bring caviar. Bring the bill.

Shouldn't colleges take an honest look at the reality that parents are buying test scores for their children? What if colleges insisted that students inform them that they had been tutored as part of their application?

HEADLINE: ART / ARCHITECTURE;
Sharp-Eyed Collectors Drive Up the Price of Folk Art

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
OUTSIDER art continues to upstage American folk art in gallery and museum exhibitions as well as in the press. But at the auctions, traditional American folk art chalks up spectacular prices for the choicest examples, while the quirky, visionary Outsider art lags far behind in prices fetched at auction.
This month's folk-art sales began with the proverbial bang at Christie's when two extraordinary paintings by Edward Hicks rewrote the records for the artist and for folk art. The first painting, "The Residence of David Twining," which had never been on the market previously, was sold by Dr. Thomas Lincoln, a descendant of Twining and of Abraham Lincoln, for $1.4 million. Seconds later, a second painting, "Peaceable Kingdom," from 1837, was sold for $4.7 million to Richard York, a New York dealer. The total sales of folk art at Christie's was $9.3 million and $2.6 million at Sotheby's. 
 The rise in prices for folk art reflects the broadening and maturing of the market. Twenty five years ago, most collectors bought largely on instinct because the field was still relatively new and few books had been written on the subject. Today's collectors come armed with scholarly studies and advice from experts, and as a consequence, they are knowledgeable about the minutest details of objects, what makes them rare and even who owned them.
The sale of "Peaceable Kingdom" sheds light on how the prices for folk-art masterpieces have escalated over the last 20 years. The painting metaphorically depicts Isaiah's prophecy of the animals of the earth in a wooded idyll while in the background William Penn signs a treaty with Indians. It was auctioned in 1980 at Samuel T. Freeman in Philadelphia for $210,000, which was then the record for the artist and for folk art. Long admired as among the most gripping of the 62 versions of "Peaceable Kingdom," it is also considered desirable because it is one of few that include every animal in Isaiah's prophecy.
The sales at Christie's and Sotheby's offered works from important collections, each of which exceeded the totals expected. The largest was the 660-piece collection of John Gordon, a folk-art dealer in New York who had amassed pottery, weathervanes, painted furniture and watercolors as well as the idiosyncratic 20th-century works of Bill Traylor, Minnie Evans and Edgar Tolson. The pieces fetched a total of $2.8 million at Christie's.
Susan Kleckner, director of folk art sales at Christie's, attributed the success of the Gordon sale in part to new findings by scholars over the last five years. Three frakturs in the sale from Bucks County in Pennsylvania, for example, which were identified as having been painted by a man called the Rockhill Township artist, brought from two to four times expectations. When not attributed to an artist, similar works sold below estimates.
Likewise, an 18th century floral-decorated redware bowl was expected to sell for at most $3,500 but brought $13,800. Until recently, Ms. Klechner said, the bowl would have been identified as generic redware from Pennsylvania, but because its origins could now be pinpointed to Hagerstown, Md., it was more valuable.
At Sotheby's, traditional portraits, landscapes and marine paintings from the collection of Edgar William and Bernice Chrysler Garbisch, well-known collectors of Americana, were sold for the Whitney Museum of American Art for a total of $685,000. And the collection of Outsider art works by Traylor, Henry Darger, Nelly Mae Rowe and Lee Godie, assembled by Herbert Waide Hemphill Jr., a pioneer collector in this field. The collection was sold for $239,200 by the National Museum of American Art. The costliest lot was a surreal Traylor drawing of a leaping man on the head of a bird, which was sold for $46,000 to James Curtis, a New York private dealer in 20th century prints.
"We had the best economic environment for this sale," said Nancy Druckman, the director of folk art at Sotheby's. "And we had an unusually high number of pieces that were fresh to the market. This was really the last public chunk of the Garbisch folk art."
DAVID WHEATCROFT, a folk-art dealer from Westboro, Mass., was an active buyer at both houses this month, spending in all more than $330,000 for about about 30 items. His buying ranged from redware pottery and paper cutwork to a Garbisch prize, a richly detailed watercolor, "Berks County Almhouse, Hospital and Lunatic Asylum" by C. C. Hofmann. The painting is the only such watercolor on paper known by Hofmann, and it sold for $112,500, more than three times what Sotheby's had expected.
"Serious money was spent this month on folk art," Mr. Wheatcroft said. "It's pretty obvious that the folk art field is carried by the economy. This market is not so superheated as the late 1980's when it was almost as good as sold when you bought it. But we did see some wild abandon at these sales."

HEADLINE: ART /ARCHITECTURE;
A Caravaggio Leaves Its Dublin Home to Visit Boston

BYLINE: By KEN SHULMAN; Ken Shulman writes about art from Boston.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
SINCE it was rediscovered in the Jesuit Residence in Dublin in 1990, Caravaggio's "Taking of Christ" has left Ireland only twice. In 1995, the painting spent a month at the National Gallery in London and two months in Rome. "The Taking of Christ" was not scheduled to leave Dublin -- where the Jesuit Fathers have left it on indefinite loan at the National Gallery of Ireland -- for the next 25 years. Yet tomorrow it will be on view in Boston, as the centerpiece of "Saints and Sinners: Caravaggio and the Baroque Image," a show of 17th-century Italian religious art that opens at the McMullen Museum of Art at Boston College, through May 24.
"This is simply a case of one Jesuit institution helping out another Jesuit institution," says Franco Mormando, the director of "Saints and Sinners" and a Jesuit priest who teaches art history at the college. "There are also long-standing ties between the Catholic communities of Dublin and Boston, as well as the Jesuits in those two cities." 
 "Saints and Sinners" is ostensibly a show about the stylistic and thematic changes that occurred in Italian religious art following the Protestant Reformation and the Council of Trent. The art of this period, which is known traditionally as the Italian Baroque, is characterized by a heightened sense of drama and naturalism designed to draw the viewer into the composition. The Boston College exhibition features 30 paintings, including canvases by Guido Reni, Domenichino, Bernardo Strozzi and Ludovico Carracci. But the long-lost Dublin Caravaggio -- one of two Caravaggio compositions in the show, and the only work coming from outside the United States -- is definitely the show stopper, and it's reason for being.
 Caravaggio's "Taking of Christ" depicts the moment when Jesus is captured in the Garden of Gethsemane. At the center of the painting, Jesus and Judas Iscariot lock in an embrace, an instant after the traitorous apostle has planted what is perhaps the most famous kiss in Western tradition on the Savior's cheek. The pair is pressed together by a handful of armor-clad guards come to arrest Jesus. Caravaggio himself is also present in the drama, a figure on the right-hand edge of the group holding the lantern that illuminates part of the scene.
Approximately 5 1/2 feet wide by 4 feet high, "The Taking of Christ" was rediscovered in 1990 by Sergio Benedetti, a conservator at the National Gallery of Ireland whom the Jesuit Fathers invited to their residence during a renovation. Caravaggio executed the painting in 1602 on a generous commission from Ciriaco Mattei, a merchant banker from Rome. The work hung in the Mattei family palace through 1802, when one of Mattei's heirs sold it to William Hamilton Nisbet of Scotland. Somewhere along the way, the attribution was changed from Caravaggio to Gerrit von Honthorst, a Dutch follower of Caravaggio. In 1921, "The Taking of Christ" and five other Nesbit paintings were offered for sale at an Edinburgh auction house. The lot was withdrawn when bids did not reach the eight-guinea ($50) minimum estimate.
"The Taking of Christ" entered the Jesuit residence in the 1930's as a gift from a Dublin woman. It was hanging in the library when Mr. Benedetti first saw it. On close inspection, he was stunned by the quality of the painting and suspected it might be by Caravaggio. His intuition grew stronger as he restored the painting over the next several months. For two years, Mr. Benedetti did extensive archival research to retrace the itinerary of the masterpiece and invited several leading Caravaggio scholars to authenticate the attribution. All of them concurred. In 1993, the Dublin Caravaggio was made public. The exquisite and rare painting -- there are fewer than 60 known Caravaggios -- made headlines around the world.
"Saints and Sinners" is not, despite its full title, a show about Caravaggio. It is an intimate and elastic period show. Too small to be encyclopedic, it aims instead for effect. Apart from an economical wall text, the Baroque atmosphere is evoked entirely through inflection, through the selection and juxtaposition of the paintings. The show's pedantry is subtle, almost subliminal, a series of images that re-create some of the sensations -- if not the knowledge -- of 17th-century Italian spirituality. "There was a sense of the whole world living within a tradition both classical and Christian," says John O'Malley, a professor of church history, a Jesuit priest and a collaborator on the exhibition. "For these people, the past was incredibly vivid and had an immediate import in the present. For them, the stories of saints were not mere curiosities. They were relevant to daily life. This is something most of us in the 20th century seem to have lost."
FOLLOWING the Protestant Reformation, which began in 1517 with Martin Luther in Wittenburg, Germany, leaders of the Roman Catholic Church met in Trent from 1545 through 1563. There the Council of Trent drafted its strategy for countering the Protestant challenge. It also discussed long-neglected matters of internal Church reform. One of the subjects of the council was the use of images in religious art. The Tridentine document stipulated that "in the use of sacred images, all superstition shall be removed, all filthy quest for gain eliminated, and all lasciviousness avoided." In 1564, the year after the council concluded, Pope Pius IV ordered Daniele da Volterra to paint braghe or loincloths over some of the racier nudes in Michelangelo's "Last Judgment" in the Sistine Chapel.
Yet the religious art of Baroque Italy, a period historians chart between 1580 and 1700, is hardly puritan. If anything, it is more carnal and sensual than the religious art that preceded it. There may be less nudity than in the paintings of the High Renaissance, but the figures in Baroque art are usually real people, with real pain and passion. "The element of flesh was hardly expunged from Italian religious art," says Mr. O'Malley. "The proscriptions against avarice and lasciviousness in art that came out of Trent are incredibly mild when compared with Erasmus's strictures against seductiveness in churches. Erasmus educated the rest of Europe to be prudish in this regard, while Italy pretty much followed its own path. I also think there was much more of a sense about the goodness of the flesh in Italy."
The Catholic Church had always used painted images as devotional aids. But the Baroque images represented both a thematic and stylistic departure from the images that preceded them. Saints began to be featured in the moments of their martyrdom. Penitence and conversion paintings became extremely popular. There was a tremendous resurgence in "fallible" saints like Mary Magdalene and St. Peter. Indeed, an entire section of the Boston College show is dedicated to them. "Mary Magdalene and Peter became popular as penitential icons," says Mr. Mormando. "They were effective role models precisely because they had sinned. They had failures. They repented. And they were forgiven. In short, they were human."
This same humanism seeped into the treatment of religious subjects in Baroque art. Artists working in 17th-century Italy focused on breaking down the visual barrier that kept viewers from participating in the drama of their religious subjects. They set their figures at the forefront of their canvases, and heightened their already moving scenes with acute effects of light and shade. It was the 17th-century equivalent of today's hand-held movie camera. "This is something that Caravaggio did with remarkable power," says Pamela Jones, the head of the Department of Art History at the University of Massachusetts, Boston, and a member of the curatorial committee for the Boston College show. "He was acutely aware that there was going to be somebody there looking at his paintings. It just makes his art look very different from anything that came before it."
The Italian Baroque was an age of paradox. During the Papacy of Clement VIII (1592-1605), the Pontiff issued a strict edict against prostitution, and even banned nude swimming in the Tiber. Yet during those same years, Caravaggio used nude street boys and prostitutes as models in paintings he then sold to some of the most refined -- and devout -- connoisseurs in Rome. It was an age that vacillated tra il devoto, et profano -- between the sacred and the profane -- as Cardinal Ottavio Paravicino described the art of Caravaggio in a 1603 letter.
This friction animated Baroque art, which in turn injected new vitality into a church still smarting from the blow of the Reformation. "One could even argue that this art speaks toward a new legitimization of Catholicism, and of the Catholic Church," says Mr. O'Malley. "Toward the validity of sacrament and of confession. For Lutherans and Calvinists, once you're saved, you're saved. Sinning and getting up again is very Catholic."

PERSON: SHULMAN, KEN; CARAVAGGIO (MICHELANGO MERISI) (1573-1610); MERISI, MICHELANGEO (CARAVAGGIO) (1573-1610)

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2679 words

HEADLINE: Caught in the Undertow

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK

 BODY:
SUMMER and winter are different here only because of the weather. The ocean breeze blows across an empty boardwalk and right through the spectral hulk that was supposed to become a condominium building. The streets off Ocean Avenue are lined with parking meters that rarely see a car, in January or in August.
And in winter as in summer, Asbury Park residents line up at City Council meetings to plead for attention to the oceanfront blocks that many compare with Beirut. They have been devastated for 15 years, ever since the city made a deal with a developer who bought up acres, bought out businesses and then went bankrupt -- a failure that had a shriveling effect on the rest of the city, too. 
 At the last meeting, Thomas Hayes, president of the Chamber of Commerce, given two minutes to speak like everybody else, told the five council members: "Just this past week I talked to several businesses who said, 'We can't hang in anymore.' We need an answer from the council people."
The question, asked over and over in Asbury Park, is: Why did the council turn down an offer from the state to set up a redevelopment authority that would extricate the city from its tortured dealings with the developer, pay his $7 million in back taxes and get started again?
The council's 3-to-2 vote last fall against opening discussions with the state was especially frustrating to the residents who have staked their futures on the handsome old houses and small businesses here. They had been looking to an infusion of capital -- it will take hundreds of millions of dollars just to rebuild the redevelopment zone -- in the city that was once a magic kingdom resort with manicured lakes, elegant hotels and a mile-long carnival of a boardwalk.
There were 200 hotels in 1938, and now there is one, the Berkeley Carteret, whose grand front entrance is nevertheless locked night and day. Except for a roller rink with a few video games, the amusements have vanished. The Stone Pony nightclub closed in September. And while real estate prices keep climbing along the Jersey Shore, the tax base -- the total value of taxable property -- in Asbury has shrunk each year since 1993.
Innumerable hopes for revival have come to grief in local politics scarred by racial resentments, disruptions in city government and feuds that are too intricate to chronicle. Residents of all political stripes refer to sinister absentee landlords and developers' back pockets, though for all the criminal indictments of public officials over the last decade, none has shown corruption linked to the redevelopment mess.
It is hardly clear what anyone has to gain from years of delay in development. Eugene M. LaVergne, a lawyer who moved his office to Asbury several years ago "because I think it has a future," said: "Everything's always been for sale in the city. What's enraging and ironic is that they're buying the town to keep it down."
The city government's resistance to state help is even more puzzling to outsiders. "I've kind of walked away," said State Senator John O. Bennett of Little Silver, who was Asbury Park's city attorney for eight months in 1997 and 1998. "I don't know what else you can do for a city. This is the absolute best chance for the city. I can't understand why it doesn't happen. Is what they have now better? If not the state, why not?"
William E. Best, the executive director of the New Jersey Redevelopment Authority, acknowledged "a degree of dismay" at the council's vote, taken a few weeks after he addressed a standing-room-only meeting where dozens of speakers cheered on the state's proposal. "We've said time and time again that it was our intent to work with the city as the plan was being modified," Mr. Best said. "We want not only to work with the city but with community support."
But the council members who opposed the plan reply that they are hamstrung by litigation with the original developer, Joseph Carabetta, and are close to a settlement that would transfer control of the redevelopment zone to the city or another developer. Finally, they say, they cannot accept the state's proposed local redevelopment authority, which would have a majority of members appointed by the state.
"They want a majority on the board," said Mayor Kenneth Saunders, one of the three council members who opposes the plan. "No. This is our town, and we should have a majority."
"In the meantime," Mr. Saunders said, "I've got some other things going, and I hope to be able to make a big announcement over the next few weeks. We've had 17 years of going back and forth, and we're closer than we've ever been."
 Those "other things" are settlement talks with Mr. Carabetta as well as other prospective developers. Mr. Carabetta, whose offices are in Meriden, Conn., declined to answer any questions for this article, and city officials say they cannot estimate his total investment in the project. But one group of investors interested in taking over the project reached an agreement with Mr. Carabetta last summer to pay more than $16 million of the developer's debts. This group was rejected by the City Council because it could not guarantee financing for the construction.
Carabetta Enterprises Inc. went bankrupt in 1992, after negotiating an extension with the city and recasting the development plan to include entertainment centers and theme restaurants. The only construction that had materialized from the original plan was the skeleton of the Ocean Mile condominium high-rise and a row of town houses that burned before they were sold.
As for who else might acquire the property and the redevelopment rights, Mayor Saunders said: "I'm willing to work with anyone. I'd work with Daffy Duck. The first ones that come in and show me the money I can work with."
Asbury Park has seen many builders express interest, only to recoil because of the bankruptcy proceedings and the litigation over the redevelopment agreement. Others, including K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, have withdrawn in exasperation over the city's political leadership.
I N recent months, three groups of investors have put plans before the City Council. After the Council rejected the first for its failure to guarantee financing, a second group also dropped out. The third, a consortium of builders that have completed projects in Jersey City, Hoboken and Weehawken, remains interested, if frustrated. "We have been trying to do what we thought the city wanted," said Brian Doherty, the group's lawyer. "We'd work with the city, we'd work with the state."
But Mr. Doherty added that the city was poorly equipped to evaluate and broker a huge real estate development. "There's no planning staff and no economic development staff," he said. "There's no strong voice on City Council. You're dealing with laypeople who have other jobs and are called upon to be Council people. Twelve or 13 years later, it hasn't dawned on them that you've got to build something."
The city is indeed in political shambles. It has had seven mayors in 10 years, and the Council seats have rotated with each election, including a recall vote in 1996. The recently departed city planner is suing the city, claiming his dismissal was racially motivated; the former public safety director is suing, too, claiming he was dismissed because he refused to fix a parking ticket for the Mayor. The school board attorney, who was subsequently removed, and the assistant city manager, among others, were indicted last year on bid-rigging charges and awaiting trial dates.
The council members snap at one another in their meetings, which one former Councilman said he tried to persuade a television station to film because "they're much better than Judge Judy." In their vote on the state plan, the two supporters contended that two of the opponents had conflicts stemming from business connections to Mr. Carabetta or his former partner.
After the last Council meeting, Councilwoman Sheila C. Solomon, a supporter of state intervention, was fuming because Mr. Hayes had been cut off while pleading for a public forum to discuss the state's offer. "All this time they've blocked out having a hearing," Ms. Solomon said. "All these people are asking for is a hearing."
"This is wrong," she went on. "In July it will be two years I've been sitting up here, and nothing has been accomplished. I wrote letters to the press, I had people calling me and I said, 'Keep up the pressure.' I've written the Attorney General. I've written the Governor. Somebody's got to listen."
Councilman John J. Hamilton Jr., the first to ask the state Redevelopment Authority to intercede, said: "I've spoken to Assembly people who say, 'What's wrong with people there?' We've spent more than $1 million on legal fees fighting Carabetta, and the state would take over all our litigation."
"I'm kind of stuck," Mr. Hamilton added. "I've spoken out. I don't want to attack the council."
But Councilwoman Louise Murray responds that it would be better to let the city or another developer strike a deal with Mr. Carabetta than to wait for the state to wrest redevelopment rights from him. Meanwhile, Ms. Murray said, "I'm not ready to put Asbury Park in somebody else's hands."
"I laid awake nights when I made this decision," she said. "I slept with a pad of paper by the bed. But every Council since Carabetta has thought they had the answers. They've all just made more of a mess."
Councilman James G. Condos, who like the Mayor and Ms. Murray will not agree to a redevelopment board with a majority appointed by the state, said most residents did not want to cede local control. "It's a vocal minority that shows up at Council meetings," Mr. Condos said.
Another opponent of state involvement is Henry Vaccaro, Mr. Carabetta's partner in the original redevelopment contract with the city. Mr. Vaccaro, who says the developer's failure wiped out his assets too, is trying to organize a group to buy out Mr. Carabetta and hopes to get construction contracts in the eventual rebuilding. While Mr. Vaccaro said of the council that "there's not a brain among them," he has no use for the state. "Look at what the state's given us so far," he said. "Subsidized housing all over the west side. Mental patients who ruined the beachfront."
Mr. Vaccaro has a long history in Asbury Park politics. Though he no longer lives here, he runs a guitar manufacturing company in town and has bought and sold numerous properties in and near the redevelopment zone. In what he said was an attempt to revive the project, even though he had sold out to Mr. Carabetta years ago, Mr. Vaccaro backed a successful campaign in 1996 to recall two Council members.
The recall also became a cause for a group of black activists who called themselves Asbury United. Recent campaigns have been vicious. An unsigned flyer supporting Mr. Saunders urged blacks, who make up about 60 percent of Asbury Park's population, to "drop white supremacy"; it showed tombstones bearing the names of political enemies, including two African-Americans identified with the label "slave."
Still, opinions on redevelopment do not divide along racial lines, or even on discernible political lines. In September, for example, 16 civic groups issued an open letter to the Mayor supporting the state's offer; many minority organizations, including Asbury United, were represented, as were the Salvation Army and the Chamber of Commerce.
"It's not a matter of black or white," said Mr. Mauro, the former Council candidate, who has lived here for eight years. "It's a matter of green, and of ignorance and greed. This city has been bled so dry with back-room deals." In running for office, Mr. Mauro said, "you're vilified, you're threatened. They've made it so good people won't get involved. When it was over, I said, I must have been crazy to do that."
Mr. Mauro's civic life began with the Asbury Park Garden Club, which he and a few friends formed to restore the once-spectacular gardens around the city. Both the club and the gardens flourished for a time, then withered from vandalism and official neglect. When the slate that defeated his Council candidacy took office, Mr. Mauro said, the Council scheduled concerts on the park grounds that had been the garden club's flagship project, and the plantings were trampled. "That's when I threw in the towel," he said. "It broke my heart."
THERE still is a garden club, and Mr. Mauro, a lab technician, is still a keeper of the city's esthetic history, which he presents in a video -- another garden club project -- that uses restored frames of a 1938 promotional film to trace Asbury Park's stunning decline. When he showed the film at a housing complex for the elderly, he said, people were sobbing. "One little old lady said, 'The developers have done to this city what the Depression couldn't do.' "
Dr. Angelo Chinnici, a former Council member, recalled how his tuition was paid by his family's restaurant and his own summers selling hot dogs on the boardwalk. "In the 70's the typical boardwalk lease was $16,000 to $18,000 for concession space," Dr. Chinnici said. "Now you'd be lucky to get $500."
Dr. Chinnici is largely credited with regaining possession of the Paramount Theater and Convention Hall -- the elegant city-owned buildings that once generated so much boardwalk business -- when he was on the Council several years ago. The complex has been restored and is host to the New Jersey Shorecats basketball team and to concerts, though it is hardly lucrative.
"I invite the Attorney General and the state of New Jersey to take a good, hard look at what's going on," Dr. Chinnici said. "There's no other city in the U.S. that's suffered so much financial blight because of a few individuals."
While most properties near the beach remain in Mr. Carabetta's control, a few others have recently changed hands and raised hopes. The Berkeley Carteret was sold last month to a Queens businessman for $5.1 million. Preservationists keep fighting to save the Palace Amusements building -- they have already recovered its original Ferris wheel -- and a group of Bruce Springsteen fans is making contingency plans to save Tillie, the grinning clown face painted on the Palace building and pictured in Springsteen videos and posters.
The state's more unsentimental interest remains alive, Mr. Best said. He noted that control of the board that would oversee the project is not negotiable, since the legislation providing state financing for urban redevelopment requires that a majority of board members be members or employees of the state Redevelopment Authority.
But he insisted that the state's role would be limited in time -- to 10 years or until 80 percent of construction is completed -- and in substance. He said the funds to pay back taxes remain available, without any legislative approval, though they would have to be repaid when the development becomes financially viable.
Mr. Best, who had met with City Council members individually in coffee shops to explain the plan, said he was baffled by their vote. He said that a few weeks later, in October, he wrote to the City Manager, the Mayor and Council members, asking them to outline their concerns. But except for a phone call from Mr. Hamilton, he said, he received no response.
The City Manager, Wilbert C. Russell, said the state's offer, which does not exist in any written form, was vague. "It's unclear what the state's intention is," Mr. Russell said, "other than to give a loan and set up a board with a majority."
John Loffredo, president of the Asbury Park Homeowners Association, said the Mayor had made campaign promises to seek help from the state. And while the state proposal "isn't that great," Mr. Loffredo said, "you don't dismiss it out of hand. You go back and talk."
"Everybody is waiting for some savior to drop out of the sky, whether it's the state or a redeveloper," he said. "If we'd been running the city for the last 15 years the way we should have, we'd be fine. We'd be ahead of the game."

HEADLINE: The Neighborhood Bank Makes a Comeback

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
THE small-town bank, a fading institution that's been written off as a victim of mergers, is making a comeback.
Four new banks, three of them in Fairfield County, opened in the state last year. And three more are in the application process, according to the state's Department of Banking. 
 Those figures, to be sure, are dwarfed by the spate of small start-ups that occurred in the mid-80's banking boom. Nonetheless, the numbers show a turnaround from the early '90's, when banks, hammered by real estate-related loan losses and a deep recession, were being shut down throughout New England.
"It's a significant trend, a fallout from all the merger and acquisitions activity," said John S. Carusone, president of the Bank Analysis Center in Hartford. "There is a segment of banking customers that wants to deal with a familiar face at their local bank and not a toll-free telephone number."
William R. Berkley, the chief executive officer of the W. R. Berkley Corporation, a property and casualty insurance firm, has helped finance two of the new Fairfield County banks: Greenwich Bank and Trust, which opened last February, and Westport National Bank, which opened last month.
Mr. Berkley, a Greenwich resident, said his interest in beginning local banks was prompted, in part, by his wife's inability to get through to a live human being on her bank's 800 number. "The drive for efficiency and optimum profits has left the customer who wants personal service out of the picture," said Mr. Berkley. "And people want that kind of service. If someone has a question or a problem, they want to talk to their banker. They don't want to be forwarded to an operator in South Dakota."
The resurgence of banks in Connecticut is part of a national trend. There were 216 new banks formed in the nation in 1998, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, compared with 68 five years earlier.
Most of these banks, called de novos by regulators, are created in affluent areas and are run by people who worked at banks swallowed up in mergers.
Michael M. Cassell, a Greenwich resident and the president and chief executive at the Greenwich Bank and Trust Company, for example, held the same positions at the Putnam Trust Company in Greenwich, which was bought by the Bank of New York in 1995.
And Michael H. Flynn, a Fairfield resident and the president and chief executive at Westport National Bank, used to hold the same jobs at the Westport Bank and Trust Company and at Lafayette American Bank in Bridgeport, after its parent company, Hubco Inc. of Mahwah, N.J., took over Westport Bank and Trust in December 1996. Despite the flurry of new banks in the state, the recent growth of local banks, according to the F.D.I.C., has taken place mostly in the West, where the industry is considered more trend-setting and independent-minded, than in the tradition-bound Northeast, bank analysts say. Even so, the consolidation of the banking industry in New England in the 90's, along with a resurgent regional economy, has made markets like Connecticut fertile ground for new banks.
"You are seeing a lot of interest in starting banks these days," said Robert J. Oca, a Greenwich resident and the president and chief executive of the Bank of Westport, which opened in October.
"There has been a gap left by all the mergers, and people are looking to fill that gap," added Mr. Oca, who like Mr. Flynn and Mr. Cassell, is an alumnus of banks that have vanished. Mr. Oca was an executive at Connecticut Community Bank in Greenwich and later Connecticut Bank and Trust in Fairfield County. Connecticut Community Bank was taken over by Connecticut Bank and Trust, which was taken over by the Bank of New England in Boston and operated as a wholly owned subsidiary. Connecticut Bank and Trust went out of business in 1991; the Bank of New England was bought by Fleet Financial Group a year later.
Some bank analysts say there are now too many banks in some areas. "Greenwich is fully banked, at this point," Mr. Carusone said, noting that there are nine banks in the town.
The same, he added, may be true for Westport, particularly since Westport National Bank and the Bank of Westport are in direct competition.
Mr. Flynn downplays the rivalry. "There is enough there for both of us," he said, adding that the Bank of Westport appears to be focusing more on downtown Westport, while Westport National Bank will also seek to serve northern and eastern areas around Westport, such as Fairfield and Easton.
Mr. Carusone also said that both Westport banks could survive. He added that Westport is one of most promising areas in which to found a bank, due to its affluent population.
The Westport area, which includes Norwalk and Fairfield, encompasses 58,000 households and 7,600 businesses, he said. And more than 58 percent of the households have incomes of more than $50,000. Twenty-three percent have incomes of more than $100,000 annually.
"Fairfield County, as a whole, is one of the most attractive banking markets in the country," said Mr. Carusone, adding that not only is the area wealthy but also that Darien and New Canaan have lost hometown banks in recent years and may be missing such services. The Bank of Darien was taken over by Hubco, and New Canaan Bank and Trust was taken over by Summit Bancorp of Princeton, N.J.
The new Fairfield County banks raised between $5 million and $10 million each capitalization, much of it from local investors. (Regulators require a minimum of $5 million.) The three banks are aggressively seeking new deposits, against which they will make loans. Westport National Bank, for example, has begun an advertising and telephone marketing campaign. Bank officials are also meeting with lawyers and accountants to make a pitch for their business as well as making presentations to professional groups, Mr. Flynn said.
All the banks expect to take at least 18 months to turn a profit. Regulators, according to Mr. Carusone, generally prohibit the banks from selling out to competitors for at least three years.
To compete against the mega-banks and super-regionals -- Fleet, Chase Manhattan and First Union among others -- the new banks say they are emphasizing personal service. Officials say waits on the telephone will be shorter and employees will answer phones instead of relying on voice mail. They also say that standards for loans will be more flexible, the officers more accessible and the approvals quicker. Shorter lines at cashiers' windows and fewer small fees are also being promised. Westport National Bank, for example, waives most fees for customers for six months and does not charge for using A.T.M.s other than their own.
"If someone writes a check to the I.R.S. and there's not enough in the account, we might cover it for a customer and give them a call," Mr. Flynn said. "You think a larger out-of-state bank is going to do that?"
"And if someone has, say, an $800,000 balance in their account with us and they are doing a closing, we'll run that check over to them," he added. "That kind of customer with that size deposit is small change to larger banks."
Mr. Flynn also said that local banks are not fee-driven. "Larger banks, even if they get a tenth of a cent on billions, that's a lot," he said. "We don't make our money that way. We make it on the spread between interest we pay on deposits and interest we charge on loans. We're not service-charge happy."
James W. Schepker, senior vice president for media relations at Fleet National Bank in Hartford, part of Fleet Financial Group of Boston, said that the new smaller banks fill a niche market, and they indeed might be more willing to reduce fees and be more flexible in loan rates, but not necessarily faster in processing loans. "We can do it now in 24 hours," he said.
Mr. Schepker added that improved service to many customers means more than just discounted fees and rates, a polite call from the bank when a check bounces or a friendly receptionist answering the telephone. It also means, he said, offering services that only larger banks can -- like global A.T.M. access, Internet banking, 24-hour telephone banking and branch locations. "We do not necessarily believe that smaller is better," he said.
Richard Batten, a Westport detective who recently opened an account at Westport National Bank, does not necessarily agree. He closed an account at Lafayette American, which he had opened 23 years ago when it was Westport Bank and Trust.
He said Lafayette American repeatedly charged him for overdraft cash reserves he was not using and could not explain the glitches. "They couldn't answer the question," he said. "They couldn't tell me why." Officials with Hubco, Lafayette American's parent company, did not respond to repeated telephone calls seeking comment.
"They've lost all personality," Mr. Batten said. "It's a bank in Jersey. You got to flag someone down to help you. You don't get through when you call. It's not the same anymore."

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 3; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1554 words

HEADLINE: Bygone Era's Revival: Hauling Goods by Rail

BYLINE: By CAROL STEINBERG 

 BODY:
AS Long Island Rail Road commuter trains zip by on the main track just east of the Deer Park train station, the engineer, Alex Raia, and conductor, Mark Myers, get their 19-car freight train into position so they can drop off three rail cars loaded with 159 rolls of paper weighing 465,000 pounds.
The cars are headed to a spur of tracks leading to the AJM Packaging Corporation in Brentwood. There, the paper will be unloaded and eventually converted into paper plates. 
 After the drop-off, the train will switch to the main track and head east, delivering five empty gondolas to be filled with scrap iron to the Gershow Recycling Corporation in Medford, plywood to the Georgia-Pacific Corporation in Yaphank, and propane to the Paraco Gas Corporation in Riverhead before returning west with other shipments.
Timing is everything. Since the service operates on rails of the nation's busiest commuter line, it adheres strictly to the L.I.R.R.'s timetable, dodging on and off the main tracks between commuter trains.
Rail freight has operated here since the mid-19th century, but in May 1997, the New York & Atlantic Railway took over the service from the Long Island Rail Road, and it has been attempting to revitalize the moribund operation since.
"The railroad lost freight step by step over many years and it will take many years to build it up again," said Bruce Lieberman, chairman of New York & Atlantic, which is owned by Anacostia Rail Holdings, an affiliate of Anacostia & Pacific Company of Manhattan and Chicago. New York & Atlantic is based in Fresh Pond, Queens, which is also the site of its only rail yard.
With the new carrier, "we're talking a lot more about rail freight, and that's the good part of it," said Wayne Ugolik of the Long Island regional office of the state Department of Transportation. He said it could reduce the number of trucks on the road and cut pollution.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Long Island Rail Road's parent agency, privatized rail freight to allow management to focus on its core business, said Brian Dolan, a spokesman for the railroad.
The sale of the operation came after the L.I.R.R. attempted earlier in the 1990's to upgrade its freight division, which was criticized for poor service and inattention. In its last year, the division had a net profit of $576,000 on $6.29 million in revenues, according to the railroad, and had about 24 employees.
Gary Gross, a retired engineer hired by New York & Atlantic as a consultant, remembers 800 freight cars a day when he started with the L.I.R.R. 30 years ago. Riding a green-and-white locomotive recently, he recalled former customers -- "old friends," he said, like Hills supermarkets, San Salvage, Brentwood Lumber and Waldbaum's, whose sidings have since been paved over.
"You name it, we delivered it," Mr. Gross said.
But as many major shippers began to use trucks for speedier -- although costlier -- service and as the economy shifted from heavy manufacturing and agriculture to high-value smaller items, rail freight tumbled. Between 1987 and 1996, it fell from 17,131 carloads and 1.1 million tons to 11,683 carloads and 865,857 tons. Each rail car can hold two to three truckloads of material.
Rail accounts for only 1 percent of all freight transportation on the Island and almost all the rest comes from trucks, said the state Department of Transportation. Nationwide, railroads' share of freight transport was 39.2 percent in 1997, according to the Eno Transportation Foundation, a research group in Washington.
One of five bidders, Anacostia & Pacific paid $12.7 million for a 20-year concession to be run by its new subsidiary, New York & Atlantic Railway. Annual trackage and switch maintenance fees increased the total deal to $26 million to $27 million, Mr. Lieberman said.
Founded in 1985, the company had revitalized a bankrupt freight service operating over busy commuter tracks from South Bend, Ind., to Chicago. It also owns the Louisville & Indiana Railroad, and Pacific Harbor Lines, serving the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach.
Today, New York & Atlantic runs seven trains a day, five days a week, on its 269-mile route, which includes freight-only tracks in Brooklyn and Queens and extends east over commuter lines to Southold and Montauk.
In 1998, the company's total tonnage was about 40 percent rocks, stone and brick; 20 percent scrap paper and scrap metal; 15 percent paper; 10 percent lumber and the remainder food, plastics and fuel.
Since the takeover, the carrier has added six customers to the 75 on board and employs 30 people. Annual volume has risen to about 15,000 carloads and about 1.2 million tons.
Mr. Lieberman conceded that most of the increase stems from one large project, moving rock excavated from the New York City water tunnel project to Prima Asphalt Inc. in Holtsville. It will end later this year.
Compared with the commuter line, which operates 734 passenger trains with 265,000 passengers daily, "we're essentially invisible," Mr. Lieberman said.
Larry Silverman, chairman of the L.I.R.R. Commuters Council, said the two carriers "seem to be functioning without incident right now." He said the council would be concerned if there were an increase in daytime freight runs or derailments.
To insure that the commuter and freight lines co-exist safely, the L.I.R.R.'s operations center oversees the entire system. "There are prescribed windows of time where the freight train operates," said Sam Zambuto, a spokesman for the railroad.
He said the New York & Atlantic could expand by adding runs or increasing the length of trains within these windows, "as long as it doesn't impact the commuter train."
Still, the potential for disruption exists. In February 1997, an eastbound freight train loaded with gravel derailed in Westbury, delaying commuters for hours.
When the freight operation changed hands, kinks had to be worked out. At AJM Packaging, "deliveries showed up, but I had to be on their back, calling a couple of times a day," said the plant manager, Joseph Kijak. Now, he said, "Everything clicks."
The carrier had expected to use the railroad's small intermodal yard in Garden City, the only yard east of Queens with a ramp for loading and unloading to move cargo between rail and trucks.
However, responding to community outcry about increased traffic, the Long Island Rail Road closed the yard pending an environmental review.
"We need a yard in order to grow," Mr. Lieberman said.
A state Department of Transportation-sponsored regional planning study, Long Island Transportation Plan 2000, is exploring cargo-related issues, with an eye on reducing the 35,000 nonpassenger vehicles that cross the Nassau-Queens border daily.
Its cargo subcommittee has recommended building a large intermodal facility here for multiple modes, such as marine, air, rail and truck, which would reduce long-haul trucking through New York City.
Possible sites are Pilgrim State Hospital in Brentwood and the Grumman properties in Bethpage and Calverton. Any construction would be at least five years away, Mr. Ugolik said.
Local leaders agree that New York & Atlantic faces a big educational task.
"No question, the history of rail freight has turned customers off," said Mitchell Pally, vice president for legislative and economic affairs at the Long Island Association.
Further, most companies just naturally put freight on trucks. "We have to change the mindset of businesses on Long Island to at least look at rail as an option," Mr. Pally said.
One way to change that is by emphasizing the price difference. The New York & Atlantic would not release its shipping fees, but the Eno Transportation Foundation said the average price paid by shippers in 1997 was $2.40 a ton mile by rail, versus $26.12 by truck.
Mr. Lieberman said logical companies to attract are those near sidings who never used rail or "had given up on rail service." So far, the railway has added three switches, each at a cost of hundreds of thousands of dollars, to accommodate new clients.
At the 39-store P.C. Richard & Son, trucks transport electronics and appliances, leaving idle the rail sidings near its clearance center in Deer Park and warehouse in Farmingdale.
The president and chief executive, Gary Richard, said it was too hard and too expensive to unload rail cars. "It just doesn't work anymore," he said.
Don't tell that to Mid-Island Wholesale Fruit & Produce. Last September, it moved into a building with an existing rail siding in Hicksville. "When I saw it, it was a big plus," said the owner, Craig Greissman.
After some hesitation, Mr. Greissman brought in a rail car stuffed with 125,000 pounds of potatoes from Idaho last month. Although delivery took two weeks, versus five days by truck, Mid-Island saved more than $2,000 on one shipment.
Still, there are those who doubt a rail freight resurgence here.
Lee Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, said that besides technical issues, "It's very hard to recapture a market once it is lost. Couple that with the changing nature of the produce, there is less market share to garner."
Noted Mr. Pally: "It will never be a major part of Long Island transportation, but it can be a bigger player than it is now."
