HEADLINE: Why Gasoline Costs More Here

BYLINE: By TODD SHAPERA

 BODY:
DRIVERS in Westchester may be wondering why record low oil prices have not translated into commensurate savings at the pump. By year's end, county drivers were paying $1.23 for a gallon of unleaded regular gasoline, according to a survey of gas stations provided by the County Department of Weights and Measures. At the same time, the nationwide average retail price fell to 93.7 cents, the lowest inflation-adjusted level since record keeping began in 1920, according to the United States Department of Energy.
Moreover, Westchester drivers appear to be losing ground. While around the country the average price of unleaded regular gasoline fell 27.9 cents at the end of last year, average Westchester prices dropped only 17.3 cents. And pump prices here are not only well above the national average, they have also been the highest in the state outside of New York City. 
 Why? First, few drivers may know that the biggest single part of what they pay at the pump goes to Albany and the Federal Government. For every gallon of 87 octane gasoline, local drivers pay about 50 cents a gallon in Federal and state taxes. It is more tax than drivers pay in all but three states -- Connecticut, Hawaii and Nevada -- according to the American Petroleum Institute. Put 12 gallons in your car, and pay $6 in taxes. Drive 15,000 miles a year in a vehicle that gets 20 miles a gallon, and you pay $375 in taxes.
Every driver in the United States pays 18.4 cents a gallon in Federal taxes, up from 4 cents in 1980. Then Westchester drivers pay nearly 32 cents a gallon in state and local taxes, 43 percent more than the 22.4 cent average for state taxes nationwide, according to American Petroleum Institute. How does the 32 cents a gallon break down? New York State taxes drivers, then taxes them again. There is 14 cents for the state's petroleum business tax (down from 14.6 cents last year), 8 cents for a state excise tax and another half cent for fuel testing and an oil-spill fund. Then Albany and the county government add sales tax onto the other tax, of 6.75 percent in most towns, which is at the low end. In Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and Yonkers, the state and county sales tax is 8.25 percent, the high end.
According to Leslie Bennett, Deputy Budget Director in the County Executive's Office, of those sales taxes, 4 percent goes to the state, 0.25 percent goes to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and from 1.5 percent to 2.5 percent goes to the county, depending on where the gas is sold. Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and Yonkers add 2.5 percent and White Plains levies 2 percent, making the city of White Plains' total tax 7.75 percent.
According to the study "How We Pay for Gasoline," published last year by the American Petroleum Institute, New York is one of only seven states collecting sales tax on gasoline purchases. And it is one of only four states to impose its sales tax on other state and Federal taxes. Consequently, while drivers nationwide pay, on average, one-third of their pump bill to the tax collector, the New York tax bite rises to 47 percent at $1.05 a gallon. Rayola Dougher, author of the "How We Pay" study, said: "Most people don't have a clue that almost half of what they are paying is tax. I wish they put it on the pump."
No wonder pump prices are lower in New Jersey. Taxes there are 16 cents a gallon less, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Massachusetts takes 8 cents less and Pennsylvania 4 cents. In Connecticut, though, drivers pay 3.5 cents more in state taxes than New York, even after a 4 cent cut last July, Ms. Dougher says.
Still, this tax burden explains only about 10 cents of the 29-cent difference between average county prices and the average national price at year end. And it does not explain at all why Westchester prices are higher than every county in New York State outside of those that make up New York City. In 1997, the State Attorney General issued weekly surveys of prices by county. Westchester gasoline prices were consistently higher than 10 upstate counties surveyed, as well as Nassau and Suffolk Counties. (New York City was not included.)
As one example, on Labor Day weekend 1997, while the average gas price statewide for unleaded 87 octane was $1.36 a gallon, and was as low as $1.31 in Binghamton, Westchester drivers were paying $1.45. The Attorney General's office discontinued the survey last year. A spokesman for the Attorney General, Marc Violette, said that the office had no regulatory authority over gasoline prices, and that another state agency, the Energy Research and Development Authority, tracks those prices.
Still, picking random dates of April 27 and Sept. 14 last year, New York State prices were about 9 cents above the national average (which can be explained by the higher taxes). In Westchester, they were another 10 cents a gallon above the state's average price.
There seem to be several reasons why county residents pay more. A few pennies a gallon are raised because of environmental requirements in Westchester, Putnam and Rockland Counties as well as in New York City and on Long Island, which mandate oxygenated gasoline in winter months and reformulated gasoline in the summer. County station owners also face higher business costs (for labor, property and other taxes, repairs, and the like) than their Albany or Rochester counterparts. Moreover, in some regions like Rochester, American Indian station owners receive a partial tax break from the state, which they pass on to drivers, ultimately forcing down competitors' prices.
Then there is the role of the major oil companies. "Gasoline prices are influenced by what the market will bear," said Ben Brockwell, editor in chief at the Oil Price Information Service. He contends that the local market is more easily controlled by big companies because there is less competition from unbranded or independent operators.
Of about 430 stations in the county, Mobil's 70 stations account for one-fourth of all volume sold, Ida Walker, a Mobil spokeswoman, said. Mobil owns only 7 of those stations, however, she added, and franchisees set their own prices. Yet, in several interviews, Mobil and Texaco station operators said they are forced to buy the company's gasoline at prices higher than independent stations only blocks away sell their gas for.
Barbara Spruck, owner of the Mobil station in Pleasantville, said she has frequently complained to her Mobil sales representative about paying higher prices to Mobil than three nearby Coastal, Citgo and Getty stations sell gas for. "They are selling below my costs," she said. She said her Mobil sales representative replied that even so Ms. Spruck's station's volumes have not fallen. Ms. Spruck said any price decreases at her station in the last year have come only when Mobil has lowered her price. "When they go down 2 cents, I drop 2 cents," she said.
The Mobil station in Pleasantville survives, Ms. Spruck said, in part because of longevity and customer loyalty. The station has been in the community for 59 years and, she said, "Our customers know that what we charge is what we have to charge." Some motorists also believe in Mobil's brand value, she added. "They are people who won't put anything but Mobil in their car."
Mobil's prices fluctuate in part because Mobil does not charge all stations in the county the same price. "We don't price by county," Ms. Walker said. "We price by consumer market, based on buying behavior." While refusing to give specific details, she said Mobil divides Westchester County into several markets. "About half the county constitutes one consumer market, and there are various smaller markets."
Texaco's manager of strategic pricing, Shawn Carsten, refused to give specifics, saying only: "We never talk about strategies or price. It is proprietary information."
Although the major oil companies contribute to the high cost of gasoline in the county, they passed along the drop in domestic crude oil prices almost to the penny last year.
It works out like this: the decline in domestic crude to $11.30 a barrel in December from $18.30 a year earlier, represented a price decline for a gallon of crude of 16.7 cents. (There are 42 gallons in a barrel. So an $11.30 barrel works out to 26.9 cents a gallon, down from 43.6 cents.) Westchester drivers did slightly better, according to the county's survey, seeing their pump price fall 17.3 cents to $1.225 a gallon from $1.398 in December 1997.
Mr. Brockwell, the Oil Price Information Service editor in chief, said he feels that the major oil companies are making a healthy profit. By adding New York taxes to the roughly 39 cents a gallon wholesale price of unleaded regular gas in the region in December, the price becomes 89 cents. After adding a few pennies for delivery costs, a major company selling gasoline to stations for $1.11, as Mobil was earlier this month, is receiving a profit of 20 cents a gallon. "They are very nice profits," he said. He said the companies may be relying on that cushion to offset losses from the sharp drop in crude oil prices.
 
Is All Gas Really the Same, Somehow?
RON GOLDSTEIN, who changed his station from Sunoco to Coastal last year, said drivers who believe they are getting better gas by paying more for major brands, or that discount stations sell inferior quality, may be surprised to learn that it isn't so.
On a recent visit to Mr. Goldstein's Coastal station, the operator produced three receipts showing deliveries from the truck of an independent company's, Barrier Oil, which filled up at Mobil's terminal in Inwood, Queens, and Shell terminals in Brooklyn. He also said he has had deliveries that originated at Texaco terminals.
Ida Walker, a Mobil spokeswoman, disputed Mr. Goldstein's contention. "We don't sell Mobil gasoline to unbranded stations," she said, but she added, "gas is fungible, like white cake mix." Mobil sells gasoline to independent stations but with a generic additive, Ms. Walker said, which is different from Mobil's additive.
Referring to Mr. Goldstein, she said: "He may get gasoline from a terminal that we operate, but that doesn't mean he gets Mobil gasoline. Our additives make our gas our gas."
While the composition of the additive is a secret, Ms. Walker said it contains a detergent formula that helps engines run cleaner, a claim in Mobil advertisements. Ms. Walker said the Federal Trade Commissionrequired oil companies to have internal data to support such advertising.
Wayne Jeffers, president of Barrier Oil, based in Tarrytown, said: "Mobil may have its studies, but all gasoline additives have detergents. The Environmental Protection Agency requires it."
He supplies about 50 Citgo stations and 2 Coastal stations, including Mr. Goldstein's, which typically sell gas for less than the major companies. "Eighty-seven octane is 87 octane. If one oil company had a superior product they would advertise that their gasoline is the best. But they can't make those claims."
Although consumers have no way of knowing how an oil company's additive affects performance, if at all, the county's Department of Weights and Measures runs periodic tests to make sure that the octane rating is the same as that stated on the pump.
John Gaccione, a senior inspector at the department, said inspectors rarely find mislabeled gas. TODD SHAPERA

HEADLINE: In the Region / Long Island;
Riverhead Moves Ahead on Marketing Navy Site

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

 BODY:
LAST week, within five months of Riverhead's securing ownership of 2,550 acres at the Navy-owned Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant in Calverton, the Town Board approved offers totaling $36 million on 1,625 acres of its property.
One of three interested buyers is Lazarus Burman Associates, a Syosset development group, which has offered to purchase the 525-acre industrial core of the property for $17 million. That portion contains 1.1 million square feet of industrial and office space and a 10,000-foot-long runway. 
 Landmark National, a developer of golf-oriented communities, is proposing to buy 800 acres for $13.6 million. It intends to build a 300-room hotel-conference center, two 18-hole courses and up to 300 single-family houses for buyers 55 and older to be grouped around the golf courses.
The group, which is based in New Albany, Ohio, has built several top-rated golf courses including Palm Beach Polo in Palm Beach, Fla., and PGA West in Palm Springs, Calif. In Riverhead, it intends to spend more than $30 million just on the two golf courses said Spencer M. Waxman, a vice president of the company.
The third potential buyer is NHL Skate, an affiliate of the Mentmore Holdings Corporation of Manhattan, a conglomerate that owns steel, life insurance, entertainment and development companies, among others. It has proposed building a baseball stadium, a sports complex and a family entertainment center on 300 acres, for which it would pay $5.4 million.
Last week, the Riverhead Town Board authorized the Riverhead Development Corporation, a board consisting of town residents and regional business leaders experienced in real estate development, to draw up sales contracts with all three entities. Offers are all-cash, with no financing contingencies.
Public hearings will be held on each proposal before closings.
It has been almost three years since Northrop Grumman closed its operations at the 5,900-acre Calverton site. Its departure eliminated hundreds of high-paying jobs and ended the military contractor's $1 million annual payment in lieu of property taxes to the town of Riverhead.
Still to be transferred by the Navy to Riverhead's Community Development Agency are 350 acres which will be conveyed once the Navy completes an environmental cleanup.
The remaining 3,000 acres of Navy property will be turned over to the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation and will become a nature preserve. That land had been used as a buffer zone around the former aircraft manufacturing complex that Grumman had occupied for almost 40 years, leasing it from the Navy to build and test fighter aircraft.
"The town feels it is on the brink ofsignificant economic development and the impact is expected to be far-reaching throughout the county," said Andrea H. Lohneiss, the director of Riverhead's Community Development Agency, referring to the proposals for the town's property.
THE Grumman operation, which at one time employed 3,000 people, drew its labor force from a radius of at least 30 miles, Ms. Lohneiss noted, "so the town never anticipated this being a benefit only to the town in terms of job creation."
A 20-year strategy to devise new uses for the property was developed for the town in 1996 by Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler, a Manhattan real estate and economic consulting firm. It lays out a mixed-use planned development with a 525-acre industrial park -- the portion Lazarus Burman has offered to buy -- at its core.
The firm projected that within five years, 2,200 jobs with an annual payroll of $25.7 million would be created, and that within 20 years, 6,400 people with a total annual payroll of $78.5 million would be at work at the former Northrop Grumman site. Annual property taxes were projected to reach $1.7 million in five years, and $3.1 million in 20 years.
The industrial park would include the existing buildings and allow for construction of up to 2 million square feet of additional office and industrial space.
The 10,000-foot runway, the longer of two airstrips Grumman had used, would be used only for the aviation-related needs of the industrial users, and not for commercial flights.
Of the remaining 2,375 acres, 410 are part of the Pine Barrens and can never be developed.
The balance would be devoted to leisure and tourism-oriented uses including golf, and to public parks. The plan also called for a hotel and conference center.
The town began marketing its Enterprise Park at Calverton, as it has named the property, before receiving ownership, but a previous deal for the 525-acre industrial park fell through. A $17 million purchase offer from First Industrial Realty Trust was accepted by the town last June, but the Chicago-based real estate investment trust, which had a 120-day period to study the market and other factors, backed out last month.
Peter F. Murphy, the managing director of First Industrial's eastern region, said the company had unsucessfully tried to attract a major tenant and had ultimately decided to withdraw from the deal because it felt that it could not make a sufficient return on its investment.
Last year Mentmore Development, another affiliate of Mentmore Holdings, the parent company of NHL Skate, had offered to buy the entire Calverton site for $35 million plus a share to the town of future profits, but town officials favored the First Industrial offer.
Once the three current transactions are completed, the town will still have about 200 acres available for sale, Ms. Lohneiss of the Community Development Agency said. Prices range from $17,000 to $20,000 an acre. The remainder of the property will be used for parks, open space and buffer areas.
While searching for purchasers, the town also sought tenants for the existing buildings. Annual asking rents are in the $4 to $4.75 a square foot range for the industrial space, and $10 a square foot for the office space.
BY preleasing space before a sale, the town felt it could offer a potential purchaser an immediate return on investment, making the project less speculative, said Jack O'Connor, the president of Grubb & Ellis/Island Realty of Melville, the brokerage firm that is helping the town market the property.
A 300,200-square-foot building, the largest in the industrial complex, contains the remains of Flight 800, the TWA airliner that exploded off the South Shore in July 1996. The building is leased to the National Transportation Safety Board on a year-to-year basis and the agency can elect to vacate the structure with three months' notice.
Two additional rental transactions with 10-year leases are close to being signed, Mr. O'Connor said. One, a woodworking company and furniture manufacturer, would occupy 65,000 square feet. The other, a boat builder, wants 30,000 square feet. Negotiations for additional deals totaling 100,000 square feet are also under way, he added.
Ms. Lohneiss said the Calverton property had many advantages for potential users. Its buildings are in excellent condition, she said, and it has a railroad spur that could be reactivated for freight. Furthermore, Ms. Lohneiss said, last June, Gov. George E. Pataki designated 1,248 of the 2,900 acres an Economic Development Zone within which industrial and commercial tenants and owners receive a variety of tax reductions and other cost-cutting incentives. Companies within the Economic Development Zone get reduced utility rates, sales-tax exemptions on construction materials, tax credits for job creation, and a seven-year property tax abatement on new construction or improvements. Thereafter, tax increases are phased in over three years.
Ms. Lohneiss also pointed out that the Navy, before transferring ownership, had completed a full environmental review based on the reuse plan, and that a rezoning of the entire property to allow the various uses could be in place as early as April. Those two processes often delay new development for months if not years.
For local residents, success of the park is vital, said William D. Talmage, a developer whose family has lived in the town for five generations.
"This is so important to Riverhead because we are caught in the middle," he said. "We don't have the industrial and office space development to the west, and we don't have the second-home mansions to the east. We are kind of a no-man's land, and our taxes are killing us."

HEADLINE: Yonkers Bias Case, the 'Ongoing Saga'

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
IN retrospect, Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan may have spoken prematurely last December when he predicted that two decades of frustration over housing desegregation here would soon draw to a close.
"There will, at long last, be an end to this phase of the ongoing saga," said the judge, who has been the umpire since 1980 when the United States Department of Justice sued Yonkers, saying that it intentionally discriminated against minorities in housing and schools. 
 The cause of Judge Sands' optimism was an agreement by the state to pay some of the cost of integrating housing in Yonkers -- an outcome that had been sought by both the Mayor's office and leaders of the Yonkers branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
But less than two months later, the on-again, off-again alliance between the city and the N.A.A.C.P. is clearly off again, with an escalating war of words over who should benefit from the new housing.
"Money is not the issue anymore," said Symra D. Brandon, an N.A.A.C.P. member and a City Councilwoman representing parts of Yonkers' west side. "Now there are deeper concerns at stake."
The housing agreement affords no explicit advantages to black and Hispanic residents over whites, although there are preferences in the plan for people who live in subsidized or public housing in southwest Yonkers, many of them who are nonwhite.
Mayor John D. Spencer has said that the point of the agreement is to provide housing to anyone who meets the income qualifications, regardless of race, and he has been interested as well in making housing available to the city's firefighters and police officers. In an interview last week he reiterated his view that the agreement was "not about color."
But the N.A.A.C.P. says that the implicit point of the case has always been to help poor Hispanic residents and blacks move from the city's west side to its predominantly white and more prosperous east side.
In an interview, Kenneth W. Jenkins, a past president of the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter and now a member of its board of directors, described Yonkers' efforts as "abysmal" and "unacceptable" in the two years since city officials persuaded the Federal government to give them more control over the housing program.
And Leonard Buddington Jr., the N.A.A.C.P. branch's president, said, "What we've gotten from the city is a lot of promises and little action."
City officials say, however, that in the last two years they have made 171 units of affordable housing available to those who qualify, and Mayor Spencer says there will soon be more units. The N.A.A.C.P. says, however, that the numbers are not that high because some of those housing units are not yet ready for occupancy. The city's records for 1997 and last year show that 42 percent of the affordable units went to blacks, 42 percent went to Hispanic residents and the rest went to whites and other racial groups like Asians.
But critics say that the numbers failed to paint an accurate picture because the housing is not going to the poorest people.
Mr. Buddington is particularly concerned that only seven of the housing units allotted so far have gone to the people for whom the N.A.A.C.P. originally sought relief -- minority residents of the city's low- and moderate-income housing whom the Federal Government has designated as top-priority clients for the program. Other units have gone to people who meet the income qualifications but have significantly higher household income.
For example, Mr. Buddington and Mr. Jenkins have questioned the case of Rhonda Lewis Warren and her husband, Tammie, a black couple who received a housing grant under the program to buy a $155,000, four-bedroom house in the Runyon Heights section of the city, a middle- and upper-class black neighborhood on the predominantly white east side.
"I took advantage of an opportunity that was presented and ran with it," Mrs. Warren said in an interview, adding that the program made it possible for her family to make a larger down payment.
The N.A.A.C.P. officials -- acknowledging that their position was not a popular one -- said that moving a minority couple from an apartment in Runyon Heights to a house in Runyon Heights -- the same segregated neighborhood -- although on the east side, did not advance the cause of desegregation.
Even though Mr. Spencer has deemed the program "a stunning success" under his leadership, he acknowledged that only a few west side residents responded to the city's publicity about the housing opportunities, which included letters and brochures sent to people living in subsidized housing.
"If people don't apply or they don't qualify economically, that's not our fault," the Mayor said. "Nor can we turn away others who qualify but are in the category of second or third priority."
Mr. Jenkins of the N.A.A.C.P. said, however, that the city should do more to alert the poorest residents about the housing opportunities, including advertisements in local newspapers and on cable television.
The amount of assistance available to families depends on income, with families earning less than 50 percent of the Westchester median income eligible for as much as $20,000. In 1996, the latest year for which figures are available, the Westchester County Department of Planning lists the median household income as $61,861 in 1996. Those earning between 50 and 80 percent of the median can receive as much as $15,000. And households earning between 80 and 100 percent of the median income can receive $10,000.
In an attempt to resolve the disagreements without formally returning to court, Joseph M. Pastore Jr., one of the court-appointed monitors in the case, said a meeting was being scheduled, probably within the next several weeks, with the judge, N.A.A.C.P. representatives and officials from the Mayor's office.
Mr. Jenkins and Mr. Buddington said in interviews that if the results of the meeting did not satisfy them, they would officially take the case back to the judge.
"Right now, today, this case is far from over," said "Judge Sand and the Mayor think it's over, but it's not."
Responding to that comment in another interview, the Mayor said: "Be my guest! I'll see them in court."
Such heated language has not been unusual over the 20-year history of the desegregation fight, particularly after the City Council voted in August 1988 to reject a court-ordered housing desegregation plan in defiance of the judge's threat of imposing heavy fines.
But more recently, the language used by all the parties involved in the case has been more accommodating.
Both the city and the N.A.A.C.P. applauded Judge Sand's finding in February last year that the state -- and not just Yonkers -- was responsible for segregated patterns of housing because the New York Urban Development Corporation in the 1960's and 70's built many of its low-income apartments in the southwest section of the city.
In December, the state agreed to pay $16.4 million to help Yonkers build new housing and buy existing homes for black and Hispanic families and other income-qualified buyers. The settlement committed the state over the next five years to pay $7.5 million for 600 single-family homes and condominiums, including subsidies of as much as $20,000 for the lowest-earning families for down payments, closing costs and repairs.
Under the agreement, the state will also have to pay $6.4 million for building 118 new houses and rental apartments in three locations in Yonkers -- Yonkers Avenue, Hoover Road and East Grassy Sprain Road. Yonkers is about to break ground on a fourth site required by the Federal Court order, 22 homes on Cross Street.
Besides the housing issues, there are also unresolved issues affecting the educational phase of the court order, in particular how to remove vestiges of segregation that remain in the classroom.
In 1980, the United States Justice Department, which was later joined by the N.A.A.C.P., accused Yonkers of intentionally maintaining segregated schools by confining black and Hispanic families to the southwestern section of the city.
The city implemented the first phase of school desegregation in 1986 and recently began what it called its Educational Improvement Plan, Part 2.

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
Another Link for Barnegat Bay's 'Emerald Necklace'

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
FOR the last two years there have been competing visions for the 365 acres of salt marsh and woodlands that jut into Barnegat Bay in Berkeley Township in Ocean County. But the matter was resolved earlier this month when the Trust for Public Land, bought the site from the local representative of a Dallas land investor, insuring that it will never be turned into housing.
Using money raised by county residents for preservation purposes, the trust, a national nonprofit conservation group, paid $771,250 for the site, known as Good Luck Point. It is among the 16 parcels totaling some 1,575 acres that the trust has purchased over the last three years or will soon purchase to create what it calls "an emerald necklace" along the western shore of Barnegat Bay. 
 The trust has conveyed the Good Luck Point site, at the mouth of the Toms River, to the county, which will manage it as a wildlife habitat with public access to the water.
The time it took to negotiate the deal underscores the fact that, in contrast to the site's name, it takes a lot more than luck to realize such purchases today. Just as New Jersey's economy and real estate market have grown stronger, so has the competition between developers and conservation groups to buy land. And the cost of land has risen over the last two years.
The increase varies depending on location. Peter Matone, a principal at Welsh Chester Galiney Matone, a real estate advisory firm in Morristown, said the average price of a quarter-acre lot in Ocean and Monmouth Counties rose 6 to 10 percent over the last two years to $65,000 to $75,000; in Middlesex County, the price rose 10 to 14 percent to $75,000 to $100,000 and in Essex County, the price rose 14 to 20 percent to $100,000 to $150,000.
"It is definitely a seller's market today given the increase in demand for land and the shortage of supply," said John Schilp, president of Schilp & Company, a residential and land brokerage in Chester.
New Jersey residents responded last November by supporting in a referendum the state's largest conservation effort, the first time the state established a stable source of paying for land.
Under it the state will spend nearly $1 billion over the next decade, or $98 million a year in state tax revenues, to buy a million acres of undeveloped land and retire bonds. It also gives the state the authority to issue an additional $1 billion in bonds for preservation purposes.
At the same time, residents of six counties and 45 municipalities also voted to pay a little more in property taxes to acquire open space or to increase the open-space taxes they currently pay. The state now has 98 municipalities and 13 counties with open space taxes -- including Ocean County, which established its tax of 1.2 cents per $100 of assessment in 1997, collecting some $4 million for preservation purposes since its implementation on Jan. 1, 1998. On a $100,000 home, the annual tax would amount to $12.
Typically, the Trust for Public Land contracts to buy land and uses public and private funds to consummate a transaction. It then conveys the property to a public entity.
Given today's economic realities these additional financing sources "give us the capacity to stay in the game and compete," said John Klevins, senior project manager at the Morristown office of the Trust for Public Land, who negotiated the purchase of the Good Luck Point site. The area has seen significant development and is threatened with more, Mr. Klevins said, adding: "Without the county funding the property may have been lost."
The statewide referendum approved by New Jersey voters Nov. 3 will replenish the state's 37-year old Green Acres Program, which has been the main source of funds to state, county and local government agencies for preservation projects. Since its creation the program has raised $1.39 billion in nine voter-approved bond issues to preserve 922,000 acres of open space, including farmland.
With a stable funding source in place "we are now sorting out how to promote ourselves in so competitive an environment," said Dennis B. Davidson, deputy administrator of the program within the state's Department of Environmental Protection. He said the first $98 million in funding is expected to be available the middle of the summer.
The additional supply of public money, however, has resulted in one unwelcome side effect -- the perception by sellers that the state will be willing to pay more for land.
"It is obviously on people's minds," Mr. Davidson said. "Sellers we didn't buy from before because we were unwilling to pay their purchase price are calling us now because they know there is money."
WILL such beliefs lead sellers to hold out for unrealistic prices and, in turn, cause rising land prices to rise even further? Mr. Davidson said he did not think so because the state pays only fair market prices for land. The same is true for conservation groups.
But a key advantage over other buyers, particularly developers, who may offer to pay higher prices "is that we come to the table with cash," Mr. Davidson said. Moreover, he added, buyers of land for conservation purposes do not require approvals on parcels, as a developer might in today's tight market, speeding the sales process.
And there are also tax benefits, said Mr. Klevins, such as Federal income-tax savings if a landowner donates all or part of his land for preservation. In other situations, there could be savings on capital gains or inheritance taxes.
Moreover, said David F. Moore, executive director of the New Jersey Conservation Foundation, a private nonprofit land trust in Far Hills, even in the face of rising real estate prices there is "a growing sensitivity toward preservation" in so crowded a state as New Jersey.
All those factors played a part in a recently completed transaction by the conservation foundation, which specializes in farmland preservation. Under it the foundation purchased a 150-acre farm in Washington Township in Morris County from a developer who planned to build houses on it.
The foundation then sold the development rights to a conservation group in the county under the state's Green Acres program and in a tax-free land swap traded the farm with a deed restricting it to farming to the owner of a 278-acre farm in Hardwick Township in Warren County. The new owner, who plans to use the Morris County site as a horse farm, is able to defer the capital gains tax on the sale of his Warren County farm until he sells the Morris County farm, said Mr. Moore.
The development rights on the Warren County farm were then sold to a local conservation group and the farm itself was sold with deed restrictions to a private owner, Mr. Moore said. "In the end we saved two farms for the roughly $1.5 million we paid for one," he added, noting that additional money from Warren County's open-space trust fund solidified the deal.
Having money available from Ocean County's trust fund was critical to the purchase of the Good Luck Point site, which was zoned for several hundred housing units, and was part of a larger property owned by the developer, Lifetime Homes.
The 365-acre site acquired by the trust comprises three separate parcels. On land abutting the largest parcel, approvals are being sought to build 367 active-adult homes. Ninety town houses are to be developed on land between the two smaller parcels. Mr. Klevins said his organization got involved in the purchase of the Good Luck Point site "because of the public outcry against continued development in the area."
The area is an important bird migration and wintering spot along the Atlantic Flyway. Birds found at the site, include the endangered peregrine falcon and threatened American bittern, bald eagle and osprey.
Sixty percent of the Good Luck Point site contains wetlands, which under state law cannot be developed. Given that and the local sentiment, Mr. Kevins said, "we offered the developer a price that made sense to sell the 365 acres." He added that his group closed last Thursday on a $1.7 million purchase from AT&T of an additional 375 acres south of Good Luck Point, in Lacey Township. He said the trust would use state, Federal and private sources to finance the purchase.
Mr. Davidson of the Green Acres Program sees such partnerships as an effective way to stretch state dollars and compete for large land purchases. "We're not afraid to attack the big land deals," he said, adding that buying a 1,000-acre parcel preserves it from becoming "a bunch of five-acre lots."

HEADLINE: How One Man Fights City Hall

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK

 BODY:
THE characters and interests that run this city of 17,000 City Hall and school board, landlords, politicians -- are all intertwined. Robert L. Sanders keeps tugging at the twine.
Mr. Sanders, 66, soft-spoken and not quite portly, often rises at City Council meetings to ask why the state's offer of redevelopment aid has been tabled. He is better known, though, for irritating the school board. 
 "I'm the one they arrested for taking videos," Mr. Sanders offered pleasantly. That was in November 1997, when he was thrown out of a Board of Education meeting that he was taping with a video camera. Arrested on a disorderly conduct charge, he was led out in handcuffs.
A judge dismissed the charge against Mr. Sanders. Later, the board's lawyer and three members were removed from office for other reasons.
Mr. Sanders and his wife, Cleo, moved to their four-bedroom frame house 31 years ago but paid little attention to city politics until recently, after Mr. Sanders retired from his job as area plant manager for Bell Atlantic. Their daughter, Sheree, an A student at Asbury Park High School, entered Delaware State University and nearly flunked out, and Mr. Sanders concluded "There's no education going on here."
Mr. Sanders's retirement also allowed time for the Homeowners Association, an unsuccessful City Council candidacy and regular attention to City Hall.
He discovered Asbury Park while stationed at Fort Monmouth. "Every chance you got, you went to Asbury," he recalled, "to the beach, the theaters, the clubs."
When Bell Atlantic hired him and asked where the area office should be, he chose Asbury Park. "It was such a beautiful city," he said. "We had elaborate movie houses, hundreds of thousands of people came to town every weekend, and you had some of the best clubs in the world."
Then, he said, ineptitude and corruption devastated the downtown and cost the city its golf course, water works and sanitation department.
"A lot of people got rich on this poor little town," he said, "a lot of people who don't live here."
After years of strangled hopes for the city's recovery, he said, "last summer, the state gave us the best offer we had; everybody was for it, and you see where we're at." LAURA MANSNERUS

HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT;
As Aid Is Reduced, the Rodent Problem Explodes in Urban Areas

BYLINE: By KIRSTY SUCATO 

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
Henry Jones, an exterminator for the Camden County Health Department, could smell the rats as soon as he entered the dilapidated East Camden row house on Wednesday morning.
A breathtaking, acrid odor, something like a combination of urine and rotten food. Mr. Jones followed the stench through the darkened living room, where a young woman sat nursing a 2-week-old infant, to the kitchen, where the linoleum floor was worn away in large, damp patches and the sink brimmed with dishes clotted with a white, pasty batter. There, behind the stove, which was thickly crusted with burned food and aluminum foil, lay a large, dead rat, killed by poison left by Mr. Jones and his rodent control team a week before. 
 Nyesha Cherry, who rents the house on North 22d Street with the young mother, who is her sister, and their three brothers, told the men she had found four other dead rats "the size of kittens" in the kitchen during the past week. Her landlord had ignored her complaints of scrabbling noises, chewed clothing, rodent droppings and finally a live rat in the dining room. So she called the county health department.
"Somebody has got to get the rats out of here," she said.
The four-member Camden County Rodent Control team is the last line of defense for the residents of Camden and 57 surrounding municipalities. From Monday to Friday they respond to a never-ending supply of agitated callers. The complaints are just as likely to come from wealthy suburbs like Cherry Hill and Pennsauken, where bird feeders and restaurant dumpsters provide food for the ubiquitous scavengers. With complaints growing each year, the officers know they are fighting a losing battle.
It was not always this way. In the early 1970's, Federal assistance allowed Camden to hire 20 health education workers who conducted door-to-door inspections, lectured in schools and day-care centers and organized block-cleaning awards. The idea was to teach residents how to prevent rat infestations by keeping food and garbage tightly sealed and repairing cracks and broken windows where rodents enter homes. Poisoning is a last resort, Mr. Jones said. Rats always rebound where there is food and shelter, often in greater numbers.
"Sanitation and education is what keeps the rats down in the long term," he said. "The killing of rats is always the last thing. But now it's just the killing, and education as far as we can."
In the 1970's and early 1980's, the Federal Government gave New Jersey as much as $2 million a year for urban rodent control programs. But the aid ended in the early 1980's, when the responsibility for rodent control was transferred from the United States Public Health Service to the Department of Agriculture. Since 1993, New Jersey has spent only $177,000 a year for rodent control programs in four cities: Camden, Paterson, Newark and Jersey City. The money comes from a Federal block grant for preventive health services, leaving rat control to compete with other priorities like childhood immunizations and hypertension screening, said David Adam, of the State Department of Health and Human Services.
But the rats pose a significant public health threat. As well as causing fear and revulsion, they carry bacterial diseases like salmonella and leptospirosis, which can cause illness and even death. Norway rats, most common in New Jersey, are host to disease-carrying ticks and fleas. They also cause economic damage like house fires by gnawing through electrical cables
Rats can survive on almost any food, including waste in sewers, and they need only a half-inch crack to enter any dwelling, where they scurry along the walls, urinating and defecating more than 100 times a day. But surprisingly little is known about the extent of the damage they cause. Bruce A. Colvin, an environmental consultant and rat expert, said there is currently not a single Federal or academic study into the habits of urban rats in the United States, although there are thought to be as many rats as people. He said their numbers seem to be increasing even as state and Federal assistance to eliminate them decreases, but there is little scientific data to prove it.
"The vast majority of the public has just been left to fend for itself," Mr. Colvin said. "This is really a national issue and it is an issue of national shame."
Camden's $500,000-a-year program, financed mainly by county taxpayers, is one of the best in the state. Many cities, including Atlantic City, East Orange, Passaic and Plainfield, do not even have rodent control units. Homeowners and municipalities must hire private pest control companies, which tend to focus on extermination rather than prevention, Mr. Adam said.
Paterson's program was so poorly financed that it stopped for several years, resuming only last year. The hiatus prompted Assemblywoman Nellie Poe, a Democrat, to ask the State Legislature to spend an extra $336,000 for rat control in the four cities this year. The bill was approved by the Assembly Health Committee on Jan. 21 and now heads to the Assembly Appropriations Committee for consideration.
But the Assemblywoman acknowledged that even the additional aid was not enough.
"I am sure that if research is done we would come upon other areas that are in just as much need," she said. "But this is a step in the right direction."
The Camden team will probably continue to spend most days visiting the sites of known rat infestation, where Miguel Nunez, an exterminator, drops plastic bags filled with Telon, a bright blue-green poison pellet, into rat holes. The characteristic burrows are about the circumference of a baseball, often capped with soggy layers of garbage.
On Morton Street in the Whitman Park section, the holes were at the grassy edge of a badly cracked sidewalk littered with glistening plastic wrappers and wet cardboard. Nearby, a vacant lot between two narrow houses was piled high with brush and garbage: plastic juice bottles, candy wrappers, sheets of green felt and a jar of creamy pesto sauce. The unmistakable smell of rats lingered in the air. "It is certainly going to get worse if they don't curtail it," said Ralph Green, the principal sanitarian for Camden County. "It should be more preventative. They need to put more resources into it. We've become reactionary now."

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Winners and Losers in the Governor's Budget

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
After years of trimming various projects and programs, Governor Whitman offered a budget last week that recommends spending a little more here and a little more there for the second year in a row.
The strong economy is largely responsible for this largess. Hundreds of millions of dollars in additional tax revenue is pouring into the state's already overflowing coffers, giving Mrs. Whitman more than $1.1 billion to spend in the fiscal year starts July 1. 
 As a result, state workers do not have to worry about layoffs. And low-income elderly residents who participate in the state-subsidized prescription program need not be concerned about rising co-payments.
"This is a Christmas budget," said Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, a Republican from Salem County who wore a necktie festooned with Santa Claus for the Governor's annual budget address to lawmakers. "Everyone should be happy with it."
Mrs. Whitman is not recommending that every dime get spent in the $19.16 billion budget. She proposes keeping $750 million in the state's rainy day fund should the economy bottom out.
She has also recommended giving $200 million back to property tax payers with the property tax relief program she announced earlier this month. By Labor Day, she said, she hoped to get checks averaging about $200 to homeowners. Under her five-year plan, the rebates would increase every year until 2002, when they would reach an average of $600.
Is there any more in this budget that the average taxpayer can count on putting back in his wallet? What about all of this extra spending? How will it benefit residents?
Of course, not everyone thinks that spending increases are appropriate and prudent. Some fiscal conservatives say they think Mrs. Whitman should be salting away more money to pay down the state's debt or cover the eventual $1 billion annual price tag for her property tax plan.
At the same time, there are many people who say she is not spending enough in some areas -- from social services to road repairs. Take public schools, for example. Of the $1.1 billion more to spend in the coming fiscal year, more than $300 million in new assistance has been proposed for schools. Not all school districts are happy.
Two-thirds of the state's school districts would see state aid go up or remain the same. But the other districts were notified that their aid will decline, which could cause property taxes to rise in some towns.
Mrs. Whitman's budget is just a proposal at this point. The General Assembly and the Senate, both controlled by Republicans, need to look it over and vote on it before it becomes law. While Mr. Collins and other Republican leaders say they think the budget is likely to receive bipartisan support, no one can remember a state budget that was not changed, at least at the margins.
Here is a look at how Mrs. Whitman's proposals might affect residents:
COLLEGE STUDENTS Those enrolled in the state's public colleges or universities might want to question any significant tuition increases. They might also want to ask whether the school is getting a new library, classrooms or gymnasium in a few years. The proposed budget includes a net increase of $70 million over last year's budget, including $12.4 million to help colleges cover some of their borrowing costs for deferred maintenance and capital projects.
SENIOR CITIZENS There is $10.3 million for a new initiative aimed at offering alternatives to seniors who do not want to move into a nursing home. For example, one alternative would include a new caregiver assistance program, which would allow payments to help certain family caregivers purchase at-home care services for a senior citizen who otherwise might be in a nursing home.
TAXES In addition to the property tax rebates, the new budget includes enough money so that 200,000 low-income New Jerseyans would be excused from paying state income tax. The budget also includes extra money for a new program that freezes property tax rates for senior citizens.
PARKS In addition to the borrowed money that voters approved last year to preserve open space, there is $3.5 million to hire 100 additional full-time and seasonal park rangers and maintenance staff for 52 state parks, forests and recreation areas. Another $10 million will be made available to municipalities and counties to develop local parks.
HEALTH INSURANCE There is $10.2 million more to expand the subsidized health care program for children, called KidCare. The extra dollars would increase the eligibility requirements so that a family of four earning up to $57,575 a year could enroll. The program would also make the program available for those who have not had health care insurance for 6 months, rather than 12 months. The change means that 6,000 more children are expected to enroll.
CRIME To give county prosecutors more access to DNA testing, the budget includes $380,000 for DNA testing to investigate and prosecute crimes.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Bridging a 'Generation Next' Gap

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

DATELINE: PURCHASE, N.Y.

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, Pepsi-Cola was marking its 100th anniversary, but no amount of corporate merrymaking could conceal the problems plaguing the brand. Bottlers attending a company extravaganza in Hawaii spent much of their time fuming about Pepsi ads, particularly one set to the Rolling Stones song "Brown Sugar." Pepsi was losing market share to its perennial rival, Coca-Cola Classic. And it was going through an identity crisis. Just who was supposed to be buying it -- teen-agers? Generation X'ers? Retirees?
Now, however, there's been a changing of the guard within the streamlined, art-covered walls of Pepsico headquarters here in Purchase. Among the newcomers is Dawn Hudson, whose many tasks as chief of marketing for Pepsi-Cola North America include overseeing the creation of a new slogan for Pepsi -- one that will stake out the elusive middle ground between uncool and too cool. 
 Ms. Hudson has tackled the task with an old-fashioned thoroughness that critics say had been sadly lacking at the company: a lot of brainstorming, formal research, consumer testing and revisiting everything to squeeze out every last drop of improvement. "I think we're very close to having something good that knits the brand back together," said Ms. Hudson, 40, who even in business attire exudes an outdoorsy manner. Until recently, she added, "Pepsi had a history of changing too frequently and getting schizophrenic."
The new slogan remains top secret. It will be introduced to the public in March, and will replace the two-year-old "Generation next," which is widely maligned for conveying a hip image that alienated older Pepsi drinkers.
After nearly two decades in advertising, Ms. Hudson was hired in 1996 by Roger A. Enrico, Pepsico's chairman and chief executive, to head up the marketing of Frito-Lay products. Last year, she was named to her current job, replacing Brian R. Swette, who left after Philip A. Marineau, the president of Pepsi-Cola North America, made remarks suggesting that "Generation next" would soon be put out to pasture.
Her quick ascent marks Ms. Hudson as a rising star within Pepsico; she is whispered to be one of the few who might run it one day. And it is no secret why the company took such a shine to her. As an executive with DDB Needham, the advertising agency, she developed a campaign for Frito-Lay's Rold Gold pretzels, including television commercials starring the "Seinfeld" actor Jason Alexander, that pumped up the company's market share from 11 percent to 30 percent.
"They really put it on the map," recalls Steven S Reinemund, chairman and chief executive of Frito-Lay. "She's a very smart and pragmatic marketer who gets things done."
And she appears to manage that without losing her perspective or sense of humor. During an interview late last month, her two daughters, 8 and 1, arriving for a holiday party, ran in and out of her office. Several assistants, some secretaries dressed in sequined holiday garb and a job candidate who had arrived too early for his interview also burst in. She remained calm throughout, smiling frequently as she discussed Pepsi's marketing priorities, sometimes with both children balanced on her lap.
People at the company know, however, that beneath her tranquil surface lurks a highly competitive player. Within Pepsi's Mountain Dew division, she has earned the code name Leopard.
In her spare time, Ms. Hudson reads, skis, plays tennis and visits child-friendly places like the zoo. She is married to Bruce Beach, the president of an executive-search firm. Her home in Bronxville, N.Y., is just a short hop from Pepsico, and Ms. Hudson is often home on weeknights, watching "The Brady Bunch" with Morgan, her 8-year-old. A year ago she gave birth to Kendall, whose name, she likes to point out, was not chosen to curry favor with Donald M. Kendall, a co-founder and former chairman of Pepsico.
Her whole career, she says, was something she just fell into. After graduating from Dartmouth College as an English and economics major, she took a job in the school's fund-raising office. Walking across the campus one day, she ran into a friend who told her that an advertising agency was interviewing prospects that afternoon. With no appointment, and with a hastily typed resume, Ms. Hudson waited on the doorstep until someone agreed to talk to her.
She got the job, with Compton Advertising, since absorbed by Saatchi & Saatchi. "I tried it, and I loved it," she recalls. A few years later she landed at DDB Needham, where she eventually became a managing partner.
 THE eldest of three sisters growing up in Winchester, Mass., Ms. Hudson early on felt a desire to prove herself in a way that would be distinct from what her parents (in law and banking) had done. "You want to chart your own course," she said.
Unlike many other marketers, she shuns jargon. And she is known for sitting down with company reports and examining every page, crossing out hackneyed adjectives and cringing, she says, over "anything that reeks of hyperbole."
What she does like, though, is clever marketing.
A summer '99 promotion for Pepsi, built around the latest installment in the "Star Wars" series, has impressed her. "What's critical is how we leverage it in a way that gets our brands moving," she said. She plans to push hard to make Pepsi available in places large and small, with the formation of a "channel strategy group" that examines where consumers shop and what kinds of products, as well as package size and shape, they prefer. And marketing to the 8- to-12-year-old set is a priority. "We're absolutely going to look at preteens," she said.
Ms. Hudson counsels her marketing team to "work hard, play hard," on the theory that if they don't have lives outside the office, their performance at Pepsi will suffer. "Part of being a good marketer," she said, "is just being a regular person."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
The Battle Is On: Whose Kids Need the Most Help?

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIR

 BODY:
In doling out about $4 million a year to the city's many youth groups, the Department of Youth and Community Development has used something called the Fair Share Formula since 1983.
But critics say that the formula is anything but fair. Based largely on 1980 Census data, the formula, they say, is outdated and flawed and has led to gross inequities. 
 For that reason, the department asked the Center for Urban Research at the City University of New York to recommend improvements, which it did last summer. There are actually nine proposed formulas, ranging from one that looks just at the population of young people in a community district to others that weigh such factors as the number of teen-age mothers.
With the department set to decide on a new formula next month, leaders of some of the city's 59 community boards are blasting the new options.
Craig Hammerman, district manager for Brooklyn's Community Board 6, which covers a region from Cobble Hill and Park Slope to Carroll Gardens and Red Hook, said his district's portion would drop to around $40,000 from just over $70,000 under any of the new formulas.
"It means that good groups that have good programs are going to be punished," he said.
One of those groups is the St. Francis Xavier Action Youth Center, a nonsectarian program in Park Slope that offers after-school programs involving arts and crafts, homework tutoring, basketball and leadership training.
"We are really going to suffer," said Dr. Annette Hall, the center's executive director, noting that the $11,500 her group received last year -- about 15 percent of its revenue -- might be halved.
But Robert Mascali, the department's assistant commissioner, pointed out inequities in the current formula, under which Brooklyn's Board 6 gets $4.51 per child but Board 13, in Coney Island, gets $2.08 per child.
"What sense does this make?" he asked.
An even greater difference: Community Board 1 in downtown Manhattan now gets $26 per child, while Community Board 8 on the Upper East Side gets $2.
"These numbers have to be revised," Mr. Mascali said. "Populations have changed. We are talking 1980."
The existing formula uses several factors -- the number of children, the number of families on welfare, the number of single parents and the number of unemployed youths -- to determine a community's share. It also sets a $40,000 minimum share per district.
The authors of the new formulas favor using housing and vacancy surveys, which are conducted every three years, instead of census data, which are collected only once a decade. They also prefer shedding the $40,000 minimum, and claim that statistics like the number of school dropouts and admissions to juvenile detention centers are better indicators of need than such economic factors as the number of families on welfare.
The best approach, said Timothy Ross, one of the authors, "is to send the money where the problems are."
But others are upset. If the $40,000 minimum is dropped, said Paul Goldstein, the district manager of Community Board 1 in Manhattan, "they may as well tell our kids to go play in the Hudson River."
And while Community Board 1 in Staten Island may get more money under a new formula, the board's district manager, Joe Carroll, still detects an overall problem.
"There is," he said, "just not enough money." RICHARD WEIR

HEADLINE: VIEW;
Not So Fly (for This White Guy)

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS CENTURY; Douglas Century is the author of "Street Kingdom," an account of street life in Brooklyn, to be published next month by Warner Books.

 BODY:
ON a recent wintry morning, walking a desolate strip of Flatbush Avenue in downtown Brooklyn, I heard a baritone voice growl my name, followed by an emphatic, "Yo! What's the deal?" The menacing bark emanated from the driver's side of a passing Mercury Sable, the tinted window of which was now rapidly descending.
Fortunately, I soon saw that the grimace and hard glare, half concealed under a jet-black Fubu baseball hat, belonged to my good friend Justice. His look of mock anger dissolved into a broad smile, gold cap gleaming in the sun. A hulking construction worker and hip-hop clotheshorse, Justice was going on one of his marathon shopping sprees, and invited me along. 
 En route to a Costco in Sunset Park, I took in the impressive effect of his urban uniform du jour. He was, as he put it, "Fubued out to the max." Not just the ball cap, but the black satin Fubu baseball jacket and the baggy, prefaded Fubu jeans, impeccably pressed and cuffed.
"It'd be kind of hard for a white guy to pull off that look," I told him with a laugh.
"No," Justice countered, "a lot of white people are rockin' Fubu right now."
That may be so, but I knew I would never attempt Justice's Fubu flush. Although I've dabbled in hip-hop fashion over the years, it's always been with some uneasiness. Street trends change so quickly, they're hard for an outsider to keep track of. Even the letters of the Fubu logo are an acronym of exclusion: "For us, by us."
As a white, rap-music-obsessed journalist based in Manhattan, I have spent much of the last decade traveling through the city's hip-hop underground. For several years in the mid 1990's, much to my amazement, I found myself moonlighting as the de facto manager for an aspiring rapper called Big K.
Almost from the first night we met, in the Nuyorican Poets Cafe on the Lower East Side, Big K would howl at my lack of street panache -- the way I'd allow my sneakers to get scuffed up and filthy (he'd clean his nightly with a toothbrush, and moisturize the leather with Jergen's hand cream), the way my baseball caps were sweat-stained and shapeless (his collection of some 50 ball caps remained, miraculously, virginal).
How could I possibly be his right-hand man, K would loudly wonder, if I insisted on dressing like such a cornball?
Under the guidance of guys like Big K and Justice -- my bedroom closet has become a veritable archive of failed hip-hop fashion experiments. There's the black quilted zip-front hunting vest, street chic on rap groups like Naughty by Nature, but an accessory that tends to make a diminutive Jewish male, like me, resemble Chico Marx on an ice-fishing expedition. Or my black Kangol Spitfire cap, which when spun backward -- and worn beret style, a la Samuel L. Jackson -- makes me look about as tough as one of the Backstreet Boys.
Then, there's the pair of burgundy suede "British walker" loafers that Big K gave me two winters back, no doubt the strangest Hanukkah gift I've ever received. On K, as on countless other Brooklyn "rudeboys" (homeboys, in the West Indian variant), the crepe-soled shoes available in myriad shades, including hot yellow, have long been a hallmark of a tough streetwise fashion.
On me, however, they were eerily reminiscent of those hated Hush Puppies that would have earned any seventh grader a strafing of noogies on his way out of homeroom.
But it's the ascendancy of black-owned, black-oriented clothiers like Fubu, Shabazz Brothers, Pure Playaz and Mecca that's given me the most pause. Yes, it's true, as my friend Justice noted, that a lot of white people are rockin' Fubu today. A headline in Women's Wear Daily recently proclaimed "Fubu's Move to the Suburbs." But can a white consumer really get away with wearing a product designed and marketed by a youthful African-American company whose very name is a rallying cry of racial solidarity and economic empowerment?
In the hit video "Pretty Fly (for a White Guy)" by the alternative band the Offspring, a white hip-hop wannabe is seen flashing ersatz gang signs and making a foolish attempt at break dancing while dressed in a powder blue Fubu football jersey. Fubu merchandise should come with a warning label: "Can backfire with humiliating consequences."
And there are many other fashion hazards out there in the streets. Regional distinctions and subtleties abound. These days, for instance, the Brooklyn hip-hop demimonde is riven by fashion-related isms and schisms.
There's the so-called Big Willie look (flashy designer labels), popularized by the late Notorious B.I.G., in sharp contrast to the "roughneck" gear (camouflage and boots) of rappers like Jeru the Damaja, Buckshot and M.O.P. And now, with many of the leading rappers hitting their 30's, a more conservative, GQ-influenced hip-hop style is emerging, even in the streets of Brooklyn. Witness the basic-black wiseguy ensemble sported by Jay-Z, a rapper from Bedford-Stuyvesant, on the cover of his chart-topping CD, "Vol. 2 . . . Hard Knock Life." He appears in a black four-button blazer over black cashmere sports shirt, buttoned to the neck. Diamond pinky ring optional.
Today, hip-hop fashion is a big tent, encompassing both the flamboyant matador-on-speed get-ups of Busta Rhymes and the understated, surburban-friendly T-shirts and baggy khakis of the XL boutiques owned by Mike D of the Beastie Boys. Hip-hop runs through so many trends you never know what will turn up next.
A few years back, it seemed that even my own personal style (I grew up in Western Canada) had come into vogue during the great hip-hop hockey jersey craze, when rap superstars like Snoop Doggy Dogg had, for inexplicable reasons, fallen in love with the regulation National Hockey League uniforms of the Toronto Maple Leafs. Flipping through fashion spreads in Vibe and the Source, I was bemused but delighted: my northern compatriots, suddenly and unwittingly, had become the height of homeboy fashion.
Sadly, the hip-hop-hockey nexus was short lived. By the time I dusted off my vintage Rangers jersey to accompany Big K to a rap showcase downtown, I felt myself the object of countless smirks and glares.
That's because of the ineffable element of all street fashion: attitude. Snoop can sport a regulation N.H.L. jersey without being taken for a gap-toothed Canadian on skates, just as he can adorn his braids with baby-girl baubles or colorful rubber bands without looking like a long-missing member of Hanson.
Attitude seems to have no strict correlation with age, class, or even ethnicity. My friend Jack, an Ivy League-trained clinical psychologist -- like me, in his early 30's -- counsels patients at St. Luke's-Roosevelt by day and is a devotee of the downtown drum-and-bass scene by night. Shedding his suit and tie, he opts for the ultra-baggy jeans and exotic skateboarding sneakers that are de rigueur in such after-hours spots as Jungle Nation.
One night last summer, as we were heading out to a club, Jack insisted that I try on his latest accessory: a tan-colored Eddie Bauer fishing cap. On him, the soft cloth hat was either old-school hip-hop or new-school drum-and-bass. But on me, I realized, the droopy cap made an even bolder statement: Gilligan.
With the advent of the new year (and my wife's repeated requests that I start dressing like a grown-up), I've resolved to do away with all such overreaching attempts at youth-culture fashion.
I'll still head out on my regular shopping runs with Justice, and I may try on some of the more mature outfits at Phat Farm. But the next time I throw on my vintage hockey jersey, I'll be sitting in the icy glow of the MSG Network, rooting for Gretzky and the other Ranger old timers.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
A Pox on the High-Rates 'Cure'

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
WHEN financial crisis strikes and a currency plunges, the Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund press the suffering country to raise interest rates. Sometimes the currency recovers, but the higher interest rates always produce a recession. Critics of this remedy, ever more vociferous, are suggesting that high rates are akin to the 18th-century medical practice of bleeding patients to try to cure disease. George Washington's last illness was a bad cold; doctors bled him, and he died within a week.
Much has been staked on high interest rates as the treatment of choice for sick economies, but evidence is accumulating that suggests it is the wrong prescription, capable of turning a global financial crisis into a global recession reminiscent of the 1930's. The high rates applied in East Asian countries, Russia and now Brazil were supposed to restore confidence in each nation's financial system and draw foreign investors and lenders back in. Currencies would then stabilize, interest rates would fall, borrowing and investment would resume and, most important of all, the damaged economies would revive. 
 That is not what has happened in South Korea and Thailand, the first countries to be caught in the financial panic that started in East Asia 19 months ago. Rates have indeed fallen and their currencies are now stronger, but recessions continue in both countries.
"High interest rates are harmful, not helpful; they signal that debtors are in danger of defaulting on foreign loans," said Jeffrey D. Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development, who is making the critics' case at the World Economic Forum, an annual gathering here of political, cultural and economic leaders from many countries. "You put up rates to 35 percent, and that makes investors nervous about a nation's currency. By insisting on higher rates, the Treasury and the I.M.F. have helped to create economic contractions all over the developing world."
 FLEXIBLE interest rates that are allowed to find their own level are more to the liking of critics like Mr. Sachs. He would leave interest rates alone even in a crisis, a tactic that in his view is more likely to keep an economy out of recession. "You show investors that you have economic growth and a way to get out of a financial crisis, and they will come back, strengthening the currency as they come," Mr. Sachs said.
He subscribes to a recent World Bank study that found no correlation between the movements of interest rates and exchange rates in a number of cases. Too many other factors besides interest rates affect currency values: Political upheaval, for example, or too much capacity in manufacturing, which drives down profits and thereby discourages investment.
The World Bank study reflects the views of Joseph Stiglitz, the bank's chief economist, who signed the preface. He, too, has argued that high rates are viewed as a signal that borrowers in the nations offering the high rates are likely to default. Economists who see the issue his way say high rates can be counted on to stabilize a currency only in a fanciful world that somehow has no risk, no bankruptcies, no defaults. Only in such a sure-fire, risk-free world could foreign investors be counted on to respond to higher interest rates, certain they wouldn't lose their money.
 THE United States Treasury and the I.M.F., speaking pretty much as one voice, have disagreed. They have argued, for example, that if Korea and Thailand had not raised interest rates when disaster struck, the devaluations of their currencies would have been even steeper. Debtors would have had much more difficulty repaying foreign lenders in hard currency, and excessive devaluations would eventually accelerate inflation.
But in the face of the recessions that high rates have generated, the Treasury appears to be moving toward a middle ground.
"There is a balance needed," Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said in an interview here on Friday. "High rates have important costs that have to be recognized. At the same time, too much liquidity" -- rates that, in effect, are too low -- "can be a prescription for disaster. A balance has to be found."
That compromise view appears to reflect current thinking on Wall Street.
Securities investors are effectively lenders, so the institutions that reflect their views are eager to keep exchange rates in developing countries as calm and predictable as possible.
"Investors recognize the political and social costs of trying to keep interest rates too high for too long," said Robert D. Hormats, a vice chairman of Goldman Sachs. "When a good-faith effort to sustain a currency with high rates turns sour, you have to be flexible."
And so the harsh medicine of high interest rates that has put a half-dozen emerging economies into recession over the last 19 months may be losing favor -- perhaps in time to soften the damage to the Brazilian economy in a world that starts putting economic growth first, with exchange rate stability to follow.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Confidently Riding the Technology Bubble

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
IT is pretty easy to be excited and amazed about exciting and amazing technology stocks. It is equally easy to be scared to death of them.
Last year, the 250 stocks that make up Hambrecht & Quist's technology index rose 55.4 percent, the biggest annual gain ever. 
 And the gains have not stopped; for 1999 through Friday, the index, which does not include Internet stocks, was up 13.7 percent. The firm's Internet index is up 48.6 percent so far this year.
All good things, of course, come to an end. And expectations are high and rising that sooner rather than later the bubble will burst, particularly for Internet stocks.
But from his office in Half Moon Bay, Calif., Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter, took some time last week to share his views on why technology stocks are likely to remain white-hot.
 
Q. Last summer, technology stocks stumbled badly, along with everything else. You don't think that selloff was justified, do you?
 
A. No, I don't. There was a real fear last summer and early fall that personal computer sales were not growing and communications and semiconductor sales were never going to pick up. It was utterly wrong. At the time, we were in the process of seeing accelerating sales, which have continued into this year.
On the communications side -- hardware, routers and switches -- there never was a slowdown.
Semiconductor pricing bottomed in May or June, and now we are hearing that there is a real imbalance of supply and demand for certain, mostly higher-valued, chips. And that has translated pretty quickly into orders for semiconductor equipment. So the business looks like it may be approaching a year of normal growth in 1999. And 2000 may be a boom year.
 
Q. Why is that?
 
A. There are three legs to technology: communications, computing and biotech. All three are having very strong positive product cycles. It is those product cycles that drive the business, not the economy.
At the semiconductor industry's forecasting meeting in Monterey earlier this month, they were talking about sales growth of 7 percent for 1999, but with sales exiting the year at a 20 percent growth rate, which is a tremendous amount of momentum.
At the end of this year, we will get Windows 2000 from Microsoft, which should further personal computer spending. The Internet will continue its build-out, which will further communications spending. In biotech, we had 50 new drugs approved last year, almost double 1997, and this year we expect that 80 new drugs will be approved. There are 10 profitable biotech companies today. That number will probably double this year.
 
Q. How do you think this forecast will play itself out in the stock market?
 
A. For the last 18 to 24 months, we have had a very strong rally in the big technology stocks, the Microsofts, the Dells, the MCI Worldcoms. If this move is going to continue, it will spread out to the smaller-cap issues. If it doesn't, I think the rally will die.
For example, Oracle is selling at or close to an all-time high, but Informix is selling at half its previous all-time high. Cisco Systems is extremely overpriced, but Premisys, another data communications company, is underpriced. There are lots of mid-cap, second-tier companies that are selling at big disparities to the leaders.
 
Q. Speaking of overpriced stocks, what is your opinion of Internet shares?
 
A. We are short most of the Internet stocks. My theory has been that you can pop a bubble like this without taking the rest of the market down.
The Internet bubble has to pop because the supply of stock is so large. Investment bankers are filing as many offerings as they can, and lots of stock is beginning to unlock from I.P.O.'s done last year as insiders are allowed to sell their shares.
 
Q. Has Internet mania inflated prices of issues that are not pure Web plays?
 
A. The Internet has infected the rest a lot more than I thought it would have. Cisco, for example, has gotten an extra run because people believe the overwhelming demand will spread out.
 
Q. What do you tell people who own shares in companies you consider overpriced or fully priced -- the Microsofts, Intels, Ciscos and Lucents of the world?
 
A. I tell people that companies like these are core holdings, that even if in the short term they go down, don't buy them so you can trade the shares. There are none I would run out and buy this minute, but none I would sell right now because they are grossly overpriced.
I think people should have 30 percent to 50 percent of their portfolio in these kinds of stocks. If you don't already own them, start dollar cost averaging into them over a six-month period.
