HEADLINE: Briton Issues An Ultimatum To Both Sides Over Kosovo

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain told Yugoslav and ethnic Albanian leaders today that they must show up in France next weekend to negotiate effective self-government for Serbia's battle-ravaged Kosovo province or face NATO bombing and other military action to force them to negotiate agreement.
Mr. Cook said President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia promised him a speedy response to the demands of the six-nation "contact group" on the Balkans. As usual, Mr. Milosevic did not appear in public, speaking instead to his domestic and foreign audiences through news media and other officials. 
 For the Serbian audience, the official Yugoslav news agency, Tanyug, quoted him as reiterating to Mr. Cook that Kosovo's problems should be solved in Serbia -- rather than at a conference abroad. Meanwhile, other Serbian officials in interviews today expressed a wary willingness to attend the talks in France.
Simultaneously, Serbian forces in Kosovo continued to hit the ethnic Albanian fighters hard, to seize as much ground as possible before negotiations begin, Western diplomats here said, while there was a grenade attack on a Serbian cafe in the Kosovo capital, Pristina, and another reported attack on a Serbian couple in a fiercely contested village.
Mr. Cook acted on behalf of the six nations of the Balkan contact group -- the United States, Britain, France, Russia, Germany and Italy. He said he emphasized to Mr. Milosevic the need to reach a settlement in February and the unity of the international demand for Kosovo's self-government in the Yugoslav Federation, which is made up of the republics of Serbia and Montenegro.
Mr. Cook then flew on to Skopje, Macedonia, to meet ethnic Albanian leaders including Ibrahim Rugova, the nonviolent elected leader of the Albanians, and Adem Demaci, who has connections to the armed Albanian rebels of the Kosovo Liberation Army. Mr. Cook also told them to go to France prepared to negotiate and reach an interim settlement that will let Kosovo run its own affairs, but not give it independence, with Kosovo's future status to be determined after three years.
Mr. Cook told reporters afterward that Mr. Rugova was willing to attend the talks, but that Mr. Demaci would reply in a few days, Agence France-Presse reported from Skopje. "I insisted that we would expect that to be a positive reply," Mr. Cook was quoted as saying.
Serbian officials close to Mr. Milosevic said he was likely to send a delegation to the talks. He would not go there himself, but instead probably send Milan Milutinovic, the Serbian President and a Milosevic loyalist, whom Mr. Cook also met today.
Mr. Milosevic is said by these officials to resent the pressure of the West to sacrifice Serbian sovereignty over Kosovo, which was the heart of the Serbs' medieval empire and is the cradle of Serbian nationalism, and to fear that he could be arrested on a secret indictment for war-crimes charges if he leaves Belgrade.
Mr. Milosevic is widely considered the main architect of the Bosnian Serbs' aggression during the 1992-95 war in Bosnia. But Western leaders have never mentioned any indictment, nor given any public indication that he would be called to account for alleged war crimes by facing the United Nations tribunal for war crimes in The Hague, the Netherlands.
The Serbian officials, insisting on anonymity, said Mr. Milosevic was likely to concede only when pressed very strongly by NATO and its bomb threats, so he can explain his concessions to his people without paying a significant political price.
The same officials noted that Kosovo is a political and financial drain for Belgrade, and if NATO is willing to take responsibility for restraining the rebels and keeping Kosovo from independence for three years, Mr. Milosevic may see that as an advantage. This would be especially true if he can also win a lifting of international economic sanctions against Belgrade.
On Friday, state television here showed Mr. Milosevic telling the visiting Russian Communist leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, that Yugoslavia "advocates a peaceful solution to the problems in Kosovo through direct political dialogue with representatives of national communities in Kosovo and state institutions."
Deputy Prime Minister Vuk Draskovic, in an interview today, said "there is no reason for us to say 'no' now." He noted, though, that the federal Government and Mr. Milosevic had not yet made a decision.
Mr. Draskovic, a recent addition to the Milosevic Government, said he favored a negotiated solution, but with these preconditions: that there be "no independent Kosovo, no 'greater Albania,' and no equal status for Kosovo as a third republic within Yugoslavia -- that is a secret name for an independent Kosovo."
Mr. Draskovic also insisted on equal rights for all citizens of Kosovo, including the minority Serbs, who make up only about 10 percent of the estimated population of two million but currently run all its affairs.
There should be no independent state institutions such as the police set up by the ethnic Albanians, Mr. Draskovic said.
But the ethnic Albanian leaders all seek independence, and the Kosovo Liberation Army is fighting for it. The Albanians are finding it hard to unite under one negotiating position and one delegation.
Pleurat Sejdiu, a rebel spokesman based in London, reacted cautiously to the contact group's demands, saying: "We are not rejecting the Contact Group statement. We just can't say anything positive about it. This is not the time to talk. The fighting has to stop."
On Friday, 24 more Albanians, a few of them dressed in K.L.A. uniform, were killed by the Serbian police. International monitors said a number of them appeared to have been shot in the head at close range. The monitors' leader, the American diplomat William Walker, said in an interview today that an investigation into the deaths was in progress.
Also Friday night, six Serbs were badly wounded when a grenade exploded outside a Pristina cafe owned by Serbs. In Pristina, the Serb Media Center today said a Serb civilian was killed and his wife seriously wounded when assailants threw a grenade into their bedroom. The attack occurred in the contested northwestern Kosovo village of Rakos.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 18; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1117 words

HEADLINE: The Micromonarch

BYLINE: By Anthony Pagden; Anthony Pagden's most recent book is "Lords of All the World: Ideologies of Empire in Spain, Britain and France, c.1500-c.1800."

 BODY:

THE GRAND STRATEGY
OF PHILIP II
By Geoffrey Parker.
Illustrated. 446 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $35. 
 Philip II, contemporaries were fond of saying, ruled over the greatest empire that ever was. In fact, the Roman Empire at its height occupied far more inhabited space. But he certainly ruled over the most extensive empire, and -- with the conquest of the Philippines in 1565 -- the first truly global one. When he died in 1598 he was the most powerful monarch in the Western world. But he left behind a badly weakened conglomerate of states, divided religiously and culturally, economically unstable and, at least in Europe, in retreat. His successors, Philip III and Philip IV, would be able to do little as Spain steadily lost ground to its old rival France and the rising new commercial powers of England and the Netherlands. Like all those who sought to control what Edmund Burke called "extensive and detached empire," Philip faced a finally intractable problem of how to keep together regions that were distant from Spain and from one another and whose sense of attachment to their King could be tenuous at times. As the Roman historian Livy famously remarked, every empire had been built up one piece at a time, but it had to be held together as a whole. In the days before modern information technology and modern weaponry, however, holding it together as a whole had, as the Romans themselves discovered, generally proved to be impossible.
Geoffrey Parker has already written extensively about Philip. His new book is not so much a biography, although it covers much of Philip's life in painstaking detail, as a consideration of the question: Did Philip II have a "grand strategy" for holding his empire together, and if so what was it? Parker does not really provide an answer, although the book ends by assuming that he did, and that, although in general it was not exactly a failure, it could have been better. On his death, Philip had lost a part of what both he, like his father Charles V before him, regarded as the jewel in their crown: the Netherlands. True, he was able to hold on to most of what is now modern Belgium and Luxembourg, but only at crippling expense. The war against the Dutch, one of his advisers lamented, was a "voracious monster which gobbles up the troops and treasure of Spain."
The creation of a new state in Holland -- Protestant and republican -- was also a crushing ideological blow. He had added Portugal, and with Portugal all the Portuguese settlements overseas, and the Philippines, and consolidated his hold over large areas of Central and South America. However, it was clear that Portugal could not be maintained for long, while English and Dutch privateers preyed constantly on Portuguese and Spanish shipping in the East and West Indies. England -- against which in 1588 he had sent the greatest fleet ever assembled -- was a lot stronger at the end of his reign than at the beginning. The Protestant Reformation, the source of most of his difficulties, had divided Europe permanently in two and unleashed confessional wars that would not cease until well into the following century.
Philip's overextended domains presented many problems that were to afflict subsequent imperial rulers. Like his great rival, the Ottoman Sultan, and such later imperial rulers as Stalin and Hitler (all of whom Parker compares him with) Philip had constantly to shift attention from one front to another. In the north he had the Dutch rebels, England and the French Protestants to contend with, in the south and east the Turks, and potential dissidents everywhere. Yet, as he himself once wrote, "one cannot deal effectively with more than one thing at a time." His financial resources were greater than those of any other European ruler. Yet the costs of incessant warfare were so high that the monarchy was frequently bankrupt, and in March 1588 Philip was even driven to sell his wife's jewelry.
Philip's greatest problem, however, was himself. Called by those who admired him "the prudent King," at best an ambiguous compliment, he insisted on handling even the smallest detail of his vastly complex administration himself. When one minister apologized, saying, "I am sorry to fatigue your Majesty with such trifling matters," he replied, "They do not fatigue me, they delight me!" He was obsessed not only with matters of state, but details of etiquette, nuances of grammar, building plans and titles used at court. He worked excessive hours and generated more paper than any monarch before or since. As he grew older he complained increasingly of the strain. In February 1587 he took to his bed with arthritis, brought on, he believed, by overwork, and did not emerge until July. In the meantime Sir Francis Drake sacked the city of Cadiz.
Philip's personalization of power was accompanied by a belief that only he should be fully informed on every detail of any situation. He was deeply distrustful of even his most intimate associates, many of whom were close members of his own family, and inevitably he did everything with painstaking slowness. In a world in which news traveled slowly and uncertainly this could be disastrous. In his long central chapters on the Armada, Parker shows how delay and distrust were perhaps the key factors in one of Philip's most humiliating defeats. The English had the weather on their side. They had superior ships and better guns. But if it had not been for Philip's "prudence" they might still have been invaded in 1588.
Parker makes frequent comparisons between Philip's apparent strategies and those employed by modern commanders to show that despite the great differences separating the 16th from the 20th century, problems of international warfare remain largely similar in structure. This is a history that moves backward from the strategic concerns of today; that gives it an edge and an immediacy few other books on Philip have achieved. It also insists that human actions are the outcome not, as so many historians have insisted, of long-term economic or social forces, but of acts of will. Philip was as constrained as any ruler by economics (which he barely understood), by the social world into which he had been born, by climate and geography and, perhaps most of all, by his religious beliefs. But his actions, and the "grand strategy," not to mention the many lesser strategies, he pursued throughout his long reign were ultimately the outcome of his own decisions. To understand those we have to understand the man. Parker's highly detailed but also immensely readable book has come far closer to that than any previous account of the most enigmatic of Spanish kings.
